University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Syngynge he was or floytynge alle þe daye
He was as fresshe as is þe moneth of Maye
Schorte was his gowne with sleves longe ⁊and wyde
Wele couthe he sitte on an horse ande fair ride
He cowde songes make ande wele endite
Iuste ⁊and eke daunse purtreye and wryte
So hoote he louede þat by nyȝht̉er tale
He slepte no more þan doith a nyghtyngale
Curteyse he was louely ande seruisable
Ande kerffe be forne his fader at þe table
A yoman hadde he and seruᵃntes no moo
At þat tyme for hym lyste ryde soo .
Ande he was cladde in coote and hoode of grene
A scheefe of pococke arwes bryȝht ⁊and keene
Vnder his belte he bare full thriftely
Wel cowthe he dresse his takell yomanly
His Arwes drowȝed noȝt with feres lowe
Ande in his horde he bare a myȝhty bowe
A notte hede hadde he with a browne visage
Off wode crafte wel couthe he all þe vsage
Vp on his arme he bare a gaye bracēre
Ande be his side a swerde and a boclere
Ande on þat other side a gaye dagere
Harneseide wele and scharpe as poynte of spere
A xpofore on his breste of siluer schene
An horne he bare þe Bawderike was of grene
A forster was he sothely as I gesse
Ther was also a nonne a Prioresse
That of hir smylynge was full sympile and coye
Hir greteste othe was but by seynt loye
Ande sche was iclepede madame englentyne
Full wele sche songe þe seruise diuine
Entuned in hire nose full semely
Ande frenssh sche spake ful faire ande fetisly
After þe scole at Stratforde at þe bowe
For frenssh of paryssh was to hire vnknowe
At meete wele y taught was sche with alle
She lete no morsell from hir lippes falle
Ne wette hire fyngris in hir sause depe
Wel couthe sche carye a morsell ande wel kepe
That no drope ne fill opon hir breste
In curtesye was she full michill hir leste
Hir ouer lippe wyped scho so clene
That in hire coppe þer was no ferthynge seene
Of grece whan sche dronken hadde hire draughte
Full semely after hire mete sche raughte
Ande sikerly scho was of grete desporte
Ande full plesaunte ande amyable of porte
Ande peyned hir to countrefete chere
Off courte and to bene estateliche of maners
Ande to bene holden digne of reuerence
But for to speken of hire consience
She was so charitable and so pytous
She wolde wepe ȝiff þat sche sawe a mous
Kaughte in a trappe if it were dede or bledde
Off smale houndes hadde sche þat sche fedde
With rostede flessh or mylke or wastell brede
But soore wepte scho if one of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a ȝerde smerte
Ande alle was conscience ande tendir herte
Full semelich hire wympill / pynchede was
Hire noose was streiȝhte hir eyen greye as glasse
Hire mouthe full smalle ande þerto softe and rede
But sikerly scho hadde a faire forhede
It was al moste a spanne broode I trowe
For hardely scho was not vndirgrowe
Full fetyse was hire clooke as I was ware
Of smal corall a boute hire arme sche bare
A paire of bedes gawdede all with grene
Ande þer on henge a broche of golde full schene
On whiche þ̉er was firste writen a Crownede . A
Ande after / Amor vincit omnia .
An nother Nonne with hire hadde sche
That was hire chappelleyn ande pstes three
A Monke þ̉er was a faire for þe maystrye
An owte rider þat louede venerye
A manly man to bene an abbot able
Full mony a deynte horse he hadde in stable
Ande when he rode men myȝhte his bridell here
Gyngelynge in a whystlynge wynde as clere
Ande eke as lowde as doith þe chapell belle
There as þis lorde was keper of the selle
The rewle of seynt Mawre or of seynte beneite
By cause þat it was olde ande som dele streite
This ilke monke lete olde thynges pace
Ande helde after þe newe worlde þe space
He ȝaf of þe texte a pullede henne
That seith þat hunters bene noȝt holy men
Ne þat a monke whan he is rechelesse
Is likkenede till a fyssh when he is waterlesse
This is to seye A monke owte of his Cloystere
But þilke texte helde he noȝte worth an oystre
Ande I seide his opinioıı̄un was goode
What schulde he studye ande make hym selfe woode
Vp on a booke in Cloystre al weye to poure
Or swynke with his hondes ande laboure
As Austyn bitt howe schall þe worlde be ʆseruede
Lat Austyn haue his swynke to hym reseruede
Ther fore he was a prykasour a ryȝhte
Greyhoundes he hadde as swyfte as fowle in flyghte
Off prykkynge ande of huntynge for þe hare
Was all his luste for no coste wolde he spare
I seigh his sleves y pᵃfiled att þe honde
With grise and þat þe fyneste of a londe
Ande for to festene his hoode vndir þe chynne
He hadde of golde y wroȝhte a full curious pynne
A loue knotte in þe gretter ende þer was
His hede was ballede þat schone as eny glasse
Ande eke his face as he hadde bene anoynte
He was a lorde full fatte ande in goode poynte
His eyen were stepe ⁊and rollynge in his hede
That stemed as a fourneys of a leede
His botes souple his horse in greteastate
Nowe certanly he was a faire prelate
He nas not pale as a for pynnede goyste
A fatte swan loued he beste of any royste
His palfreye was as browne as is a berye
A frere þer was a wantoıı̄un ande a merye
A lymytour a full solempne man
In alle þe orders foure is none þat kan
So mychell of dalyaunce ande faire langage
He hadde made full monye a maryage
Of ȝonge wōmmen at his own coste
Vn to his ordre he was a noble poste
Ful wele belouede ande familiare was he
With Fraunkeleyns ouer alle in his cuntree
Ande with worthy wōmmen of the towne
For he hadde power of confessioune
As seide hym selfe more þan a curate
For in his ordre he was licenciate
Full swetely herde he confessioıı̄un
Ande plesaunte was his absolucioun
He was an esy man to ȝefe penaunce
Ther as he wyste to haue a goode pytaunce
For vnto a poure order forto ȝiffe
It is a signe þᵗat a man is wele y schryffe
For if he ȝaff he durste make a vaunte
He wyste þat a manne was repentaunte
For mony a man is so harde of his herte
He may noȝt wepe all þof hym sore a smerte
There fore in stede of wepynge and prayers
Men mote ȝiffe siluer to þe pour freres
His typete was aye farsed full of knyves
Ande pynnes for to ȝiff faire wyffes
And certenly he hadde a mery note
Wele cowth he syngen ande pleyen on a roote
Off ȝeddynges he bare witterly þe prise
His nekke was was whyte as þe floure delyse
Ther to he was stronge as a champioıı̄un
He knewe þe tauernes wele in eủery towne
Ande eủeryche hostiler and tapister
Bette þan a lazare or a beggere
For vn to swiche a worthy man as he
Acorded noȝt as by his faculte
To haue with swiche seke lazars acquayntaıı̄unce
It is noȝt honeste it may noȝte avaunce
Forto delen with swiche poraille
But all with ryche ande with sellers of vitaille
Ande oủer alle þer as ꝓprofite schulde arise
Curtas he was ande lowly of seruyse
Ther nas no man nowher so vertuose
He was þe beste begger in all his house
For thogh a wydewe hadde noȝte a scho
So plesaıı̄unte was he in principio
Ȝet wolde he haf a farthynge or he wente
His purchase was wele bett̉er þan his rente
Ande rage he cowthe riȝht as it were a whelpe
In louedayes þer cowthe he myche helpe
For ther he was noȝt liche a Cloysterer
With a thredebare cope as a pore scolere
But he was like a maistr or a pope
Off double worstede was his semy cope
That rounded was as a bell . on þe presse
Somwhat he lispede for his wantounesse
To make his ynglyssh swete opon his tonge
And in his harpynge when þat he hadde y songe
His eyen twynklede in his hede a ryght
As done þe sterres in þe frosty nyghte
This worthy limitour was cleped huberte
A marchaunt þ̉er was with a forkede berde
In mot ⁊and hiegh on horse he satte
Vpon his hede a flaundressbeuer hatte
His botes clasped fair ande fetyslye
His resoıı̄uns he spake full solempnely
Shewynge al weye þe encrese of his wynnynge
He wolde þe see were kepte for eny thynge
Betwyx Midellburgh ande Orwelle
Wele cowthe he in eschaunche scheldes selle
This worthy man full wele his wytte be sette
Ther wyste no wyȝhte þat he was in dette
So estately was he of his gouernance
With his bargaynes and with his cheuysshance
For sothe he was a worthy man with alle
But sotheliche to seyne I note howe men hym calle
A Clerke þer was of Oxenforde also
That vn to logyke hadde longe y goo
As lene was his horse as is a raake
Ande he nas not right fatte I vndirtake
But loked holowe and þer to soburly
Full thredbare was his ouereste courtebye
For he hadde geten hym no benefice
Ne was so worldly to haue an office
For hym leuer haffe at his beddys hede
Twenty bookes y cladde in blakke anderede
Off Aristotill ande of philosophie
Than robes riche or fythel or gaye sawterye
But alle bi þat he was a philisopher
Ȝet hadde he but litill colde in coffr
But all þat he myȝhte of his frendes hente
On bookes ande on lernynge he it spente
Ande besily gan for þe soules preye
Of hem þat fonde hym to scole whar with aye
Off studye toke he moste cure ande hede
Nought oo worde spake he mor þan was nede
Ande þat was seide in forme ande reuerence
And schorte and quyk and full of goode sentence
Sownynge in morall vertue was his specche
Ande gladly wolde he lerne and gladlyteecche
A sergeant of þe lawe ware and wyse
That often hadde bene at paruyce
That was also full riche of excellence
Discrete he was ande of grete reuerence
He semed swiche his wordes wer so wyse
Iustise he was full often in assise
By patent and by pleyne cōmmissione
For his science ande for his heigh renowne
Off fees and robes hadde he mony one
So grete a purchasour was nowhere none
Alle was fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasynge myȝht not bene in fecte
Nowhere so besy as he þer nas
Ande ȝet he semede besier þan he was
In termes hadde he caases and domes all
That from þe tyme of kynge Willᵃm wer falle
Ther to he cowthe endite ande make a thynge
Ther couthe no wyght pynche at his wrytynge
Ande euery statute couthe he pleyne by rote
He roode but homly in a medlede coote
Gert with a seynt of selke with barres smale
Off his aray tell I no lenger tale
A Fraunkeleyn was in his companye
White was his berde as is þe daysye
Of his complexion he was sanguyne
Wele louede he by þe morue a soppe in wyne
To lyuen in delite eủer was his wone
For he was Epycurues own sonne
That helde opinion þat pleyne delite
Was verrey felicite perfite
An householder ande þat a grete was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his cuntree
His brede his ale was alweys aft̉er one
A bett̉er envyned man was nowhere noone
With oute Baken mete was neuer his house
Off fyssh ande flessh ande þat so plentevous
It sewede in his howse of mete and drynke
Offall deyntes þat men couthe thynke
After þe sondry sesoıı̄uns of þe ȝere
So chaunchede he his mete and his sopere
Full mony a fatte partriche hadde he in Mewe
And mony a breme ande eke luces in stewe
Woo was his Cooke but his sauce were
Poynant ande scharpe and redy in all his geere
His table dormant in his halle alweye
Stoode redy couerede all þe longe daye
At sessions þer was he lorde ande sire
Full ofte tyme he was knyȝhte of þe schyre
An Anelas ande a gisperal of silke
Henge at his gyrdell white as morne mylke
A scherreffe hadde he bene ande a countour
Was nowher swiche a worthy vauasour
An haburdassher ande a carpentere
A webbe a Dyere ande a tapesere
And þei were clothed alle in oo lyuereye
Off a solempne and a grete fraternite
Full fressh ande newe here eere a pyked was
Her knyffes wer chapede noȝte with brasse
But all wyth siluer wroȝhte full clene and wele
Here gerdells and her pouches eủerydele
Wele semed eche of hem a feir burgeyse
To sitten in a ȝelde halle on a deese
Eủeryche For þe wysdome þat he kanne
Was schaply for to bene an Alderman
For Catell hadde þei ynogh ande rente
And eke her wyffes wolde it wele assente
And ellis ceyteyn þei wer to blame
It is full fair to be cleped madame
And gone to vigilies all be fore
Ande haue a mantell ryallyche y boor
A Cooke þei hadde with hem for þe nonse
To boylle þe Chikens with þe marybones
And powdr marchant tarte and Galyngale
Wele cowthe he knowe a draght of londoıı̄un ale
He couthe roiste ande seeth ande broill and frye
Maken mortrewes and wele baken a pye
But grete harme was it as it thoghte me
That on his schyne a mormaylle hadde he
For blanke manger þat made he with þe beste
A schipman was þer wōnnynge fer be weste
For ought I wote he was of dertenmouthe
He roode opon a Rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldynge to to kenee
A dagger hangyng in a lase hadde he
A bowten his nekke vndir his arme down
The hote somer hadde made his hewe al browne
Ande certenly he was a goode felawe
Full mony a draȝhte of wyne hadde he drawe
From Burdeux warde while þe chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Yff þat he fauȝhte ande hadde þe hyer honde
By water he sente hem home to euery londe
But of his Crafte to rekken wele his tydes
Hys stremes and his daungers hym besydes
His herberewe ⁊and his moone ⁊and his ledmaunage
Ther nas none swiche from hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was and wyse to vndirtake
With mony a tempeste hadde his berde bene schake
He knewe alle þe hauenes as þei wer
Fro Gotlonde to þe Cape defynyster
And eủery Cryke in bretaygne ande in spayne
His barge y clepede y clepede was þe Mawdeleyne
With us þer was a doctour of phisyke
In all þis worlde ne was þ̉er none hym like
To speke of phisyke ande of surgerye
For he was groundede in astronomye
He kepte his pacience a full grete dele
In houres by his magyk naturelle
Wele couthe he fortune þe ascendente
Off his ymage for his paciente
He knewe þe cause of eủeriche maladye
Were it of hoote or colde or moste or drye
And wher engendred and of what humor
He was a verrey parfite practisour
The cause I knowe and of his harme þe rote
Onon he ȝaff þe seke man his boote
Full redy hadde he his apotekaries
To sonde hem dragges and his lettuaries
For eche of hem made other for to wynne
Her frendschipe nas not newe for to gynne
Wele knowe he þe olde Escalapius
Ande discorides ande eke Rufus
Olde ypocras . haly . Ande Galien
Serapioıı̄un rasy and auyen .
Aueroys damascien / ⁊and constantyne
Bernarde ⁊and Gatisdene ⁊and Gilbertyne
Off his dyete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑperfluite
But of grete nurryshynge ande digestable
His studye was but litill on þe bible
In sangweyne ande in peres cladde he was alle
Lynede with tapheta and with sendall
And ȝet he was bot esy of despense
He kepte þat he wanne in pestilence
For golde in phisike is acordiall
Ther for he louede golde in specialle
A goode wyffe þ̉er was of beside bathe
But sche was somdele defe and þat was skaathe
Of clothe makynge scho hadde swiche an haunte
She passed hem of ypres ande of gaunte
In all þe parissh wyffe ne was þer none
That to þe offerynge to forne hir schulde goone
Ande if þer did certeyne wrothe was sche
That sche was oute of all charitee
Hir coủerchiefes full fyne wer of grounde
I dorste swer þei weyden . x pounde
That on a sonday weren vp on hir hede
Her hosen weren fyne of rede skarlete
Full streyte y tyede and schoose full softe and newe
Bolde was hir face ande fair and rede of hewe
She was a worthy wōmman all her lyue
Husbondes at þe chirche dor scho hadde fyffe
With outen oþer company in thouȝhte
But þer of nedeth it to speke riȝhte moȝhte
Ande thries hadde sche bene at Ihrlm
She hadde passed mony a stronge streme
At Rome scho hadde bene and at boloigne
In galise at seynt Iames and at Coloigne
Sho couthe myche on wandrynge be þe weye
Gat tothede was scho sothely for to seye
Vpon an ambler esily sche satte
Y wymplede wele ande on hir hede an hatte
Als brode as is a Bokeler or a targe
A fote mantell A bouten hir hippes large
Ande on hir feete a paire of spores scharpe
In felaschipe wele couthe scho laugh and karpe
Off remedies of loue sche knewe ꝑparchaunce
For scho cowthe . of þat arte þe olde daunce
A goode man was þer of religioıı̄un
And was a ꝑpersone of a towne
But riche he was of holy thoȝhte ande werke
He was also a lernede man and a clerke
That Cristes gospell trewly wolde preche
His parysshyns deuoutly wolde he tecche
Benigne he was Ande wonder diligente
And in aduersite full paciente
And swiche he was preved ofte sythes
Full lothe wer hym to cursen for his tythes
But rather wolde he ȝeffen oute of doute
Vn to his poure parisshens a boute
Off his offringes and of his substaunce
He couthe in litill thynge haf suffisaunce
Wyde was his ꝑparryssh ande house ferr a sundre
But he ne lafte not for rayne ne for thundre
In sekenes ner in myschiefe to visite
The ferrest in his ꝑparryssh both myche and lite
Vpon his fete and in his honde a staffe
This noble onsample to his schepe he ȝaffe
That ferste he wroȝht and aft̉erwarde þᵗat he tauȝhte
Oute of þe gospell he þo wrdes kaughte
Ande þis figur he hadde eke þerto
That if golde ruste what schall iren doo
For if a preste be foule on whome we truste
No wonder is a lewde man to ruste
Ande schame it is if a preste take kepe
A . schiten scheparde ande a clene schepe
Wele ouȝhte a preste en sample for to ȝyffe
By his clennesse howe þat his schepe schulde lyffe
He sette noȝte his benefice to hyre
Ande lete his schepe to ben acombred in þe myre
And ranne to londoıı̄un vn to seynt Poules
To seeke hym a Chauntr for soules
Or with a bretherede to bene with holde
But dwelled at home and kepte his folde
So þat þe wolff ne made it not myscarye
He was a scheparde ande not a Mercenarye
And þof he were holy ande vertuose
He was nouȝt to synfull men despitous
Ne of speche daungerous ne digne
But in his techynge discrete ande benigne
To drawen folke to heuen by fairnesse
By goode ensample þis was his besynesse
But it were eny ꝑpersoıı̄un obstinate
What so he were of hiegh or lowe astate
Hym wolde he snybbe scharply for þe nones
A bett̉er preste I trowe þat nowher none is
He wayted aft̉er no pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spicede conscience
But Cristes lore and his Apostells twelfe
He tauȝte but firste he folowed hem in hym selfe
With hym þ̉er was a plogh man þat was his brother
That hadde y ladde of donge full mony a fother
And a trewe swynker ande a goode was he
Lyffynge in peese ande ꝑparfite charite
Godde loued he beste with all his herte
At alle tymes þogh he gamed or smerte
And þan his neiȝhbore riȝht as hym selfe
He wolde thresshe and þ̉er to dyke ande delue
For Cristes sake for eủery pore wyȝhte
With oute hir if it lay in his myghte
His tythes paied he full fair ande wele
Bothen of his ꝓpropre swynke and his Catell
In a tabbarde he roode opon a mere
Ther was also A Reve and A Mellere
A sompnoure and A pardoner also
A Maunciple and my selfe þer . war no moo
The Meller was a stoute Carle for þe nones
Full byg he was of brawne ande eke of bones
That proued wele For oủer alle þ̉er he cam
At wrastelynge he wolde ber a weye þe Ram
He was schorte schuldered a thykke knarre
Ther nas no dore þat he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennynge with his hede
His berde as eny sowe or fox was rede
Ande þerto brode as þof it wer a spade
Vpon þe coppe riȝht of his noose he hadde
A werte and þ̉er on stoode a tufte of heeres
Reede as þe birstelles of a sowes eres
His noose thrilles blakke wer ande wyde
A swerde ande Bokeler bare he be his syde
His mouthe als grete was as a grete fourneyse
He was a Iangler ande a goliardeys
And þat was moste of synne and of harlotries
Wele couthe he stelen corne and toll it thries
And ȝit he hadde a thombe of golde parde
A white Cote and a blewe hode wered he
A baggepipe wele couthe he blowe and sowne
And þ̉er with all he broȝht us oute of towne
A gentill manciple was þ̉er of a temple
Of whiche acatours myght take en semple
For to bene wyse in byynge of vitaill
For wheder þat he paied or toke be tayll
Algate he waytede so in his achate
That he was ay be forne ande in goode estate
Nowe is not þat of godde a full fair grace
That swiche a lewede māmnys wytte schall passe
The wysdom of an hepe of lerned men
Of maystres hadde he mo than thries ten
That wer of lawe exꝑparte ande curiouse
Of whiche þ̉er was a dosseyn in þat house
Worthy to bene Stewardes of Rente and londe
Off ony lorde þat is in Englelonde
To make hym lyffe by his ꝓpropre goode
In honour detteles / but if þᵗat he wer wode
Or liff als skarsly als hym liste desire
Ande able for to helpen all a schir
In eny Caase þat myȝhte falle or happe
And ȝet þis manciple sate her allder cappe
The Reue was a sklender colerike man
His berde was schauen as nyeȝh as eủer he can
His heer was by his eres full rownde y schorne
His toppe was dokked like a preste be forne
Full longe wer his legges and full lene
Y lyke a staffe þ̉er was no Calfe y seene
Wele couthe he kepe a garner or a bynne
Ther was non auditour couthe on hym wynne
Wele wyste he by þe droghte ande by þe Reyne
The ȝeldynge of his seede and of his greyne
His lordes schepe his nete his dayrye
His swyne his horse his store and his pulterye
Was holy in þis Reues gouernynge
Ande by his couenᵃnt ȝaff þe rekkenynge
Syn þat his lorde was xx ȝer of age
Ther couthe no man brynge hym in arrerage
Ther nas Baillyff ner herde ner oþ̉er hyne
That he ne knewe his sleght ande his covyne
Thei wer a dredde of hym as of þe deeth
His wonnynge was full fair opon an heeth
With grene treese y schadewede was his plase
He couthe bett̉er þan his lorde purchase
Full riche he was astored priuely
His lorde he couthe wele plesen sotelly
To yiue ⁊and lene hym of his owne goode
And haf a thanke and ȝet a cote ⁊and an hoode
In thoughte he hadde lernede a goode mister
He was a wel goode wryght a Carpenter
This Reue satte opon a full goode stotte
That was all pomely grey and hye scotte
A longe surcote of Peeres vpon he hadde
Ande by his side he bar a Rusty bladde
Off Northfolke was þis Reve of whiche I telle
Besiden a towne men clepen it Baldeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere a boute
Ande eủer herode þe hyndereste of our Route
A somnour was þer with us in þat plase
That hadde a fyri cherubynnes face
For sausefleme he was with eyen narowe
Als hote he was and leccherouse as a sparowe
With scalled browes blak and piled berde
Off his visage Children weren a ferde
Ther nas quykke silủer litarge or brennestone
Boras orsur ne oylle of tartr noone
Ne oynement þat wolde clense and bite
That hym myȝhte helpe of his whelkes whyte
Nor of þe knobbes syttynge in his chekes
Wele loued he garleke oynyons ande eke leekꝭes
And for to drynke stronge wyne reede as blode
Than wolde he speke and crye as he wer woode
And whan þat he wel dronken hadde þe wyne
That wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe termes hadde he two orthr
That he hadde lernede oute of som decree
No wonder is he harde it al þe daye
Ande eke ȝe knowen it wele howe þat a Iaye
Kan clepe watte as wele as I can þe pope
But who so couthe in other thynge hym grope
Than hadde he spente all his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crye .
He was a gentill harlotte ande a kynde
A better felowe schulde men not fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A goode felowe to haue his concubyne
A twelfe moneth ande excuse hym at þe full
Full pⁱriuely eke a fynche couthe he pulle
Ande if he fonde owher a goode felawe
He wolde techen hym to haue none awe
In swiche caas of þe arsdekyns curs
But if mannes soule wer in his purs
For in his purse he schulde punysshede be
Purse is þe arsdekenes helle seide he
But wele I wote he liede riȝhte in dede
Off cursynge ought eche gilty man hym drede
For curs will slee / riȝht as assoilynge sauith
And also war hym of a . significauit
In daunger hadde he at his owne gyse
The ȝonge gyrles of þe diocise
Ande knewe hir counsell and what was al hir reede
A garlande hadde he sate opon his heede
Als grete as it wer for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made hy of a kake
With hym þ̉er rode a gentill pardoner
Off Rouncyvale his frende and his comper
That streiȝht was cōmen fro þe courte of rome
Full lowde he songe come hider loue to me
This somnour bar to hym a styff burdoıı̄un
Was neủer trompe of halfe so grete a sown
This ꝑpardoner hadde heer as ȝelowe as wexe
But smothe it henge as doith a strike of flexe
By ounces henge his lokkes þat he hadde
And þ̉er with he his schuldernes ouer spradde
But thynne it lay by culpons one and one
But hoode for Iolitee werede he noone
For it was trussed up in his walette
Hym thouȝhte he roode al of þe newe gette
Discheuele saf his cappe he rode all bare
Swiche glarynge eyen hadde he as an hare
A vernykle hadde he sewed opon his cappe
His walet beforne hym was in his lappe
Bret full of ꝑpardone come fro rome all hote
A voys he hadde als small as a goote
No berde ne hadde he ne neủer schulde haue
Als smothe it was as it wer late y schaue
I trowe he wer a geldynge or a mare
But of his Crafte fro Berwyke in to ware
Ne was þ̉er swiche a nother ꝑpardonere
For in his male he hadde a pyleweber
Whiche þat he saide was oure lady vaille
He seide he hadde a gobette of þe seylle
That seynt Petir hadde when þat he wente
Vp on þe see till Ihu Criste hym sente
He hadde a Croyse of latoıı̄un full of stones
Ande in a glasse he hadde pikges bones
But with þise relikes when þat he fonde
A poure ꝑpersone dwellyng opon londe
O pon a day he gat hym more monye
Than þe ꝑpersonne gat in monethis tweye
And þus with feyned flat̉erynge and with Iapes
He made þe ꝑpersone and þe peple his apes
But trewly to tellen at þe laste
He was in chirche a noble ecciaste
Wele couthe he rede a lessoıı̄un or a storye
But alderbeste he songe an offertorye
For wele he wyste whan þat songe was songen
He moste preche ande wele a fyle his tonge
To wynnen siluer as he wele couthe
Ther fore he sange so merely ande lowde
Nowe haf I tolde ȝowe sothely in a clause
The astate þe araye þe noumbr ande eke þe cause
Why þat assembled was þis companye
In Suthwerke at þis gentill hostelerye
That hiȝht þe tabbarde faste by þe belle
But nowe is tyme to ȝowe for to telle
Howe þat we beren us þat ilke nyȝht
Whan we wer in þat Osterye a liȝhte
Ande after woll I tellen of our viage
And alle remenaunte of oure pilgrimage
But ferste I preye ȝowe of ȝoure Curtesye
That ȝe ne rette it noȝte my vilaynye
Thof þat I pleynly speke in þis matere
To tellen ȝowe her wordes and her cher
Ne thogh I speke her wordes ꝓpropurlye
For þis ȝe knowen als wele as I .
Who so schall tellen a tale after a man
He mote reherce als neigh as eủer he can
Eủeryche a worde if it be in his charge
All speke he neủer so rudely ande large
Or ells he mot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thynges or fynde wordes newe
He may nouȝt spare all þof he wer his brother
He mot als wele seye oo . worde as a nother
Criste spake hym selfe full brode in holy writte
And wele ȝe wote no vilanye is it
Eke plato seith who so can hym reede
The wordes mote bene Cosyn to þe dede
Also I pray ȝowe forȝiff it me
All haf I not sette folke in hir degree
Here in þis tale as þat þei schulden stonde
My wytte is schorte ȝe may wele vndirstonde
Grete chere made oure oste us eủerichon
And to þe soper sette he us onon
He ʆserued us with vitailles at þe beste
Stronge was þe wyne ande wele drynke us leste
A semely man oure oste was with alle
For to bene a Merschall in an halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A fairer burgese is none in chepe
Bolde of his speche ande wise and wele y tauȝhte
Ande of manhode hym lakkede riȝht nauȝhte
Eke þ̉erto he was riȝht a mery manne
Ande aft̉er soper pleien he began
Ande spake of mirthe amonge oþer thynges
Whan þat we hadde made our rekkenynges
And seide þus Nowe lordynges trewly
Ȝe beene to me welcome riȝht hertely
For be my trouthe if þat I schall not lye
I seye noȝte þis ȝere so mery a companye
At ones in þis herberowe as is nowe
Fayne wolde I done ȝowe mirthe wiste I howe
And of a myrthe I am ryght nowe be thōghte
To done ȝowe ese Ande it schall coste noȝte
Ȝe gone to Caunturbury godde ȝowe spede
The Blesfull martir quite ȝowe ȝoure mede
Ande wele I wote as ȝe gone by þe waye
Ȝe schapen ȝowe to talen and to pleye
For trewly comforte ne mirthe is þ̉er none
To riden by þe weye dombe as a stoone
Ande þer for woll I maken ȝowe desporte
As I seide arste ande done ȝowe som 9forte
Ande if ȝowe liketh alle by one assente
For to stonden at my Iuggemente
Ande for to werken as I schall . ȝewe seye .
To morowen when we riden by þe weye
Nowe be my fader soule þat is dede
But ȝe be mery I will ȝiff ȝowe my hede
Holde up ȝour hondes with oute more speche
Our counseall was not longe for to seeche
Vs thought it was not worth to make to wyse
And grauntede hym withoute more avise
And badde hym seye his verdeyte as hym lyste
Lordynges qd he nowe herkeneth for þe beste
But take it noȝte I preye ȝowe in disdeigne
This is þe poynte to speke schorte ande pleyne
That eche of ȝowe to schorte with oþer weye
In þis viage schall tellen tales tweye
To Cauntirbury warde I mene it . soo
And homwardes he schall tellen other two
Off auentures þat whilom hauen befalle
Ande whiche of ȝowe þat berith hym beste of all
That is to seyne þat tellith in þis case
Tales of beste sentence Ande moste solace
Shall haue a soper at our aller cooste
Her in þis place sittynge by þis poste
Whan þat comyn a gayn from caunterbery
And for to make ȝowe þe mor merye
I will my selfe goodly with ȝowe ride
Riȝht at myn own coste and be ȝour gyde
And who so will my Iuggement withsaye
Shall paye all þat we spende by þe weye
And if ȝe wouchesaue þat it be soo
Tell me onon with outen wordes moo
Ande I woll arly schape me þer fore
This thynge was gᵃunted and our othes y swore
With full gladde herte and preiden hym alsoo
That he wolde wouchesaue for to don soo
And þat he wolde be oure gouernour
And of our tales Iugge ande repirtour
And sette a soper at a certeyn prise
And we willen rewlede bene at his deuyse
In heigh ande lowe and þus by one assente
We bene acorded to þat Iuggemente
And þer opon þe wyne was fette onone
We dronken ande to reste wente eủerychone
With outen eny lenger taryynge
A morowe whan þe daye gan to sprynge
Vp rose our ooste ande was our alder Cokke
Ande gadered us to gider in a flokke
And forthe we ridden a litill mor þn paase
Vn to þe waterynge of seynte thomas
Ande þere our oste gan his horse areste
And seide lordes herkeneth if ȝowe leste
Ye wote ȝe forwarde and I it ȝow recorde
Yff euensonge and morowen songe acorde
Lat se nowe ho schall . tell þe firste tale
As euer motte I drynke wyne or ale
Who so be rebeƚƚ to my Iuggemente
Shall paye for aƚƚ þat by þe weye is spente
Nowe draweth or þat we ferþer wynne
Whiche þat hath þe schorteste schaƚƚ begynne
Sir͗e knyght qduod he my maister and my lorde
Nowe draweth cutte for þat is myne accorde
Cometh nere qduod he my lady prioresse
And ȝe sir Clerke lat be ȝour schamefastnesse
Ne studieth not leye honde to euery manne
A noon̄ to drawe eủery wighte beganne
And schortly for to tellen̄ as it was
Wer͗e it by auentur͗e or sorte or caase
The south is þis þe cutte felle to þe knyȝhte
Of whiche fuƚƚ gladde and blithe was eủery wyȝhte
And tellen he moste his tale as it was resoune
By forwarde ande by composicioıı̄un
As ȝe han̄ herde what nedith wordes moo
And whan þis goode man sawgh þat it was soo
As he þat wise was ande obediente
To kepen̄ his forwarde by his free assente
He seide sethen I schall begynne þe game
What welcome be þe cutte of goddis name
Nowe lat us ride ande herkenyth what I seye
And witħ þat worde we riden̄ forthe our͗e weye
Ande beganne with riȝht a mery cheer͗e
His taale onon and seide as ȝe may her͗e

I am que domos patrias seitate post aspera gentis
prelia laurigero

l.hi: ¶ Here endith þe prologe of þis booke

div.l: ¶ Here bigynneth þe knyghtis taale
Whilom was as olde stories tellen us
Ther was a Duke þat hiȝhte Theseus
Off Athenes he was lorde ande gouernour͗e
And in his tyme swiche a conquerour͗e
That gretter was none vndir þe sonne
Fuƚƚ mony a riche contr͗e hadde he wonne
What with his wysdome ande his chiualrye
He conquerede all þe reigne of femenye
That whilom was yclepede Scithia
And wedded þe quene ypolita
And broght hir͗e home with hym in his contre
With myche glorie and grete solempnite
And eke here ȝonge suster emelye
And þus with victorie ande with melodye
Lat I þis noble Duke to Athenes ryde
And aƚƚ his oste in armes hym be syde
And certes ȝiff it nere to longe to here
I wolde haf tolde fully þe manere
Howe wonnen was þe reigne of femynye
By theseus ande by his Chiualrye
And of þe grete bataille for þe nones
Bytwixen Athenes and Amaȝones
And howe assegede was ypolita
The fair͗e hardy quene of scithia
And of þe feste þat was at hir͗e weddynge
And of þe tempeste at hir͗e home cōmmynge
But aƚƚ þat thynge I mot as nowe forbere
I haf godde wote a large felde to ere
Ande weyke bene þe oxen in my plough
The remanent of þe tale is longe ynogh
I woƚƚ not letten̄ eke none of þis route
Lat eủery felowe teƚƚ his tale aboute
And lat see nowe who schaƚƚ þe soper wynne
And þ̉er I lafte I wiƚƚ a ȝeyne begynne
This duke of whome I make mencioıı̄un
When he was cōmmen̄ al moste to þe towne
In aƚƚ his wele and his moste pride
He was ware as he caste his eye a side
Wher͗e þat þer knelede in þe hiegh weye
A companye of ladyes tweye and tweye
Eche after oþer cladde in clothes blakke
But swich a crye and swiche a woo þei make
That in þis worlde is creature lyffynge
That harde swiche a nother weymentynge
Ande of þis crye þei nolde neuer stentyn
Til þei þe Reynes of his brideƚƚ henten̄
What folke be ȝe þat at myno home ꝯcomynge
Perturbe so my feste witħ cryynge
Qduod theseus haue ȝe so grete envye
Off myn̄ honoᵘur þat þus ꝯcompleyne and crye
Or who hatħ nowe mysboden̄ or offended
Ande teƚƚ it me if it may ben̄ amendede
And why þat ȝe bene clothed þus in blakke /
The eldest lady of hem alle spake
Whan sche had swonned with a dedly chier͗e
That it was routhe to seen̄ ande here
She seide lorde to whome fortune hath ȝiffen̄
Victorie ande as a conquerour to lyuen̄
Nat greuyth vs ȝour͗e glorie and ȝour͗e honoure
But we biseche of mercy ande socour͗e
Haf mercy on oure wo and on our͗e distresse
Som drope of pite for þi gentilnesse
Vpon vs wrecched wommen lat þou falle
For certes lorde þer is noone of us alle
That sche hath bene a duchesse or a quene
Now be wee Caytiffes as it is wele seene
Thankede be fortune and hir͗e fals whele
That noone estate ensureth for to bene wele
Nowe certis lorde to abiden̄ ȝoure persence
Her͗e in þis temple of þe goddesse clemence
We haff bene waytynge al þis fourte nyȝte
Helpe us lorde seth it is in þi myȝte
I wrecche whiche þat wepe and weylle þus
Was whilom þe wiffe to kynge Cappaneus
That starfe at thebeus cursed be þat daye
And alle we þat bene in þis arraye
And maken̄ aƚƚ þis lamentacioıı̄un
We losten alle oure husbondes at þat towne
Whil þat þe assege there a boute lay
Ande ȝet nowe þe olde Creon cryen cryen creon welowaye
That lorde is nowe of thebes citee
Ful filled of ire ande of Iniquite
He for despite ande for his tiranntrye
To done þe dede bodies vilenye
Off alle our͗e lordes whiche þat bene slawe
Hath alle þe bodies on an hepe drawe
And woƚƚ not suffre hem by non assente
Neiþ̉er to bene y buriede nouþ̉er y brente
But maketh houndes to ete þam in despite
And with þat worde with oute more respite
Thei fillen̄ gruffe and crieden̄ pitously
Haue on vs wrecchede wōmmen som mercy
And latte our͗e sorowe synken in þine herte
This gentiƚƚ duke down̄ from his courser sterte
With herte pitous when he harde hem speke
Hym thoughte þat his herte wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem so petousfuƚƚ and so maate
That whylome wer͗e of so grete astate
And in his armes he hem alle up hente
Ande conforted hem in fuƚƚ goode entente
And swure his oothe as he was trewe knyȝht
He wolde done so ferforthly his myȝhte
Vpon̄ þe tiraunte Creon̄ hem to wrecke
That alle þe peple of grece schuld speke
Howe Creon̄ was of theseus yseruede
As he þat hadde his deth fuƚƚ wele deʆseruede
And riȝħt onon̄ witħ outen mor͗e abode
His baner he displaied ande forthe roode
To tebes warde ande aƚƚ his oste him him bisyde
Ne nerrer͗e Athenes wolde he gon̄ nor ride
Ne take his ease fully halfe a daye
But onwarde on his waye þat nyȝht he laye
And sente onon̄ y polita þe quene
And Emelye her ȝonge suster schene
Vn to þe towne of Athenes to dwelle
And forthe he ritte þer nys na mor͗e to telle
The rede statue of Mars with spere and targe
So shyneth in his white baner large
That aƚƚ þe felde glitered vp and down̄
And by his baner borne is his pynown̄
Off golde fuƚƚ riche in whiche þer was ybete
The Mynataur whiche þat we wan̄ in Crete
Thus riȝht þis duke þus riȝht þis conquerour͗e
And in his oste of Chiualrie þe floure
Tiƚƚ þat he come to thebes ande aliȝhte
Fair͗e in a felde þer as he thouȝhte to Fiȝhte
But schortly for to spekyn of þis thynge
Witħ Creon̄ whiche þat was of thebes kynge
He faughte ande slowgh hym manly as a knyȝht
In pleyne bataille ande putte þe folke to fliȝhte
And by assent he wane þe Cite after
And rente a downe both walle and sparre ⁊and raffter
And to þe ladyes he restorede a ȝeyne
The bones of þer frendes þat weren slayne
To done obsequies as was þo þe gyse
But it wer͗e aƚƚ to longe for to deuyse
The grete clamour͗e ande þe weymentynge
That þe ladies made at þe brennynge
Of þe bodies ande þe grete honoure
That theseus þe noble conqueroure
Dothe to þe ladyes when̄ þei from hym wente
But schortly to tellen̄ is myne entente
Whan þat þis worthy duke þis theseus
Hatħ Creon̄ slayne and wonne Thebes þus
Stiƚƚ in þat felde he tooke al nyȝht his reste
And didde with aƚƚ þe contre as hym leste
To ransake in þe taase of þe bodies dede
Hem for to strepe of harneys and of wede
The pyloures diden̄ bysynes and cur͗e
After þe bataille ande þe discomfiture
Ande so byfeƚƚ þat in þe caase þei founde
Thurgħ girte with many a blody wonnde
Two ȝonge knyghtes liggynge by and by
Bothen in armes same wroght full richely
Of whiche two Arcita hight þe tone
And þat oþ̉er knyght hyȝhte Palamon̄
Nat fully quykke ne fully dede þei wer͗e
But by her͗e cote armours and by her͗e ger͗e
The herawdes knewe hem selfe in speciaƚƚlle
As þei þat weren of þe blode ryaƚƚlle
Off thebes ande of sustren twoo y borne
Oute of þe caas þe pilours han hem torne
And han hem caried softe Vnto þe tente
Of theseus ande he fuƚƚ sone hem sente
To athenes to dwellen̄ in prison
ꝐPerpetuelly hem nolde he not raunsoun
And when̄ þis worthy duke had þus doone
He toke his oste ande home he ritte onoon̄
With laurer coronede as a conquerour͗e
And þer he liffeth in ioye and in honoure
Terme of his lyffe what nedetħ wordes moo
And in a tour͗e in angwise ande in woo
Dwellen̄ þis palamon̄ ande eke arcite
For eủermor͗e þer may no golde hem quite
This passeth þer by ȝere ande daye by daye
Tiƚƚ it fiƚƚ oones in a morowe of may
That Emely þat fair͗er͗e was to seene
Than is þe lilye opon his stalke grene
And fresher þan he may witħ floures newe
For witħ þe roose colour͗e stroffe hir͗e hewe
I note whiche was þe fairer of hem twoo
Er it wer͗e day as was hir͗e wone to doo
She was arisen̄ ande aƚƚ redy diȝhte
For May wiƚƚ haf no slogardrye on nygħt
The seson̄ prikketħ euery gentiƚƚ herte
And makitħ it oute of his slepe to sterte
Ande sithen a rise ande done may obseruᵃaunce
This makith emely to haue remembraunce
To done honour͗e to may and for to rise
Y clothed was sche fressh for to deuyse
Hir͗e ȝalowe heer͗e was broyded in a tresse
By hynde her bakle a ȝerde longe I gesse
And in þe gardyn at þe sonne vp riste
She walketh up and dawn̄ and as hir͗e liste
She gadereth floures ꝑpartie white and reede
To make a sotiƚƚ garlonde for hir͗e hede
And as an Aungeƚƚ heuenysshly she songe
The grete tour͗e þat was so thikke and stronge
Whiche of þe casteƚƚ was þe chiefe dunchen̄
Ther͗e as þe knyghtes weren in prison̄
Off whiche I tolde ȝowe ande teƚƚ schaƚƚlle
Was euen̄ ioynant to þe gardyn̄ waƚƚlle
Ther͗e as þis emelye hadde hire pleyynge
Briȝht was þe sonne ande cler͗e in þat mornynge
And palamon þis woofuƚƚ prisoner͗e
As was his wone by leue of his gailler͗e

div.l: (base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun

div.l: (base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
What wilt þou seyne þou wiste it nouȝt ȝit nowe
Whedir sche be a wōmman or goddesse
Thin is affeccion of holynesse
Ande myne is loue as to a creatur͗e
For whiche I tolde þe myne aventur͗e
As to my Cosyn and to my broþ̉er sworne
I pose þat þou louedeste hir͗e beforne
Wotest þou not wele þe olde clerkis sawe
That who shaƚƚ ȝiff a louer eny lawe
Loue is a grett̉er lawe be my panne
Þan may be ȝiff to eny erthly manne
And þ̉er for positife lawe and swiche decree
Is broke aƚƚ daye for loue in swiche degree
A man mote nedes loue maugr͗e his heede
He may not flyen it þof he schulde be dede
All be scho mayde or wydowe or elles wyffe
And eke it is not likly aƚƚ þi lyffe
To stonden in hir͗e grace no mor͗e schaƚƚ I
For wele þou wotest þi selfe verrely
That þou and I bene dampnede to prisoun
ꝐPerpetuelly vs gayneth noo raunsoun
We striven as houndes for þe bone
Þei fouȝhten al day and ȝit hir͗e parte was none
Ther come a kyte while þat þei wer͗e so wroothe
That bar͗e a weye þe bone betwix hem bothe
And Ask And þ̉er for at þe kynges courte my brother
Eche man for hym selfe þ̉er is none other͗e
Loue if þou liste for I luff ande aye schaƚƚlle
A soothly leue brother þis is aƚƚlle
Her͗e in þis prison̄ mot we endur͗e
And eueriche of us take his auentur͗e
Grete was þe striffe ande longe betwix hem þēm tweye
Yf þat I hadde leiser for to seye
But to þis effecte it happed on a daye
To tellen it ȝowe it schortly as I may
A worthy duke þat hiȝht ꝑparotheus
That felowe was vn to duke theseus
Syn þilke daye þat þei weren childrēn lite
Was comen to atthenes his felowe to visite
And for to pleye as he was wonte to doo
For in þis worlde he loued no man̄ soo
And he louede hym also tendirly agayne
So world þei louede as olde bookes seyne
Than̄ whan̄ þat one was dede sothely to telle
His felawe wente and soughte hym down̄ in helle
But of þat storye liste me not to writte
Duke ꝑparotheus louede wele arcite
And hadde hym knowe at Thebes ỷer be ȝere
And finaly at þe requeste and preyer
Of ꝑparotheus with outen eny raunsoun
Duke theseus lete hym oute of prisoun
Frely to gone wher͗e þat hym lyste ouer aƚƚlle
In swiche a gyse as I ȝowe tellen schaƚƚlle
This was þe forwarde pleynly for to endite
Be twix theseus and hym arcite
That if so were þat arcite wer͗e founde
Eủere in his liffe be daye or nyȝht or stonde
In any Countr͗e of þis Theseus
And he wer͗e kauȝte it was accordede þus
That witħ a swerde he schulde lese his hede
Ther nas none other remedie ne reede
But takith his leue ande homwarde he hym spedde
Lat hym be war͗e his nekke lieth to wedde
Howe grete a sorowe suffreth nowe Arcite
The deth he felith thurgh his herte smyte
He wepith weyleth and crieth pitously
To sleen hym selfe he waitith priuely
He saide allas þat day þat I was borne
Now is my prisoune wors þan it was beforne
Now is me eternaly to dwelle
Noȝht in purgatorie but in helle
Allas þat euer I knewe ꝑparotheus
For els had I y dwelled with theseus
I fetered in his prison̄ eủermoo
Than hadde I bene in blisse and not in woo
Oonly þe siȝht of hir͗e whome þat I serue
Thof þat I neủer had grace may diserue
Wolde haf suffised riȝht ynogh for me
O der͗e Cosyn̄ palamon̄ qduod he
Thyn is þe victorie of þis auentur͗e
Fuƚƚ blisfully in prison maȝhte you endur͗e
In prison̄ Certis Nay but ꝑparadise
Wele hath fortune y turned þe þe dyse
That hast þe siȝhte of hir͗e and and þe absence
For possible is sen̄ þou haste hir͗e p̉resence
And arte a knyȝħt a worthy ande an able
That by som caas syne fortune is chaungeable
Thowe maiste somtyme to þi desir͗e atteyne
But I þat am exiled ande barreyne
Off all grace and in so grete despeir͗e
That þ̉er nis erthe water Fir͗e ner eyr͗e
Nor creatur͗e þat of hem maked is
That may me helpe or done ꝯconforte in þis
Wele ouȝht I to sterffe in wanhope and distresse
Far͗e wele my lyffe my luste and my gladnesse
Allas why pleynen̄ men̄ so in cōmmıı̄un
On þe purueaunce of godde or of fortune
That ȝeueth hem fuƚƚ ofte in mony a gyse
Wele bette þan þei kan hem self deuyse
Som man̄ desireth to haf richesse
That cause is of his mordre or grete sikenesse
Ande som man̄ wolde oute of his prison̄ fayne
That in his own house is of his menȝe slayne
Infinite harmes bene in þis mater͗e
We wote not what thynge þat we preyen her͗e
We faren as he þat dronken is as a mouse
A dronke man wote wele he hath an house
But he noot whiche is þe riȝhte weye is þider
And to a dronken man þe weye is slether
Ande certes in þis worlde so faren we
We seken faste after felicite
But we gone wronge fuƚƚ ofte trewly
Thus may we seyne alle and nameliche I
That wende and hadde a grete opinioıı̄un
That if I myȝht scappen̄ fro prisoune
Than hadde I bene in ioye and ꝑparfite heele
Ther nowe I am exiled fro my wele
Sethen þat I may not seen̄ ȝowe emelye
I am but dede þ̉er nys no remedye
Opon þe toþ̉er side Palamon̄
Whan þat he wiste þat Arcite was a gone
Swiche sorowe he maketh þat þe grete toure
Resouneth of his yollyng and clamour͗e
The pure fetteres of his schynnes grete
Wer͗e of his bitter salte teres wete
Allas qduod he Arcita Cosyn myne
Off aƚƚ our͗e striffe god wote þe fruyte is þine
Thowe walkeste nowe in thebes at þi large
And of my woo þou ȝerueste litiƚƚ charche
Thou maiste sen þou haste wysdome and manhede
Assemble aƚƚ þe folke of our͗e kynrede
And make a werr͗e so scharpe on þis Citee
That by som auentur͗e or tretee
Thou maiste haf hir͗e to lady and to wyffe
For whome þat I moste nedes lese my lyffe
For as by weye of possibilite
Seth þou arte at þi large of prison̄ free
And arte a lorde grete is þine auᵃauntage
More þan is myne þat sterue her͗e in a kage
For I mote wepe and waille whil þat I liffe
With aƚƚ þe wo þat prison̄ may me ȝiffe

div.l: (base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
In cheynes and fettres to þe dede
And Arcite is exiled vp his hede
For eủer more as ouȝht of þat contr͗e
Ne neủer ne schaƚƚ his lady see
¶ Ȝowe louers aske I nowe þis questioıı̄un
Who hath þe worse arcite or palemoun̄
The tone may sene his lady day by daye
But in pⁱrison̄ mote he dweƚƚ al weye
The to þ̉er wher͗e hym liste may ride or goo
But seen̄ his lady schaƚƚ he neủer moo
Nowe dymmeth as ȝowe liste and iuggeth þᵗat ȝekan̄
For I wiƚƚ teƚƚ forthe as I began̄
When̄ þat arcite to Thebes comen was
Fuƚƚ often a daye he swelte and saide allas
For seene his lady schaƚƚ he neủer þe moo
And schortly to concluden̄ aƚƚ his woo
So mucheƚƚ sorowe hadde neủer creatur͗e
That is or schaƚƚ þat þe worlde may dur͗e
His sleepe his mete his drynke is hym berafte
That lene he wex and drye as is a schafte
His eyhen hollowen ande grisly to beholde
His hewe falowe ande pale as asshes colde
And solitarie he was ande eủer allone
Ande wayllynge al þe nyȝht makynge his moone
And if he herde songe or instrumente
Than wolde he wepe he myȝht not be stente
So feble eke wer͗e his spirites ande he he so lowe
And chaunged soo þat no man̄ cowde knowe
His speche neþ̉er his voise þogh men̄ it harde
And in his ger͗e for aƚƚ þe worlde he ferde
Not comly like to louers maladye
Of heroes heres heroes but rather like monye
Engendred of humoᵘur malencolik
Beforne his celle fantastyke
And schortly turned was aƚƚ up and downe
Bothe habite and disposicioıı̄un
Of hym þis wofuƚƚ louer dame dame done Arcite
What schuld I alday of his woo endite
When̄ he endurede hadde a ȝeer͗e or twoo
This cruwe͗eƚƚ torment ⁊and þise peynes and woo
At thebes in his contre as I seide
Opon a nyȝht in slope as he hym leide
Hym thouȝht howe þat þe wenched godde m̉ercurye
By forne hym stode ande badde hym to be merye
His slepy ȝerde in honde he bar͗e up riȝht
An hatte he wered vpon̄ his eres briȝhte
Arraied was þis godde as he toke kepe
As he was when þat Argus toke his slepe
Ande seide hym þus to Athenes schalt þᵘ wende
Ther is þe shapen̄ of þi wo an ende
And with þat worde Arcite woke and sterte
Nowe treweliche howe sor͗e þat me smerte
Qduod he to Athenes riȝht nowe wiƚƚ I far͗e
Ne for þe drede of deeth schaƚƚ I not spar͗e
To se my lady þat I loue ande serue
In hir͗e p̉resence I ne recche not to sterue
And with þat worde he kauȝhte a grete Mirour
Ande sagh þat chaunged was aƚƚ his colour͗e
And sagh his visage aƚƚ in a nother kynde
Ande riȝht onon it ranne hym in his mynde
That sethen̄ his face was so disfigurede
Off maladye þe whiche he hadde endurede
He myȝht wele if þat he bar͗e hym lowe
Lyue in Athenes eueremor͗e vnknowe
Ande seen his lady wel nye day be day
And riȝht a non̄ he chaunged his araye
Ande cladde hym as a pour͗e laborer͗e
And al allone saue only a Squier
Þat knewe his priuete ande aƚƚ his case
Whiche was disgised poủrely as he was
To Athenes is he gone þe nexte waye
And to þe courte he wente opon a daye
And at þe gate he ꝓprofreth his seruise
To drugge and drawe what so men wolde deuyse
Ande schortly of þis mater for to seyne
He fille in office with a Chambreleyne
The which þat was dwellynge was wᵗith emelye
For he was wise ande couthe aspie
Off eủeryche ʆseruaᵃaunt whiche þat ʆserued her͗e
Wele couthe he hewen̄ wode and water ber͗e
For he was ȝonge and myȝhty for þe nones
Ande þ̉er to he was stronge and bigge of boones
To done þat eny wiȝhte hym couthe deuyse
A ȝeer͗e or two he was in þis seruice
Page of þe Chambr͗e of Emelye þe briȝhte
And Philostrat he seide þat he hiȝht
But halfe so wele beloued a man as he
Ne was þ̉er neủer in court of his degree
He was so gentiƚƚ of condicioıı̄un
That thurgh oute aƚƚ þe courte was his renoun̄
Thei seide þat it wer͗e a charite
That theseus wolde enhance his degree
And putten hym in worshipfuƚƚ seruise
Ther as he myȝhte his vertue excercise
And þus with In a while his name is spronge
Bothen of his dedes ande his goode tonge
That theseus hath taken hym so ner͗e
That of his chambr͗e he made hym a Squier͗e
And gaff hym golde to mayntegne his degree
And eke men brouȝht hym oute of his contree
Fro yer to yeer fuƚƚ priuely his rente
But honestly ande slely he it spente
That no man wondrede howe þat he it hadde
And thr͗e ȝeer͗e in þis wise his liffe he ladde
And bar͗e hym so in pees ande eke in wer͗er͗e
Ther was no man þat Theseus hath mor͗e derr͗e
And in þis blisse lete I nowe Arcite
And speke I woƚƚ of Palamon̄ a lite

¶ This seuen ȝeer͗e
hath seten Palamon̄In derkenes horrible and stronge prison̄
For pyned what for woo ande for destresse
Who feleth double soor͗e and heuynesse
But Palemon þat loue distreynede so
That wodde oute of his witte he goith for woo
And eke þ̉er to he is a prisoner
ꝐPerpetuelly not oonly for a ȝeer͗e
Who couthe ryme in englysshe ꝓpropirlye
His martirdome for sothe it am not I
Ther͗efor͗e I passe also liȝhtly as I may
It felle þat in þe seuēnt ȝeer͗e of May
The thridde nyȝht as olde bokes seyne
That alls þis storie telleth mor͗e pleyne
Wer͗e it by auentur͗e or destenye
As whan̄ a thynge is schape it schaƚƚ be
That sone after þe mydnyȝht Palemon̄
Bi helpynge of a frende brakke prisoun̄
And flieth þe Citee faste as he may goo
For he hadde ȝiffe his Gailler drynke so
Off a Clarr͗e made of a certeyn̄ wyne
With nercokꝭes and opie of thebes fyne / /
That all þat nyȝht þof þat men̄ wold hym schake
The Gailler͗e slepe he myȝht not awake
And þus he fleeth as faste as euer he maye
The nyȝght was schorte and faste by þe daye
That nedes coste he moste hym selfe hiden̄
And tiƚƚ a groue faste þ̉er besiden̄
With dredfuƚƚ foot þan stalkede Palamon̄
For schortly þis was his opinioıı̄un
That in þat grove he wolde hym hide al daye
Ande in þe nyȝhte þan wolde he take his waye
To Thebes warde his frendes for to preye
On Theseus to helpe hym to werreaye
And schortly he wolde owþer lese his lyffe
Or wynnen Emelye to his worthy wyffe
This is þe effecte and his entente pleyne
Nowe wiƚƚ I turne to Arcite a gayne
That liteƚƚ wiste howe niegh þat was his care
Tiƚƚ þat fortune had kauȝht hym in his snare
The besy larke messanger of daye
Salueth in hire songe þe morowe graye
And firy phebus riseth up so briȝhte
That alle þe oriente laughed of þe liȝhte
Ande with his stremes drieth in þe greues
The seluir dropes hangynge in þe leeues
And Arcita þat in þe courte roiaƚƚlle
With theseus his squier principaƚƚlle
Is rysen̄ and loketh on þe mery daye
And for to done his obʆseruᵃaunce to maye
Remembrynge on þe poynte of his desire
He on his courser stertyng as þe fire
Is riden̄ in to þe feldes hym to pleye
Oute of þe courte wer it a mile or tweye
Ande to þe groue of þe whiche þat I ȝow tolde
By auentur͗e his weye he gan to holde
To maken hym a garlonde of þe greues
Wer͗e it of wodebynde or hawthorne leeues
Ande lowde he songe a ȝein þe sone schene
May with aƚƚ þi floures and þi grene
Welcome be þou fair͗e fressh Maye
In hope þat I some grene gete may
And from his couʳser with a lusty herte
In to þe groue fuƚƚ hastly he sterte
And in a pathe he rometh up and down
Ther as by auentur͗e of þis Palemon
Was in a bussh þat no man myȝhte hym see
For sore a ferde of his deeth was he
No thynge ne knewe he þat it was Arcite
God wote he wolde haf trowed it fuƚƚ lite
But soth is seide go sithen mony ȝeres
That felde hath eyen̄ and þe wode hath eeres
It is fuƚƚ fair͗e a man to ber͗e hym euen
For al daye meteth men̄ at vnsette steven̄
Fuƚƚ liteƚƚ woote Arcite of his felowe
That was so nyegh to herken of his sawe
For in þe busshe he sitteth nowe fuƚƚ stille
Whan þat Arcite had romed al his fille
And songen̄ aƚƚ þe roundeƚƚ lustily
In to a studye he feƚƚ sothanly

div.l: (base) As doon thise louerys / in hir queynte gerys
(base) Now in the crop / now down in the brerys
(base) Now vp / now down / as boket in a welle
(base) Right as the friday / soothly for to telle
(base) Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
(base) Right so / kan gery Venus ouercaste
(base) The hertes of hir folk . right as hir day
(base) Is gerful / right so chaungeth she array
(base) Selde is the friday / al the wike ylike
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite hadde songe / he gan to syke
(base) And sette hym down / withouten any moore
(base) Allas quod he / that day / that I was bore
(base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
(base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde

div.l: (base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
(base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wᵗith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe

div.l: (base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
(base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
(base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
(base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
(base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.
(base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe
(base) Or he moot sle me / if that me myshappe
(base) So ferden they / in chaungyng of hir hewe
(base) As fer / as euerich / oother of hem knewe
(base) ¶ Ther nas no good day / ne no saluynge
(base) But streight withouten word / or rehersynge
(base) Euerich of hem / heelp for to armen oother
(base) As frendly / as he weere / his owene brother
(base) And after that with sharpe speres stronge
(base) They foynen / ech at oother / wonder longe
(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun
(base) In his fightyng were a wood leoun
(base) And as a crewel Tygre / was Arcite
(base) As wilde boores / gonnen they to smyte
(base) That frothen / whit as foom / for Ire wood
(base) Vp to the Anclees / foghte they in hir blood
(base) And in this wise / I lete hem fightyng dwelle
(base) And forth I wole / of Theseus yow telle
(base) ¶ The destynee / Ministre general
(base) That executeth / in the world oueral
(base) The purueiance / that god hath seyn biforn
(base) So stroong it is / that thogh the world hadde sworn
(base) The contrarie of a thyng by ye / or nay
(base) Yet som tyme / it shal fallen on a day
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer
(base) For certeinly / oure appetites heer
(base) Be it of werre / or pees / or hate / or loue
(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May
(base) That in his bed / ther daweth hym no day
(base) That he nys clad / and redy for to ryde
(base) With hunte and horn / and houndes hym bisyde
(base) For in his huntyng hath he swich delit
(base) That it is / al his ioye and appetit
(base) To been hymself the grete hertes bane
(base) For after Mars / he serueth now Diane
(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this
(base) And Theseus / with alle ioye and blys
(base) With his ypolita / the faire queene
(base) And Emelie / clothed al in greene
(base) On huntyng be they riden roially
(base) And to the groue / that stood ful faste by
(base) In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
(base) Duc Theseus / the streighte wey hath holde
(base) And to the launde / he rideth hym ful right
(base) For thider was the hert wont haue his flight
(base) And ouer a brook / and so forth on his weye
(base) This duc / wol han a cours at hym / or tweye
(base) With houndes swiche / as that hym list comaunde
(base) And whan this Duc. was come vnto the launde
(base) Vnder the sonne he looketh / and anon
(base) He was war / of Arcite and Palamoun
(base) That foghten breme / as it were boles two
(base) The brighte swerdes / wenten to and fro
(base) So hidously / that with the leeste strook
(base) It semed / as it wolde felle an ook
(base) But what they weere / no thyng he ne woot
(base) This Duc his courser / with the spores smoot
(base) And at a stert he was bitwix hem two
(base) And pulled out a swerd / and cryed hoo
(base) Namoore / vpon peyne / of lesyng of youre heed
(base) By myghty Mars / he shal anon be deed
(base) That smyteth any strook / that I may seen
(base) But telleth me / what myster men ye been
(base) That been so hardy / for to fighten heer
(base) Withouten Iuge / or oother officer
(base) As it weere in a lystes roially
(base) ¶ This Palamon / answerde hastily
(base) And seyde / sire / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And seide sire what nedith wordes moo
(base) We haue the deeth disserued / bothe two
(base) Two woful wrecches been we / two caytyues
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That been encombred / of oure owene lyues
(base) And as thow art a rightful lord and Iuge
(base) Ne yif vs / neither mercy ne refuge
(base) But slee me first. for seinte charitee
(base) But slee my felawe eek as wel as me
(base) Or slee hym first. for thogh thow knowe it lite
(base) This is thy mortal foo / this is Arcite
(base) That fro thy lond / is banysshed on his heed
(base) For which / he hath deserued to be deed
(base) For this is he / that cam vnto thy yate
(base) And seyde / that he highte Philostrate
(base) Thus hath he iaped thee / ful many a yeer
(base) And thow hast maked hym / thy chief Squyer
(base) And this is he / that loueth Emelye
(base) For sith the day is come / that I shal dye
(base) I make pleynly / my confessioun
(base) That I am / thilke woful Palamoun
(base) That hath thy prisoun / broken wikkedly
(base) I am thy mortal foo / and it am I
(base) That loueth so hoote / Emelye the brighte
(base) That I wol dyen / present in hir sighte
(base) Wherfore I axe deeth / and my Iuwise
(base) But slee my felawe / in the same wise
(base) For bothe haue we / deserued to be slayn
(base) ¶ This worthy Duc answerde anoon agayn
(base) And seyde / this is a short conclusioun
(base) Youre owene mouth / by youre confessioun
(base) Hath dampned yow / and I wol it recorde
(base) It nedeth noght to pyne yow with the corde
(base) Ye shul be deed / by myghty Mars the rede
(base) ¶ The queene anoon / for verray wommanhede
(base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye
(base) And alle the ladies / in the compaignye
(base) Greet pitee was it / as it thoughte hem alle
(base) That euere swich a chaunce / sholde falle
(base) For gentil men they weere / of greet estaat
(base) And no thyng but for loue / was this debaat
(base) And sawe / hir blody wowndes / wide and soore
(base) And alle cryden / bothe lasse and moore
(base) Haue mercy lord / vpon vs wommen alle
(base) And on hir bare knees / adown they falle
(base) And wolde haue kist his feet ther as he stood
(base) Til at the laste / aslaked was his mood
(base) For pitee / renneth soone in gentil herte
(base) And thogh he first. for Ire quook and sterte
(base) He hath considred / shorthly in a clause
The trespase of hem bothe and þe cause
And alle þough his Ire her gilte accusede
Ȝet in his reson̄ he helde hem bothe excusede
And þus he thought wele þat euery man̄
Wolde helpe hym selfe in loue if þat he can̄
And eke delyuer hym selfe oute of prison̄
And eke hym selfe hadde compassioıı̄un
Off wymmen for þei wepten̄ euer in oone
And in his gentiƚƚ herte he thouȝhte onon̄
And softe vn to hym selfe he saide fye
Vp on a lorde þat woll haue no mercy
But be a lyon̄ bothe in worde and dede
To hem þat bene in repentance and drede
Als wele as to a proude despitous man̄
That wiƚƚ mayntene þat he firste bigan̄
That lorde hath litiƚƚ of discrecioıı̄un
That in suche caase can no diuisioıı̄un
But weieth pride and humblesse aft̉er oone
And schortly when̄ his ir͗e was þus þ̉er gone
He gan̄ to loken̄ up with eyen̄ liȝhte
Ande spake þise same wordes aƚƚ on hiȝhte
The godde of luff o benedicite
Howe myȝhty and howe grete a lorde is he
A gayn̄ his miȝht þer͗e agayneth non obstacles
He may be cleped a godde for his miracles
For he can̄ maken̄ at his own̄ gyse
Of eủeriche herte as þat hym liste devise
Loo her͗e þis arcite and þis palemon̄
That quytely wer͗e oute of my prison̄ goone
And miȝht haue liffed in Thebes ryally
And wyten þat I am her͗e morteƚƚ enmye
(base) And that hir deeth / lyth in my myght also
(base) And yet hath loue / maugree hir eyen two
(base) Broght hem hyder / bothe for to dye
(base) Now looketh / is nat that an heigh folye
(base) ¶ Who may been a fool / but if he loue
(base) Bihoold for goddes sake / that sit aboue
(base) Se how they blede / be they noght wel arrayed
(base) Thus hath hir lord / the god of loue ypayed
(base) Hir wages / and hir fees / for hir seruyse
(base) And yet they wenen / for to be ful wyse
(base) That seruen loue / for aught that may bifalle
(base) But this is yet the beste game of alle
(base) That she / for whom / they haue this Iolitee
(base) Kan hem therfore / as muche thank as me
(base) She woot namoore / of al this hoote fare
Bi godde þan wote a Cukkoo or an haar͗e
But aƚƚ mote bene assaied bothe hote ande colde
A man̄ mote bene a foole outher ȝouge or olde
I wote it be my selfe iiij ȝer͗e agone
For in my tyme a seruᵃaunt was I oone
And þer for seth I knowe of loffes peyne
And wote howe soor͗e it can̄ a man̄ distreyne
As he þat hath ofte ben kauȝhte in his laase
I ȝowe forȝiffe alle holy þis trespasse
At requeste of þe quene þat knelith here
And eke of Emely mȳn suster͗e der͗e
And ȝe schaƚƚ bothe onon vn to me sweer͗e
That neủer mer͗e ȝe schaƚƚ my contr͗e deer͗e
Ne make werr͗e opon̄ me nyȝht ne daye
But bene my frendes in alle þat ȝe may
I nowe forȝiffe ȝowe þis trespas eủery dele
And þei hym sworen̄ his axynge fair͗e and wele
And hym of lordschipe and of mercy preiede
And he hem graunted grace and þis he seide
To speke of riaƚƚ lynage and richesse
Thof þat sche wer͗e a quene or a princesse
Ehe of ȝowe bothe is worthy doutelesse
To wedden̄ whan tyme is but nathelesse
I speke as for my suster Emelye
For whome ȝe haff þis striffe ande Ielousie
Ȝe wote ȝour͗e selfe sche may not wedden̄ twoo
Atones þof ȝe fiȝhten̄ eủermoo
The cone of ȝowe be he lothe or leefe
He mote go pipen̄ in an Iue leefe
This is to seye sche may not nowe haf bothe
Ne be ȝe neuer so Ielouse ne so wroothe
And for þi I þer nowe put in þis degree
That eche of ȝowe schaƚƚ haf his destyne
As hym is schape and herkneth in what wyse
Lo her͗e ȝour͗e ende of þat I schaƚƚ deuyse
My wiƚƚ is þis for platte ꝯconclusioıı̄un
With oute eny replicacioıı̄un
Ȝiff þat ȝowe liketh it taketh for þe beste
That eủery of ȝowe schaƚƚ go wher͗e hym leste
Frely with outen raunson̄ or daunger͗e
And þis day fifty wekes ferr͗e ne neer͗e
Eủeryche of ȝowe schaƚƚ brynge an hundreth knyghtes
Armed for lystes vp at all ryȝhtes
Al redy to darreyne hir͗e by bataille
And þis behote I ȝowe with oute faille
Vp on my trouthe ande as I am a knyȝht
That whedir of ȝowe bothe þat hath myȝhte
This is to seyne þat whedir he or þᵘ
May with his hundreth as I haf speke of nowe
Slee his ꝯcontrarie or oute of listes dryue
Than schaƚƚ I ȝiff hym emely to wyffe
To whome þat fortune hath ȝiff so fair͗e a grace
The lystes schaƚƚ I doo maken in þis place
Ande god so wysly on my soule rewe
As I schaƚƚ euen̄ Iugge be and trewe
Ȝe schaƚƚ non other ende with me make
Þat one of ȝowe schaƚƚ be dede or take
And if ȝowe thynke þis is wele y seide
Seye ȝour͗e avys ande holde ȝow a paiede
This is ȝour͗e ende and ȝour͗e conclusioıı̄un
Who lokith lightly now but palamon̄
Who spryngeth up for ioye but arcite
Who cowthe telle or who couthe it endite
The ioye þat is made in þat plase
