And hym araieth gaye ande poynt deuyse
But ferste he cheweth grayne and likorise
To smellen swote or he hadde kempte his her
Vndir his tonge a trewe loue he ber
For þer by wende he to be gracious
He rowmeth to þe Carpenters house
And still he stante vndir þe schotwyndowe
Vn to his breste it rauȝht it was so lowe
And softe he coughed with a semy sown
What doith ye honycombe swete Alisoun
My fair bridde my swete synamōme
A waketh lēmman myn and spekith to me
Wel litell thenken ye vp on my woo /
That for your loue I swete as / I goo
No wonder is þough þat I swelte and swete
I morne as dothe þe lambe aft̉er þe tete
I wys lēmman I haue swiche loue longynge
That elke a turtell trewe is mornyng
I may not eten namor þan a mayde
Go fro þe wyndowe Iakke foole sche seide
As helpe me god it will not be compame
I loue another and ells I wer to blame
Wel bette þan þe by Ihıı̄un Absoloıı̄un
Go forth þi weye or I will or I will caste a stoon
Ande lete me slepe a xx . deuell weiye
Allas qd Absoloıı̄un and walow way
That trewe loue was eủer so yuell by sette
Than kisse me sen itmay be no bette
For Ihıı̄un loue and for þe loue of me
Woltest þou þan go þi wey þ̉er with qd sche
Ȝa c̉ertis lēmman qd þis Absoloıı̄un
Than make þe redy qd sche I come onoıı̄un
This absolon sette hym downe on his knees
And saide I am a lorde atte alle degrees
For aft̉er þis I hope þer comyth moore
Lēmman þi grace and swete bridde þin ore
The wyndowe sche vndoth and þat in haste
Haf do qd sche come of and spede þe faste
Lest þat our neiȝhbores þe aspie
This Absoloıı̄un gan wipe his mouthe full drye
Derke was þe nyȝht as pycche or as þe coole
And at þe wyndowe oute sche putte hir hole
And Absolon hym fell no better weres
But with his mouthe he kissed hir naked ers
Full sauourly or he was war of þis
A bak he stirte and thoȝht it was a mys
For wele he wiste a woman had no berde
He felte a thynge al rough and longe y hered
And seide fye . Allas what haue I doo .
Tehe qd sche and clapped þe wyndowe too
And absoloıı̄un goith forth a sory pase
A berde a berde seyde hende Nicolas
By goddꝭes corpus þis goith fair and wele
This sely Absoloıı̄un herde it euy dele
And on his lippe he gan for angir bite
And to hym selfe he seide I schall þe quyte
Who rubbeth nowe who froteth nowe his lippes
With duste with sonde with strawe with cloth with chippes
But Absolon þat seith full ofte allas
My soule betake I to sathanas
But me wer leủer þan al þis towne qd he
Of þis despite a wroken for to be
Allas qd he allas þat I ne had y blente
His hote loue is colde and al y queynte
For fro þat tyme þat he had kyssed her erse
Of ꝑparamours he sette not a kers
For he was heled of his maladye
Full ofte ꝑparamours he gan defye
And weped as doith a childe þat is y bete
A softe paas he wente ouer þe strete
Vn till a smyth men clepen dawn garueys
That in his forge smythieth plugh harneys
He scharpeth schare and cultur besily
This absoloıı̄un knokketh all esely
And seyde vn to garueys and þat a noon
What who arte þou it am I Absoloıı̄un
What Absolon what Cristis swete tree
Why rise ȝe so rathe benedicite
What erly ȝowe som gay gerle god it wote
Hath brouȝt ȝowe þus on þe virtotte
Be seynte note ȝe wote wele what I mene
This absolon ne rought not a bene
Off all his pleye no worde a ȝeyn he ȝaff
He hadde mor towe on his distaffe
Than garueys knewe ande seide frende so dere
The hote culter in þe chymyney her
As lene it me I haf þer with to done
I woll brynge it a gayn full sone
Garueys answerde certis wer it golde
Or in a pole nobles al vntolde
Thowe schuldest haf as I am trewe smyth
Ey Cristes foo what will ȝe do þ̉er with
Therof qd Absolon be as be may
I schall wele tell it þe to morwe daye
And cauȝht þe cultr be þe colde stele
Ful softe oute at þe dor he gan stele
And wente vn to þe Carpent̉er walle
He koghed firste and knokked þ̉erwith all
Vpon þe wyndowe riȝht as he did er
This Alison answered who is þer
That knokketh so I warant it a thefe
Wy nay qd he god wite my swete lefe
I am þin Absoloıı̄un þi der derlynge
Of gold qd he I haf þe broȝht a rynge
My moder ȝaff it me so god me saue
Full fyne it is and þer to wele y graue
This will I ȝiffen þe if þou me kysse
This Nicolas was risen for to pisse
And thouȝht he wolde amenden al þe iape
He schuld kisse his ers er he did skape
And up þe wyndowe did he hastily
And oute his ers he putte priuely
Ouer þe bottoke to þe haunche bone
And þerwith spake þis clerke þis Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete bridde I note wher þou arte
This nycholas onoıı̄un let flye a farte
Als grete as it had bene a thunder dent
That with þe stroke he was almoste y blente
And he was redy with his iren hote
And nicholas in þe ers he smote
Off goth þe skynne an handbrede a boute
The hote cultr brenned so his toute
And for þe smerte he wenyd for to dye
As he wer wode for woo he gan to crye
Help water water helpe for goddis herte
This Carpent̉er oute of his slomber sterte
And harde one crien water as he wer wode
And thouȝht allas Noyes flode
And sette hym with wordes moo
And with an ax he smote þe corde a twoo
And down goith all he fonde neither to selle
Brede nether ale till he come to þe sell
Opon þe floor ande þer in swown he laye
Vp stirte hir Alison and Nicolay
And criede oute and and harrowe in þe strete
The neȝhbores both smale and grete
In runnen for to gawren on þis man
That a swowen lay both pale and wanne
For with þat fall he hath y brusten his arme
But stonden he moste vn to his own harme
For whan he spake he was onon borne down
With hende Nicolas and Alisoun
Thei tolde eủery man þat he was wode
He was so a gaste of þe Noyes flode
Thurgh fantasie þat of his vanite
He hadde y bouȝht hym knedynge tubbes thr
And had hem hanged in þe roofe a bouen
And þat he praied hym for goddis louen
To sitten in þe roofe pur companye
The folk gan laghen at his fantasye
And to þe roofe þei kokyn and þei gape
And turned all his harme vn to a Iape
For what so þis Carpenter answerde
It was for noȝht no man his resoıı̄un herde
With othes grete he was so sworne a down
That he was holden wode in al þat town
For eủery clerk onon riȝht helde with other
Thei seide þe man is wode my lefe brother
And eủery wiȝht gan laghen at his stryfe
Thus swyved was þe Carpenters wyffe
For all his kepyng and his Ialowsie
And Absolon hath kyssed her nethereye
And Nicolas is skalded in his toute
Þis tale is done and god saue all þe route

l.hi: ¶Explicit fabula molendinari

div.l: ¶ Here begynneth þe ꝓprologe of þe Reves tale
Whan folke hauen laghen at þis nyce case
Off Absolon̄ and hende Nicolas
Diuerse folke diuersly þei seide
But for þe mor͗e parte þei logh and pleide
Ne at þis tale I saugh no man hym greue
But if it wer͗e only Oswalde þe Reue
By cause he was of Carpenters crafte
A litell ire is in his herte lafte
He gan to grucche and blamed it a lite
So the yk qduod he full wele kouothe I ȝowe quyte
With bleryng of a proude myllers eye
Yf þat me liste to speke of Ribaldrye
But I am olde me liste not pleye for age
Grasse tyme is done my foder is forrage
This white top writeth myn olde ȝeres
Myn herte is also mowled as myn heres
But if I far͗e as doith an open̄ ers
That ilke fruyte is eủer lenger þe wers
Till it be roten̄ in Mulloke or in stree
We olde men I drede so fare we
Till we be roten̄ kan̄ we not be ripe
We hoppen̄ all weye whil þe world will pipe
For in our͗e will þer stiketh eủer a nayll
To haue an hoor͗e her͗e and a grene tayll
As hath a leke for þogh our͗e myȝht be gone
Our͗e wille desireth folye eủer in one
For whan̄ we may not done þan woll we speke
Ȝit in our͗e Asshyn olde is fir͗e y reke
Four͗e gledes hauen̄ we which I schall devise
Auᵃauntyng lying Anger couetise
This iiij sparkles longeth vn to elde
Our͗e olde lymes mowe wel bene vnwelde
But will ne schall not faillen þat is sothe
And ȝet haf I al weye a coltes tothe
Als mony a ȝer͗e as it is passed henne
Sen þat my tap of lyffe began to renne
For sikerly whan I was borne anone
Deth drough þe tappe of lyffe and lete it gone
And eủer sithen hath so þe tappe y ronne
Till þat almoste all empty is þe tonne
The streme of liffe nowe droppeth on þe chymbe
The sely tonge may wele rynge and clymbe
Of wrecchednes þat passed is full yor͗e
With olde folke saue dotage is no more
When þat our͗e oste had hard þis sermonynge
He gan̄ to speken̄ als lordly as a kyng
He saide what amounteth alle þis wytte
What schall we speke al daye of holy wrytte
The deuell made a Reve for to precche
Or of a sowter schipman or a leche
Seye forth þi tale and tarye not þe tyme
Loo depforth and it is halfe weye pryme
Loo grenwyche þat mony a schrewe is Inne
It wer͗e al tyme þi tale for to gynne
Nowe sirres qduod þis Ossewald þe Reue
I pray ȝowe alle þat ȝe take it not to greue
Þogh I answer͗e ande somdel sette his houwe
For leuefull is with force force to shouwe
This dronken̄ Meller͗e hath y told us here
Howe þat begiled was a carpenter͗e
ꝐPar auentur͗e in skorne for I am oone
And by ȝour͗e leue I schall hym quyte a noon̄
Riȝt in his cherlis termes will I speke
I pray to god his nekke mot to breke
He can well in myn̄ eye seen̄ a stalke
But in his owene he can̄ not sene a balke
¶ Hic incipit fabula
Atte Trumpyngton̄ noȝht ferr͗e from Cantirbrigge
Ther goth a broke and ouer þat a brygge
Opon þe whiche brooke þer stant a melle
And þis a verrey sothe þat I ȝowe telle
A Meller͗e was þer dwellynge many a daye
As eny pecoke he was proude and gaye
Pypen̄ he couthe and fysshen̄ and nettes bete
And turne coppes ande wele wrastell ande schete
Ay by his belte he bar͗e a longe panade
And of a swerde full trenchant was þe blade
A Ioly popper bar͗e he in his pouche
Ther was no man̄ for p̉erill durste hym touche
A Sheffeld twhytell bar͗e he in his hose
Rounde was his face and camuse was his noose
As pilled as an ape was his sculle
He was a market beter at þe full
Ther was no wyȝht þat dorste hande on hym legge
But if he swor͗e he schuld onon̄ a begge
A thefe he was forsothe of corne and meele
And þat a sleygh and vsaunte for to steele
His name was hoten̄ deynous symkyn̄
A wyffe he hadde comen̄ of noble kynne
The ꝑperson of þe town̄ hir͗e fader was
With hir͗e he ȝaff full mony a pan̄ of brasse
For þat symkyn̄ schuld in his blode aly
She was y fostred in a Nonnerye
For symkyn wolde no wiffe as he seide
But if sche wer͗e wele y nurrysshed and a maide
To sauen his astate of yomanrye
And sche was proude and perte as a pye
A full fair͗e siȝht was it opon̄ hem twoo
On halidayes beforne hir͗e wolde he goo
With his typet wounden̄ a boute his heuede
And sche cam aft̉er in a gyte of rede
And symkyn̄ hadde hosen̄ of þe same
Ther͗e dorste no wyȝht clepen̄ hir͗e but dame
Was none so hardy þat wente by þe waye
That with hir͗e dorste onys rage or playe
But if he wolde be slayn of symkyn̄
With panade or with knyff or bodekyn̄
For Ielous folke bene p̉erlyous eủer moo
Algate þei wolde her͗e wyues wenden̄ so
And eke for scho was som dele smoterliche
She was as digne as wat̉er in a dyssh
As full of ocur and of bismare
Hir͗e thought þat a lady schuld hir͗e spar͗e
What for hir͗e kynrede ande hir͗e notelrye

rdg.seg:
That sche had lernede
in þe Nonnerye

app.rdg: That sche had lernede in þe Nonnerye

div.l: A dought̉er hadde þei betwix hem twoo
Of xx ȝer͗e with outen eny moo
Semyng a childe þat was of half ȝer͗e age
In cradell it lay and was a ꝓproper page
This wenche þikke and wel y growen̄ was
With Camoys noyse and eyen̄ gray as glas
With buttokkꝭes brode and brestis rounde and hye
But riȝht fair͗e was hir͗e her͗e I will not lye
¶ The ꝑperson of þe town̄ for sche was so fair͗e
In purpose was to make hir͗e his eyr͗e
Both of his catell and his me ssuagem ssuagemessuage
And straunge he made it of hir͗e mariage
His pᵘurpose was to be stowe her͗e hye
In to some worthy blode of auncetrye
For holy chirches good mot bene dispended
On holy chirche blode þat is descendede
Ther for he wold his hole blode honour
Thow þat þe holy cherche scholde deuour͗e
Grete soken̄ hath þis myller oute of doute
With whete and malte of þe lande a bowte
And nameliche þer was a grete college
Men clepeth it þe soler hall at Cauntabregge
Ther was hir͗e whete and eke hir͗e malte y ground
And on a daye it happed in a stounde
Syke lay þe maunciple on a maladye
Men̄ wenden̄ wysly þat he schuld dye
For whiche þis myller͗e stale both mele and corne
An hundreth tyme mor͗e þan beforne
For þ̉er be forne he stale but curtaslye
But nowe he was a thefe outreachously
For whiche þe wardeyn̄ chydde and made far͗e
But þ̉er of sette þe myller͗e noȝt a tar͗e
He crakked boste and swor͗e it was not so
Than wer þer ȝonge scolers twoo
That dwelten̄ in þe halle of þe whiche I seye
Testyff þei wer͗e and lustaff for to pleye
And only for hir͗e myrthe and reuerye
Vp on þe wardeyn̄ besily þei crye
To ȝif hem leve but a litill stounde
To go to þe mylle and sene her͗e corne y grounde
And hardily þei dorste leye her͗e nekke
The myller͗e schuld not stele hem half a pekke
Of corne ne by force ne by sleyȝht hem reve
And at þe laste þe wardeyn̄ ȝaff hem leve
Iohn hyȝht þe tone and aleyn̄ hiȝht þe toþer
Of one towne wer þei borne þat hiȝht Stroþer
Fer͗e in þe north I can not tell wher͗e
This aleyn̄ maketh redy all his geere
And on an horse þe sakke he caste onon̄
Forth goth aleyn̄ þe clerk and also Iohn
With goode swerde and with bokeler͗e be his side
Iohn knewe þe weye hym neded no gyde
And at þe Milne þe sakke a down̄ he leyth
Aleyn̄ spake firste al heyll Symon̄ in feyth
Howe fares þi fair͗e doghter and þi wyffe
Aleyn̄ welcome qduod symkyn̄ be my lyffe
And Iohn also · howe nowe what do ȝe her͗e
By god symond qduod Iohn nede hath no peer͗e
Hym behoues serue hym selfe þat has no swayn̄
Or ells he is a foole as clerkes seyne
Our͗e maunciple I hope he will be dede
So werkes hym ay þe wanges in his hede
And þer for am I comen̄ and eke Aleyn̄
To grynde our͗e corne ande karie it home a gayn̄
I pray ȝow spede us hennes all þat ȝe may
¶ It schall be done qduod symkyn̄ be my fay
What will ȝe done whil þat it is in hande
By god riȝht by þe hoper will I stande
Qduod Iohn and see how gates þe corne gase in
Þat sawe I neủer be my fader kynne
Howe þat þe hoper wagges till and fro
Aleyn answerde Iohn wilt þou soo
Than will I be beneth be my crowne
And se howe gates þe mylle falles a down̄
In til þe troȝh þat schall be my desporte
Qduod Iohn in faith I may bene of ȝour͗e sorte
I am als euell a myller as arne ȝee
This myller͗e smyled of her͗e nycite
And thought alle þis nys done but for a wyle
Thei wene þat no man̄ may þam begile
But be my thryfte ȝit schall I bler͗e her͗e eye
For all þe sleight in her͗e philosophie
The mor͗e wil I stele crekes þat þei make
The mor͗e will I stele whan̄ I take
In stede of flour͗e þan will I ȝif hem branne
The grettest clerkes bene noȝht þe wisest men
As whilom to þe wolfe þus spake þe mar͗e
Of all her͗e arte counte I not a tar͗e
Oute of þe dor͗e he goith full priuely
Whan̄ þat he sawgh his tyme softely
He loketh up and down̄ til he hath founde
The clerkes horse þ̉er as he stode y bounde
Be hynde þe Mylle vndir a leuesell
And to þe hors he goith hym fair͗e and well
He strepeth of þe bridell riȝht onon̄
And whan̄ þe hors was louse he gynneth to gone
To warde þe fenne þer wild mares renne
And forth with wehe thurgh thykke and thynne
This Meller͗e goith a gayn̄ no worde he saide
But doith his note and with his clerkes pleyede
Till þat þer corne was fair͗e and wele y grounde
And when̄ þe mele was sakked and y bounde
This Iohn goith oute and fyndeth his hors a waye
And gan̄ to crie harrowe and wele awaye
Our͗e horse is loste Aleyn̄ be goddes bones
Step on þi fete come on man al at ones
Allas our͗e wardeyn hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn al forgate both mele and corne
All was oute of his mynde his husbondrye
What whilke weye is he gone he gan̄ to crie
The wyff come lepynge inwarde at a renne
She seith allas ȝour͗e horse goith to þe fenne
With wilde mares as faste as he may goo
Vnthank come on his honde þat bonde hym so
And he þat bett̉er schuld haf knytte þe reyne
Allas alleyn̄ qduod Iohn for cristes peyne
Leye doun̄ þi swerde and I will myn als
I am full swyfte god wote as is a Roo
By goddes herte he schall not skape us bathe
Why ne hadde þou putte þe capull in þe lathe
Ill haill by god aleyne þou arte a fonne
Thise sely clerkes han full faste y ronne
Towarde þe fenne bothen̄ aleyn and eke Iohn
And when̄ þe Meller͗e seygh þat þei wer͗e gone
He half a busshell of her͗e flour͗e hath take
And bad his wiff go knede it in a kake
And seid I trowe þe clerkes weren a ferde
Ȝet can̄ a Meller͗e make a clerkes berde
For all his arte ȝit lete hem gone her͗e weye
Lo wher͗e þei gone / ȝa lat þe children̄ pleye
Thei gete hym not so liȝhtly be my crowne
Thise sely clerkes rennen̄ up and downe
With kepe kepe / stand stande Ieste ⁊and warderer͗e
Go whistill ȝowe and I schall kepe hym her͗e
But schortly till it was verrey nyȝht
Thei couthe not þof þei did all her͗e myȝht
Hir͗e Caple cacche he ranne al wey so faste
Till in a dyche þei cauȝht hym at þe laste
Werey and wete as beste is in þe rayne
Comyth sely Iohn and with hym ꝯcommith Aleyn̄
¶ Allas qduod Iohn þe day þat I was borne
Nowe ar we dryven̄ til hethynge and to scorne
Our͗e corne is stolne men̄ woll us foles calle
But þe wardeyn̄ and his felowes alle
And namely þe myller͗e welaweye
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he goith by þe weye
Towarde þe Mille and bayȝarde in his honde
The Miller͗e sittynge be þe fir͗e he fonde
For it was nyȝht and ferþ̉er myȝht he noȝht
But for þe luff of god þei hym besouȝht
Of herberowe and of es as for hir͗e peny
The meller͗e seide a ȝein if þ̉er be eny
Swiche as it is ȝet schall ȝe haf ȝour͗e parte
My house is streite but ȝe han̄ lerned arte
Ȝe can̄ be argument make a place
A Mile brode of xx fote of space
Lat se nowe ȝif þis place mowe suffise
Or make it rowmer with speche as is ȝour͗e gyse
Nowe symonde seide þis Iohn be seynt cutberte
Ay arte þou mery and þat is fair͗e answerde
I haf hard seye men̄ schall taken of two thynge
Suche as he fynde or take suche as he brynges
But specially I preye þe oste der͗e
¶ Gete us som mete and drynke and make us cher͗e
And we woll paien̄ trewly at þe full
With empty handes men̄ may non̄ hawkes tull
Loo her͗e our͗e siluer redy for to spende
This myller to þe towne his doȝht̉er sende
For ale and brede and rosted hem a goose
And bonde hir͗e hors it schuld no mor͗e go loose
And in his own̄ chambre he made a bedde
With schetes and with chalons fair͗e y spredde
Noȝt from his owne bedde · x · fete of twelfe
His doȝht̉er had a bedde all be her͗e selue
Riȝht in þe same chambr͗e by and by
It myȝht be no better and cause why
Ther was no rowmer herber in þat place
Þei soupen̄ and speken̄ hem to solace
And drynken̄ euer stronge ale at þe beste
A boute mydde nyȝht wente þei to reste
Wele hath þis meller͗e vernysshed his hede
Fule pale he was for dronken and not rede
He ȝexith and he spekith thurgh þe noose
As he war͗e in þe quakke or in þe pose
To bedde he goith and with hym goith his wyffe
As any Iay he was liȝht and Iolyffe
So was hir͗e Ioly whistell wele y wette
The credell at hir͗e beddes fete is y sette
To rokken̄ and to ȝiff þe childe to souke
And whan̄ þat dronken̄ was al in þe crouke
To bedde wente þe doght̉er riȝht onoon̄
To bedde goith Aleyn̄ and also Iohn
Ther nas no mor͗e / þam neded no dwale
This myller͗e hath so wysly bibbed good ale
That as an hors he snorteth in his slepe
Ne of his taille be hynde he toke no kepe
His wiff bar͗e hym a burdon̄ a full stronge
Men̄ myȝhten̄ her͗e her routynge wel a furlonge
The wenche rowteth eke pur compaygnye
Aleyn̄ þe clerke þat harde þis melodye
He powked Iohn and seide slepist þowe
Herdest þou eủer slike a songe ar͗e or nowe
Loo swiche a cowplynge is betwene hem alle
A wilde fir͗e on þeir bodies fall
Who herkened euer suche a ferly thynge
Ȝa þei schall haue þe flour͗e of euyll endynge
¶ This longe nyȝht þer tides me no reste
But ȝit na force all schall be for þe best
For Iohn he seide as eủer mot I thryue
Yf þat I may þe wenche woll I swyffe
Som esement hath lawe schapen̄ us
For Iohn þer is a lawe þat seith þus
That if a man in oo poynte be agreuede
That in an other he schall be releuede
Our͗e corne is stolne sothely it is no nay
Ande we han̄ hadde an euyll fytte to daye
Ande sen̄ I schall haue non̄ amendement
A gayn̄ my losse I woll haue esemente
By goddes saule it schall non oþer be
This Iohn answered Aleyn avise þe
The Miller͗e is a ꝑperlious man̄ he saide
And if þat he oute of his slepe a braide
He myȝht done us both a vilanye
Aleyn̄ answerd I counte not be hym a flye
And up he riste and by þe wenche he crepid
This wenche lay up riȝht and feste slepede
Till he so nyȝh was or scho myȝht aspie
That it hadde bene to late for to crye
And schortly for to seyn̄ þei wer͗e at one
Now play Aleyn̄ for I will speke of Iohn
This Iohn lieth still a furlonge while or twoo
And to hym selfe he makith routhe and woo
Allas qduod he þis is a wykked iape
Now may I seyn þat I am but an ape
Ȝit hath my felowe somwhat for his harme
He hathe þe Millers doght̉er in his arme
He antreth hym and hath his nedes spedde
And I lye as a draffe segge in my bedde
And whan̄ þis iape is tolde a nother daye
I schall be holde a daff and a Cokeney
I wol arise and auentur͗e it be my feith
Vnhardy is vnsely þus men̄ seyth
And up he rose ande softly he wente
Vn to þe cradell and in his honde it hente
And bare it softe vn to his beddes fete
Sone aft̉er þe wyffe her routynge lete
And gan to wake and wente hir͗e oute to pisse
And come a gayn̄ and gan̄ hir͗e cradell mysse
And groped her͗e and þer but scho fonde none
Allas qduod sche I had al moste mysgone
I had almoste gone to þe clerkes bedde
Ey benedicite þan had I foule y spedde
And forth sche goith till sche þe cradell fonde
She gropith al weye ferþer with hir͗e hond
And fonde þe bedde and thoȝht noȝht but goode
By cause þat þe Cradell by it stode
And nyste wher͗e sche was for it was derke
But fair͗e and wele sche crepe in to þe clerke
And lieth full still ande wolde haf cauȝt a slepe
With in a while þis Iohn þe clerke up lepe
And on þis goode wiffe he leith on soore
So mery a fitte ne had sche not full ȝor͗e
He prikketh harde and depe as he wer͗e madde
This lyff iolily hauen þis two clerkes hadde
Til þat þe thridde cok began̄ to synge
¶ Aleyn wex wery in þe dawenynge
For he hadde swonken all þat longe nyȝht
And seide far͗e wele malyn̄ swete wyȝhte
The day is comen̄ I may no leng̉er bide
But euer mor͗e wher so I go or ride
I am þine own̄ clerke so haf I hele
Nowe der͗e leman qduod sche go far͗e wele
But or þou go / oo thyng I woll þe tell
Whan̄ þat þou wendest homward by þe mylle
Riȝht at þe entr͗e of þe dor͗e behynde
Thou schalt a kake of half a busshell fynde
That was y maked of þine owne mele
Whiche þat I helpe my sir͗e for to stele
And gode lēmman god þe saue and kepe
And with þat worde al moste he gan to wepe
Aleyn up a riste and thouȝht or þat it dawe
I woll go crepen̄ in be my felowe
And fonde þe credill with his honde onon̄
By god thought he al wronge I haf mysgoon̄
Myn hede is toty of my swynke to nyȝht
That makith me þat I go not a right
I wote wele by þe cradell I haf mysgoo
Her͗e lieth þe meller͗e and his wiff also
And forthe he goith on xx · deuell wey
Vn to þe bedde þer as þe myller leye
He wende haf cropen̄ be his felowe Iohn
And by þe miller in he crepe onoon̄
And kauȝhte hym by þe nekke and softe he spake
He seide þou Iohn þou swynes heued a wake
For cristes soule and her͗e a noble game
For by þat lorde þat called is seynt Iame
As I haf thries in þis schorte nyȝht
Swyved þe millers doght̉er bolte up riȝht
Whil þou haste as a coward bene a gaste
Ȝa fals harlot qduod þe myller hast
A fals traytour͗e fals clerk qduod he
Thou schalt be dede be goddis dignite
Who durste be so bolde to disꝑparage
My doȝht̉er þat is comen̄ of swiche lynage
And by þe throte boll he cauȝht Aleyne
And he hente hym despitouslydesitouslydespitously a gayne
And on þe nose he smote hym with his fiste
Down̄ ranne þe blody streme opon his breste
And in þe flore with nose and mouthe to broke
Þei walowed as doith þe pigges in a poke
And up þei gone and down̄ a gayn̄ onon̄
Till þat þe Miller spurned at a stone
And down̄ he fill bakwarde vp on his wyffe
That wiste no thynge of þis nyce stryfe
For sche was falle a slepe a litill wyȝht
With Iohn þe Clerke þat waked had al þe nyȝht
And with þe fall oute of hir͗e slepe sche braide
Help holy crosse of bromholme sche seide
In manus tuas lorde to þe I calle
A wake symonde þe fende is on me falle
Myne hert is broken̄ I ne am but dede
Ther͗e lieth one up my wombe and vp myn̄ hede
Helpe symkyn̄ for þe fals clerkes fiȝȝht
This Iohn sterte up as faste as euer he myȝhte
And grasped by þe walles both to and froo
To fynden̄ a staffe and sche stirte up also
And knewe þe Estr͗es bett̉er þan did þat Iohn
And by þe walle a staff sche fonde onon̄
And sawe a litill schimerynge of a liȝht
For at an hole in schone þe mone brygth
And by þat liȝht sche sawe hem both twoo
But sikerly scho nyst who was whoo
But as sche sawe a white thynge in hir͗e eye
And whan̄ sche gan̄ þis whyte thynge aspie
She wende þe Clerke had wered a voluper
And with þe staff sche drough ay ner͗e and ner͗e
And wente han hitte þis aleyn̄ at þe full
And smote þe miller͗e on þe pilled skull
That down̄ he goith and cried harrowe I dye
Thise clerkꝭes bet hym wele and lete hym lye
And graythen̄ hem and toke her͗e horse a non̄
And eke her͗e mele and on her͗e waye þei gone
And at þe Mille ȝit þai toke her cake
Of half a busshell of flour full wele y bake
Thus is þe proude Miller͗e wele y bet
And hath y loste þe gryndynge of þe whete
And paied for þe soper euery dele
Of aleyn̄ and of Iohn þat bette hym wele
His wyff is swyved and his doght̉er als
Loo suche it is a Miller͗e to be fals
And þerfor͗e þis ꝓprouerbe is saide full sothe
Hym thar not wene wele þat euyll doith
A gilour schall hym selfe be giled be
And god þat sitteth hye in maieste
Saue all þis company grete and smale
Thus haf I quytte þe Meller͗e in my tale
Here begynneth þe prologe of þe Cokes tale
The Cooke of Lond whil þe Reve spake
For ioye he thougȝht he clowed on þe bak
Ha ha qduod he for cristas passioun̄
This Meller hath a scharpe conclusion̄
Opon his argument of herbergage
Wele saide Salon in his langage
Ne bryng not eủery man in to þin house
For herberynge be nyȝht is p̉erlyous
Wele ought a man̄ a vised for to be
Whome þat he broȝht in to his priuete
I pray to god so ȝiff me sorowen̄ and kar͗e
Yf eủer sithen̄ I hiȝht hogge of war͗e
Harde I eny myller bett̉er y sette on werke
He had a Iape of malise in þe derke
And þerfor if ȝe vouchesaue to her͗e
But god forbede þat we stynte her͗e
A tale of me þat am a por͗e man
I wol ȝowe tell als wele as eủer I kan
A litell iape þat fill in our͗e Cite
¶ Our͗e oste answerde and seide I gᵃraunte it þe
Nowe tell on roger loke þat it be goode
For mony a paste hast þou leten blode
And mony a Iakk hast þou solde
That hath bene twyes hote and twyes colde
Of mony a pilgryme hast þou cristis curse
For of þi p̉ersely ȝet far͗e þei þe worse
That þei haf eten with þi stobbedstobedstobbed goose
For in þi schoppe is mony a fle loose
Nowe tell on gentill roger be þi name
But ȝit I pray þe be not wroth for game
A man̄ may saye full sothe in game and pleye
Thou seiste ful trewe qduod roger be my fay
But soth playe quade pleye as þe flemyng saithe
And þer for͗e henry bailliff be þi faithe
Be þou not wrooth er we deꝑparten her͗e
Thogh þat my tale be of an Osteler͗e
But natheles I will not tellen̄ it ȝit
But or we parte I wys þou schalte be quytte
And þer with all logh and made goode cher͗e
And saide his tale as ȝe schall after her͗e
¶ Here endith þe ꝓprologe
and her begynneth þe tale
A prentys whilom dwelled in our͗e Citee
And of a Crafte of viteyllers was he
Gaillard he was as goldfynche in þe schawe
Broune as bery a ꝓpropre schorte felowe
With lokkes y kembed full fetisly
Daunce he couthe so wele and Iolily
That he was cleped parkyn reuellour͗e
He was all full of loue and ꝑparamour͗e
As is þe hyve full of hony swete
Wele was þe wenche wyth hym miȝht mete
At eủery bride ale wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bett̉er þe taủerne þan þe schoppe
For when̄ þer eny rydynge was in chepe
Oute of þe schoppe þider wolde he lepe
Till þat he had all þe siȝht y seyne
And daunced wele wold he not com̄ a gayn̄
And gadred hym a menȝee of his sorte
To hoppe and synge and make suche desporte
And þer þei setten̄ steuen̄ for to mete
To pleyen at þe dyse in suche a strete
For in þe toune nas þ̉er no p̉rentys
That fairer couthe caste a pair͗e of dyse
Than p̉erkyn couthe and þ̉er to he was free
Of his dispense in place of priuete
That fonde his maist̉er wele in his chaffar͗e
For ofte tyme he fonde his box full bar͗e
For sikerly a prentys reuelour
That hauntith dise ryoth or ꝑparamoᵘur
His maist̉er schuld it in his schop a bye
Al haf he not parte of his mimstralsie
For thefte and ryote þei bene ꝯconuertible
Al con̄ he pleye on gyterne or on ribible
Reuell and trowth as in lowe degree
Thei bene full wrothe al day as men̄ may see
This Ioly prentis with his maist̉er boode
Till he wer͗e neiȝh oute of his prentyshod
Al wer͗e he snybbed erly and late
And somtyme y ladde with reuell to Newgate
But at þe laste his maist̉er hym bethoȝht
Vp on a day when he his papir͗e soȝht
Of a ꝓprouerbe þat seith þis same worde
Wel bet is roten̄ appull oute of hoorde
Than þan it roteth alle þe remenᵃaunte
So farith it by a ryotous seruᵃaunte
It is full lasse harme to lat hym passe
Than he schende all þe seruᵃauntes in þe place
Ther for͗e his maist̉er ȝaff hym a quitaunce
And bad hym go with sorowe and myschaunce
And þus þis Ioly prentys had his leve
Nowe lete hym ryot all þe nyȝht or leue
And for þ̉er is no theef with oute a look
That helpeth hym to wasten̄ and to souke
Of þat he bribe can̄ or borowe may
Onon̄ he sente his bedde and his araye
Vn to a comper͗e of his own̄ sorte
That loued dise reuell and disporte
And had a wyffe þat held for ꝯcontinance
A schoppe and swived for hir͗e sustenᵃaunce
But her of I will passe as nowe
And of ȝonge gamelyne I will tell ȝowe
¶ The tale of ȝonge gamelyn:
Lithen and listenyth and herkenyth a riȝht
And ȝe schull her of a doghty knyȝht
Sir Iohn of boundes was his name
He couthe of nurtur and of mychel game
Thre sones þe knyght had and with his bodye
The eldest was a myche schrewe and sone be gan
His brethern loued wele hir fader and of hym wer a gaste
The eldest disserued his faders curs and had it at þe laste
The goode knyght his fader lyffed so ȝoor
That deth was cōmyn hym to and handeled hym ful soor
The goode knyȝht cared sor syke þ̉er he laye
Howe his childern schuld liffen aft̉er his daye
He had bene wyde wher but non husbonde he was
All þe londe þat he hadde it was of purchase
Fayn he wold it wer dressed a monge hem alle
That iche of hem had his parte as it myȝht falle
Thoo sente he in to cuntr after wise knyghtes
To helpen to delen his londes and dressen hem to riȝhtes
He sente hem worde by lettres þei schuld hyen blyve
Iff þei wolde speke with hym whils he was on lyffe
div.fw: Tho þe knyghtes herden̄ seke þᵗat he la
div.l: Thoo þe knyȝhtes herden syke þat he lay
Had þei no reste nouther nyȝht ner daye
Til þei come to hym þer he leye still
On his deth bedde to abiden goddis will
Than seide þe goode knyȝht sike þer he lay
Lordes I ȝowe warne for soth with outen nay
I may no lenger lyffen her in þis stounde
For thurgh goddes will deth drawes me to gᵒunde
Thar nas none of hem all þat hard hym a riȝht
But þei hadden rewthe of þat ilke knyȝhte
And seiden sir for goddes loue ne dismay ȝowe noȝht
God may done bote of bale þat is nowe y wroȝht
Than spake þe good knyȝht seke þ̉er he lay
Bote of bale god may sende I wote it is no nay
But I beseke ȝowe knyghtes for þe loue of me
Goth and dresseth my londes amongꝭes my sones thr
And for þe luff of god delith not hem a mys
And forȝetith not gamelyn my ȝonge þat is
Taketh hede to þe tone als wele as to þe toþ̉er
Selde ȝe seen eny heyr helpen his brother
Tho leten þei þe knyȝht lyen þat was not in hele
And wenten in to ꝙquodsell his londes for to dele
Forto delen hem all to one þat was hir thoȝhte
And for gamelyn was þe ȝongest he schuld haf noȝte
Alle þe londe þat þer was þei delten it in two
And leten gamelyn þe ȝonge with outen londe goo
And eche of hem seide to oþ̉er full lowde
His brethern myȝht ȝiff hym londe whe he goode couthe
When þei hadden deled þe londe at her will
Thei comen to þe knyȝht þ̉er he lay still
And told hym onon howe þei had wroght
And þe knyȝht þ̉er he lay liked it riȝht noȝht
Than seide þe knyȝht be seynt martyne
For all þat ȝe haue done ȝit is þe lond myn
For goddꝭes loue neiȝhbores stondeth al styll
And I will delen my londe at myn own will
Iohn myn eldest son shal haf ploghes fyfe
That was my faders eritage while he was on lyffe
And my mydleste sone fyve plowghes of londe
That I halpe for to gete with my riȝht honde
And all myn other purchase of londes and ledes
That I be queeth gamelyn and al my goode stedes
And I beseke ȝowe good men þat lawe con of londe
For gamelynes loue þat my queste stonde
Thus dalte þe knyȝht his londe be his daye
Riȝht on his dethe bedde syke þer he lay
And sone afterwarde he leye stone styll
And died when tyme come as it was cristꝭes will
Onone as he was dede and vnder grasse y graue
Sone þe elder brother giled þe ȝonge knawe
He toke in to his honde his londe and his lede
And gamlyn hym selfe to clothen and to feede
He clothed hym and fedde hym yuell and eke wroothe
And lete his londes forfar and his howse bothe
His parkes and his wodes and did no thyng welle
And seithen he it aboȝht on his own fell
So longe was gamelyn in his broþ̉eres halle
For þe strengeste of good will þei doutened hym alle
Ther was none þ̉er in neþ̉er ȝonge ner olde
That wold wrath gamelyn wer he neủer so bolde
Gamelyn stode on a daye in his brothers ȝerde
And began with his honde to handell his berde
He thouȝht on his londes þat lay vnsawe
And his fair okes þat down wer y drawe
His parkes wer broken and his der rewde
Of all his goode stedis none was hym bylevede
And howse wer vnhilde and ful euyll y diȝht
Tho thouȝht gamelyn it went not ariȝht
Aftirwarde cam his brother walkyng þer
And seide to gamelyn is our mete ȝar
Tho wrathed hym gamelyn and swor be goddꝭes boke
Thowe schalt go bake þⁱ selfe I will not be þi cooke
Howe brother gamelyn howe answerest þou nowe
Þou spakkest new̉er suche a worde as þou dost nowe
Be my feith seide gamelyn nowe methynketh nede
Of alle þe harme þat I haf I toke new̉er ȝit hede
My parkes bene broken and my der ben revede
Of myn armes and my stedes noȝht is me beleuede
Al þat my fader me bequaath al goth to schame
And þ̉er for haue þou goddis curse brother be þyne name
Than spake his brother þat rape was of rees
Stande still gadlynd and holde þi pese
Thou schalt be fayn to haue þi mete and þi wede
What spekes þou gadlynge of londe or of lede
Than seide gamelyn þe childe was ȝinge
Cristes curse mote he haf þat clepith me gadlynge
I am no worse gadlyng nor no worse wyȝhte
But borne of a lady and geten of a knyȝhte
Ne dorste he not to gamelyn neuer a fote goo
But cleped to hym his men and saide to hym þoo
Goith and betith þis boy and reveth hym his wytte
And late hym lerne a nother tyme to answer me bette
Than saide þe childe ȝonge gamelyne
Cristes curs mot þou haf brother art þou myne
And if I schal algates be betyn onoon
Cristes curse mote þou haf but þou be þe tone
And onon his brother in þat grete hete
Made his men to fette staffes gamelyn to bete
When eủery of hem hadde a staffe y nomen
Gamelyn was war þo he seigh hym comen
Tho gamelyn sagh hem comen he loked oủerall
And was war of a pestell stode vnder þe wall
Gamelyn was liȝht and þider gon he lepe
And droffe all his brothers men riȝht sone on an hepe
And loked as a wilde lyoıı̄un and leyde on goode wone
Tho his broþ̉er seigh þat he began to gone
He flye vp in to a lofte and schete þe dor faste
Þus gamelyn with his pestell made hem al a gaste
Some for gamelyns loue and som for eye
Al þei drowen hem to halues þo he gan to pleye
¶ What nowe seide gamelyn euyll mote ȝe thee
Will ȝe be gynne contek and so sone flye
Gamelyn soȝht his broþ̉er whider he was flowe
And sawgh wher he loked oute at a wyndowe
Brother saide gamelyn come a litill ner
And I will teche þe to pleye at þe bokeler
His brother hym answered and seid be seynt Richer
Whil þat pestill is in þine honde I will come no ner
Brother I will make þi pees I swer be cristes oore
Caste a waye þe pestell and wrath the nomor
I moste nede said gamelyn wreth me at ones
For þou wold make þi men to breke my bones
Ne hadde I hadde mayn and myȝht in myn armes
To hane hem fro me þei wolde haf do me harmes
Gamelyn saide his brother be þou not wrothe
For to sene þe haf harme me wer riȝht loothe
I ne did it noȝt broþ̉er but for a fondynge
For to loken or þou be stronge and arte so ȝynge
Come a downe þan to me and graunte me my bone
Of oo thynge I will þe axe and we schull saȝht sone
Doun þan come his broþ̉er þat fikell was and fell
And was swithe sor a ferde of þe pestell
He saide brother gamelyn axe me þi bone
And loke þat þou me blame but I it graunt sone
Than seide gamelyn brothe I wys
Ande we schull be at one þou moste graunte me þis
All þat my fader me bequath whils he was on lyffe
Thowe moste do me it haue ȝiff we schall not striffe

Nay qd þis monke be god and be seynt Martyn
He nys no mor Cosyn vn to me
Than is þe lefe þat hongeth on þe tree
I clepe hym so be seynt denys in fraunce
To haue þe mor cause of a quayntance
Of ȝowe the whiche I haf loued specially
A bouen alle womēn sikerly
This swer I ȝowe on my professioun
Tellith ȝour greefe leste he com a down
And hasteth ȝowe and goith ȝour wey onon
My der loue qd sche o dan Iohn
Ful lef me wer this 9sell to hide
But oute it mot it may no mor abide
Myn husbond is to me þe worste man
That eủer was seth þe worlde be gan
But sithen I am a wyff it suteth not to me
To telle no wyȝhte of our priuete
Nether in bedde ne in none other place
God schelde I schuld tell it for his grace
A wyffe ne schall not saye of hir husbonde
But alle honour as I con vndirstonde
Saue vn to ȝowe þus myche tell I schall
As help me god he is not worth at all
In no degree þe value of a flye
But ȝit me grevith moste his negardrye
And wele ȝe wote þat women naturelly
Desirith cyche thynges as wele as I
Þei wolde þat hir husbonde schulde be
Hardy and wyse riche and þerto free
And boxom to his wyffe and fressh abedde
But by þat ilke lorde þat for us bledde
For his honour my selfe to araye
On sonday nexte I most paye
An hundrēth fraunkꝭes or els am I lorne
Ȝet wer me leủer þat I wer vnborne
Then me wer done a sclaunder or a vilenye
And if myn husbonde eke myȝht aspie
I ner but loste and þerfore I ȝowe pᵃye
Lene me þis some and els mote I deye
Dan Iohn I seye lene me þise hundreth fraunkes
ꝐParde I wol not faill þe my thankes
If þat ȝowe luste to do þat I ȝowe preye
For a certeyn daye I will ȝowe paye
And do to ȝowe what plesaunce and seruise
That I may do riȝht as ȝowe luste devise
And but I do god take on me vengeaunce
As foule as hadde genyloıı̄un of fraunce
This gentill monke answerde in þis maner
Nowe trewly myn own lady dere
I haue on ȝowe qd he so grete a rowthe
That I ȝowe swer and pliȝht ȝowe my trouthe
That / whan ȝour husbonde is to flaundres far
I woll deliuer ȝowe oute of þis worldes car
For I will brynge ȝowe an hundreth fraunkes
And with þat he kaught hir be þe schankes
And her enbraced harde and kyssed ofte
Goyth nowe ȝour weye qd he all still and softe
And lat us dyne as sone as eủer ȝe may
For be my kalender it is prime of þe daye
Goith nowe and beeth als trewe as I schall be
Nowe els god forbede sir qd sche
And forth sche goith as gelous as a pye
And bad ye Cokes þat þei schuld hem hye
So þat men myght dyne and þat onon
Vp to hir husbonde is þis wyffe gone
And knokketh at his countr̉e boldely
Qe. la. qd he. petir It am I
Qd sche what howe longe woll ȝe faste
Howe longe tyme woll ȝe rekken and caste
Ȝour somes ȝour bokis and ȝour thynges
The deuyll haf parte on all suche rekkenynges
Ȝe hauen ynogh ꝐParde of goddis sonde
Come down to daye and lat ȝour bag stonde
Ne be ȝe not asshamed þat daun Iohn
Shall fastyng al þis daye elengely gone
What lat us her masse and go we to dyne
¶ Wyff qd þis man litill canst þou devyne
The curious besynes can we / haue
For of us chapmen so god me saue
And by þat lorde þat Called is seynt yue /
Skarsly amonges twelfe þei schullen thryue
Continuelly lastynge vn to our age
We may wele make cher and goode visage
And driffe forth þe worlde as it may be
And kepen our astate in priuete
Till we be dede or els þat we pleye
A pilgⁱmage or gone oute of þe weye
And þer for haue I grete necessite
Vpon þis queynte worlde to avisen me
For eủermor we mot stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune in our chapmanhede
To flaundres woll I gone to morue at daye
And come a gayne as eủer þat I may
For whiche my der wyffe I þe beseche
As be to eủery wiȝht buxom and meke
And for to kepe our goode loke þou be curyous
And honestly goủerne wele our house
Thowe haste y nowgh in eủery maid wyse
That to a thryfty husbonde may suffise
The lakketh none aray ne no vitaille
Off siluer in thi purse thou maiste not faille
And with that worde his counter dor he schette
And down he goith no lenger nolde he lette
And hastely a masse was ther saide
And spedely the tables wer y laide
And to þe dyner faste thei hem spedde
And richely this monke the chapman fedde
And after dyner daun Iohn soburly
This Chapman toke a parte al priuely
He saide hym þus Cosyn it stondeth so
That wele I see to bruggꝭes ȝe woll goo
God and seynt austyne spede ȝowe and gyde
I pray ȝowe Cosyn wysely þat ȝe ride
Goủerneth ȝowe also of ȝour diete
And temꝑperately and namely in þis hete
Betwix us two nedith no stronge far
Far wele cosyn god scheld ȝowe from car
Ȝiff eny thing þer be by day or nyȝht
Ȝiff it ligge in in power and my myȝht
That ȝe me wole cōmmande in euy wise
It schall be done riȝht as ȝe woll devise
Oo / thyng ot þat ȝe gone if þat it / may be
I wolde preye ȝowe for to leue me
An hundreth Fraunkes for a wyke or tweye
For certeyn bestys þat I moste bye
To stor with a place þat is oures
God helpe me so I wolde þat it war ȝowr̉es
I schall not faill surely of my daye
Noȝht for a thousand fraunkes a Mile waye
But lete þis thynges be secr I ȝowe praye
And god of heuen spede ȝowe in ȝour weye
And far wele nowe myn own cosyn der
Graunt mercy of ȝour coste and chere
This noble marchante gentelly onon
Answerde and saide O cosyn daun Iohn
Nowe sikerly thus is a small requeste
My gold is ȝowrs when þat ȝowe lyste
And not only my gold but my Chaffar
Take what ȝowe lyste god scheld þat ȝe spar
But oo thynge is ȝe knowe it wel ynogh
Off chapmen þat her mony is her plogh
We may creaunce whils we haue a name
But goldles for to be is no game
Paye it a ȝeyn when it lieth in ȝour ese
After my myght full fayne wolde I ȝowe plese
This hundreth fraunkes he fette forth onon
And priuely he toke it to daun Ion
No wiȝht in alle þis worlde wiste of þis lone
But only þis machant and daun Iohn allone
Thei dranken and romed and did pleye
Till þat daun Iohn rideth to his Abbeye
The morne cam and forth þis marchant rideth
To flaundres warde his pntys wele hym gideth
Till he com in to brugges meryly
Nowe goith þis marchaunt faste and besyly
A boute his nede and byeth and creaunseth
He nether pleyeth at þe dyse ne daunseth
But as a marchant schortly for to tell
He lette his lyffe and þ̉er I lete hym dwell
The sonday nexte þe marchaunte was agone
To seynt denys y com is daun Iohn
With crown and berde fressh and newe y schaue
In all þe house þ̉er nas so lite a knaue
Ne no wyght ells but þat he was fayn
For þat my lorde daun Iohn was comen a ȝeyn
And schortly to þe poynte for to gone
This fair wyffe acordeth to daun Iohn
And for this hundreth fraunke he schuld al nyȝht
Haue hir in his armes bolt up riȝhte
And þis acorde ꝐParfourmed was in dede
In myrthe all nyȝht a besy lyffe þei ledde
Till it was day þat daun Iohn went his waye
And bad þe menȝye Far wele haf goode daye
For non of hem ne no wyȝht in þe town
Hath of daun Iohn riȝht noo suspicion
And forth he rideth home to his Abbeye
Or wher hym lyste no mor of hym I seye
This marchant when þat ended was þe fair
To seynt denys he gan to repair
And with his wyffe he maketh feste and cher
And tellith her þat Chaffar is so der
That nedes moste hym make a cheuysance
For he was bounden in a reconysaunce
To paye xx thousand scheldes anon
For whiche þis marchaunte is wonte to gone
To borowe of c̉erteyn frendes that he hadde
A c̉erteyn fraunkes and som with hym he ladde
And when that he was com in to þe town
For grete chierte and grete affeccion /
Vn to daun Iohn he firste hym goith to pleye
Noȝht for to borowe of hym no moneye
But for to wyte and se of hys welfar
And for to tellen hy of his chaffar
As frendes done when þei bene mette y fer
Daun Iohn hym maketh feste and mery cher
And he hym tolde a ȝein full specially
Howe he hadde bouȝt full wele and graciously
Thanked he godde al hole his marchaundise
Saue þat he / moste / in all man wise /
Maken a cheuysaunce / as for his beste
And than he schulde be in ioye and reste
Daun Iohn answerde certes I am fayn
That ȝe in hele be come home a ȝeyn
And ȝiff þat I wer riche as haf I blisse
Of xx thousand scheldes schuld I not mysse
For ȝe so kyndely this other daye
Lent me golde and as I can and may
I thanke ȝowe be god and by seynt Iame
But nathelesse I toke vn to our dame
Ȝour wyff at home þe same golde a ȝeym
Opon ȝour benche sche wote it wele certeyn
By c̉erteyn tokens þat I kan her telle
Nowe be ȝour leue I may no lenger dwell
Our abbot woll oute of his town onon
And in his 9panye I mote gone
Grete wele our dame myn own nece swete
And far wele der cosyn til we mete
This marchant with þat was full war and wyse
Creaunced hath ande eke paied in paryse
To certeyn lumbardes redy in her hande
This some of golde and gat of hym þe bande
And home he goith mery as a popyngey
For wele he knewe he stode in suche araye
That nedes moste he wynne in suche a viage
A thousand fraunkes a bouen al his costage /
His wyff full redy mette hym at þe / gate
As sche was wonte of olde vsage algate
And all þat nyȝhte in mirthe þei be sette
For he was riche and clerly oute of dette
When it was daye this marchaunt gan enbrase /
His wyffe all newe and kyssed hir on hir face
And up he goith and makith it wonder tough
No mor qd sche by god ȝe haue ynogh
And wantunly a ȝein with hym sche pleyde
Till at þe laste þat þis marchaunt saide
¶ By god qd he I am a litell wroothe
With ȝowe my wyffe al þof it be me lothe
And wote ȝe why be god as þat I gesse
For ȝe haf made a man straungenesse
Betwixen me and my cosyn daun Iohn
Ȝe schuld haf warned me or I had gone
That he hadde ȝowe an hundreth fraunkes paied
Be redy token and he hym helde euyll a paied
For þat I to hym spake of cheuisaunce
Me semed so as by his 9tenᵃnce
But nathelesse be godde heuen kynge
I thouȝht not to axe of hym no thynge
I pray þe wyffe ne do no mor soo /
Tell me al weye er þat fro þe goo /
If euy deccour hath in myn absence
I paied þe lest thıı̄unrgh þi necligence
I myȝht hym oo thynge þat he hath paied
This wyffe nas not aferde ner affraiede
But boldly sche saide and þat onon
Mary I diffie þat fals monke daıı̄unn Ione
I kepe not of his tokens neủer a dele
He toke me c̉erteyn golde þis wote I wele
What euyll thedam on his monkes snowte
For god wote I wende with outen doute
That he had ȝoff it me be cause of ȝowe
To do þ̉er with myn honour and my prowe
For cosynage and eke for beel cheer
That he hath hadde full often tyme her
But sethens I see I stande in suche disioynte
I will answer ȝowe schortly to þe poynte
Ȝe haf mo slakker deccours þan am I
For I woll paye ȝowe wele and redyly
Fro day to daye and if so be I faill
I am ȝour wyffe . scor it on my taille
And I schall paye as sone as eủer I may
For be my trowthe I haf on myn araye
And not on waste be stowed it / eủery dele
And for I haf bestowed it so well
To ȝour honour for goddes sake I saye
As be not wrothe but lat us laȝhg / and pleye
Ȝe schull my Ioly body haf to wedde
By god I nyll not paye ȝowe but a bedde
For ȝiff it me myn own spouse der
Turne hiderwarde and maketh bett̉er cher
This marchaunt sawe þ̉er was no remedye
And for to chide it ner but folye
Seth þat þᵉ thynge may not amended be
Nowe wyffe he saide and I for ȝiff it þe
But be þi lyffe ne be no mor so large
Kepe bet my goode this ȝiff I þe in charge
Thus endith nowe my tale and god us sende
Toyllyng ynogh vn to our lyffes ende
; Explicit ;
¶ Here begynneth þe Prioresse tale ;
Well saide be corpus dıı̄uns ꝙquod our oste
Nowe longe mot þou sail by þe see coste
Sir gentil maistr gentiell mariner
God ȝiff þe monke a thousand laste of quade ȝer
A ha felowes beth war of suche a Iape
The monke putte in þe māmnys hode an Ape
And in his wyffes eke be seynt austyn
Draweth no monkes mor in to ȝour Inne
But nowe passe oủer and lat us seke a boute
Who schall nowe tell firste of all þis route
A nother tale and with þat worde he saide
Als curtasly as it had bene a mayde
My lady prioresse be ȝour lefe
So þat I schulde ȝowe not greue
I wolde deme þat ȝe tell schulde
A tale if so wer nexte / þat ȝe wolde
Nowe woll ȝe wouchesaue my lady der

l.hi: Gladly qd sche and said in þis maner

div.l:
Here begynneth þe tale of Alma redeptoris
¶dıı̄une dıı̄uns noster/
O lorde our lorde þi name howe marveillous
Is in þis large worlde y spadde qd sche
For not only þis laude preciouse
ꝐParfourmede is be mēn of dignite
But by þe mouthe of children þhi bownte
Afourmed as for on our breste soukynge

l.hi: Somtyme schewen þei ynne heryinge

div.l: Wherrfor in laude as I kan best or may
Off þe and of þi white lyly flour
Whiche þat þe bare and is amayde alweye
To tell a storye I woll done my labour
Noȝt þat I may encrese her honour
For sche her selfe is honour and þ̉er to rote

l.hi: Of bounte next to her son of soules bote

div.l: ¶ O moder maide O mayde modre fr̉e
O bussh vnbrent brynnyng in moyses siȝht
That rauyssheth doun fro þe deytele
Thurgh þine humbles / þe gost þat in þe aliȝht
Of whose vertue when he in þi goste aliȝhte
Conceyued was þe faders sapience

l.hi: Helpe me to tell it in þi reuerence

div.l: ¶ Lady þi bounte and þi magnificence
Thy vertu and þi grete humilite
Ther may no tonge expsse in no science
For somtyme lady er men preye to þe
Thowe goiste be forne of þi benignite
And getest us to liȝht thurgh þi praier

l.hi: To giden us vn to þi son so cler

div.l: ¶ My kōnnyng is to wayke o blesfull quene
For to declar þi grete worthinesse
That I ne may the weȝht not sustene
But as a childe of xij moneth elde or lesse
That kan vnnethes eny worde expsse
Riȝht so far I and þerfor I ȝowe praye

l.hi: Gydith my songe þat I schall of ȝowe saye

div.l: Ther was in asye in a grete Citee
Amanges Cristen folke and Iwrye
Sustened by a lorde of þat cuntr̉e
For foule vsur̉e and lucr̉e of vylanye
Hatfull to criste / and and to his 9panye
And thrugh þe strete men myȝht ride or wende

l.hi: For it was fr̉e and open at euery ende

div.l: ¶ A litill scole of Cristen folke / þer stode
Doun at þe ferþer ende in whiche þ̉er wer
Children an hepe y com of Criste blode
That lerned in þat scole ȝer by ȝer
Suche man doctrine as men vseth þer
This is to sey syngen and to rede

l.hi: As smale children done in her childhede

div.l: ¶ A monge þis children was a wydewes son
A litell clergioun vij ȝer of age
That day be day to scole was he wone
And eke also wher he sagh þe ymage
Of cristes moder had he in vsage
And hym was tauȝht to knele a doun and seye

l.hi: His aue marie as he goith by þe waye

div.l: ¶ Thus hath þis wydowe hir litill childe y taught
Our blesfull lady Cristes moder der
To worschip / ay and he forgat it not
For sely childe wolde alday sone ler
But ay when I remembr me on þis mater
Seynt Nicolas stant eủer in my psence

l.hi: For he so ȝonge to criste did reuerence /

div.l: ¶ This childe his litill boke lernynge
As he satte in þe scole at his primer
He / alma redemptoris mat̉er harde syng
As childern lerned hir antiphoner
And as he durste he drogh hym ner and ner
Ande herkened aye þe wordes and þe note

l.hi: Till he þe firste verse couthe all be rote

div.l: ¶ Noȝht wiste he what þe latyn was to seye
For he so ȝonge and tender was of age
But on a day he felowe gan he preye
To expoun hym þis songe in his langage
Or tellen hym why þis songe was in vsage
This preied he hym to 9strue and declar

l.hi: Ful ofte tyme opon his knees bar

div.l: ¶ His felowe which þat elder was þan he
Answerd hym þus / þis songe I haf harde seye
Was maked of our blesfull lady fr̉e
Her to salue and eke hir for to preye
To bene our helpe and socour when we dye.
I can no mor expounde in þis mater

l.hi: I lerne songe I can but small gramer

div.l: ¶ And þis is þe songe y made in reủerence
Of Cristes moder saide þis Innocent
Nowe certes I woll don my diligence
To kon it er Cristen masse be wente
Thof þat I for my pⁱrimer schall be schente
And schall be beten thries in an hour

l.hi: I woll it kon our lady for to honour

div.l: ¶ His felowe tauȝht hym homward priuely
Fro day to day till he couthe it be rote
And þen he sange it wele and boldlye
Fro word to worde acordynge to þe note
Thries on a day it passed thurgh his throte
To scole ward and homeward when he wente

l.hi: On cristꝭes moder sette he his intente

div.l: ¶ As I haf saide thurgh oute þe Iwrye
¶ This litill childe as he cam to and froo
Full merily þen wolde he synge and crye
On alma redemptoris euermoo
The swetnes hath his herte ꝑperced so
Of Cristes moder þat to hir to praye

l.hi: He can not stynte of syngynge be þe weye

div.l: ¶ Our firste foo þe serpent sathanas
That hath in Iwys his waspis neste
Vp swall and saide O ebraike peple allas
Is þis a thynge to ȝowe þat is honeste
That suche a boye schall walken as hym leste
In ȝour despite and syngyn of suche sentence

l.hi: Whiche is a ȝeyn ȝour lawes reuerence

div.l: ¶ Fro thennes forth þe Iwys han conspirede
This Innocent oute of þis worlde to chase
In homicidie þer to han þei huyred /
That in an aley had a priue plase
And as þe childe gan by for to pase
This cursed Iwe hym hente and helde faste

l.hi: And kutte his throte and in a pitte hym caste

div.l: ¶ I say þat in a wardrobe þei hym drewgh
Wher as þis Iwys did purgen entraille
O cursed folke of herowdꝭes al newe
What may ȝour euyll entente ȝowe availle
Murdr̉e woll oute certeyn it woll not faille
And namely þ̉er honour of god schuld sprede

l.hi: The blode oute crieth on ȝour cursed dede

div.l: ¶ O Martir sounded to virginite
Nowe maiste þou syngen folowyng eủer in one
The white lambe celestiall qd he
Of whiche þe grete euᵃngeliste seynt Iohn
In pathmos wrote whiche saith þei þat gone
Beforne þis lambe and syng a songe al newe

l.hi: That neủer flesshly wōmmen þei knewe

div.l: ¶ This por̉e wydowe wayteth all þe niȝht
Aft̉er þis litill childe but home com he noȝht
For whome als sone as it was daies liȝht
With face pale for drede and besy thoȝhte
She hath at þe scole and ells wher hym soȝhte
Till finally sche gan so ferr̉e aspye

l.hi: That he was seen laste in þe Iwrye

div.l: ¶ With moders pite in hir breste y closede
She goith as þof sche wer half oute of mynde
To eur place / wher sche hath supposede
Be liklyhede her childe to fynde
And eủer on Cristes moder meke and kynde
She cried and at þe laste þus sche wroght

l.hi: Amonge þe cursed Iwys sche hym soght

div.l: ¶ She feyneth and sche preyeth pitously
To euery Iwe þat dwelled in þilke plase
To tell hir if hir childe wente hym bye
Thei seiden nay . but Ihc of his grace
Ȝaff in hir thouȝht with in a litill space
That in þat place after hir son sche cried

l.hi: Ther he was caste in a pitte beside

div.l: ¶ O grete god þat performed þine lawde
By mouthe of Innocentes lo her þi myghte
This gēmme of chastite þis emeraude
And eke of martirdome þe rubie briȝhte
Ther he with koroven throte lay up riȝht
He alma redemptoris mater gan to synge

l.hi: So longe þat al þe plase gan to rynge

div.l: ¶ The cristen folke þat thurgh þe strete wente
In camyn for to wondren on þis thynge
And hastily þei for þe ꝓproueste sente
He cam onone with outen taryynge
And herieth criste þat is of heuen kynge
And eke his moder honour of mankynde

l.hi: And after þat þe Iwys let he bynde /

div.l: ¶ This childe with pitous lamentacioıı̄un
Was up taken syngynge his songe al weye
And with honour of grete processioıı̄un
Thei carien hym to þe nexte Abbeye
His moder swownynge by þe beer laye
Vnnethes myȝht þe peple þat was þer

l.hi: This newe rachell brynge from his beer

div.l: ¶ With turment and with schamefull deth ilkone
This ꝓproueste did þis Iwys for to sterue
That of þis murther wiste and þat onone
He nolde none suche cursednes obserue
Euyll schall haue þat euyll will deserue
Ther for with wilde horse he did hem drawe

l.hi: And after þat he henge hem by þe lawe

div.l: ¶ Opon þis ber ay laye þis Innocente
Beforne þe chief autre whils messe laste
And after þat þe abbot with his conuent
Spedde hem for to berye hym faste /
And when þei holy water on hym caste
Ȝit spake þe childe / when spreynt was þe holy water

l.hi: And sang o alma redemptoris mater

div.l: ¶ This abbot whiche þat was an holy man
As monkes bene or els oughten to be
This ȝonge childe to coniure þei began
And saide o der childe I hailse the
By þe vertue of þe holy trinite
Tell me what is þi cause for to synge

l.hi: Sethens þi throte is kutte at my semynge

div.l: ¶ Mi throte is kutte vn to my nekke bone
Said þis childe and as be way of kynde
I schuld haf dyed ȝa longe tyme a gone
Bot ihu Criste as ȝe in bokes fynde
Woll take his glorye laste and be in mynde
And for þe worschipe of his moder der

l.hi: I may ȝit synge O alma loude and cler

div.l: ¶ This welle of mercy Cristes moder swete
I loued al weye as after my konnynge
And when þat I my lyffe schulde lete
To me sche cam and badde me for to synge
This anteme verrely in my mynde dyynge
As ȝe haf harde and when þat I had songen

l.hi: Me thoght sche laide a greyn opon my tonge

div.l: ¶ Wher for I fynde and synge motte certeyn
In honour of þe blesfull martir free
Till of my tonge of taken is þe greyn
And after þat said sche þus to me
Nay littell childe nowe woll I fecche þe
When þat þi greyn is from þi tonge y take

l.hi: Be not a gaste I will þe not forsake

div.l: ¶ This holy monke þis Abbot hym mene I
His tonge oute kaught and toke a weye þe greyn
Than he ȝaff up þe goiste full softely
And when þe abbot had þis wonder seyn
His salte teres striked down as reyn
And gruff he fell al plat vn to þe grounde

l.hi: And still he laye als he had bene y bounde

div.l: ¶ The conuent eke laye vp on þe pauymente
Wepyng and heryynge Cristes moder der
And after þat þei rose and forthe bene wente
And toke a weye þis martir from his beer
And in a tombe of marbill stones cler
Thei enclosed his litill body swete

l.hi: Ther he is nowe god leue us forto mete

div.l: ¶ O ȝonge hewe of lincoln slayn also
With cursed Iwys as it is notable
For it ne is but a litill while a goo
Prey eke for us synfull folke vnstable
That of his mercy godde so merciable
On us his grete mercy multiplie
For þe reuerence of his moder marye
¶ Explicit
¶ Here begynneth þe prologe of þe monke
When ended was þe tale of mellibe
And of prudence and of her benignite
Our oste saide as I am feithfull man
And by þe pcious corpus madrian
I hadde leuer þan a barell ale
That goode lefe my wiffe had harde þis tale
For sche nys no thyng of suche pacience
As was þis mellibeus wiffe prudence
By goddes bones when I bette my knaves
She broght me þe grete clubbed staffes
And crieth slee þe dogges euerychon
And breeke both bak and bone
And ȝif þat eny neighburgh of myne
Will not in chirche to my wiffe enclyne
Or be so hardy to hire to trespasse
When sche cometh home sche rıı̄unpeth in my face
And crieth fals cowarde wreke þi wiffe
By corpus bonys I will haf þi knyffe
And thou schalt haf my distaffe and go spynne
From daye to nyght riȝht þus sche will begynne
Allas sche saith þat euer I was schape
To wedde a melkesoppe or a coward apee
That will be ouerledde with euery wyght
Thow darste not stonde by þi wiffe a riȝht
This is my liffe but if þat I wolde fiȝht
And oute at þe dore onone I mote me diȝht
Or elles I am loste bot if þat I
Ben like a wilde lion fool hardy
I wote wele sche will do me slee som day
Some nēighbor and þan go my waye
For I am ꝑparlious with knyffe on honde
Al be it þat I dar not hir withstonde
For sche is bigge in armes be my feyth
That schall he fynde þat her mysdoith or saith
But lat us passe a weye fro þis matier
My lorde sir monke he saith be mery of cher
For ȝe schull tell a tale trewly
Loo Rowchestr stant her fast by
Ride forth myn own lorde breke not our game
But be my trouthe I knowe not ȝour name
Wheþ̉er I schall call ȝowe my lorde dawn Iohn
Or daun thomas or daun albin
Other of what house be ȝe by ȝoᵘur fader kyn
I vowe to god þou haste a ful fair skyn
It is a gentill pastur þer þou goiste
Thou art not like a penᵃnt or a gooste
Opon my feith þou art some officer
Some worthy sextene or some celerer
For be my faders soule as to my dome
Thou art a maister when þou art at home
No por cloistrer ne no por novyse
But gouernour wylye and wise
And þ̉er with al of brawnes and of bones
A welfaryng ꝑperson for þe nones
I pray to god ȝiff hym confusion
That firste þe broght in to religion
Thowe woldest han bene a dredfull a riȝht
Haddest þou as grete leue as þou haste myȝht
To ꝐParfourme al thi luste in engendrur
Thou haddest begeten mony a creatur
Allas why weres þou so wide a cope
God ȝiff me sorowe and I wer a pope
Nought only that but eủery myghty man
They he wer schor hiegh opon his panne
Shuld haf a wyff for al þis worlde is lorne
Religiōn hath take up al the corne
Of tredynge / and we borell men ben schrympes
Of feble trees þer comyth wrechede ympes
This makith þat our eyrs bene so sklender
And feble þat þei may not wele engender
This maketh þat our wiffes will assaye
Religious folke for þei may better paye
Off venus payment þen mowe we
God wote no luscheburnes paye ȝe
But beith not wrothe my lorde þof þat I pleye
Ful ofte in game a sothe I haf harde seye
This worthy monke toke al in pacience
And said I woll don al my diligence
As ferr as sowneth in to honeste
To tell ȝowe a tale or two or thr
And ȝiff ȝowe liste herken hiderwarde
I will ȝowe seyn þe liffe of seynt edward
Or ells tregedrys firste will I tell
Off whiche I haf an hundreth in my selle
Tregedye is for to tell a certeyn storye
As olde bokes maken memorye
Off hem þat stode in grete propsperite
And is y fall oute of hie degree
In to miserie and endeth wrecchedly
And þei bene versefyed comonly
Of sixe fete whiche þat men clepe examitron
In prose eke bene endited mony one
And eke in metr in mony a sondry wise
Lo þis aught to ȝowe y nowe suffise
Nowe herkenyth ȝiff ȝowe liste for to her
But firste I ȝowe beseche in this matier
Þough I be ordr tell not þise thynges
Be it of popes Emperours or kynges
And after her ages as men write fynd
But tell hem som byfor som be hynde
And it cometh nowe to my remembraunce
Haue me excused of myne ignorance
¶ Explicit prologus
; Incipit Fabula .
¶ Here telleth the monke . de casibus virorum Illustrium.
I Wol be waille in maner of tregedrie
The harme of hem þat standeth in hie degree
And fellen so that þer nas no remedye
To brynge hem once of her aduersite
For certeyn when þat fortune luste to flye
The may no man of her þe course withholde
Lat no man truste on blynde prosperitee
Beeth war by þise ensamples ȝonge and olde /
At lucifer þough he an Aungell wer
And nought a man at hym I wol begynne
For theigh fortune may none aungel der
From heigh degree ȝet felle he for his synne
Doun in to helle wher as he ȝet is Inne
O lucifer bryȝhtest of aungells alle
Nowe art þou sathanas that maist not twynne
Oute of miserie in whiche þou arte falle /
Loo Adam in þe felde of damacene
With goddis own fynger wrought was he
And not begeten of mannes sparme vnclene
And welded al ꝑparadise sauyng oo tree
Hadde neủer worldly man so hie degree
As Adam til he for his gouernaunce
Was driven oute of his hie prosperite
To labour and to helle and to myschaunce
Loo Sampson whiche was anıı̄unciate
By the aungell lange er his natiuite
And was to god almyghty consecrate
And stoode in nobles whiles he myght see
Was neuer suche a nother as was he
To speke of strenghte and þer to hardynesse
But to his wiffes tolde he his secree

l.hi: Thurgh whiche he slowe hym self for wrecchednesse

div.l: Sampson this noble and myghty Campyoun
With outen wepen saue his hondes tweye
He slowgh and al to rente the lyoun
Toward his weddyng walkyng by þe weye
His false wiffe couthe hym so plese and preye
Til sche his counsell knewe and sche vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counsell gan be wreye

l.hi: And hym forsoke and tooke a nother newe

div.l: ¶ An hundreth foxes toke sampson for ir
And al her tailles he to gider bonde
And sette þe foxes tailles al on a fuyr
For he in euery taille hadde putte a bronde
And þei brent al þe cornes in þat londe
And al hir olyues and her vynes eke
A thowsand men eke he slowh with his honde

l.hi: And hadde no wepen but an asse cheke

div.l: ¶ When þei wer slayn so thursted hym þat he
Was wel nyegh lorne for whiche he gan to preye
That god wolde of his peyne haf som pite
And sende hym drynke or els moste he deye
And of þis asse cheke þat was so drye
Oute of a wang toothe sprange onon a welle
Of whiche he dranke ynogh schortly to seye

l.hi: Thus helped hym god as Iudicu can tell

div.l: ¶ By verrey force at gasan on a nyȝht
Mawgr philistiens of that citee
The gate of þe toun he hath up plyȝht
And on his bakke y karied hem hath he
Hiegh on an hill wher as men myght see
O noble and myghty sampson liefe and der
Ne hadde þou tolde to woman þi secree

l.hi: In al þis worlde ne hadde þer bene þi peer

div.l: ¶ This sampson neuer tater drank no wyne
Ne on his hede come rasour ne no scher
By pcepte of þe messanger diuine
For al his strenghte was in his heer
And fully xx ȝer . by ȝer
He hadde of israel þe gouernance
But after sone schall he wepe mony a ter

l.hi: For wymen schullen brynge hym to myschaunce

div.l: ¶ Vn to his leman dalida he tolde
That in his heres al his strenght laye
And falsly to his foomen sche hym solde
And slepyng vpon hir barme vpon a day
She made to clippe or scher his her a weye
And made his fomen al his crafte aspien
And when þat þei hym fonde in suche araye

l.hi: Thei bonde hym faste and putten oute his eyen

div.l: ¶ But er his heer was y clipped or I schaue
Ther was no bonde þat myȝht hym bynde
But nowe is he in prisoun putte in a kaue
Wher þat þei made hym at þe querne grynde
O noble sampson strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse
Nowe maiste þou wepe with þin eyen blynde

l.hi: Sethens þou art from wele fallen in to wrecchednesse

div.l: ¶ The ende of þise catiffes was as I schall seye
His Fomen made a feste opon a day
And made hym as her fole beforne hym pleye
And þis was a temple of a grete araye
But at þe laste he made a foule affraye
For he two postes schoke and made hem falle
And doun fell þe temple and al þ̉er it laye
And slowgh hym selfe and eke his foomen alle
¶ This is to say the princes euerichon
And eke a thowsand bodies wer þer slain
With fallyng of þe grete temple of stone
Of Sampson ne woll I no mor seyne
Beth war of this ensamples olde and playn
That no man tell her consell to her wiffes
Of suche thynges as þei wolde haf secre fayn

l.hi: Ȝif þat it touche her lymes or hir liffes

div.l: Of Ercule þe souereyn conquerour
Syngen his werkes leuede and hie renoun
For in his tyme of strenghte he bar þe flour
He slowe and rafte þe skyn fro the lyon
He of Sentaures leyde þe boste a doun
He arpyes slowe the Crwell briddes felle
He golden appels raffte the dragoun

l.hi: He drewe oute Serborois þe hounde of helle

div.l: ¶ He slowe þe crwell tiraunt buserus
And made his horse to frete hym flessh and bone
He slowgh þe verrey serpent venymous
Of achilles two hornes brake he one
He slowe þe geaunt / Anteus þe stronge
He slowe cacus in a caue of stone
He slowgh þe grisly bor and þat onon

l.hi: And bar þe hede opon his nek / longe

div.l: ¶ Was neủer wight sethen þe world began
That slowe so mony monstres as did he
Thurgh oute þis wilde world his name ran
What for his strenght / and for his bounte
And euery reeme wente he for to see
He was so stronge þat no man myght hym lette
And bothe the worldes ende saith trophe

l.hi: In stede of boundes he a piler sette

div.l: ¶ A lēmman hadde þis noble campyon
That hight dyainyr fressh as as may
And as þe clerkes maden mencion
She hath hym sent a scherte fressh and gaye
Allas þis scherte and welaway
Envenemyd was subtily with all
That er he had wered it halfe a daye

l.hi: It made his bonys from his flessh to falle

div.l: ¶ But nathelesse som clerkꝭes hir excusen
By one þat hiȝht nessus that it maked
Be as be may I woll her not accusen
But on his bak þis schert he weres al naken
Till þat his flessh was for the venym blaked
And when he sawe non other remedie
In hote coles he hath hym selfe raked

l.hi: For with no venym deyned he to deye

div.l: ¶ Thus starf þis worthy myghty ercules
Loo who may trust on fortune eny throwe
For hym þat foloweth al þis worlde of pse
Er he bewar is ofte y leide full lowe
Ful wise is he þat hym selfe can knowe
Beth war for when þat fortune liste to glose
Then wayteth sche her man doun to throwe

l.hi: Be suche a wey as he wolde leste suppose

div.l: The myghty trone þe pcious tresour
The glorious septr and reall mageste
That had þe kyng nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethes may desrived be
He twies toke Ihrlm þe citee
The vessell of þe temple he with hym ladde
At babiloyn was his souereyn see

l.hi: In whiche his glorie and his delite he hadde

div.l: ¶ The fairest children of þe blode roiall
Of Ihrlm he did do gilde onon
And maked eche of hem to bene his cherle
Amonge al other Danyell was one
That was þe wisest childe of eủerichon
For he þe dremes of þe kyng expowned
Wher as in caldeye clerk was þer non

l.hi: That wiste to what fyne his dremes sowned

div.l: ¶ This proude kynge lete make a statue of golde
Sixty cubites longe and vij . in brede
To swiche an ymage bothe ȝonge and olde
Cōmmanded he to lowte and haf in drede
Or in a fourneys full of flāmmes rede
He schuld be brente þat wold not obeye
Bot neủer wold assent to þat dede

l.hi: Daniell ne his ȝonge felowes tweye

div.l: ¶ This kynge of kynges prowde and elate
He wente god þat sitte in mageste
Ne myȝht hym not bereue of his estate
But sodenly he loste his dignite
And like a beeste hym semed for to be
And ete hay as an ox and laye þ̉er oute
In reyn with wilde bestes walked he

l.hi: Till c̉erteyn tyme was come abowte

div.l: ¶ And like an Egles feders was his heres
His nailles like briddes clawes wer
God releued hym a c̉erteyn ȝeres
And ȝaff hym witte and þᵃn with mony a ter
He thanked god and eủer his liffe in fer
Was . he to don amys or mor trespasse
And or þat tyme he laide was on his ber
He knewe wele þat god was full of myght ⁊and gᵃce
¶ His sonne whiche þat hight baltasar
That helde þe reigne after his faders daye
He by his fader couthe not bewar
For proude he was of herte and of araye
And eke an ydolatr was he ay
His hiegh astate assured hym in pride
Bot fortune caste hym down and þ̉er he laye

l.hi: And sodenly his regne gan devide

div.l: ¶ A feste he made vn to his lordes alle
Opon a tyme he made hem blithe to be
And þenne his officers gan he calle
Gooth bryngeth forth þe vessels qd he
Whiche þat my fader in his prosperite
Oute of þe temple of Ihrlm berafte
And to our hiegh goddꝭes thank we

l.hi: Of honour þat our eldres with us lafte

div.l: ¶ His wiffe his lordes and his concubines
Ay drunken whils hir appetite laste
Oute of þise noble vessels sundry wynes
And on a wall þis kyng his eyen caste
And sawgh an hande armeles þat wrote ful faste
For fer of whiche he qwoke and sighed sor
This hand þat baltasar made so sor a gaste

l.hi: Wrote . Mane techel phares . and no mor

div.l: ¶ In al þat lande magicien was þer none
That couthe expoune what þis lettr mente
But daniel expowned it onon
And said kyng god to þi fader sent
Glorie and honour reigne tresour and rente
And he was proude and no thyng god ne / dradde
And þ̉er for god grete wrecche opon hym sente

l.hi: And hym birafte þe reigne þat he hadde

div.l: ¶ He was oute caste of mannes compaignye
With Asses was his habitacion
And ete hay as a beste in wete and drye
Til þat he knewe by grace and bi reson
That god of heuen hath dominacion
Ouer euery reigne and eủery creatur
And þenne had god of hym compassion

l.hi: And hy restored his reigne and his figur

div.l: ¶ Eke þou þat arte his son arte proude also
And knowest al þise / thynges priuely
And arte rebell to god and arte his foo
Thowe drank eke of his vessels boldly
Thy wiffe eke and þi wenches synfully
Drank of þe same vessels sondry wynes
And heried fals goddes cursedly

l.hi: Therfor to þe schapen grete peyne is

div.l: ¶ This hand was sent from god þᵗat on þe wall
Wrote Mane techel phares . truste me
Thy reigne is don þou weiest not at al
Dyuided is thi reigne and it schall be
To medis. and to ꝑpersis . ȝiffen qd he
And þilke same nyght þe kynge was slawe
And daryus occupieth his degree

l.hi: Þōgh he þer to ne had neþ̉er riȝht ne lawe .

div.l: ¶ Lordyngꝭes herby ensample may ȝe take
Howe þat in lordschip is no sikernesse
For when fortune woll a man forsake
He bereth a weye his reigne and his richesse
And eke his frendes both mor and lesse
And what man hath frendes thurgh fortune
Mishappe woll make hem enmyse I gesse

l.hi: This prouerbe is ful sothe and full comune

div.l: ¶ Cenobia of palymer þe quene
As writen ꝑpersyens of hir noblesse
So worthy was in armes and so kene.
That no wiȝht passed hir in hardynesse
Ne in lynage ne in other gentilnesse
Of þe kyngꝭes blode of ꝑpersye is sche descended
I saye þat sche ne had not moste fairnes

l.hi: Bot of hir schap sche myght not be amended

div.l: ¶ From childhode I fynde þat sche fledde
Office of women and in to þe wod sche wente
And mony a wilde hertis blode sche schedde
With arowes brode þat sche to hem sent /
She was so swyfte þat sche onon hem hent
And when þat sche was elder sche wolde kille
Lyons liberdes and beres alto rente

l.hi: And in hir armes welded hem at hir will

div.l: ¶ She durste wildse bestes dennes seke
And renne in þe mounteyn al þe nyght
And slepe vnder a bıı̄unsch sche couthe eke
Wrastlen be verray force and myght
With eny ȝong man wer he neủer so wiȝht
Ther myȝht no thyng in hir armes stonde
She kepte hir maydenhode from eủery wiȝht

l.hi: To no man deyned hir to be bonde

div.l: ¶ But at þe laste hir frendes han hir maried
To odonake a prince of þat cite
Al wer it so þat sche hem longe taried
And ȝe schall vnderstonde howe þat he
Had suche fantasies as hadde sche
But natheles when þei wer knytte in fer
Þei liffeden in ioye and in felicite

l.hi: For eche of hem had other liefe and der

div.l: ¶ Saue oo thynge þat sche nold neủer assente
By no weye þat he schuld by hir lye
But ones . for it was hir pleyn entente
To haf a childe þe worlde to multiplie
And also sone as sche myght aspie
Þat sche was not with childe with þat dede
Than wolde sche suffr hym done his fantasie

l.hi: Eftsone and not but ones oute of drede

div.l: ¶ And / if sche wer with childe at þilke caste
Nomor schuld he pleye þilke game
Til fourty daies wer paste
Than wold sche ones suffr hym to do þe same
Al wer þis Odonak wilde or tame
He gate no mor of hir for þus sche saide
It was to wyffes licherye and schame

l.hi: IN oþ̉er case if þat men myght with hem played

div.l: ¶ Two sonnes by þis Odonak had sche
The whiche sche kepte in vertue and in letterur
But nowe vn to our tale turne we
I say þat worschipfull creatur
And wise þ̉er with and large with mesur
So penyble in þe werr and curtas eke
No mor labour myght in werr endur

l.hi: Was none þeigh al þis worlde men schuld seke

div.l: ¶ Hir riche aray myght not be tolde
As wele in vessell as in clothynge
She was al cladde in perr and in golde
And eke sche lefte not for none huntynge
To haf of sundry tonges folke knowynge
Whan þat sche laiser had and for to entende
To lerne bokes was al hir likynge

l.hi: Howe sche in vertue myȝht hir liffe dispende

div.l: ¶ And schortly of þis schortly for to entrete
So doughty was hir husbonde as sche
That þei / conquered mony reignes grete
IN þe oriente with mony a fair cite
Aꝑpartenᵃnt vn to þe mageste
Of rome and with stronge honde held hem faste
Ne neủer myght her foomen done hem flee

l.hi: Ay whiles þat Odenak dayes laste

div.l: ¶ Her batailles who so liste hem for to rede
A gayn soper þe kyng and other moo
And howe þat al þe ꝓprocesse fell in dede
Whi sche conquered and what title had þ̉er to
And after of hir myschief and of hir woo
Howe þat sche was biseged and y take
Lete hym vn to my maister petrark go

l.hi: That writeth ynogh of þis I vndertake

div.l: ¶ When odenak was dede sche myghtily
The reignes helde and with hir ꝓpropre honde
A gayn hir foos sche fāught trewly
That þ̉er nas kyng ne prinde in al þat londe
Þat he nas glad ȝif he þat grace fonde
That sche ne wolde vpon his londe werray
With hir þei made a lyaunce by bande

l.hi: To bene in peese and lete hir ride and pleye

div.l: ¶ The emꝑperour of rome claudius
Ne hym beforne þe romayn galiene
Ne dorste neủer be so coragius
Ne noon Ermyn ne none egipciene /
Ne surriene ne none arabiene
With in þe felde þat durste with hir to fight
Leste þat sche wolde with hir hondes hym sleen

l.hi: Or with hir manȝee putten hem to flyght

div.l: ¶ In kynges abite wente hir sonnes twoo
As heirs of hir reignes alle
And hermanno / and Tinalito
Her names wer as ꝑpersiens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in hir hony galle
This myghty quene may no whille endur
Fortune oute of hir reigne made hir falle

l.hi: To wrecchednes and to mysauentur

div.l: ¶ Aurelian when þat / þe gouernaunce
Of rome came in to his handes tweye
Towarde Cenobye and schortly for to seye
He made hir flie and at þe laste hir hente
And fettred hir and eke hir childern tweye
And wan þe londe and home to rome þei wente
Amonge þise other thynges þat he wanne

l.hi: Hir chaar þat wroȝht with golde was and perree

div.l: ¶ This grete romeyn this Aureliane
Hath with hym ladde for þat men schuld see
Beforne his triumphe walketh sche
With gilte cheynes on hir nekke hongynge
Coroned sche was as after her degree
And full of perry charched hir clothynge
Allas fortune sche saide þat whilom was
Dredfull to kynges and to emperoures
Nowe gawreth al þe peple on hir allas
And sche þat helmed was in starke stoures
Shall on hir hede nowe ber a vitrmyte
And sche þat bar þe sceptr full of floures
Shall bie a distaff hir coste for to quyte
O noble o worthy petre Glorie of Spayne
Whome fortune helde so high in maiestee
Wele ought men thy pytous dethe compleyn
Thi bastarde brother made þe to flye
And after at a seege by subtilite
Thou wer betraied and ladde to his tente
Wher as he with his own honde slough þe
Succedyng in þi reigne and in þi rente
The felde of snowe with þe egle blak þ̉er inne
Cauȝht with þe lyme rede colours as þe glede
He brewe þis cursednes and all þe synne
¶ The wykked neste was wirker of þise nedes
Nouȝht Charles Olyfer þat ay toke goode hede
Of trouthe and honour but Armorekke
Genilon Oliuer corrupte for nede
Broughtest þis worthy kynge in suche brekke
Worthi petr kynge of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wan be heigh maistrie
Ful mony an hethan wroughtest þou for woo
Of whiche þine own lieges hadde envie
And for no thynge but for thi chilaulrie
Thei in þi bedde han slayn þe by þe morne
Thus gan fortune gouerne and gye
And oute of Ioye brynge in to sorowe
Of Melane grete barnabo viscounte
God of delite and scourge of lumbardie
Why schuld not I þi fortune acounte
Sithen in estate þou clomben wer so hie
Thi brother sone þat was þi double allie
For he þi nevewe was and sonne in lawe
With inne his prison made þe to deye
Bot whi ne howe wote I þat þou wer slawe
Of þe erle hugelyne of pise þe langour
Ther may no tunge tell for pite
