But litell oute of pise stant a tour
In whiche tour in prison putte was he
And with hym hym ben his litell children three
Þe eldeste skarsly v ȝer was of age
Allas fortune is was grete cruelte
Suche briddes for to putte in such a cage
Dampned he was to deye in þat prisoun
For roger whiche þat bysshop was of pise
Had on hym made a fals suggestion
Thurgh whiche þe peple gān on hym arise
And putten hym to prison in suche awise
As ȝe haf harde and mete / and drynke he hadde
So small þat vnnethe it may suffise

l.hi: And þ̉er with al / it was full por and badde

div.l: ¶ On a day bifell þat in þat houre
When þat his mete was wonte to be broȝht
The Iaillour schette þe dores of þe toure
He harde it wele but he sawe it noȝht
And in his herte onon þer fell a thought /
That þei for hunger wolde done hym deyen
Allas qd he allas þat I was wroȝht

l.hi: Ther with þe teeres fell from his eyen

div.l: ¶ His ȝonge son that thr ȝeer was of age
Vn to hym saide Fader why do ȝe wepe
When wol þe Iaillour bryng our potage
Is þer no morsell brede þat ȝe did kepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wold god þat I myght slepe euer
Then schuld none hunger in my wombe crepe

l.hi: Ther is no thyng saue brede þat me wer leuer

div.l: ¶ Thus day be day this childe gan to crie
Til in his fadres barme a doun it leye
And said . Far wele fader for I mot dye
And kissed his fader and died þe same daie
And when þe wofull fader dede hym saye
For woo his armes twoo he gan to bite
And said Allas fortune and wele away

l.hi: Thy fals whele my woo I may al wite

div.l: ¶ His childer þat it for hunger was
That he his armes gnewe and not for woo
Thei saiden Fader do not so allas
But rather ete þe flessh opon us two
Our flessh þou ȝaff us take our flessh us froo
And ete ynogh riȝht þus to hym þei seide
And after þat with inne a daye or twoo

l.hi: Thei leide hem doun in his lappe and died

div.l: ¶ Hym selfe despeired eke for hunger starffe
Thus ended is þis myghty erle of pyse
For hie astate fortune from hym karfe
Of his tregetrie it ought ynogh suffise
Who so wolde her it in a lenger wise
Redeth þe grete poete of Italye
That hiȝht Daunte for he can it deuise

l.hi: Fro poynt to poynt not oo worde woll he faill

div.l: ¶ Al þogh þat Nero wer als viciouse
As eny fende þat lieth full lowe a doun
Ȝit he / as telleth us Swetheneus
This wide worlde had in subieccion
Bothe este and weste and septetroune
Of rubies saphirs and of ꝑparles white
Wer al his clothes browthered up and doun

l.hi: For he in gemmes grete / gan delite

div.l: ¶ Mor delicate mor pompouse of araye
Mor proude was neủer empour þan he
That ilke clothe þat he had wered a day
After þat tyme he nolde it neủer see
Nettes of gold threde had he grete plente
To fysshen in tibr when hym luste to playe
His lustes wer as lawe in his degree

l.hi: For fortune as his frende wold hym obeye

div.l: ¶ He rome brente for his delicasie
The senatours he slowgh opon a daye
To her howe þat men wolde wepe and crye
And slogh his brother and by his suster laye
His moder made he in a pitous araye
For he hir wombe did slitte to be holde
Wher he 9ceyued was so weleaweye

l.hi: That he so litell of is moder tolde

div.l: ¶ No teer oute of his eyen ȝede for þᵗat sight
Ne cam but said a fair woman was sche
Grete wonder is þat he couthe or myght
Be domesman of her dede beaute
The wyne to brynge comaunded he
He dranke onone / none oþ̉er wo he made
When myght is ioyned vn to crwelte

l.hi: Allas to depe will þe venym wade

div.l: ¶ In ȝouthe a maister had þis emꝑperour
To teche hym lettur and curtasie
For of moralite he was þe Flour
As in his tyme but ȝiff bokes lye
And whils his maister had of hym maistre
He made hym so konnyng and so souple
That longe tyme is was or tiranrye

l.hi: Or eny vice in hym durste vncouple

div.l: ¶ This seneca of whiche I devise
Bi cause nero had of hym suche drede
For he for vices wolde hym chastise
Discretely as by worde and not by dede
Sir wolde he sayn an emꝑperour mot nede
Be vertuous and hate tirannie
For whiche he hym in bath made blede

l.hi: On bothe his armes til he moste deye

div.l: ¶ This Nero had eke of a custumance
In ȝowthe a ȝeyn his maist̉er for to rise
Whiche afterwarde hym thought a grete greuᵃnce
Therfor he made hym deye in þis wise
But nathelesse þis senek þe wise
Chees in a bath to deye in his maner
Rather þan han a noþ̉er turmentrie

l.hi: And þus hath nero slayn his maister der

div.l: ¶ Nowe fell it so that fortune liste no lenger
The hiegh pride of nero to cherice
For þogh he wer stronge ȝit was sche strenger
She thought þus by god I am to nyce
To sette a man þat is fulfilled of vice
In hie degree an emꝑperour hym calle
By god oute of his sete I wole hym trice

l.hi: When he leeste weneth sonnest schall he fall

div.l: ¶ The peple rose opon hym on a nyght
For his defaute and when he it a spied
Oute of his dores onone he hath hym dight
Allone and þ̉er he wende han bene alyed
He knokked faste and ay þe mor he cryed
The faster schotten þei þe dores alle
Tho wiste he wele he had hym selfe mysgyed

l.hi: And went his waye no leng dorste he calle

div.l: ¶ The peple cried and rombled up and down
That with his eeres harde he howe þei seide
Wher is þis fals traitour þis neron
For fer al moste oute of his witte he braide
And to his goddes pitously he praied
For socour bot it myȝht not be tide
For drede of þis hym thought þat he diede

l.hi: And ranne in to a gardyn hym to hide

div.l: ¶ And in þis gardyn fand he cherles tweye
That seten by a fir full grete and rede
And to þe cherles tweye he gan to preye
To sleen hym and to gurden of his hede
That to his body / whan þat he wer dede
Wer no despite y done for his diffame
Hym selfe he slowgh he coude no bett̉er rede

l.hi: Of whiche fortune lowgh and made a game

div.l: ¶ Was neuer Capitayn vnder a kynge
That reignes mor put in subieccon
Ne strenger was in felde of alle thynge
As in his tyme nor gretter of renoun
Ne mor pompouse in hiegh psumpcion
Then oliferne whiche fortune ay keste
So likorously and ledde hym up and doun

l.hi: Till þat his hede was of er þan he wiste

div.l: ¶ Nouȝht þat þis worlde hadde of hym awe
For lesynge of richesse and of liberte
Bot he made eủery man reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lorde said he
Non other god schuld Honured be
A ȝeinste his heste no wyȝht dar trespase
Sauf in bethulia a stronge cite

l.hi: Wher eliachym a preste was of þat plase

div.l: ¶ Bot take kepe of þe deth of oliphern
A mydde his ooste he dronken laye anyght
With inne his tente large as is a berne
And ȝit for al his pompe and al his myȝht
Iudith a wōmman as he lay up riȝht
Slepyng his heede of smote and fro his tente
Ful priuely sche stale from eủery wyȝht

l.hi: And aȝein to bethulie with þe hede sche wente

div.l: ¶ What nedith it of kynge antiochus
To tell his hiegh and riall mageste
His hie pride his werke venymous
For suche a nother was neủer none as he
Redeth whiche þat he was in Machabe
And redeth þe proude wordes þat he seide
And why he fell from his ꝓprosꝑperite

l.hi: And in an hall howe wrecchedly he dyede

div.l: ¶ Fortune hym hadde enhaunced so in pride
That verrely he wende he myȝht atteyne
Un to þe sterres opon eủery side
And in a balaunce to wey þe monteyn
And al þe floodes of þe see restreyn
And goddes peple hadde he moste in hate
Hem wolde he slee in torment and peyne

l.hi: Wenyng þat god ne myȝht his pride abate

div.l: ¶ And for þat Nichamour and thymothe
With Iewes wer venquished myghtily
Vn to þe Iewys suche an hate had he
That he had greithed his char ful hastifly
And swor and seide full despitously
Vn to Ihrlm he wolde eft sone
To wreke his ir on it full crwelly

l.hi: But of his purpos he was lette ful sone

div.l: ¶ God of his manace hym so sor smote
With invisible wounde ay vncurable
That in his guttes karffe so and bote
That his paynes wer inportable
And certenly þe wrecche was resonable
For meny mannes guttes did he peyn
But from his purpose cursed and dampnable

l.hi: For al his smerte he nolde hym restreyn

div.l: ¶ But bad onone apparilen his ooste
And sodenly er he was of it war
God daunted al his pride and al his boste
For he so sor fell oute of his chare
Þat he hurte his lymes and his skyn to tar
So þat he ne myȝht go ne ride
But in a Chaier men a boute hym bar

l.hi: Al for brussed both bak ande side

div.l: ¶ The wrecche of god hym smote so cruelly
That in his body wikked wermes crepte
And þ̉er with all he stank so horribly
That none of all his menȝe þat hym kepte
Wheder so þat he woke or els slepte
Ne myȝht not þe stynke of hym endur
In þis mischief he wailled and eke wepte

l.hi: And knewe god lorde of eủery creatur

div.l: ¶ To alle his ooste / and to hym selfe also
Full lothesum was þe stynke of his careyn
No man myȝht hym ber to ne froo
And in his stynke and in his horrible peyn
He starffe full wrecchedly in a mounteyn
Thus hath þis robbour ; and homicide
That mony a man made to wepe and pleyn

l.hi: Suche guerdon as bilongeth vn to pride

div.l: ¶ The story of alisaundr is so cōmmıı̄unne
That eủery wiȝht þat hath discrecion
Hath hard somwhat or al of his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusion
He wan by strenght or for his hie renoun
Thei weren glad for pees vn to hym sende
The pride of man and beste he leide a doun

l.hi: Wher so he came in to þe worldes ende

div.l: ¶ Comparison myȝht neủer be maked
Be twix hym and a nother conquerour
For al this worlde for drede of hym hath quaked
He was of knyghthode and of fredom flour
Fortune hym made þe heir of hir honour
Safe wyne and wymen no thyng myȝht a swage
¶ His hiegh entente in armes and labour

l.hi: So was he full of louing corage

div.l: What pite wer it to hym þeigh I ȝowe tolde
Of darius and an hundreth thousand moo
Of kynges princes Erles bolde
Whiche he conquered and broȝht hem in to woo
I seye as fer as man may ride or goo
The worlde was his what schuld I mor devise
For þogh I write and tolde ȝowe eủer mo

l.hi: Of his knyhthode it might not suffise

div.l: ¶ Twelf ȝer he reigned as seith machabee
Philippes son of Macedonie he was
That firste was kynge of grece þe contre
O worthy gentill alisaundr allas
That eủer schuld falle suche a caas
Enpoysened of thy folke þou wer
Thyne . v . fortune hath turned in to an aase

l.hi: And ȝit for the ne wepe sche neủer a teer

div.l: ¶ Who schall ȝeue teres men to compleyn
The deeth of gentilnesse and of fraunchise
That al þe worlde welded in his demeyne
And ȝit hym thought it myȝht not suffise
So full was his corage of hiegh emprise
Allas who schall me helpe to endite
Fals fortune and poison to despise

l.hi: The whiche twoo of al þis woo y wyte

div.l: ¶ By wysdome manhede and by labour
Fro humblehede and fro riall mageste
Vp ros he Iulius þe conquerour
That al þe occident by land and see
By strenght of hand or els by tretee
And vn to rome made hem tributarie
And sethens of rome þe emꝑperour was he

l.hi: Til þat fortune wax his aduersarie

div.l: ¶ O myȝhty cesar þat in thessalie
A ȝeinst pompeius fader thyn in lawe
That of þe orient had al þe chiualrie
As fer as þe day begynneth to dawe
Þeigh thurgh thy knyghthode hast he take and slowe
Safe fewe folke þat with pompeius fledde
Thurgh whiche þou puttest al þe orient in awe

l.hi: Thanke fortune that so wele þe spedde

div.l: ¶ But nowe a littell while I woll bewaile
This pompeius this noble gouernour
Of rome which þat sleigh at this bataill
I say one of his men a fals traytour
His hede of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and hym þe hede broght
Allas pompeye of þe oriente conquerour

l.hi: That fortune vn to suche a fine broght

div.l: ¶ To rome a ȝein repaireth Iulius
With his trihumphe laureate full hiegh
But on a tyme brutus cassius
That eủer had of his estate envie
Ful pⁱriuely he made 9spiracye
Aȝeinst þis Iulius in subtile wise
And caste þe plase in whiche he schuld deye

l.hi: With bodkyns as I schall ȝowe devise

div.l: ¶ This Iulius to þe Capitoille wente
Vp on a daye as he was wonte to gone
And in þe capitoille onone hym hente
This fals brutus and his foule foon
And stykked hym with bodkyns onon
With mony a wounde and þus þei lete hym lye
But neủer gronted he at no stroke bot one

l.hi: Or ells at two bot if þe storie lye

div.l: ¶ So manly was þis Iulius of herte
And so wele loued in stately honeste
That þof his dedly woundes so sor did smerte
His mantell oủer his hippes ȝit keste he
For no man schuld sene his priuete
And as he laye on deyng in a traunse
And wiste verrely þat dede was he

l.hi: Of honeste ȝit had he remembraunce

div.l: ¶ Lucane to þe / þis storie . I recōmmende
And to Sweten and to valerius also
That of þis storie writeth worde and ende
Nowe þat to þise grete conquerours twoo /
Fortune was firste frende and sethen a foo
No man ne truste opon his fauour longe
But haf hir in a waite eủermoo

l.hi: Witnesse on al þise conquerours stronge

div.l: ¶ This riche Cresus whilom kynge of lyde
Of whiche Cresus Cyquus sor hym dradde
Ȝit was he caught amonges al his pride
And to be brente men to þe fir hym ladde
But suche a reyn down from þe welken schadde
That slough þe fir and made hym to scape
But to be war ȝit no grace he hadde

l.hi: Til fortune on þe galwes made hym gape

div.l: ¶ When he a scaped was he can not stente
For to begynne a newe reyn aȝayn
He wende wele for þat fortune hym sente
Suche hap þat he escaped thurgh þe reyne
That of his foos he myȝht not be slayn
And swiche a sweuen vp on a nyȝht he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke fayn

l.hi: That in vengeaunce he all his herte sette

div.l: ¶ Opon a tre he was as hym thoughte
Ther Iubit̉er wesshe bothe hals ⁊and side
And phebus eke a fair towaill hym broght
To drie hym with and þ̉er for wax his pride
And to his doughter þat stode hym be side
Whiche þat he knewe in hie sentence abounde
He bad hir tell hym what it signified

l.hi: And sche his dremes began riȝht þus expownde

div.l: ¶ The tree qd sche þe galewes is to mene
And Iubiter betokeneth snowe and reyne
And phebus with his towaill so clene
Tho bene þe son stremes for to seyn
Thowe schall an hanged be Fader certeyn
Rayn schall þe wessh and son schall þe drie
Thus warned sche hym ful plat and ful playn

l.hi: His doughter þat called was phanie

div.l: ¶ An honged was Cresus þe proude kynge
His roial trone myght hym not availl
Tregedye is none other maner thynge
Ne can in synnyng crye ne be waill
Bot þat fortune al weye woll assaill
With vnwar stroke þe reignes þᵃt bene proude
For when men trusteth hir þan wol sche faill

l.hi: And kouer hir bright face with a cloude

div.l: ¶ Here endith . þe monkes . tale ;

div.note: ¶ Capliii.h.ⁱⁱⁱ
div.l: ¶ Explicit
¶ Incipit ꝓprohemni fabule legis piti ;
Oure ofte sawh wele yat ye briȝht sone
The arke of his artificiall day hadde ronne
The ferth parte and half an hour͗e and more
And yof he wer͗e not depe experte in lor͗e
He Wiste it was ye xviii daye
Off April yat is messange to may
And sawgh wele yat ye shadowe of eu͗ery tre͗e
Was as in a lengthe ye same quantite
That was ye body ercite yat caused it
And yerfor͗e by ye schadowe / he toke hys Wytte
That Phebus whiche yat schone so cler͗e and bryȝhte
Degrees was ·xlv· clombe on hight
And for yat day / as in yat latitude
It was ·x· at ye clokke he gan̄ conclude
And sothenly he pliȝht his horse a aboute
Lordynges qᵈuod he I warne ȝowe all yis route
The ferthe ꝑpartie of yis of yis day is gone
Nowe for ye loue of godde and of Seynt Iohn
Leseth no tyme as ferforth as ȝe may
Lordyngꝭes ye tyme wasteth nyȝht and daye
And stelith from hus / what priuely slepynge
And what thurgh necligence in our͗e Wakynge
As doth ye streeme yat turneth neu͗re a gayn
Descendynge from ye mownteyn in to pleyne
Wele can̄ seneke and mony a Philisophr͗e
Beweylen tyme mor͗e yan golde in Cofr͗e
For losse of catell may recouered be
But losse of tyme shendeth vs qᵈuod he
It will not come a gayn̄ with outen̄ drede
No mor͗e yan will malkyns maydenhede
Whan̄ scho hath lost it in hir͗e Wantonesse
Lat vs not / mowlen̄ yus in ydlenesse
Sir man̄ of lawe ꝙquod he / so haf ȝe blisse
Tell vs a tale onon̄ / as forwarde is
Ȝe ben̄ submitted thurgh ȝour͗e fr͗e assente
To stonden̄ in yis case at my iuggemente
Aquiteth ȝowe nowe of ȝour͗e beheste
Than haue ȝe done ȝour͗e deuer at ye leste
Oste qduod he deꝑpardieux ich assente
To breke forwarde is not myne entente
Beheste is dette and I woll holden̄ fayn̄
Al my beheste I can no bett̉re sayn̄
For swyche lawe / as a man ȝiffeth a nother wyȝhte /
He schuld hymselfe / vsen it be riȝhte
Thus wol our͗e texts but nathelesse certeyn
I can riȝht nowe no thryfty tale seyne
That Chaucer yof he can bot lewedly
On metres and in rymynge craftily
Hath saide hem in swuche ynglyssh as he can
Of olde tyme as knoweth mony a man
And if he haf not saide hem leue brother
In oo booke · he hath saide in an other
For he hath tolde of louers vp and down
Mo yan ouide made mencioıı̄un
In his epistels yat bene full olde
What sholde I tellen hem / syn they been tolde
In ȝowthe he made of Ceys and Alcion
And seith hath he spoken of eủerychon
Thise noble wyffes and yise loủers eke
Who so yat wele his large volom seke
Clepede ye seyntes legende of cupide
Ther may he seen ye large woundes wyde
Of lucresse and of babilan tisbee
The swerde of Dido for ye fals ene
The tr͗e of phillis for her͗e Demophon
The pleynt of Dyanyr͗e and of ermyoun
Off Adryan and of ysiphilee
The barreyn ysle stondynge in ye see
The dreynt leander for his erro
The teres of Elyne and eke ye woo
Of Brixhede and of ye Ladomia
The crwelte of queene medea
The litill children hangynge by ye hals
For thi Iason̄ yat was of loue so fals
Of yꝑpermistra penolope Alceste
Yoủre wyffhode he ꝯconmendeth with ye beste
But certenly no worde ne writeth he
Of yilke wikke ensample of Canace
That loued hir̉e own̄ brother synfully
Of swyche cursed stories I seye fy
Or ellis of tyro Apolloneus
Howe yat ye cursed kynge Antiochus
Birafte his dought͗er of hir͗e maydenhede
That is so horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he hir͗e threwe though ye the pauement
Ande yerfor he of full avisemente
Nolde neu͗er write in none of his sermouns
Of whiche vnkynde abhominacions
Ne I will none reherse if yat I may
Bot of my tale howe shall I do yis daye
Me were looth / be likned doutelees
To muses yat men clepen Pierides
Methamorphoseos woote what I meene
But nathelesse I recche not a bene
Thof I com͗e aft͗er hym with have we bake
I speke in prose and lat hym rymes make
And with yat worde he with a sob͗re cher͗e
Be gan his tale as ȝe schall aft͗er her͗e
¶ Incipit fabula.
O hatefull harme condicon of pouerte
With thurste with colde with honger so ꝯconfounded
To asken helpe ye shameth in yine herte
Yf you nowe aske with nede arte you so woundede
That verrey nede vnwrappith al yi wonde hid
Mawgr͗e yine hede you moste for indigence
Outher stele or begge or borowe yi despence
¶ Thou blamest Crist and seyst full bitterly
He mys deꝑparteth riches temporall
Thy neȝhbor͗e you Wyteste synfully
And seiste you haste to litell and he hath all
Parfey seist you som tyme hereken shall
When yat his taill shall brennen in ye glede
For he nouȝht helped nedefull in hir͗e nede
Herken what is ye menynge of ye wyse
Bet is to dyen̄ yan haue indigence
Thy selfe neyȝhbor͗e wele ye despise
Yf you be por͗e far͗e wele yi reuerence
Ȝit of ye wyseman take yis sentance
Alle ye dayes of por͗e men bene wykke
Be war͗e yerfore or you come in yat prikke
¶ Ȝiff you be por͗e yi brether haten ye
And all yi frendes flien fro ye ye allas
O riche Marchauntȝ full of wele be ye
O noble o prudent folke as in yis caas
Ȝour͗e bagges bens not filled with ambes aass
But with syse synk yat renneth be ȝour͗e chaunce
At Cristes masse mery may ye daunce
¶ Ȝe seken londe and see for ȝour͗e wynnynges
As wise folke yar knowen̄ al ye state
Of regnes ȝe bene faders of tydynges
As wise folke yar knowen̄ al ye state
And tales bothen̄ of pess and of debats
I wer͗e riȝht nowe of tales desolats
Ner͗e yat a marchaᵘnt gone is mony a ȝer͗e
Me taught a tale whiche yat ȝe shall her͗e
¶ In surrye whilom dwelled Acompaenie
Of chapmen̄ riche and yerto sadde and trewe
That wide wher͗e senten̄ her͗e spicerye
Clothes of golde and Satyn̄ riche of hewe
Her͗e cheffar͗e was so thrifty and so newe
That eủery wyȝht hath deynte to chaffair͗e
With hem and eke to sellen hem her͗e war͗e
Nowe fell it yat ye maisters of yat sorte
Han̄ shapen̄ hem to rome for to wende
Wer͗e it for chapmanhode or for desporte
None other message wolde yei yider sende
But comen̄ hem selfe to rome yis is ye ende
And in swuche place as thought hem Avauntage
For her͗e entente yei take her͗e herbergage
Soiourned haue yise Marchauntȝ in yat town̄
A certeyn̄ tyme as fill to hir͗e plesaunce
But so byfell yat ye excellent renoun̄
Of ye empour̉er doght̉er dame custance
Reported was with eủery circumstaunce
Fro day to daye as I shall ȝowe devise
Vn to yise surrien̄ marchauntȝ in swiche wyse
¶ This was ye comm voys of eủery man
Our̉e emꝑperour̉e of rome god hym see
A doghter he hath yat seth ye world began
To rekken als wel hir goodnesse as beautee
Nas neủer swiche another as is sche
I praye to god in honour̉e hir̉e sustane
And wolde sche wer̉e of al europe ye quene
¶ In hir̉e is hyegh beaute with oute pride
Thoȝht withoute grenehod of folye
To all hir̉e werkes vertuys hir̉e guyde
Humblesse hath slayn̄ in hir̉e al tirannye
Sho is a merour of alle curtesye
Hir͗e herte is verrey chambr͗e of holynesse
Hir͗e hande ministr͗e of fredom for Almesse
¶ And all yis voise was soith as god is trewe
But nowe to purpose lat us tʳue agayn̄
Thise marchantes han̄ don̄ fraȝht hir͗e shippes newe
And when yei hanen̄ yis blisfull mayden seyne
Home to surrey bene yei wente a gayn̄
And done her͗e nedes as yei han̄ don̄ ȝor͗e
And lyven̄ in wele I can̄ sey ȝowe no mor͗e
¶ Nowe fill it yat yise marchauntꝭes stoden̄ in gᵃrace
Off hym yat was ye sowdan̄ of surrye
For whan̄ yat yei come from eny stronge plase
He wolde of his benigne curteisie
Make hem good͗e cher͗e and besily aspie
Tydynges of sundry Remes for to ler͗e
The wondres yat yei myȝhte see or her͗e
¶ Amonges oþ͗er thynges specially
Thise Marchauntȝ han̄ hym tolde of dame custaunce
So grete noblesse in erneste ceriously
That yis sowdan hath cauȝht so grete plesaunce
To haue hir͗e figur͗e in his remembraunce
And all his luste and all his besy cure͗e
Was for to loue hir͗e whil his lyff may dur͗e
¶ ꝐParauentur͗e in ye large thilke boke
Which͗e yat cleped ye heuen̄ y writen̄ was
With sterres whan̄ yat he his birthe toke
That he forloue shuld haue his dethe allas
For in ye sterres clerer͗e yan is ye glasse
It writen̄ god wote who so couthe it rede
The deth of eủery man̄ with oute drede
¶ In sterres mony a wynt̉er yer befor͗en
Was writen̄ yᵉ deth of Ectour Achilles
Of pompe Iulius yei were born̄
The stryfe of thebes and of Hercules
Of Sampson̄ turnus and of socrates
The deth but mennꝭes wyttes ben so dull
That no wyȝht can wels rede it at ye full
¶ This sowdan̄ for his pⁱriue ꝯconsell sente
And schortly of yis mat̉er for to pase
He hath to hem declared his entente
And seide hem c̉erteyn̄ but if he myȝhte haue gᵃrace
To haue Custaunce with in a litill space
He nas but dede and charched hem in hye
To shapen̄ for his lyffe some remedye
¶ Diuerse men̄ diuerse thynges saiden̄
The argumentes custen̄ vp and doun
Mony a sotell reson̄ forthe yei leyden̄
They speken̄ of magik and abusioun
But finally as in conclusion̄
Thei can̄ not sene in yat non̄ auᵃuntage
Ne in nons other͗e weye safe mariage
¶ Than sawgh yei yer͗er in suche difficultee
Be weye of reson̄ for to speke al pleyns
Be cause yat yer was suche diuersite
Betwene hir͗e both lawes yat yei sayn̄
Thei trowe yat no cristen̄ prince wold fayn̄
Wedden̄ his childe vnder our͗e lawes so swete
That vs was tauȝht be Mahon̄ our͗e ꝓprophete
¶ And he answerde rather yan I lese
Custauce I will be cristned doutelees
I mot bene hires I may non̄ other chese
I pᵃraye ȝow holdeth ȝour͗e Argumentȝ in peese
Saueth my liffe and beeth not recchelees
To geten̄ hir͗e yat hath my lyffe in cur͗e
For in yis wo I may nat longe endur͗e
¶ What nedeth gretter dilatacioun̄
I seye be tretys ande embassatrye
And by ye Popes mediacion̄
And all ye chirche and al ye chiualrye
That in destruccion̄ of Mawmentrie
And in encrese of Cristꝭes lawe der͗e
They bene acorded so as ȝe shal her͗e
¶ Howe yat ye sowdan̄ and his baronage
And all his lieges schuld y cristened be
And he shall hase custaunce in mariage
And certeyn̄ golde I not what quantite
And herto founden̄ sufficiant sewrtee
This same acorde was sworne in eu͗ey side
Now faire Custaunce al myȝhty god ye gyde
¶ Nowe wold som͗e men̄ wayten as I gesse
That I shuld tellen̄ all ye purveance
That ye emꝑperour͗e of his noblesse
Hath shapen̄ for his dowht͗er dame custaunce
Wele may men̄ knowen̄ yat so grete ordenance
May no man̄ tellen̄ in a litill clause
As was araied for so hye a cause
¶Bysshopes ben̄ schapen̄ with hir͗e to wende
Lordes ladies knyȝhtes of renoun̄
And oy͗er folke ynowe yus is ye ende
And notified is thurgh oute ye town̄
That eủery wyȝht with greet deuocoıı̄un
Shold preye crist yat he yis mariage
Receyue in gree and spede yis viage
¶ The days is comen̄ of hir͗e deꝑpartynge
I seye ye wofull daye fatale is comen̄
That y͗e may vs no lenger taryynge
But forthwarde yei hem dresse all and some
Custance yat with sorowe is al ou͗ercom̄e
Full pale arists and dresseth hir͗e to wende
For wele sche seeth yer is non̄ other ende
¶ Allas what wonder is it yof sche wepte
That shall be sente to straunge nacioıı̄un
Fro frendes yat so tendirly hir͗e kepte
And to be bounden̄ vnder subieccioun̄
Of ons sche knoweth not his ꝯcondicioıı̄un
Husbondes ben̄ al goode and han̄ ben̄ ȝor͗e
That knowen̄ wyffes I dar͗e seye ȝowe no mor͗e
¶ Fader sche saide yi wrecched childe custaunce
Thi ȝonge doght͗er fostred vp so softe
And ȝe my moder my souereyn plesaunce
Our͗e al thyng oute take criste on lofte
Custaunce ȝour͗e child hath recōmmanded ofte
Vnto ȝour͗e grace for I shall to surrye
Ne shall I neu͗er seen̄ ȝowe mor͗e with eye
¶ Allas vn to ye barbary nacioun̄
I moste onon̄ seth it is ȝour͗e wille
But criste yat starffe for our͗e redempcoıı̄un
So ȝif me grace his hestes to fulfill
I wrecched woman no force yof I spille
Wōmmen̄ arue borne to thraldome and penᵃaunce
And to bene vnder manes gou͗ernaunce
¶ I trowe at Troye whan̄ Pirrus brak ye walsl
Or ylion̄ yat brente Thebes yat Citee
Nor rome for ye harme thurgh hanyball
That Romayns hath venquysshed tymes thr͗e
Nas y harde suche tender wepynge for pite
As in ye Chambr͗e for hir͗e deꝑpartynge
But forth scho mot whedir so scho wepe or synge
¶ O firste moeuynge crwell firmamente
With yi diurnall sweight yat crowdest aye
And hurleste all fro ye este to ye occidente
That naturelly wolde holde a nother weye
Thy crowdynge sete ye heuen̄ in swiche Araye
At ye begynnynge of yis fiers viage
That crwell Mars hath slayn̄ yis maryage
¶ Infortunat Ascendent tortuose
Of whiche ye lorde is helpelesse falle allas
Oute of his angle in to ye derkeste howse
Of mars o Ataȝir as in this caase
O feble moone vnhappy ben yi pase
Thou knett este ye ther you nart not resseynede
Ther͗e you wer͗e wele fro yennes nowe art you weyuede
¶ Inprudent emꝑperour͗e of rome Allas
Was y͗er no Philisopher͗e in all yi town̄
Is no tyme better yan other in suche case
Of viage is y͗er none eleccioıı̄un
Namely to folke of hiegh condicioıı̄un
Not whan̄ a rote is of a birthe I knowe
Allas ȝe bene to lewde or to slowe
¶ To shippe is broȝht yis wofull fair͗e mayde
Solemply with eu͗ery circumstaunce
Nowe iħuihesu Criste be with ȝowe alle sche saide
Ther nys no mor͗e but far͗e wele fair͗e custaunce
She peyneth hir͗e to make goode contenᵃaunce
And forthe I lete her͗e saillen̄ īn īn yis maner͗e
And turne I woll agayn̄ to my mater͗e
¶ The moder of ye Sowdon̄ well of vices
Aspied hath hir͗e sones pleyne entente
Howe he woll lete his olde sacrifice
And riȝht onone she for hir͗e counsell sente
And yei bene com̄e to knowe what she mente
And when̄ assembled was this folke in fer͗e
She sette hir͗e down̄ and seyde as ȝe shal her͗e
¶ Lordes qduod she ȝe knowen̄ eu͗erychon̄
Howe yat my son̄ in poynte is for to lete
The holy lawes of our͗e Aklaroun̄
Yeue be goddis messang͗er machamete
Butt one a vow to grete god I hete
The liffe schall rather oute of my body sterte
Or makametes lawe oute of myn̄ herte
¶ What shuld us tyden̄ of yis newe lawe
But thraldom̄ to our͗e bodyes and penᵃaunce
And aft͗erwarde in hell to bene drawe
For we renyede Mahoıı̄un our͗e creaunce
But lordes will ȝe maken assuraunce
As I shall seyne assentyng to· my lor͗e
And I shall make us saf for eu͗er mor͗e
¶ Thei sworen̄ and did assenten̄ eủery man̄
To lyff with hir̉e and dye and by her̉e stonde
And eủeriche in ye beste wyse he can̄
To strengthen̄ hir̉e shall all his frendes fonde
And sche hath yis emprise take on honde
Which ȝe shall her̉e as I shall devise
And to hem alle sche spak in suche wyse
¶ We shull firste feyne us cristendome to take
Colde wat̉er shall not greue us but a lite
And I shall suche a revell and feste make
That I trowe I shall ye sowdan̄ quyte
For yof his wyffe be cristnede neủer so white
She shall haue nede to wassh a waye ye rede
Thogh sche a fonte full wat̉er with hir̉e lede
¶ O sowdanesse rote of iniquite
Virago you semyram ye secounde
O ʆserpent vnder femenynete
Like to ye serpent depe in hell y bounde
O feyned wōmman̄ al yat may ꝯconfounde
Vertu and Innocence thurgh yi malice
Is bredde in ye as neste of eủery vice
¶ O sathan̄ envious syn̄ yilke daye
That you wer̉e chased from our̉e erytage
Wele knowest you to wymmen̄ ye olde waye
Thou madeste eua to brynge in seruage
Thou wilt fordone cristen̄ marage
Thyn instrument so wele a weye ye while
Makest you of wȳmmen̄ when you wilte begile
¶ This sowdanesse whome I yus blame and werye
Lete priuely her̉e counseill gone hir̉e waye
What shuld I in yus tale leng̉er tarye
She rideth to ye Sowdan̄ on a daye
And saide hym yat sche wolde renye hir̉e laye
And Cristendeme of p̉restes hondes fonge
Repentynge sche hethen̄ was so longe
¶ Besekynge hym to don̄ hir̉e yat honour
The sche moste haue ye cristen̄ folke to feste
To plesen̄ hem I will do my labour
The sowdan̄ seith I will done at ȝour̉e heste
And knelynge thanked hir̉e of yat requeste
So gladde he was he nyste what to seye
She kissed hir̉e son̄ and home sche goith hir̉e weye
¶ Arryued bene yise cristen̄ folke to londe
In surrey with a grete solempne route
And hastlishe yis Sowdan̄ sente his sonde
Firste to his moder and al to his regne a boute
And saide his wiffe was come oute of doute
And preyede hir͗e forto riden̄ agayn̄ ye quene
The honour of his reigne to sustene
¶ Grete was ye preese and riche was ye Array
Of Surreyens and Romayns met y feer͗e
The moder of ye Sowdan̄ riche and gaye
Resseyueth hir͗e with also gladde a chere
As eny moder myȝht hir͗e doght͗er deer͗e
Ande to ye nexte Cite yer be side
A softe pas soleply yei ride
¶ Nouȝt trowe I ye trihumphe of Iulius
Of whiche yat lukan maketh swiche a boste
Was rialler͗e ne mor͗e curiouse
Than̄ was ye assemble of yis blisfull ooste
But yis scorpion̄ yis wykked goiste
The sowdanesse for all hir͗e flaterynge
Caste vnder yis full mortaly to stynge
¶ The Sowdan cometh hym selfe sone aft͗er yis
So rially yat wonder is to telle
He welcomyth hir͗e with all ioye and blisse
And yus in myrthe and Ioye I lete hem dwell
The fruyte of yis mat͗er is yat I tell
When̄ tyme come men̄ thouȝht it for ye beste
That reuell stynte and men̄ gone to hir͗e reste
¶ The tyme come yis olde Sowdanesse
Ordeyned hath yis feste of ye whiche I tolde
And to ye feste Cristen̄ folke hem dresse
In generall both ȝonge and olde
Her͗e may men̄ feste and rialte be holde
And deyntes mo yan I kan̄ ȝowe devise
But all to der͗e yei boȝht it er yei did ryse
¶ O sodeyn̄ wo yat eu͗er arte successour
To werldly blysse spreynde is with bitternesse
The ende of ye ioie of our͗e worldly labour
Wo occupieth ye fyne of our͗e gladnesse
Herke yis counseill for yi sikernesse
Vpon yi gladde daye haf in yi mynde
The vnwar͗e woo or harme yat cōmmyth be hynde
¶ For shortly for to tellen̄ at oo worde
The Sowdan̄ and ye Cristen̄ eu͗eychon̄
Bene al to hewe and stykked at ye bord
But it wer͗e only Dame custaunce allone
This olde Sowdanesse Kurside krone
Hath with hir͗e frendes done yis cursed dede
For sche her͗e selfe wolde all ye cont͗re lede
¶ Ne y͗er nas surryan̄ none yat was conuertede
That of ye conseill of ye sowdan̄ woote
That he nas al to hewe er he astertede
And Custance ance hauen̄ they take onon̄ foote hoote
And in a Ship al sterelees god woot
Thei hauen̄ hir͗e settre and bidden̄ hir͗e lerne saile
Oute of surrey agaynwarde to ytale
¶ A certeyn̄ tresour yat sche yider ladde
And sothe to seyne vitaille grete plente
Thei hauen hir͗e ȝeuen̄ and clothes eke sche hadde
And forth sche saillede in ye salte see
O my custaunce full of benignite
O emꝑperours ȝonge doȝht͗er der͗e
He yat is lord ou͗er fortune be yi ster͗e
¶ She blessith hir͗e with full pytous voys
Vn to ye crosse of Criste yus saith sche
O cler͗e o welefull Aut͗er holy croys
Reede of ye lambes blode full of pite
That wasshe ye worlde fro ye olde iniquite
Me fro ye fende and from his clawes kepe
That yat I shall drenche in ye depe
¶ Victorious tr͗e proteccion̄ of trewe
That only worthy wer͗e for to ber͗e
The kynge of heuen with his woundes newe
The white lambe yat hurte was with a sper͗e
Flemer of fendes oute of hym and her͗e
On whiche yi lynes faithfully extenden̄
Me kepe and ȝiff me myȝht my lyffe to Amenden̄
¶ Ȝeeres and daies fleeted yis creatur͗e
Thurgh oute ye see of grece vnto ye strayte
Of Marroke as it was hir͗e auentur͗e
O mony a sory mele nowe may sche bayte
Aft͗er hir͗e dethe full ofte may sche wayte
Or yat ye wilde walles will hir͗e dryve
Vn to ye place y͗er sche shall arryue
Men̄ myȝhten̄ axen why sche was not slayne
Eke at ye feste who myȝht hir͗e body saue
I answer͗e to yat demande a ȝeyne
Who saued Daniell in ye horrible Caue
The eu͗ery wight saue he· maist͗er and knaue
Was with ye lyouns frette or a sterte
No wyȝht but god yat he bar͗e in his herte
¶ God lieste to scheve wonderfull miracle
In hir͗e for scho shuld seen̄ his myȝhty werke
Criste whiche yat is of eu͗e harme treacle
By certeyn̄ menes ofte as knowen̄ clerkes
Doth thynges for certeyn̄ ende yat full derke is
To mannys wytts yat for our͗e ignoraunce
Ne konne not knowe his prudente pᵘurueaunce
¶ Nowe seth sche was not at ye feste y slawe
Who kepte hir͗e fro ye drenchynge in ye see
Who kepte Ionas in ye Fysshes mawe
Til he was spowted up at Niniue
Wele may men̄ knowe it was no wyȝht but he
That kepte ye peple ebraike from her͗e drenchynge
With drye feete thurgh oute ye see passynge
¶ Who badde ye four͗e spirites of tempeste
That power hauen̄ to Anoyen̄ both londe and see
Both northe and southe and also weste and este
Anoyeth neither see lande guer tr͗e
Sothely ye Somandour of yat was he
That fro ye tempeste ay yis wōmman̄ kepte
Als wele when̄ sche woke as when̄ sche slepte
¶ Wher͗e myȝhte yis wōmman̄ mete and drynke haue
Thr͗e ȝeer͗e and mor͗e howe lasteth her͗e vitaill
Who fedde ye egipcien̄ mary in ye caue
Or in deserte noȝt but Criste sanȝ faille
V. thousand folke it was as grete mervaille
With loues fyfe and fysshes two to fede
God sente his foyson̄ at hir͗e grete nede
¶ She driveth forth ou͗re in to occean̄
Thurgh oute ye wilde see till at ye laste
Vnder an hold yat neuenen̄ I ne kan̄
For in Northumberlande ye wawe hir͗e caste
And in ye sonde hir͗e schippe stykked so faste
That yeues wolde it not of all a tyde
The will of Criste was yat sche shuld abide
¶ The constable of ye Castell doun is far͗e
To seen yis wrakke and all ye schippe he soȝhte
And fonde yis wary woman̄ full of Car͗e
He fonde also ye tresour͗e yat sche brought
In hir͗e langage mercy sche besoȝhte
The lyffe oute of hir͗e body for to twynne
Her͗e to deliuer of woo yat sche was Inne
¶ A maner latyn corupte was hir͗e speche
The Constable whan hym luste no lenger seche
This wofull wōmman̄ broȝhte he to ye londe
She kneleth down̄ and thanked goddes sonde
But what sche was sche wolde no man̄ seye
For foule ne fair͗e yof yat sche shulde dye
¶ She saide sche was so mased in ye see
That sche forgat hir͗e mynde be her͗e trowthe
The Constable hath of hir͗e so grete pite
And eke his wyffe yat yei wepten̄ for routhe
She was so diligent with outen̄ slowthe
To ʆserue and plese eu͗eryche in yat plase
That all hir͗e loueden̄ yat loked on hir͗e face
¶ The Constable and Dame Ermechilde his wyffe
Wer͗e panyins and yat Cont͗re eu͗ery wher͗e
But Hermengilde loued hir͗e riȝht as hir͗e lyffe
And Custaunce hath so longe soiournede yer͗e
In orisons with mony a bitter teer͗e
Till IħuIhesu hath ꝯconuerted thurgh his grace
Dame Ermengilde Constablesse of yilke plase
¶ In all yat lande dorste no Cristen̄ route
All cristen̄ folke ben̄ fledde from yat cont͗re
Thurgh paynyins yat conquereden̄ her͗e a bowte
The plages of ye North be londe and see
To Wales fledde ye Cristyainte
Of olde Bretons dwellynge in yis yslee
Ther was hir͗e refute for ye mene whilee
¶ But ȝit nas neu͗er Cristen̄ bretons so exiled
That y͗er nas some in hir͗e priuete
Honoured criste and hethen folke begiled
And nyȝht ye Castell swiche y͗er dwelleden̄ thr͗e
That one of hem was blynde and myȝht not see
But it wer͗e with yilke eyen̄ of his mynde
With whiche men̄ seen̄ aft͗e yat yei bene blynde
¶ Briȝht was yat sone as in yat som͗ers daye
For whiche ye Constable and his wyffe also
And custance han ytake ye riȝht waye
To warde ye see a furlonge weye or two
To pleyen ande to romen̄ to and froo
And in hir͗e walkyng yr͗e blynde men̄ yei mete
Croked and olde with faste eyn̄ y sthette
¶ In ye name of Criste crede this blynde briton̄
Dame Hermengilde ȝeue me sight agayne
This lady waxe affrayede of ye sowne
Leste yat hir͗e husbonde schortly for to seyn
Wolde hir͗e for IħuIhesu Cristes loue haf slayn
Till Custance made hir͗e bolde and bad hir͗e wyrche
The will of Criste as dought̉er of his chirche
¶ The Constable wax abaste al of yat syȝhte
And saide what amounteth all yis faar̉e
Custance answerd sir̉e it is Cristes myȝhte
That helpeth folke oute of ye fendys snar̉e
And so ferforth scho gan̄ our̉e laye declar̉e
That sche ye constable or yat it was euen
Conủerted and on criste made hym beleuen̄
¶ This Constable was no thynge lorde of yis plase
Of whiche I speke ỷer he custaunce fonde
But kepte it strongly mony a wynt̉er space
Vndir alla kyng of al Northumberlande
That was full wyse and worthy of his honde
A gan̄ ye scottes as men̄ may wele here
But turne I wile a gayn̄ to my mater̉e
¶ Sathan̄ yat eủer us waiteth forto begile
Sagh of Custance al hir̉e ꝑperfeccioun̄
And caste onon howe he myȝht quyte her̉e while
And made a ȝong knyȝht yat dwelled in ye town̄
Loue hir̉e so hote of foule affeccion̄
That verrely hym thoughte he shuld spille
But he of hir̉e myȝhte ones haf his wylle
¶ He woweth hir̉e but it availleth noȝte
She wolde do no synne by no weye
And for despite he compassed in his thoȝht
To maken hir̉e on shameful dethe to dye
He wayteth when̄ the Constable was a weye
And priuely opon a nyȝht he crepte
In Hermengildes chambre wher̉e sche slepte
¶ Wery for waked in hir̉e orisons
Slepeth Custaunce and hermēngilde also
This knyȝhte thurgh Sathanas temptacions
All soft ely is to bedde y goo
And kutte ye throte of Hermengilde a twoo
And leyde ye blody knyffe be dame Custaunce
And wente his weye ỷer god ȝiff hym myschance
¶ Sone aft̉er cometh yis Constable home a gayn̄
And eke Alla· yat kynge was of yat lande
And sawgh his wyffe despitousliche ·y· slayne
For whiche full ofte he wetpe and wronge his hande
And in ye bedde ye blody knyff he fonde
By Dame Custauce Allas what myȝhte sche saye
For verrey woo hir̉e wytte was al a weye
To kynge Alla was tolde all yis myschaunce
And eke ye tyme and wher͗e and in what wyse
That in a schippe was founden̄ yis custaunce
As her͗e beforne ȝe han̄ herd eer͗e deuyse
The kynges herte of pyte gan a grise
Whan he seith so benigne a creature
Falle in disese and in mysauentur͗e
¶ For as ye lombe to ward his deth is broȝhte
So stante yis Innocente be for ye kynge
This fals knyȝht yat hath yis treson̄ wroȝhte
Berith hir͗e an hande yat sche hath do yis thynge
But nathelesse y͗er was grete mornynge
Amonge ye peple and sey yei kan̄ not gesse
That sche had done so grete a wykkednesse
¶ For yei haue seyne her͗e euer so vertuose
And loffynge ermengild riȝht as her lyffe
Of yis bar͗e wytnes eu͗eryche in yat howse
Saf he yat Hermēngild slowgh with his knyffe
This gentill kynge hath kauȝht a grete motyfe
Of yise wytnesse and thouȝht he wolde enquer͗e
Depper͗e in yis case a trouthe for to ler͗e
¶ Allas Custaunce thou ne hast no champioun̄
Ne fiȝht kanst you not so wale waye
But he yat for our͗e redempcioıı̄un
And bond sathan and lieth in y͗er he lay
So be yi stronge champion̄ yis daye
For but if criste open ye miracle kythe
With outen gilte you shall bene slayn̄ als swythe
¶ She sette hir͗e doun on knees and yus sche saide
Immortale god yat sauedest Susanne
From fals blame and you mercyfull mayde
Marie I mene doȝht͗e to seynte Anne
Be forne her child Aungells synge osanne
If I be giltles of yis felonye
My socoʳur be .or els I shall deye
¶ Haf ȝe not sene somtyme a pale face
Amonge a preese of hym yat hath be ladde
Toward his dethe wher͗e as hym gete no grace
And swiche a colour͗e in his face hath had
Men̄ myȝht knowe his face yat was by stadde
Amonges alle ye faces in yat route
So stante custance and loketh hir͗e abowte
¶ O queenes lyffynge in prosꝑperite
Duchesses and ye ladyes eu͗erichone
Haue sōe rewthe on hir͗e aduersitee
An emꝑperours doȝht͗er stante allone
She hath no wyȝht to whome to make hir͗e mone
O bloode reall yat stondest in yis drede
Fer bene yi frendes at yi grete nede
¶ This Alla ye kynge hath swiche compassioıı̄un
As gentill herte is fulfilled of pyte
That from his eyen̄ ranne ye wat̉re a doun̄
Nowe Hastiliche do fecche a booke qduod he
And ȝiff yis knyȝht will swer͗e howe yat sche
This woman slowe ȝit will we us avise
Whome yat we wolde yat shall be oủre Iustise
¶ A briton̄ booke writen̄ with euᵃaungiles
Was fete and on yus boke he swor͗e onon̄
She giltiff was In yis mene whiles
An hand hym smote opon ye nekke bone
That down̄ he fell at ones as a stone
And both his eyen̄ bruste oute of his face
In siȝht of eủrey body in that place
¶ A voys was harde in generall audience
And saide you haste disclaundred giltlees
The dought̉er of holy chirche in hiegh presence
Thus hast you don̄ and ȝit I mot holde my pees
Of yis meruaille a gaaste was all ye prees
As maȝed folke yei stoden̄ eủerychone
For drede of wrecche saue custance allone
¶ Grete was ye drede ande eke ye repentaunce
Off hem yat hadden̄ wronge suspesioun̄
Opon yis sely Innocent custaunce
And for yis miracle in conclusioun̄
And by custaunce mediacioıı̄un
The kynge and mony another in yat place
Conuerted was thonked be cristes grace
¶ This fals knyȝht was slayne for his vntrowthe
By Iuggement of kyng Alla hastifly
And ȝit Custaunce hath of his dethe grete Routhe
And aft̉er yis IħcIhesu of his mercy
Made Alla wedden̄ full solemply
This holy mayden̄ yat is so briȝht and schene
And yus hath Criste made Custance a quene
¶ But who was wofull if I schuld not lye
Of yis weddynge but Donegilde and no moo
The kynges moder full of tyrannye
Hir thoȝht hir͗e cursed herte braste a twoo
She wold not hir͗e sone hadde done soo
Hir͗e thoȝht despute yat he schuld take
So straunge a creatur͗e vnto his make
¶ Me liste not of ye chaff ner of ye stree
Make so longe a tale as of ye corne
What shuld I tellen̄ of ye ryalte
Of mariage or whiche cours gotth beforne
Who bloweth in trompe or in an horne
The fruyte of eủery tale is for to seye
Thei ete and drynke and daunce and synge and pleye
¶ Thei gone to bedde as it was skil and riȝht
For though yat wyffes bene full holy thynges
Thei moste take a pacience a nyȝhte
Swiche man̉er necessaries as bene plesynges
To folke yan hauen̄ y wedded hem wyth rynges
And leye a lite yeir holynes beside
As for ye tyme it may non̄ other betyde
¶ On hir͗e he gat a knaue childe onon̄
And to a Busshope and his constable eke
He tooke his wyffe to kepe when̄ he schuld gone
To scotlonde warde his fomen̄ for to seeke
Nowe fair͗e Custance yat is so humble and meke
So longe is gone with childe yat scho kepte hir͗e stylle
And holde her͗e chambr͗e Abydynge at Cristꝭes will
¶ The tyme is cōe a knaue childe sche ber͗e
Mauricius at ye fontstone yei hym calle
This Constable doith forth come a messanger
And wrote to hys kynge yat cleped was Alle
Howe yat yis blisfull tydyng is be fall
And other tydynges spedfull for to seye
He takith ye lett̉er and forth he gotth his weye
¶ This messang̉er to done his avantage
Vn to ye kynges moder rideth swythe
And salweth hir͗e full fair͗e in his langage
Madame qduod he ȝe may be gladde and blithe
And thonketh god an hundreth thousand sythe
My lady quene hath childe with oute doute
To Ioye and blisse of all yis reigne a boute
¶ Lo her͗e ye letters seled of yis thynge
That I mote ber͗e with all ye haste I may
If ȝe will ouȝht vn to ȝour͗e son̄ ye kynge
I am ȝour͗e seruᵃaunt both nyȝht and daye
Dowgild answerde as nowe at yis tyme nay
But her͗e al nyȝht I will yat you take yi reste
To morowe will I seye what me leste
¶ This messang̉er dranke sadly ale and wyne
And stolne wer͗e his letters pⁱriuely
Out of his box whil he sleepe as a swyn̄
And countrefeted was full subtily
And another łletre wrote full synfully
Vn to ye kynge directe of yis mater͗e
Fro his ꝯconstable as ȝe shall aft̉er her͗e
¶ The letter spake ye quene deliuered was
Of so horrible a fendliche creatur͗e
That in ye Castell none so hardy was
That eny while durste ỷer in endur͗e
The moder was an Elfe by auentur͗e
Y come be charmes or by sorcery
And eủery wiȝht hateth hir͗e companye
¶ Wo was this kynge whan̄ he yis lettr͗e had seyne
But to no wyȝht he tolde his sorowes sor͗e
But of his own̄ honde he wrote agayn̄
Welcome be ye sonde of Criste for eủer mor͗e
To me yat am nowe lerned in his lore
Lorde welcome be ỷer luste and yi plesaunce
My luste is putte alle in yine ordenᵃaunce
¶ Kepith yis childe al be it foule or fair͗e
And eke my wyffe vn to myn̄ home ꝯconmynge
Criste whan hym lyste may send me an eyr͗e
Mor͗e agreable yan yis is to my lykynge
This lett̉re he seleth priuely wepynge
Whiche to ye messanger was taken sone
Forth he goith ỷer is no mor͗e to done
¶ O messanger fulfilled of dronkenesse
Stronge is yi breth yi lymmes faltren̄ aye
And you bewreieste alle sikerenesse
Thi mynde is lorne you iangeliste as a Iaye
Thy face is tᵘurned in a newe araye
Ther dronkenes reigneth in eny route
Ther nys no ꝯconsell hidde withouten doute
¶ O Donegild I ne haf non̄ ynglyssh digne
Vnto yi malice and yi tirannye
And ỷerfor to ye fende I ye resigne
Lat hym enditen of yi traitorie
Fy manyssh fy o nay be god I lye
Fy fendliche spirit for I dar͗e wele tell
Thoff you her͗e walke yi spirit is in hell
¶ This messang̉er comyth from ye kynge agayn̄
And at ye kyngꝭes moders courte he liȝhte
And sche was of yis messanger full fayn
And plesed hym in alle yat eủer sche myȝhte
He dranke and wele his girdell vndir pyȝhte
He slepith and he fuorteth in his gise
All nyȝht till ye sone be gan to arise
¶ Efte wer͗e his lett̉ers stolne eủerichon̄
And contirfeted lett̉ers in yis wise
The kynge ꝯconmandeth his ꝯconstable onon̄
Vp peyn of hangynge and of hie Iwyse
That he ne shulde suffr͗e in no wyse
Custance with in his reigne to abide
Thr͗e daies and a quart̉er of a tyde
¶ But in ye same schip as he hir͗e fonde
Hir͗e and hir͗e ȝonge sone and al hir͗e ger͗e
He shuld putte and crowde fro ye londe
And charche hir͗e yat sche neủer efte come yer
O my Custance wel may yi goste haf fer͗e
And slepynge in yi dreme bien in penᵃaunce
When̄ Donegild caste all yis ordinᵃaunce
¶ This messang̉er on morowe when he wooke
Vn to ye Castell he halte ye nexte waye
And to ye Constable he ye lett̉er toke
And when yat he yis pytous łletre say
Full ofte he saide allas and welewey
Lorde criste qduod he howe may yis łletre endur͗e
So full of synne is mony a creatur͗e
¶ O myȝhty god if yat it be yi wille
Seth you art riȝhtfall Iugge howe may it be
That you wolt suffren̄ Innocentꝭes to spille
And wikkede folke reignen in prosꝑperite
O goode Custance allas so wo is me
That I mot be yi tormentour or dye
On schames dethe ỷer is non̄ other weye
¶ Thei wepten̄ both olde and ȝonge in al yis place
Whan̄ yat ye kynge yis cursed lett̉er sente
And Custance with a dedly pale face
The ferthe day towarde hir͗e schip sche wente
But nathelesse sche taketh in goode entente
The wille of Criste and knelynge mye stronde
She saide lorde ay welcome be yi sonde
¶ He yat me kepte fro ye fals blame
Whil I was on ye londe amangꝭes ȝowe
He kan̄ me kepe from harme and eke from schame
In salte se all yof I se not howe
Als stronge as eủer he was he is riȝht nowe
In hym triste I and in his moder der͗e
That is to me my saile and eke my ster͗e
¶ Hir͗e litill Childe lay wepynge in hir͗e arme
And knelȳng pytously to hym scho seide
Pees litill sone I will do ye none harme
With yat hir͗e con̉erchiefe of hir͗e hede sche braide
And oủer his litill eyen̄ sche it layde
And in hir͗e arme sche lullith it full faste
And in to heuen̄ hir͗e eyen̄ up sche caste
¶ Moder qduod sche and mayde bryȝht Marye
Sothe it is yat thurgh wōmmanes eggemente
Mankynde was lorne and dampned ay to dye
For whiche yi childe was on a crosse y rente
Thy blesfull eyen̄ sagh al his turmente
Than is ỷer no ꝯconparisoıı̄un betwene
Thy woo and eny woo man̄ may sustene
¶ Thou sawgh yi sone y slayne be for yine eyen̄
And ȝit nowe liffeth my litill child ꝑparfay
Nowe lady briȝht to whome al wofull cryen̄
Thou glorie of wōmmanhede you fair͗e may
Thou haue of refute briȝht sterr͗e of daye
Rewe on my my childe yat of yi gentilnesse
Rewest on eủery rewfull in distresse
¶ O litill childe allas what is yi gilte
That neủer wroȝhteste synne as ȝit ꝑparde
Why will yine harde fader haf ye spilte
O mercy der͗e Constable qduod sche
As lat my litill child dwell her͗e with ye
And ȝiff you darrest not sauen̄ hym from blame
So kysse hym ones in his faders name
¶ Ther with scho loked bacwarde to ye londe
And seide far͗e wele husbonde rewtheles
And up sche riste and walketh doun̄ ye stronde
Towarde ye schip hir͗e foloweth all ye preese
And eủer sche pᵃrayeth her childe to holde his peese
And taketh hir͗e leve and with an holy entente
She blisseth hir͗e and in to schippe sche wente
¶ Vitailled was ye schip it is no drede
Haboundantly for hir͗e full longe space
And ỏery necessaries yat schuld nede
She had ynowe heried be goddes grace
For wynde and wedir almyȝhty god pᵘurchase
And brynge hir͗e home I can no bett̉er seye
But in ye see sche driveth forthe hir͗e waye
¶ Alla ye kynge comyth home sone aft̉er yis
Vn to his castell of ye whiche I tolde
And axeth wher͗e his wyffe and his childe is
The constable gan̄ a boute his herte colde
And pleynly all ye maner͗e he hym tolde
As ȝe han̄ herde I kan tell it no bett̉er
And scheweth ye kynge his sele and his lett̉er
¶ And seide lorde as ȝe cōmmanded me
Opon peyn̄ of deth so haf I done certeyn̄
This messang̉er turmented was til he
Moste beknowen̄ and tellen plat and pleyn̄
From nyȝht to nyȝht in what plase he had leyen̄
And yus be wyt and by subtile enquerynge
Ymagined was by whome yis harme gan sprynge
¶ The honde was knowe yat ye lett̉er wroote
And alle ye venym of yis cursed dede
But in what wise certenly I not
The effecte is yis yat Alla oute of drede
His moder slowe yat may men̄ pleynly rede
For yat sche traitour was to hir͗e licheaunce
Thus endith olde Donegild with myschaunce
¶ The sorowe yat yis Alla nyȝht and daye
Maketh for his wyffe and for his child also
Ther is no tonge yat it tell may
But nowe woll I to custaunce goo
That fletith in ye see in peyne and woo
V· ȝer͗e and mor͗e as liked Cristes sonde
Er yat hir͗e schip approched to eny londe
¶ Vnder an hethen castell at ye laste
Of whiche ye name in my texte noȝt I fynde
Custaunce ande eke hir͗e childe ye see up caste
Almyȝhty god yat saueth al man̄ kynde
Haue on custaunce and hir͗e childe som̄ mynde
That fallen is in hethen̄ honde efte sone
In poynte to spill as I schall tell ȝowe sone
¶ Doun fro ye castell comyth yer mony a wiȝhte
To gawren̄ on yis schip and on custaunce
But shortly fro ye Castell on a nyȝht
The lordes stiwarde god ȝif hym myschaunce
A theef yat had renyed our͗e creaunce
Come in to schip allone and seide he shulde
Hir͗e lēmman be wher so scho wolde or nolde
¶ Woo was yis wrecched wōmman yo begone
Her child criede and sche criede pitouslye
But blisfull marie halp hir͗e riȝht onon
For with hir͗e strogelynge wele and myȝhtyly
The thefe fell our̉re ye borde al sodenly
And in ye see he dreynte for vengeaunce
And yus vnwēmmed hath criste kepte custaunce
¶ O foul luste of luxurie loo yine ende
Not only yat you fayntest mannes mynde
But verrelly you wolt his Body schende
The ende of yi werke or of yi lustes blynde
Is ꝯconnpleynyng howe mony one may men̄ fynde
That not for werke somtyme but for ye entente
To done yis synne bene either slayn or schente
¶ Howe may yis waike woman hauen yis threnȝthe
Hir͗e to defende agayn̄ yis renegate
O golias vnmesurable of lengthe
How myȝhte Dauid make ye so mate
So ȝonge and of armur so desolate
How dorste he looke up on yi dredfull face
Wele may men seen it was but goddes grace
¶ Who ȝaf Iudith corage or hardinesse
To sleen hym olophernes in his tente
And to delyueren oute of wrecchednes
The peple of god I seye for yis entente
That riȝht as god spirit of vigoᵘur sente
To hem and saued hem oute of myschance
So sent he myȝht and vigor to custance
¶ Forth gotth hir͗e schipe thurgh on the narwe mouthe
Of Iubaltar and septe dryuyng ay
Somtyme weste and somtyme north and southe
And somtyme Este full mony a wery way
Til Crists moder blessed be be sche ay
Hath schapen thurgh hir͗e endles goodnesse
To make an ende of all hir͗e heuynesse
¶ Now lat us stynte of Custance but a throwe
And speke we of ye romayn̄ emꝑperour
That oute of Surrey hath be lett̉ers y knowe
The slaughtre of cristen folk and dishonoᵘur
Don̄ to his doght̉er by a fals traitour
I mene ye cursed wykked sowdonesse
That at ye feste lete sleen both mor͗e and lesse
¶ For ye whiche yis Emꝑperour hath sente onon
His senatour with ryall ordenᵃaunce
And oỷer lordes god wote mony one
On Surryens to taken hys vencheance
Thei brenen sleen and bryngen hem to myschance
Full mony a day but shortly yis is ye ende
Homwarde to rome yei schapen hem to wende
¶ This senatour repaireth with victorie
To rome warde saillynge full ryally
And mette ye schipe dryvyng as seith ye storie
In whiche Custance satte full pitously
No thynge ne knewe he what sche was ne why
She was in cyche aray ne sche nyll saye
Of hir͗e astate though sche shulde deye
¶ He bryngeth hir͗e to rome and to his wyffe
He ȝaff hir͗e and hir͗e ȝonge son̄ also
And with ye senator sche ladde her͗e lyffe
Thus kan̄ our͗e lady bryngen̄ oute of woo
Woofull Custaunce and mony an other moo
And longe tyme dwelled sche in yat place
In holy werkes eủer as was hir͗e grace
¶ The senatours wyff hir͗e Awnte was
But for al yat sche knewe hir͗e neủer ye mor͗e
I will no leng̉er tarien in yis case
But to kynge Alla whiche I spak of ȝor͗e
That for his wyffe wepyth and siȝheth sor͗e
I woll retorne and lete I will custaunce
Vnder ye senatours gouernance
This senatourys wif hyre aıı̄unte was
¶ Kyng Alla whiche yat hadde his moder slayn
Vpon a day fill in swiche repentance
That ȝiff I schall shortly tellen̄ and pleyne
To rome he comyth to resseyuen̄ his penᵃaunce
And putte hym in ye Popes ordenᵃaunce
In hie and lowe and IħuIhesu Criste besoȝhte
For ȝif hym his wikkede werkes yat he wroȝhte
¶ The fame onon̄ thurgh rome town̄ is borne
Howe Alla ye kyng schall yider comen̄ in pilgⁱrimage
By herberiours yat wenten̄ hym beforne
For whiche ye senatour as was vsage
Rode hym ȝeyn̄ agayns and mony of his lynage
Als wele to schewen̄ his magnificence
As to done eny kynge a reủerence
¶ Grete cher͗e dotth yis noble senatour
To kynge Alla and he to hym also
Eueriche of hēm dotth oỷer gret honoᵘur
And so bi fell yat in a day or two
This senatour is to kynge Alla go
To feste and shortly ȝiff I schall not lye
Custaunces son̄ in. his companye
¶ Som men̄ wolde seyne at requeste of Custance
This senatour hath ladde yis childe to feste
I may nat tellen̄ euerich circumstaunce
Be as be may ỷer was he at ye leste
But soth it is yat at his moders heste
Beforne Alla durynge ye metes space
The child stoode lokyng in ye kynges face
¶ This Alla kynge hath of ye Childe grete wonder
And to ye senatour he said onon̄
Whos is yat fair͗e childe yat stondeth ȝonder
I not qduod he by god and by seynt Iohn
A moder he hath but fader hath he none
That I of wote and shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla yat yis childe was founde
¶ But god wote qduod yis senatour also
So vertuos a liffer in my lyffe
Ne sawe I neủer as sche ne harde of moo
Of worldly women mayde ne of wyffe
I dar wele sayn̄ sche had leủer a knyffe
Thurgh oute hir͗e brest yᵃn bene a wōmman wykke
Ther is no man̄ couthe brynge hir͗e to yat prykke
¶ Nowe was yis Childe as like vnto Custaunce
As possible as a creatur͗e to be
This Alla hath ye face in remēmbraunce
Of dame Custaunce and ỷer on mused he
Ȝiff yat ye childe moder were ought sche
That is his wyffe and pⁱriuely he sighte
And spedde hym fro ye table yat he myȝhte
¶ ꝐParfay he thou thouȝht ye fantom̄ is in my heuede
I ought demen̄ of skilfull iuggement
That in the salte see my wif is deed
And aft̉er warde he made his argumente
What wote I ȝif yat crist hath hider sente
My wif by See as wel as he hir sente
To my contr͗e fro thennes yat sche wente
¶ And aft̉er none home with ye Senatoᵘur
Gotth Alla for to sene yis wonder chaıı̄unce
This senatour dotth Alla grete honour
And hastily he sente aft̉er Custaunce
But tristeth wele her luste not to Daunce
When̄ yat sche wyste whar͗e fore was yᵗ sonde
Vnnethes opon̄ hir͗e fete sche myȝht stonde
¶ Whan Alla saugh his wyffe fair͗e he hir͗e grette
And wepte yat it was rowthe to see
For at ye firste loke he on hir͗e sette
He knewe wele verrely yat it was sche
And for sorowe as dombe stante as a tr͗e
So was hir͗e herte schette in hir͗e distresse
Whan sche remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies sche swowned in his owene siȝhte
He weepeth and hym excuseth pitously
Now god qduod he and his halwes briȝhte
So wysly on my soule as haue mercy
That of ȝour͗e harme als giltlesse am I
As is Maurye my sone so like ȝour͗e face
Elles ye fende me fecche oute of yis place
¶ Longe was ye sobbynge and ye bitter peyne
Er yat hir͗e wooful hertes myghten̄ cesse
Grete was ye pite for to her͗e hem pleyne
Thurgh whiche pleyntes gan̄ hir͗e wo encrese
I pray ȝow all my labour͗e to relese
I may not tellen hir͗e woo vntill to morwe
I am so wery to speken of hir͗e sorowe
¶ But finally when̄ yat ye sothe was wyste
That Alla giltlesse was of hir͗e woo
I trowe an. C tymes ben yei kyssede
And suche a blisse is ỷer betwix yam twoo
That saue ye Ioye yat lasteth eủermoo
Ther is non like yat eny creatur͗e
Hath seyne or schall whill ye worlde may dur͗e
¶ Tho preyed sche hir͗e housbonde mekely
In relefe of hir͗e longe pytous peyne
That he wolde pray her fader specially
That of his mageste he wolde enclyne
To fouche saue som daye with hym to dyne
She preied hym eke he schuld be no weye
Vn to hir͗e fader no worde of hir͗e seye
¶ Som men̄ wolde seyn̄ howe yat ye childe Maurice
Dotth yis message vn till yis em ꝑperour
But as I gesse Alla was not so nyce
To hym yat was of so souereyn̄ honour
As he yat is of Cristen̄ folke ye flour
Sente any childe but it is bette to deme
He went hym selfe and so it may wele seme
¶ This Emꝑperour hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyner as he hym besought
And wele rede I he loked besily
Vpon yis Childe and on his dought̉er thoȝhte
Alla gotth to his Inne as hym ouȝhte
Arraied for yis feste in eủery wyse
Als ferforth as his konnynge may suffise
¶ The morowe come and Alla gan̄ hym dresse
And eke his wyffe yis emꝑperour for to mete
And forthe yei ride in Ioye and in gladnesse
And when̄ sche sawgh hir͗e fader in ye strete
She liȝhteth doun and falleth hym to fete
Fader qduod she youre yonge child Custaunce
Is nowe full clene oute of ȝour͗e remembraunce
¶ I am ȝour͗e doght̉er Custaunce qduod sche
That whilom ȝe sente vnto surrye
It am I fader yat in ye salte see
Was putte allone and dampned for to dye
Nowe goode fader mercy I ȝowe crye
Sende me no mor͗e vnto noon to hethenesse
But thonke my lord her͗e of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can̄ ye pitous Ioye tellen̄ alle
Betwix hem thr͗e sen yei bene yus y mette
But of my tale make an ende I schall
The day gotth faste I will no lenger lette
This glad folke to dyner yei hem sette
In ioye and blisse at mete I let hem dwell
A thousand folde wele mor͗e yan I can̄ tell
¶ This childe Maurice was sethen emꝑperour
Made by ye pope and lissed cristianly
To Cristis Chirche he did grete honour
But I lete all his story passen̄ by
Off Custance is my tale specially
In olde romeyn̄ gestes may men̄ fynde
Maurice lyffe I ber͗e it noght in mynde
¶ This kynge Alla when̄ he his tyme say
With Custaunce his holy wyffe so swete
To ynglonde ben they come the righte weye
lyffe in ioye and in quyete
But while it lasteth I ȝowe hete
Io worlde for tyme will not abide
Fro o nyȝhte it chaunheth as ye tyde
¶ Who fed eủer in swiche delite a daye
That ne meued either ꝯconscience
Or ir͗e or talent or som mauer of fraye
Envie or pride or passion̄ or offense
I ne saye but for yis ende yis sentence
That litell while in ioye or in plesaunce
Lasteth ye blisse of Alla with custaunce
¶ For deeth yat taketh of heigh and lowgh his rente
When̄ passed was a ȝer͗e euen̄ as I gesse
Oute of yis worlde this kynge Alla he hente
For whome Custance hath full grete heuynesse
Nowe lat us prayen̄ god his soule to blesse
And Dame Custaunce finally to seye
Towarde ye town̄ of rome gotth hir͗e waye
¶ To Rome is com̄ this holy creatur͗e
And fyndeth her frendes hoole and sownde
Nowe is sche skaped al hir͗e auenture
And whan sche hir͗e fader hath y founde
Doun̄ on hir͗e knees falleth sche to grounde
epynge for tendrenesse in herte blithe
She blisseth god an C thousand sythe
¶ In vertue and holy Almes dede
Thei liffen̄ alle and neủer a sundr͗e wende
Til dethe deꝑparte hem yis lyff yei lede
And fareth nowe wele my tale is at an ende
Nowe iħuihesu Criste yat of his myȝht may sende
Ioye aft̉er woo goủer ne us in his grace
And kepe all yat bene in yis place
¶ Here begynneth ye prologe of ye Squier͗e
Our ooste vpon his stiroppes stode onon̄
And saide goodmen̄ herkeneth eủerichon̄
This was a thryfty tale for ye nones
Sir parissh pⁱriste qduod he for goddes bones
Tell us a tale as was yi forwarde ȝore
I see wele yat ȝe lerned men̄ in lore
Can muche goode be goddes dignitee
The ꝑperson̄ hym answerde benedicite
What aylleth ye man̄ so synfully to swer͗e
Our ooste answerde O Ianekyn̄ be ye cher͗e
I smelle a loller͗e in ye wynde qduod he
Howe goodmen̄ qduod our͗e oste herkeneth me
Abideth for goddis digne passioıı̄un
For we schall haf a predicacioun̄
This loller͗e her͗e will prechen̄ us somwhat
Nay be my faders soule yat schal he nat
Seide ye Squier her͗e schall he not preeche
He schall no gospell glosen̄ her͗e no teche
He leuyth alle in ye grete goddes hye
He wolde sowen̄ some difficulte
Or sprⁱngen cokkell in our͗e clene corne
And yerfor ooste I warne ye beforne
My Ioly body schall o tale tell
And I schall clynken̄ ȝowe so mery a belle
That I schall waken̄ all yis companye
But it schall not bene of philosophie
Ne phisicians termes ne queynte lawe
Ther is but litell latyn̄ in my mawe
Incipit fabula Armigeri
Atte sarray in ye londe of Tartarye
Ther dwelled a kynge yat werriede Russye
Thurgh whiche ỷer died mony a dughty man̄
This noble kynge was cleped Kambyuskan
Whiche in his tyme was of so grete renoun
That ỷer nas no wher͗e in no regioıı̄un
So excellent a lorde in all thynge
Hym lakked noȝht yat longede to a kynge
As of ye sette of whiche yat he was borne
He kepte his lay to which yᵗ he was sworn̄
And yer to he was hardy wyse and riche
and pytous and Iuste and alweye y liche
Sothsast of in worde benigne and honurable
Off his corage as eny centr͗e stable·
Ȝonge fressh and stronge in armes desirous
As eny bachiler of all his howse
A fayr͗e ꝑpersone he was and fortunate
Ande kepte alweye so wele riall astate
That ỷer nas nowr͗e wher͗e suche an oyer man̄
This noble kynge yis Tartare kambyskan̄
He hadde ii sones on elchet a his wyffe
Off whiche ye eldeste hiȝht Algarsyfe
The toỷer was cleped Camballo
A dought̉er hadde yis worthy kynge also
That ȝongest was and hyght Canace
But for to tell ȝowe al hir͗e bewtee
It lieth not in my tonge ne in my kōnnynge
I dar not vndirtake so hiegh a thynge
Myn ynglissh eke is insufficiente
It moste bene a Rethor excellente
That couche hys colours longynge for yat Arte
If he schuld hir͗e descryue euy parte
I am non̄ swiche I mote speke as I can̄
And so bifell yat when̄ yis Cambuskan̄
Hadde xx wynt̉er borne his dyademe
As he was wonte from ȝer͗e to ȝer͗e I deme
He lete ye feste of his natiuite
Don̄ cryen̄ thurgh sarray his Citee
The laste ydus of marche aft̉er ye ȝer͗e
Phebus ye son̄ full iolyff was and cler͗e
For he was in his exaltacioıı̄un
In Martes face and his mansioun
In Aries ye Colerike ye Colerike ye hote signe
Full lusty was ye weder and benygne
For whiche ye foules ȝeyn̄ the son̄ schene
What for ye seson̄ and ye ȝonge grene
Full loude songe hir͗e affecciouns
Hem semed han̄ geten̄ hem ꝓproteccions
A ȝeyn ye swerde of wynt̉er kene and colde
This kambuskan̄ of ye whiche I haf ȝowe tolde
In ryall vestimente sitteth on his deyse
With diademe full hyegh in his paleys
And halts his feste solempne and so riche
That in yis worlde ne was yᵗ none so liche
Off whiche ȝiff I schall tell al ye araye
Than̄ wolde it occupie a someres daye
And eke it nedeth not to devise
At eủery cours ye ordr͗e of hir͗e seruyse
I woll not tell of hir͗e straunge sewes
Ne of hir͗e swannes ne of hir͗e heroıı̄un sewes
Eke in yat londe as tellen knyȝhtes olde
Ther is som̄ mete yat is full deynte holde
That in yis londe men̄ men recchen̄ but small
Ther nys no man̄ yat may reporten̄ all
I will not tarien̄ ȝowe for it is prime
And for it is no fruyte but losse of tyme
Vnto my firste purpose I woll haf my recours
And so befell yat aft̉er ye thridde cours
Whill yat yis kynge sitteth yus in yis nobleye
Herknyne his mimstralles hir͗e thyngꝭes pleye
Beforne hym at ye borde deliciously
In at ye hall dor͗e alle sodenly
Ther com̄ a knyȝht epon̄ a stede of brasse
And in his honde a brode merour of glasse
Opon̄ his thombe he hadde a golde rynge
And be his side a naked swerde hongynge
And vp he rideth to ye heigh borde
In alle ye halle ne was yer spoke o worde
For m̉erueylle of yis knyȝht hym to beholde
Full besily yei wayten̄ ȝonge and olde
This strange knyȝht yat come yus sothenly
Al armed saue his hede full richely
Saleved ye kynge and quene and lordes alle
By ordr͗e as yei seten̄ in ye halle
With so hiegh reủerence and obeisaunces
As wele in speche as in his contenᵃaunces
That Gawayn with his olde curtasie
Thogh he come a gayn oute of fairye
Ne couthe hym not amende with no worde
And aft̉er yis be for ye high borde
He with a manly voys saide his message
Aft̉er ye forme vsed in his langage
Withouten vice of sillable or of lettr͗e
And for yis tale schulde seme ye better
Acordant to his wordes was his cher͗e
As techeth arte of speche hem yat it ler͗e
All be it yat I kan̄ not sown̄ his style
Ne can̄ not clymben̄ oủer so hie a stiele
Ȝet seye I yus yat as to cōmmuıı̄un entente
Thus myche amounteth alle yat eủer he mente
If it so be yat I haf it in my mynde
He saide ye kynge of Arabie and of ynde
My liege lorde on yis solempne daye
Salweth ȝowe as he beste can̄ and may
And sondeth ȝowe in honour of ȝour͗e feste
By me yat am redy at all ȝour͗e heste
This stede of brasse yat esily and wele
Kan̄ in ye space of a daye naturelle
That is to seye in xxiiii houres
Wher͗e so ȝowe liste in drought or in schowres
Beren ȝour͗e body in to eủery place
To whiche ȝour͗e herte listeth for to pase
With oute wembs of ȝowe thorgh foule and fair͗e
Or ȝif ȝowe liste to flye als hye mye eyr͗e
As dotth an egle whan̄ hym liste to sor͗e
This same stede schall ber͗e ȝowe eủer more
With outen harme till ȝe be ỷer ȝowe leste
Thof yat ȝe slepen̄ on his bakke or reste
And turne a ȝeyn̄ with ye wrythynge of a pynne
He yat it wrouȝhte coude full mony a gynne
He wayted mony a ꝯconstellacioun
Or he had don̄ yis oꝑperacoıı̄un
And knewe full mony a seele and mony a bonde
This meroᵘur eke yat I haf in myn̄ honde
Hath swiche a myȝht yat men̄ may in it see
div.fw: Whan yer schall fallen̄ eny adủersite
div.l: Whan̄ ỷer schall fallen eny aduersitee
On to ȝour reigne or to ȝour selse also
And openly who is ȝour frende or foo
¶ And oủer all this if eny lady bryȝhte
Hath sette hir͗e herte on eny maner wyȝhte
If he be fals sche schall his trayson̄ see
His newe loue and all his subtilte
So openly yat y ̉er schall no thynge hide
Wherfor͗e a gayn̄ yis lusty somer tyde
This merour ande yis rynge yat ȝe may see
He hath sente to my lady Canacee
Ȝoure excellent doght̉er yat is her͗e
The vertue of yis rynge if ye woll her͗e
Ye yis yat if hir͗e list it for to wer͗e
Opon̄ hir͗e thombe or in hir͗e purse it ber͗e
Ther is no foule yat fleth vnder ye heuen̄
That heue schall vndeirstonde his steuen̄
And knowe his menynge openly and pleyn̄
And answer͗e hym in his langage agayn̄
And eủery grasse yat groweth opon̄ rote
She schall eek knowe and whome it will do bote
All be his woundes neủer so depe and wyde
¶ This naked swerde that hongeth be my side
Swiche vertue hathe yat what man so ȝe smyte
Thurgh oute his Armour it will kerue and byte
Wer͗e it als thikke as is a braunched ook
And what man̄ yat is wounded with ye stroke
Shall neủer be hole till yat ȝowe liste of grace
To stroke hym with ye platte in yilke place
Ther he is hurte yis is as muche to seyne
Ȝe mot with ye platte swerde agayn
Stroke hym in ye wounde and it will close
This is a verray sothe withouten̄ glose
It failleth not whiles it is in ȝour holde
And when̄ yis knyȝht hadde yus his tale y tolde
He rideth oute of ye halle and doun̄ he liȝhte
His stede whiche yat shone as son̄ briȝhte
Stante in ye courte still als eny stone
This knyȝht is to his chambr͗e y lad onon̄
And is vnarmed and to ye mete y sette
The p̉resentes bene full realliche yfet
This is to seyne ye swerde and ye merour
And borne onon̄ in to an hye tour
With c̉erteyn̄ officers y ordeyned yer for͗e
And vn to Canacee ye ryng is boor͗e
Solemply ỷer sche sitte at ye table
But sikerly with outen̄ eny fable
The hors of brasse yat may not be remeved
It stante as it wer to ye ground y glewede
Ther may no man̄ oute of ye plase it dryve
For none engyne of wyndas or polyue
And cause why for thei can not ye craft
And yer for in ye place yei han it lafte
Till yat ye knyȝht hath taught hem the maner͗e
To voiden̄ hym as ȝe schall aft̉er her͗e
Grete was ye prees yat swermed to and froo
To gawren̄ on yis horse yat stondeth soo
For he so hiegh was so brode and longe
So wele ꝓproporciouned for to be stronge
Riȝht as it wer͗e a stede of lumbardye
Ther with so horsly and so quykke of eye
As it a gentill poylers courser wer͗e
For certes fro his taill vn to his
Natur͗e ne arte ne couthe hym not mende
In no degr͗e as all ye peple wende
But eủermor͗e hir͗e moste wonder it was
How yat it couthe gone and was of brasse
It was of fayr͗e as ye peple semede
Diuerse folke diuersely hauen̄ demede
As mony hedes as mony wyttes ỷer ben̄
Thei mormored as done a swarme of beene
And made skilles aft̉er her fantasies
Rehersynge of ye olde poetries
And seiden̄ it was like ye pegasee
The horse yat had wenges for to flye
Or els it was ye grekes hors sinoıı̄un
That broȝht Troye to destruccioun̄
As men̄ in yise olde gestis rede
Myn herte qduod one is eủer mor͗e in drede
I trowe som̄e men̄ of armes ben̄ ỷer in
That schapen̄ hem yis citee for to wynne
It wer͗e riȝht goode yat all swiche thynge wer͗e knowe
Another rowned to his felowe lowe
And seith he lieth for it is rather like
An apparence y made by som̄e magyke
As Iogelours plēyn at yise festes grete
Of sondry thouȝhtes yus yei Iangle and trete
As lewed peple demeth cōmunily
Of thynges yat bene made mor͗e subtily
Than yei kan̄ in hir͗e lewdenesse comprehende
Thei demen̄ gladly to ye badder ende
And som of hem did wondren̄ on ye miroᵘur
That borne was vp vnto ye maist̉er tour
Howe men̄ myȝht in it swiche thynges see
Another answerde and seide it myȝht wele be
Naturelly by composicons
Of Angels and of slye reflexiouns
Ande seide yat in rome was swiche one
Thei speke of Alocin̄ and Valion̄
And of Aristotell yat write in her͗e lyffes
Of queynte merours and of ꝑperspectises
As knowen̄ yei yat haven̄ hir͗e bookes herde
And ỏery folke hauen̄ wondred on ye swerde
That wolde ꝑperce thurgh euery thynge
And fill in speche of theophilus ỷere kynge
And of Achilles for his queynte sper͗e
For he couthe with it both hele and der͗e
Riȝht in swiche wise as men̄ may with ye swerde
Of whiche riȝht nowe ȝe haue ȝour͗e selfen̄ herde
Thei speken̄ of sundry hardynge of metaiƚƚlle
And speke of medecynes yer with alle
And howe and when̄ it schuld hardened be
Whiche is vnknowe algate vnto me
¶ To speke yei begon̄ of Canacee rynge
Ande seiden̄ al that swiche a wonder thynge
Of crafte of rynges hard yei neủer none
Saue yat he moyses and kynge salamone
Had a name of konnynge in swiche arte
Thus seyn̄ ye peple and drawen̄ hem a parte
But nathelesse som seide yat it was
Wonder to maken̄ of ferne asshes glasse
And ȝit is glas not like asshen̄ of ferne
But for yei hauen̄ knowen̄ it so ferne
Therfor͗e ceseth hir͗e Ianke lyng and hir͗e wonder
As sor͗e wondren̄ som on cause of thundr͗e
On ebbe and flode on gossomer on a myste
And all thynge till ye cause is wyste
Thus ianke lyn̄ yei and demen̄ and devise
Till yat ye kynge gan̄ fro his borde arise
Phebus hath lafte ye Angle meridional
And ȝet ascendynge wels ye beste roiall
The gontill lyon̄ with his Aldrian
When yat yis Tart̉re kynge Kambuskan
Roose from his borde ỷer as he sat full hye
Be forne hym gotth ye lowde mynstralcye
Til he come to his chambr͗e of ꝑparamentes
Ther as yei sownen̄ diuerse instrumentes
That it is like an lieuen for to her͗e
Nowe daunsen̄ lusty venus children̄ der͗e
For in ye fyssh her lady satte full hye
And loketh on hem with a frendly eye
This noble kynge is sette up his throne
This straunge knyȝhte is fette to hym full sone
And on ye daunce he gotth with Canacee
Her͗e is ye reuell and ye Iolite
That is nat able a dull man̄ to devise
He moste han̄ knowe loue and his ʆseruise
And bene a festliche man̄ as fressh as may
That schulden̄ ȝowe devisen̄ ysen swiche araye
Who couthe tellen̄ ȝowe ye forme daunses
So vncouthe and swiche fressh continaunces
Swiche subtile lokynges and dissimilynges
For drede of Ialousye mennes a ꝑperceyuynges
No man̄ but launcelet and he is dede
Therfor͗e I passe oủer al this lustiheed
I say no mor͗e but in yis Iolynesse
I lete hem til men̄ to soper hem dresse
The stiwarde bit spices for to hye
And eke ye wyne in all yis melodye
The vsshers and ye squyers bene ygone
The spices and ye wyne is com̄e onon̄
Thei ete and dronke and when̄ yis hadde an ende
Vnto ye temple as reson̄ was yei wende
¶ The seruice don̄ thei soupen̄ al by daye
What nedith ȝowe rehersen̄ hir̄e arraye
Eche man̄ wote wele yat at a kynges feste
Is plente both to ye to ye leeste
And deyntees me yan̄ bene in my knowynge
And aft̉er soper gotth yis noble kynge
To sene yis horse of brasse withal a route
Of lordes and of ladies hym aboute
Swiche wondrynge was ỷer on yis horse of brasse
That sethen̄ ye grete sege of Troye was
Ther as me wondreden̄ on an horse also
Ne was ỷer swiche a wondrynge as was yoo
But finaly ye kynge asketh ye knyȝhte
The vertue of yis courser and ye myȝhte
And preide hym to telle his gouernᵃaunce
The horse onon̄ gan̄ for to trippe and daunce
Whan̄ yat yis knyȝht laide honde upon his reyne
And seide ʆser ỷer is no mor͗e to seyne
But when̄ you liste to riden̄ eny wher͗e
Ȝe mot trille a pynne stant in his er͗e
Whiche I schall yow tell ȝowe betwene no two
Ȝe mot neuen̄ hym to what place also
Or to what contr͗e yat ȝowe liste to ride
And when ȝe come ỷer as ȝe liste to abide
Bid hym descende and trile a noỷer pynne
For ỷerer in lieth ye effecte of all yat gynne
And will doun descende and done ȝoᵘur wille
And in yat plase he will abide stille
Theigh all ye worlde had ye contᵃrarie y swor͗e
He schall not yennes be throwe ne y bor͗e
Or ȝiff ȝowe liste bid hym yennes gone
Trill yis pynne and he will vanyssh onon̄
Oute of ye siȝht of eủery maner wiȝhte
And come a ȝeyn̄ be it day or nyȝhte
Whan yat ȝowe liste to clepen̄ hym a ȝeyn̄
In whiche a gyse as I schall to ȝowe seyne
Betwixen̄ ȝowe and me and yat full sone
Ride when̄ ȝowe liste ỷer is no mor͗e to done
Enformed when̄ ye kynge was of yis knyȝht
And hath conceyued in his wytte ariȝhte
The man̉er and the forme of al this thynge
Full glad and blithe ye noble doghty kynge
Reperryng to his reuell as beforne
The bridell is in to ye tour͗e borne
Ande kept a monge his Iewels lefe and der͗e
The horse vanysshede I note in what maner͗e
Oute of hir͗e siȝhte ȝe gete no mor͗e of me
But yus I lete in luste and Iolite
This Cambuskan his lordes was was festynge
Til wel nyegh ye daye began̄ to sprynge
¶ Explicit prima pars
The stag of an hert;
The norice of digestioıı̄un is slepe
Gan̄ on hym wynke and bad hem take kepe
That muche mete and labour woll haf reste
Ande with a galpynge mouthe hem all he keste
And saide yat it was tyme to lye a doun
For bloode was in his dominacoıı̄un
Cheryssheth blode natures frende qduod he
Thei thanken̄ hym galpynge bi two by thr͗e
And eủery wyȝht gan̄ drawen̄ hym to his reste
As sleepe hem badde yei toke it for ye beste
Hir͗e dreemes schull not mowe be tolde for me
Full wer͗e hir͗e hedes of fumosite
That causeth dreme of whiche yer is no charge
Thei slepen̄ till that it was pⁱrime large
The moste parte but it wer͗e Canacee
She was full mesurable as wōmmen̄ be
For of hir͗e fader hadde sche take hir͗e leue
To go to reste son̄ aft̉er it was eue
Hir͗e list not apalled for to be
For on ye morowe vnfestliche for to see
And slepte hir͗e firste slepe and awoke
For swiche a ioye sche in hir͗e herte toke
Bothe of hir͗e queynte rynge and of hir͗e meroᵘur
That xx tyme sche chaunched hir͗e colour
And in hir͗e slepe riȝht for impression̄
Of hir͗e merour sche hadde a vision̄
Wher͗e for͗e er yat ye son̄ up gan̄ glide
She cleped opon̄ hir͗e maistresse her͗e beside
And sade yat hir͗e luste for to arise
Thise olde wōmmen yat bene gladly wyse
As is hir͗e maistresse answered hir͗e onon̄
And saide madame whider woll ȝe gone
Thus erly for folke bene all in reste
I woll qduod sche arise for me leste
No lenger slepen̄ but walken̄ aboute
Hir͗e maistres clepeth wōmmen̄ a grete route
And up yei risen̄ wel ·x· or xii
Vp riseth fressh Canace her selfe
Als roddy and briȝht as yof ye ȝonge son̄
That in ye ram is x· degres up ronne
None hyer was he whan sche redy was
And forth sche walwed esyly a paas
Arraied aft̉er ye lusty seson̄ sote
Liȝhtly for to pleye and walke on foote
Not but v· or vi of hir͗e menȝeye
And in a trenche feir͗e in ye parke goth sche
The vapour whiche yat fro ye erthe glode
Make the ye sonne to seme roddy and brode
But natheles it was so fair͗e a siȝhte
That it made alle hire hertes for to liȝhte
What for ye seson̄ and ye mornynge
And for ye foules yat sche harde synge
For riȝhte onon̄ sche wyste what yei mente
Riȝht be hir͗e songe and knewe al hir͗e entente
¶ The knotte why yat eủery tale is tolde
Ȝif it be taried till luste be colde
Of hem yat haue it herkened aft̉er ȝor͗e
The sauour passeth eủer lenger ye mor͗e
For fulsomnese of prolixite
And be this same resoun̄ thenkes me
I schulde vn to ye knotte ꝯcondescende
And maken̄ of hir͗e walkynge son̄ an ende
¶ A mydde a tr͗e for drye as white as chalke
As Canacee was pleyynge in hir͗e walke
Ther satte a faukon̄ oủer hir͗e hede full hye
That with a pytous voys so gan̄ to crye
That all ye wode resede of her͗e Crye
And beten̄ hadde hir͗e selfe so pitously
