With bothen̄ hir͗e wenges till ye rede blode
Ranne endlonge ye tree ỷer as sche stode
And eủer in one sche cride alway and schryhte
And with hir͗e beeke her͗e selfen so sche pryȝhte
That ỷer ne was tigr͗e ne crwell beste
That dwelleth either in wodde or in foreste
That nolde han wepte if yat he wepe couthe
For sorowe of hir͗e sche schriȝht al wey so outhe
For ỷer nas neủer ȝit man̄ on lyffe
Yf yat I couthe a fawkon̄ wele discryue
That harde of swyche another of fairnesse
As wele of plumage as of gentilnesse
Of schappe of al yat myȝht rekkened be
A fawcon̄ ꝑperegrine yan semed sche
Off fremd londe and eủermor͗e as sche stoode
Sho swowned nowe and nowe for lakke of blode
Til wel neigh is sche fallen̄ fro ye tree
This fair͗e kynges dought̉er yis canacee
That on hir͗e fyng̉er bar͗e yis queynte rynge
Thurgh whiche sche vndirstode wele eủery thynge
That eny foule may in his ledne seyne
And kouthe answer͗e hym in his langage a ȝeyn̄
Hath vndirstande yat yis fallion̄ saide
And wel neygh for ye reuthe almoste sche diede
And to ye sho goith full hastily
And on yis fawkon̄ loketh full pitouslye
And held hir͗e lappe on brode for wele sche wyste
The Fawcon̄ moste falle fro ye twyste
Whan yat it swowned next for lakke of blode
A longe while to wayte hir͗e sche stode
Till at laste sche spake in yis maner͗e
Vn to ye hauke as ȝe schall aft̉er her͗e
What is ye cause if it be for to telle
That ȝe bene in yis furiall peyne of helle
Qduod Canacee vnto yis hauke aboue
Is yis for sorowe of dethe or losse of loue
For as I trowe yise beth causes twoo
That causen moste a gentill herte to woo
Of ỏery harme it redith not to speke
For yi ȝour͗e selfe opon ȝour͗e selfe ȝe wreke
Whiche yat ꝓproueth yat ether ir͗e or drede
Mot bene encheson̄ of ȝour crwell dede
Syn yat I se non̄ other wiȝht ȝowe chase
For loue of god so doith ȝour͗e selfe grace
Or what may be ȝour͗e helpe for westnor este
Ne sawgh I neủer er nowe ne bride ne beste
That farde with hymselfe so pitously
Ȝe slee me with ȝour͗ee sorowe verrely
I haue of ȝowe so grete compassioun
For goddis luff come fro ye tr͗e a doun
And as I am a kynges dought̉er trewe
If yat I verrely ye causes knewe
Of disese ȝif it lay in my myȝhte
I woll amende it or yat it wer͗e nyȝhte
As wys helpe me grete god of kynde
And herbes schall I riȝht y nowe fynde
To hele with ȝour͗e hurtes hastily
Tho schriȝht yis fawkon̄ ȝit mor͗e pytously
Than eủer sche did and fill to grounde onon
And lieth on swowne dede as is a stone
Til Canace hath in hir͗e lappe hir͗e take
Vn to yat tyme sche gan̄ of swowne a wake
And aft̉er yat sche of swown̄ gan̄ abraide
Riȝht in hir͗e hawkes langage yus sche saide
¶ That pite renneth sone in gentill herte
Felynge his similitude in peynes smerte
Is proued al daye as men̄ may it see
As wele by werke as by auctorite
For gentill herte kepith gentilnesse
I see wele yat ȝe hane of my distresse
Compassion̄ my fair͗e Canacee
Of verray wōmmanly benignite
That natur͗e in ȝour͗e principles hath sette
But for non̄ hope but to far͗e ye bette
But for to obeye vnto ȝour͗e herte free
And for to maken other be war͗e by me
As by ye whelp chastised is ye lyoun
Riȝht for yat cause and for yat ꝯconclusioıı̄un
While yat I haf a leyser and a space
Myn̄ harme I woll confessen̄ or I passe
And eủer whill ye tone hir͗e sorowe tolde
The toỷer wepte as sche to water wolde
Till yat ye fawcon̄ bad hir͗e to be still
And with a sigh yus sche saide hir͗e till
Ther I was bredde allas yat ilke daye
And fostred in a roche of marbull graye
So tendrely yat no thynge eyled me
I ne wiste not / what was aduersite
Til I couthe flye full hie vnder ye skye
Tho dwellede a t̉ercelet me fast by
That semed well of all gentillnesse
All wer͗e he full of treson̄ and falsnesse
It is wrapped vnder vumble chier
And vnder hewe of trowth and in swiche maner͗e
Vnder plesaunce and vnder besy peyne
That no wiȝht cowthe haf wend he couthe feyne
So depe in greyne he died his colours
Riȝht as a serpent hideth hym vnder flowrs
Till he may see his tyme for to bite
Riȝht so yis god of loues ypocrite
Dotth so his ceremonies and obesaunces
And kepte in semblante all his obseruᵃaunces
That sowneth in to gentilnesse of loue
As in a tombe is alle ye fair͗e aboue
And vnder is ye cours swiche as ȝe wote
Swiche was yis ypocrite both colde and hote
And in yis wyse he serued his entente
That saue ye fende none wyste what he mente
Till he so longe had weped and ꝯconpleynede
And mony a ȝer͗e his seruise to me feynede
Til that myn herte to pitous and to nyce
All Innocent of his crowned malise
For fered of his dethe as thought me
Vpon his othes and his seurete
Graunted hym loue opon̄ yis ꝯcondicoıı̄un
That eủer mo myn̄ honour and renoun̄
Wer͗e saued both pryevy and aperte
This is to seyne yat aft̉er his desserte
I ȝaff hym all myn̄ herte and my thouȝht
God woote and he yat oỷer wyse nouȝht
And tooke his herte in chaunge of myn̄ for ay
But soth is seid go sethen̄ mony a daye
A trewe wiȝhte and a theef thenken̄ not one
And when̄ he sawe ye thynge so ferr͗e y gone
That I grauntede hym fully my loue
In swiche a gyse as I haf seide aboue
And ȝiffen̄ hym my trewe herte as free
As he swor͗e he ȝaf his herte to me
O non̄ this tigr͗e full of doublenesse
Fill on his knees with so deuoute humblesse
With hye reủerence and as by his cher͗e
So like a gentill louer of maner͗e
So rauysshede as it semed for ye Ioye
That neuer Iason̄ ne Paris ne troye
Iason̄ certes ne non̄ other man̄
Syn̄ lameth was yat alderfirste began
To louen̄ two as writen̄ folke beforne
Ne neủer sethe ye firste man̄ was borne
Ne kouthe man̄ by twenty thousand parte
Countrefete ye Sophymmes of his arte
Ne wer͗e worthy vnboclie his galoche
Ther͗e doublenesse or feynynge schulde aproche
Ne so kouthe thanke a wyȝhte as he did me
His maner was an heuen̄ for to see
Till eny wōmman̄ wer͗e sche neủer so wyse
So peynteth he and kembeth at poynt devise
As wele his wordes as his ꝯcontenᵃaunces
And I so loued hym for his obeisaunce
And for the trouthe I demede in his herte
That if so were yat eny thynge hym smerte
All wer it neủer so lite and I it wyste
Me thouȝht I felte dethe at myn herte twyste
And schortly so ferforth yis thynge wente
That my will was his willes instrumente
This is to seyn̄ my will obeied his will
In alle thynge as ferr͗e as reson̄ fill
Kepynge ye boundes of my worschip eủer
Ne neủer had I thynge so lief ne leủer
As hym god wote ne neủer schall nomoo
This lasteth lenger yan a ȝer͗e or twoo
That I supposed of hym no thynge but goode
But finally yus at ye laste it stode
That fortune wolde yat he moste twynne
Oute of yat place whiche yat I was Inne
Wherr͗e me was woo it is no questioun̄
I can̄ not make of it descripsioıı̄un
For o thyng dar I tell boldely
I knowe what is ye peyne of dethe ỷer by
Swiche harme I felte for he ne myȝht beleue
So on a day of me he toke his leue
So sorofully eke yat I wende verrally
That he had feled as myche harmes as I
When̄ yat I harde hym speke and sawe his hewe
But natheles I thouȝht he was so trewe
And eke yat he repair͗e schuld a gayne
With in a litell while sothe to seyne
And reson̄ wolde eke yat he moste goo
For his honour as ofte happeth soo
That I made vertue of necessite
And toke it wele sen yat it moste bee
As I beste myȝht I hid from hym my sorowe
And toke hym by ye honde seynt Iohn̄ to borowe
And seid yus lo I am ȝowres alle
Beth swiche as I haue bene to ȝowe and schall
What he answerde it nedeth not reherse
Who can̄ seyn̄ bett yan he yat can do werse
When̄ he hath al wele saide yᵃn hath he don̄
Therfor behoueth hym a full longe spone
That schall eten̄ with a fende yus hard I seye
So at ye laste he mot forth his waye
And forth he flieth til he com̄e ỷer he leste
When it com hym to purpose for to reste
I trowe he hadde yilke texte in mynde
That al thynge is repairyng to his kynde
Gladeth hymself yus seyn̄ men̄ as I gesse
Men louen̄ of ꝓpropre kynde newfankelnesse
As briddes don̄ yat men̄ in kages feede
For yogh you myȝht and day take of hym hede
And strawe hir̄e kages fair̄e and softe as silke
As ȝif hem sugr̄e hony brede and mylke
Ȝit riȝht onōn as yat is dor̄e is up
He with his feete will spurne down̄ his coppe
And to ye wode he woll and wormes ete
So newfangell ben yei of yer mete
And louen̄ non̄ hers of ꝓpropr͗e kynde
No gentilnesse of blode may hem bynde
So ferde yis tercilet allas ye daye
Yof he wer̄e gentill borne fressh and gaye
And goodly for to seen and humble and fr͗e
He sawe opon a tyme a kyte flye
And sothenly he loued yis kyte soo
That all his loue is clene fro me goo
And hath his trouthe falsed in yis wise
Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir͗e seruyse
And I am lorne with oute remedye
And with yat wordw yis fawcon̄ gan̄ to crie
And swowned efte in Canaces barme
Grete was ye sorowe for yat haukes harme
That Canacee and all hir͗e wōmmen̄ made
Thei nyste how yᵗ yei myȝht ye falkon̄ glade
But Canacee home berith hir͗e in hir͗e lappe
And softly in plastres gan̄ hir͗e wrappe
Ther as sche with hir͗e beek had hurt hir͗e selfe
Now can̄ not Canace but herbes delfe
Oute of ye grownde ande maken̄ salues newe
Of herbes p̉ercious and fyne of hewe
To helen̄ with ye hauke fro day to nyȝhte
She doith hir͗e besinesse and all hir͗e myȝhte
And by her͗e beddes hede sche made a mewe
And kouered it with velivetes blewe
In signe of trouthe yat is in wōmmen̄ seene
And all with oute ye mwe is peynted grene
In whiche wer peynted all yise fals fowles
As bene yise tidifs terceletꝭes and owles
Riȝhte for ye spute wer͗e peynted hem be side
Pyes on hem for to crie and chide
Thus leet I Canacee hir͗e hauke kepynge
I woll no mor͗e as nowe speke of hir͗e rynge
Till it com̄e efte to purpose for to seyne
Howe yat yus falkone gat hir͗e loue agayn̄
Repentant as ye storie telleth vs
By mediacon̄ of Camballus
The kynges son̄ of whiche I ȝowe tolde
But hennes forth I woll ꝓprorosse holde
To speken̄ of aueuturs and of gat ailles
That ȝit was neủer hard so gret mervailles
Firste will I tell ȝowe of Kambuskan̄
That in his tyme mony a Cite wanne
And aft̉er woll I speke of Algarsife
Howe yat he wan̄ theodora to his wyffe
For when̄ full ofte in grete ꝑperill he was
Ne hadde he bene holpen̄ by ye horse of bras
And aft̉er woll I speke of Camballo
That faughte in lystes with ye brethern̄ twoo
For Canace or yat he myȝht hir͗e wynne
And yer I leste I woll a gayn̄ begynne
Apollo whirleth up his chare so hie
Till yat ye good mercuruis howse ye slye
¶ Explicit secunda pars;
¶ Incipit prologus mercatoris
In feith Squier you hast ye wele y quyt
And gentilly I priyse riȝht wele yi witte
Qd þe marchante considerynge þe ȝouthe
So felyngly þou spokest sir I þe alouthe
As to my dome þ̉er is none þat is her
Of eloquence þat schall be þi pere
For of þi speche I haf grete deynte
I haf a son and by þe trinite
I hadde leủer þan xx līm worth of londe
Thof it riȝht nowe wer fallen in myn honde
Ȝe er a man of suche distrecioun
As þat ȝe ben fye opon possessioıı̄un
But if a man be vertuose with all
I haff my son snybbed and ȝit schall
For he to vertue listeth not entende
But for to pleye at dyes and to dispende
And lese all þat he hath is his vsage
And he hath leủer talke with a paage
Than to comu with a gentill wiȝhte
Wher he myȝht lerne gentilnesse ariȝhte
Strawgh for ȝour gentilnes qd our oste
What marchand ꝐParde sir wele þou wooste
That iche of ȝowe mot tellen at þe leste
A tale or two or breken his beheste
That knowe I wele qd þe Marchant c̉erteyn
I pray ȝowe haf me not in disdeyne
Þof to þis man I speke a worde or two
Tell on þi tale with outen wordes moo
Gladly sir oste qd he I will obeye
Vn to ȝour will nowe herkeneth what I seye
I will not 9trarien ȝowe in no wyse
Als ferr as þat my wittes woll suffise
I praye to god þat it may plesen ȝowe
Than wote I wele þat it is good y nowe
¶ Here begynneth þe marchauntz tale ;
Whilom þ̉er was dwellynge in lumbardye
A worthy knyght þat borne was at pavie
In whiche he lyffed in grete prosꝑperite
And sixty ȝer a wiffles man was he
And folowed aye his bodily delyte
On wōmmen þer on was his appetite
As wēn þise foles þat bene seculers
And when þat he was passed lx . ȝeres
Wer it for holynes or els for dotage
I can not say but suche a grete corage ¶
Hadde þis knyȝht to be a wedded man
That daye and nyȝht he doith al þat he can
To aspie wher þat he wedded myȝht bee
Praynge our lorde to gᵃunten hym þat he
Myȝht ones knowe þat blisful lyffe
That is betwix an husbonde and his wyffe
And for to lyffen vnder þat holy bonde
With whiche god man firste with woman bonde
None other lyffe seide he is worthe a beene
For wedloke is so esy and so clene
That in þis worlde it is a ꝑparadise

l.seg:
Thus seith þᵉ olde knyght þat
was so wise

div.l: And certenly als sothe as god is kynge
To take a wyffe it is a gloriouse thynge
And namely when a man is olde and hoor

And ful of Ioye and blisse is euery man
Al but o squier þat hiȝht damyan ¶þ
Which karffe beforne þe knyȝht mony a daye
He was so rauysshed on his lady may
That for þe verrey peyne he was niegh wood
Al moste he swelte and swowned þer he stoode
As þat sche bar daunsynge in hir honde
So fressh scho was and þ̉er to so likande
And to his bedde he wente hym hastilye
No mor of hym at þis tyme speke I
But þer I lete hym wepe ynogh and pleyne
Til fressh may wol rewen on his peyne
¶ O ꝑparlious fyr þat in þe bed strawe bredith
O famuler foo þat his seruise bedith
O ʆseruᵃnt traitour fals holy hewe
Y like to þe nedder slyegh and in bosom vntrewe
God schelde us alle from ȝour iniquitaunce
O Ianuar dronken in plesaunce
O mariage see howe þi damyane
Thyn own squier and þi borne man
Entendith to done þe vilenye
God gᵃunte þe þine harmly forto aspie
For in þis worlde nys worse pestilence
Than homly foo al day in þi presence
ꝐParfourmed hath þis diuine day his ark diurne
No leng may þe body of hym soiorne
The Orysowte as in þat latitude
Niȝht with his mantel þat is dirke and rude
Gan for to sprede þe myspreye a boute
For whiche deꝑparted is þe lusty route
For Ianuar with thanke on eủery side
Home to her houses lustily þei ride
Ther as þei done her thyngꝭes as þam luste
And when þei sawe her tyme gon to reste
Sone eft̉er þat þis hasty Ianuar
Wol go to bedde he wol no leng car
He drynketh ypocras clarr and vernage
Of spices hote to encresen his corage
And mony a letuarye had he fulfyne
Suche as þe cursed Monke daun Constantyne
Hathe writen in his boke off Coytu
To eten hem alle he nas nothynge eschewe
And þus to his pryue frendes saide he ¶þ
For goddis loue as sone as it may be
Let voiden al þis howse in curtas wise sone
Men dronke and þe trauers drewe onon
¶ The bridde was broȝht to bedde als stil as stone
So hasted Ianuarie and moste be done
And when þe bedde was withe þe preste y blessed
Oute of þe Chambr hath eủery wyȝht hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath faste in armis take
His fressh may his ꝑparadise his make
He lullith hir he kisseth hir ful ofte
With þis bristells of his berde vnsofte
Y like to þe skyne of houndfyssh scharpe as brer
For he was schaue al newe in his maner
He rubbeth hir opon hir tendir face
And said þus allas I mot trespase
To ȝowe my spouse and ȝowe gretly offende
Or tyme com þat I wol doun descende
But natheles considereth þis qd he
Ther nys no werke man what so eủer he be
That may both wirche wele and hastily
This wol be don at leiser ꝑparfitely
It is no force howe longe þat we pleye
I trowe in wedloke coupled be we tweye
And y blessed be þe ȝok þat we bene inne
For in our actis we may do no synne
A man may do no synne wyth his own wyffe
Ne hurte hym selfe with his own knyffe
Nowe we haue leue to plaie hus by þe lawe
Thus laboreth he til þe day be gan to dawe
And þenne he taketh a soppe in fyne clarr
And up riȝht in his bedde þen sitteth he
And aft þat he songe ful lowde and cler
And kissed his wyffe and made wantoıı̄un cher
He was al coltyssh and ful of ragerye
And ful of girgoun as is a flekked pye
The slak skynne a boute his nekke schakith
Whil þat he sange so chauntith he and craketh
But god wote what may thouȝht in hir herte
When sche hym sawe vp sittyng in his scherte
In his nyȝht cappe and with his nekke lene
She preiseth not his pleynge worth a bene
Then seide he þus my restynge wol I take ¶þ
Nowe day is come I may no leng wake
And doun he leide his hede and slepe til prime
And aftirward when þat he sawe his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie but fressh may
Holte hir chambr vn to þe ferthe daye
As vsage is of wiffes for þe beste
For eủery labour som tyme mot haue reste
Or els longe may he not endur
That is to saye no liffes creatur
Be it fyssh or bridde or beste or mann
Nowe wol I speke of woful damyan
That languorith for loue as ȝe schulne her
Therfore I speke to hym in þis maner
I say o sely damyan allas
Answer to þis demᵃnde as in þis case
Howe schalt þou to þi lady fressh maye
Eke if þou speke sche schal þi wo bewreye
God be þine helpe I can no bett̉er saie
Yf þou hir tel þi woo sche wol al weye sey naye
¶ This seke damyan in venus fyr
So brenneth þat he al moste deieth for desir
For whiche he putte his liff in auentur
No leng myȝht he in þis wise endur
But pⁱriuely a penner gan he borowe
And in a letter wrote he al his sorowe
In maner of a cvmpleynte ouþ̉er alaye
Vn to þis fair and fressh lady may
And in a purse of selke henge on his scherte
He hath y put it and leyde it at his herte
The mone þat at none was þat ilke daye
That Ianuar hath wedded þat fressh maye
In two of taur was in þe cancr gliden
So longe hathe sche in hir chambr briden
As custume is / vn to þe nobles alle
A bride schal not eten in þe halle
Til daies four other in daies at þe leste
Bene passed þen let hir goo to þe feste
The ferthe daye complete from none to none
Whan þat þe hiegh messe was y done
In halle sitte þis Ianuar and may
As fressh as is þe bryȝht somers daye
And so It be fel þat þis good man
Remembreth hym opon þis damyan ¶þ
And seid seynt mary howe may þis be
That damyan entendys noȝt to me
Is he ay sike or howe may þis betide
His squiers whiche þat stoden hym beside
Excusynge hym be cause of his sekenes
Whiche þat letid hym to do his besynes
Non other cause myȝht make hym tar
That me forthynketh qd þis Ianuar
He is a gentil squier be my trouthe
Ȝiff þat he diede it wer harme and routhe
He is as wise discrete and secr
As eny man I wote of his degr
And þer to manly and eke seruisable
And for to be a thryfty man riȝht able
But aft̉er mete als sone as eủer I maye
I wol my selfe visite hym and eke may
To done hym al þe comforte þat I can
And for þat worde hym blessed eủery man
That of his bonte and of his gentilnesse
He wolde so conforten hym in his sekenes
His squier for it was a gentil dede
Dame ꝙquod he þis Ianuar take goode hede
That at aft̉er mete ȝe with ȝour wōmmen alle
When ȝe han ben in chambr ouȝte of þis hal
That al ȝe gone vn to þis damyan
Doith hym desporte he is a gentil man
And tellith hym þat I wol hym visite
Haf I no thynge but rested me a lite
Nowe with þat worde he gan to hym calle
A squier þat was þe marschal of his hal
And tolde hym c̉erteyn thynges whiche he wolde
This fressh may hath streiȝht hir weye y holde
With al hir wōmmen vnto þis damyan
Doun be his beddes side satte sche þan
Confortynge hym as goodly as sche may
This damyan when þat he his tyme saye
In secrete wise his purse and eke his bille
In whiche þat he writen had al his wille
Hath putte in to hir honde with outen mor
Saf þat he siȝhed wvnderly soor
And softly to hir riȝht softe þus said he ¶þ
Mercy and þat ȝe discoủer not me
For I am dede if þat þis thyng be kyd
This purse hath sche with in hir bosome y hidde
And wente hir way ȝe gete no mor of me
But vnto Ianuar y cōmen is sche
And on his beddys side satte ful softe
He takith hir and kyssith hir ful ofte
And leide hym doun to slepe and þat onon
She feyned her as þat sche moste gone
Ther as ȝe wote þat eủery wyȝht mot nede
And when sche of þis bille hath taken hede
She rent it al to cloutes at þe laste
And in to þe pryuee softely she it caste
Who studieth nowe but fair fressh may
And a doun be Ianuar sche hir lay
And slepe til þat þe coȝh hym hath a waked
A nōn he pᵃied her to stripen her al naked
He wold of hir he saide haue som plesaunce
He seid hir clothes did hym encombraunce
And sche obeieth be he lefe or lothe
Bot leste þat precious folke be with me wrothe
Howe þat he wroȝht . I dar to ȝowe not tel
Whedir þat he thouȝht on ꝑparadise or of helle
But I lete hem worchen in her wyse
Til euen songe rynge and þat þei moste arise
Whedir it be destyne or els auentur
Or whedir þat it be influence or by natur
Outher in 9stellacoıı̄un þat in suche astate
The heuen stoode þat tyme fortunate
Was for to put a bil of venus werkes
For al thyng hath tyme as seyn þise clerkes
To eny wōmman for to gete hir loue
I can not saye but þe grete god a boue
That knoweth þat none þat is causeles
He demeth of alle for I wol holde my peese
But soth is þis howe þat þis fressh maye
Hath taken suche inpressioıı̄un þat daye
Of pite on þis sike damyan
That fro hir herte sche ne drive can
The remembrance for to done hym ese
Certen thouȝt sche whome þat þis thyng displese
I rekke not for her I hym assur
To loue hym beste of eny creatur ¶þ
Thogh he no mor he hadde þan his scherte
Loo pite renneth sone in gentil herte
Her may ȝe see howe excellent fraunchise
In wōmmen is when þei shortly hem a vise
Som tiraunt þ̉er is as þ̉er bene mony one
That hath an herte as harde as is eny stone
Whiche wolde han leten hym sterue in þe plase
Wel rather þan hauen graunted hym þat grace
And hem reioisen in her crwel pride
And recched not to bene an homicide
This gentil may fulfilled al of pite
Riȝht se of hir honde a lett̉er made sche
In whiche sche grauntyth hym of hir verray grace
Ther lakketh noȝt only but day and space
Wher þat sche myȝht to his luste suffise
For it schal be riȝht as he wol devise
And when sche sawe her tyme opon a daye
To visit þis damyan goith fair maye
And soteily þis lett̉er doun sche thriste
Vnder his pilewe rede it if hym liste
She taketh hym by þe honde and harde hym twyste
So secrely þat no wiȝht it wyste
Ande bad hym be al hole and forth sche wente
To Ianuar when þat he for hir sente
Vp riseth Damyan opon þe nexte morowe
Al passed was his sekenesse and his sorowe
He kembeth hym and proyneth hym and pyketh
He doith al þat his lady luste and liketh
And eke to Ianuar he goith als lowe
As eu did a dog for þe bowe
He is so plesaunte to eủery man
For crafte is al who þat it kan
That eủery wiȝhte is fayn to teche hym goode
And fully in his lady grace he stoode
Thus lete I damyan aboute his nede
And in my tale forth I wil procede
Som clerkes halden þat felicite
Stant in delyȝte and þ̉erfor he
This noble Ianuar with al his myȝhte
In honeste wyse as longeth to a knyȝht
Shope hym to liffe ful deliciously
His howsynge his array alls honestly
To his degr was maked as a kynges ¶þ
A monge other of his honeste thynges
He hadde a gardyne walled al with stone
So fair a gardyn wote I now wher none
For oute of doute I verrely suppose
That he þat wrote þe romaunce of þe rose
Couthe not of it þe bewte wele deuyse
Ne priapus ne miȝht noȝt suffice
Thof he be godde of gardyns for to telle
The bewte of þe gardyn and of þe welle
That stoode vnder a lauree al way grene
Ful ofte tyme kynge pluto and his quene
Preserpina and al hir fayrye
Disportened hem and maken melodye
A bouten þat wel and daunced as men tolde
This noble knyȝht þis Ianuar þe olde
Suche deynte hath in it to walken and to pleye
That he wil suffr no wiȝhte to beren þe keye
Saf he hym selfe for of þe smal wyket
He bar al weye of siluer a kleket
With þe whiche when þat hym luste vnschete
And when þat he wolde paye his wyffe his dette
In sommer sesoıı̄un þider wolde he goo
And may his wyffe and none but þei twoo
And thynges whiche þat wer not done abedde
Þei in þe gardyn ꝐParfourmed hem and spedde
And in þis wyse mony a mery daye
Lyffed þis Ianuar and fressh maye
But worldly ioye may not al wey endur
To Ianuar ne to no wordly creatur
O sodeyn happe O þou fortune vnstable
Y like to þe scorpioun variable
That flaterest with þine hede when þou woldest stynge
Thy taille is deeth thurgh þine envenomynge
O brotel Ioye O swete poisoıı̄un queynte
O mustier þat sotelly canste peynte
Thy ȝiftes vnder þine hewe of stedfastnes
That þou desceudest both mor and lesse
Why haste þou Ianuar þus disseyuede
Ande haddeste hym for þi ful frende resseyuede
And nowe þou haste birafte hym bothe his eyen
For sorowe of whiche desireth he to dyen
Allas þis noble Ianuar þat is so free
A mydde his luste and his prosꝑperite
Is wexen blynde and al sodeynly ¶þ
His deeth þer for desireth he al vttirlye
And þer with al þe fyr of Ialowsye
Leste þat his wiffe schuld fal in som folye
So brente his herte þat he wolde fayne
That som man hir and hym hadde slayne
For neủer aft his deeth ne in his lyffe
Ne wolde he þat sche wer loue ne wyffe
But eủer liff as a wydowe in clothes blakke
Soule as þe turtil with þat hath loste hir make
But at þe laste aft̉er a monethe or tweye
His sorowe gan to swage sothe for to seye
For when he wiste it myȝht non oþer be
He paciently toke his aduersite
Saf oute of doute May he nolde for gone
For he was Ielouse eủermor in one
Whiche Ialousie was so outracheous
That neiþ̉er in hal ne in non other house
He nolde suffr hir for to ride ner goo
Ne in none oþer place neuer þe moo
But ȝif þat he had honde on hir alweye
For whiche wel ofte wepith fressh maye
That louyth Damyan so benignly
That sche mot either deye sothenly
Or els sche mot han hym at hir liste
She wayteth when her herte wolde to breste
Vpon þat oþ̉er side damyane
By comen is þe sorowfulleste man
That eủer was for neủer nyȝht nor daye
Ne myȝht he speke oo worde to fressh maye
As to his purpose of non swiche matier
But ȝiff þat Ianuar moste it her
That had oon honde opon hir eủer moo
And natheles be writyng to and froo
And pryue signes wiste he what she mente
And sche knewe of þe sygne of his entente
O Ianuar what myȝht it þe availle
Thowe myȝhteste see as ferr as schippes saille
For als good is to a blynde man disseyued be
As to be disseyuede when a man may see
Loo Arguys whiche þat had an hundreth eyen
For al þat eủer he couthe pour or pryen
Ȝit was he blente and god wote so bene moo
That wenen ful wysly þat it is not soo
Passe ouer is an ese and say no mor
This fressh may of whiche I spake of ȝor ¶þ
In warme wexe hathe enprynted þis cleket
That Ianuar bar of þat litil wyket
By whiche vn to his gardyn ofte he wente
And damyan þat knewe hir entente
The cliket countrefetid priuely
Ther nys no mor to saye but hastily
Som wonder be þis cliked schal betyde
Whiche ȝe schul heren ȝif ȝe wol abide
¶ O noble ouyde soith seiste þou god wote

rdg.seg:
What sleiȝht is it þof it
be longe and hote

div.l: That he nyl fynde it oute in som maner
By piramus and tysbe may men ler
Thof þei wer kepte ful longe streyte oủer al
Thei bene acorded rownynge thurgh þe wal
Ther is no wyȝhte þat couthe han founde oute suche a sleiȝhte
But nowe to purpose er þat daies eyȝte
Wer passede or þe moneth of Iuyl be fille
That Ianuarie hath cauȝht so grete a wille
Thurgh eggynge of his wyffe hym for to pleye
In his gardyn and none but þei tweye
That in a morwe vn to his may saide he
Rise up my wiffe my luff my lady free
The turtlys voys is herde my douse swete
The wynter is gone with al his reignes wete
Come forth nowe with þine eyen fair columbyne
Howe fairer bene þi brestis þan is þe wyne
The gardyn is enclosed al a boute
Come forth white spouse oute of dowte
Thou haste me wounded in myn herte o wyffe
No spotte in þe nas neủer in al þi liffe
Come forth and lat us take our desporte
I chees þe for my wyffe and my comforte
Suche olde lewde wordes vsed he
On damyan a signe made sche
That he schuld go be forne with his cliket
This damyan hath opynhed þe wyket
And in he stirte and þat in suche maner
That no wyȝht myȝht it see nor her
And stil he sitte vndir a bussh onon
This Ianuar so blynde is as a stone
With mayus in his hande and no wiȝht moo
In to his fressh gardyn is he goo
And clapped to þe wyket sothenly
Nowe wyff qd he her nys but þou and I
That arte þe creatur þat I beste loue
For by þat lorde þat sitte us alle aboue
I hadde leủer deyen on a knyffe ¶
Then þe offenden my der trewe wyffe
For goddes sake thenke howe I þe chees
Noȝht for no couetise douteles
But only for þe hie loue I hadde to þe
And þof þat I be olde and may not see
Be to me trewe and I wol tel ȝowe why
Certes thr thynges schullen ȝe wynne þer by
Firste loue of Criste and to ȝour selfe honour
And al myn heritage toun and tour
I ȝiff it ȝowe makith charters as ȝowe liste
This schal be do to morowe er þe son go to reste
So wisly god my soule brynge in blisse
I preye ȝowe on couenᵃnt þat ȝe me kysse
And þof I be gelous wyte me nouȝte
Ȝe bene so depe enpnted in my thouȝhte
That when þat I consider ȝour beaute
And þer with al þe vnlikhede of me
I may not Certes þof I schuld dye
For ber to bene oute of ȝour companye
For verrey loue þat is with outen doute
Nowe kisse me wiffe and lat us rome aboute
This fressh may when sche þise wordes herde
Benygly to Ianuar scho answerde
But firste and forwarde sche began to wepe
I haue qd sche a soule for to kepe
Als wele as ȝe and also myn honour
And of my wiffhede þilke tender flour
Whiche þat I haf assured in ȝour hande
When þat þe preste to ȝowe my body bande
Wher for I wol answer in þis maner
With þe leue of ȝowe my lorde so der
I pray god þat neủer dawe þat daye
þat I ne starfe as foule as eny wōmman may
Ȝiff eủer I do vn to my kynne þat schame
Or els þat I enpeir so my name
That I be fals and if I doo þat lakke
Do stripe me and putte me in a sakke
And in þe nexte riuer do me drenche
I am a gentil wōmman and no wenche
Why speke ȝe þus but men bene eủer vntrewe
And wōmmen hauen repreve of ȝowe ay newe
Ȝe can non oþ̉er9tinaunce I leue
But speke to us as vntriste and repue
And with þat worde sche sawe wher damyan
Sat in þe bussh and knele he began ¶þ
And with hir fyng sygnes made sche
That damyan schuld clymbe up on atr
That charchet was with fruyte and up he wente
For verrely he knewe al hir entente
And eủery signe þat sche couthe make
Wel bett̉er þan Ianuar hir own make
For in a lett̉er sche had tolde hym al
Of þis mat̉er howe he worchen schal
And þus I lete hym sitte in þe pirye
And Ianuarie and mayus rownyng ful mery
Briȝht was þe daye and blewe þe firmamente
Phebus of golde doun hath his stremes sente
To gladen eủery flour with his warmenesse
He was þat tyme in gemynys as I gesse
But litil fro his declinacoıı̄un
Off canser Iouis exaltacoıı̄un
And so be fel þat in a briȝht morwetyde
That in þe gardyn in þe ferþer side
Pluto þat is þe kynge of fairee
And mony a lady in his companye
Folowynge his wyffe þe quene ꝓprosarpina
Whiche þat he rauysshed oute of ꝓproserpina
Whils þat sche gadered flowres in a mede
In claudyan ȝe may þe stories rede
Howe in his grysly carte he hir sette
The kynge of fayr a doun hym sette
O pon a benche of tornys Fressh and grene
And riȝht onone said he þus to his quene
My wyff qd he þat may not say nay
The exꝑperience proueth it eủery day
The tresoun whiche þat womēn don to man
Ten hundreth thousande tellen I can
Notable of ȝour vntrowthe and brotelnes
O salon richeste of al riches
Fulfilled of sapience and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy ben þi wordes to memorie
To eủery wiȝht þat wytte and resoun can
Thus piseth he ȝit þe bonte of man
Amonge a thousand men ȝit fonde I one
But of alle wōmmen fonde he neủer none
Thus seith þis kynge þat knoweth ȝoᵘur wykednes
And Ihc filius Cyrak as I gesse
Ne speketh of ȝowe but selden reủerence ¶þ
A wilde fuyr a corrupte pestilence
So fal opon ȝour bodies ȝit to nyȝht
Ne se ȝe not þis honurable knyȝhte
Be cause allas þat he is blynde and olde
His own man schal make hym cokewolde
Loo wher he sitte þe lycchour in þe tr
Nowe wol I graunte of my maieste
Vn to þis olde blynde worthy knyȝhte
That he schal haf a ȝeyn his eyen siȝhte

l.seg: But cause allas þat he is blynde and olde

div.l: When þat his wiff wol done hym vilanye
Than schal he knowen alle his harlotrye
Both in reproffe of hir and oþ̉er moo
Ȝa schal qd proserpen and wol ȝe soo

Howe meryly þat oþer folkes fare
For certes olde dotarde be ȝour leue
Ȝe schal haf queynte riȝht ynowgh at eue
He is to grete a nygarde þat wil warne
A man to liȝht a candel at his lanterne
He schal haf neủer þe lesse lyȝht parde /
Haf þou ynowgh þe thar not pleyn / þ
Thou seiste also þat ȝiff þou make us / gaye
With clothyng or with pcious araye
That it is ꝑperil of our chastite
And ȝit with wordes ye moste enforce me
And seye þise wordes in þe Apostels name
In abite made with chastite and schame
Ȝe wōmmen schulde appairrel ȝowe qd he .
And nat entressed her and gay perr
As perle ne with golde ne clothes riche
Aft̉er þi texte ne aft̉er þi rubriche
I wol not wirke as michel as a knatte
Thou seidest als þat I was like a catte /
But who so wold swenge a cattes skynne
That wolde þe catte wele dwellen in his Inne
And ȝiff þe cattys skyn be sleight and gaye
She wil not dwel in þe house halfe a daye
¶ But forth scho wil er eny daye be dawede /
To schewe hir skynne and gon on kat̉erwawede
That is to seye / ȝif I be gaye sir schrewe
I wil renne oute myn horel for to schewe /
Sir olde fole what helpeth it þe to spien
Thof þou preye Argus with his thousand eyen
To be my warde cors as he can beste
In feithe he schal not kepe me but ȝif me liste
Ȝit couthe I make his berde so mot I thee
Thou seist eke þat þ̉er bene thynges thr
The whiche thynges troublen al þis erthe
And þat no wyȝht ne may endur þe ferthe
O lefe ʆsir schrewe . Ihu schorte þi lyffe
Ȝet prechest þou and seiste an hateful wyffe
I rekkoned it is for one of þise mychaunses
Ben þ̉er none oþ̉er man resemblaıı̄unses
That ȝe may likken ȝour ꝑparables to
But ȝiff a sely wyffe be one of þoo
Thou likkeneste wōmmannes loue to hel
To barreyn londe þ̉er wat̉er may not dwel
Thou likkeneste it also to wilde fyr
The mor it brenneth þe mor it hath desir
To 9sume eny thynge þat brente wolde be /
Thou seiste þat riȝhte as wormes schende a tr /
Riȝht so a wyffe destroieth hir husbonde
Lordynges riȝht þus as ȝe hauēn vndirstond
Bar I stifly myn olde husbondes on hande
As knowen þei þat ben þe wyffes bande
That þus þei seiden in hir drunkenesse
And eke þᵗat he hadde suspecioıı̄un and Ielousnes
On Ienken and on my nese also
O lorde þe peyn I did hem and þe woo /
Ful giltles be goddes swete pyne
For as an hors I couthe both bite and whyne
I couthe pleyne and I was in þe gilte
Or els ofte tyme I hadde bene spilte
Who so þat firste to þe myl cōmyth first grynte
I pleyned firste / so was our werr stynte
¶ Thei wer ful gladde to excusen hem be lyue
Of thyng of whiche þei a gilte neủer her lyffe
Of wenches wolde I beren hem on honde /
When þat for syke þei myȝht vnnethe stonde
Ȝit tikeled I his herte / for þat he
Wende I hadde of hym so grete chiertee
I swor þat al my walkynge be nyȝht
Was for to aspie þe wenches þat he diȝhte
Vndir þat colour had I mony a mirthe
For al suche witte is ȝiff us in our birthe
Desseyte wepyng spynnyng god hath ȝiffe
To wōmman kyndly whil þat þei may liffe
And þus of o thynge I auᵃnt me
At þe ende I hadde þe beste in ecche degr
By sleiȝhte or force / or by sum man̉er thynge
Al be 9tinuel murmoᵘur or grucchynge
Namely / in bedde / hadde þei myschaunce
Ther wolde I chide and do hem no plesaıı̄unce
I wolde no leng in þe bedde abyde
Ȝiff þat I felte his arme oủer my side /
Til he hadde made his raunsoıı̄un vnto me /
Than wolde I suffr hym do his nycete
And þerfor eủery man þis tale I telle
Wyffe who so may al arne forto sel
With empty hande men may non haukes lur
For wynnyng wold I al his luste endur
And make me a feyned appetite
And ȝit in bacoıı̄un had I neủer delite
That maked me þat eủer I wolde hym chide
For þof þe pope hadde sette hym beside
I wold not spar hym at his own bord
For be my trouthe I quitte hym worde for worde
As helpe me verrey godde omnipotente
Þof I riȝht nowe schuld make my testamente
I ne owe hym a worde þat it ne is y quytte
I broȝht it so aboute be my sotel wytte
That he muste ȝiff it up as for þe beste
Or ells hadde we neủer ben in reste
¶ For þof he loked as a lyoun
Ȝet schuld he fail of his conclusioıı̄un
Then wolde I seye nowe goode lefe take kepe
Howe mekely loketh wilkyn our schepe
Come ner my spouse lat me baa þi / cheeke
Ȝe schul be al paciente and meke
And haf a swete spiced conscience
Sethen ȝe so preche of Iobis pacience
Suffreth al weye sen ȝe so wele can pche
And but ȝe do . certeyn we schul ȝowe teche
That it is fair to haue a wyffe in pese
One of us mot bowen douteles
And suche a man is mor resonable
Than woman is . sir ȝe most be suffrable
What eyleth ȝowe to grucche þus and grone
Is it for ȝe wolde haue my queynte allone
Why take it alle lo haue it eủery dele
Petir I schrewe ȝowe but ȝiff ȝe loue me wele
For ȝiff I wolde sel my bele chose
I couthe walke as fressh as a roose
But I wol kepe it for ȝour own toothe
Ȝe be to blame by god I say ȝowe þe sothe
Suche man̉er wordes hadde we on honde
Nowe wyl I speke of my .iiij. fair husbonde
My ferthe husbonde was a reuelour
That is to saye he had a ꝑparamour
And I was ȝonge and ful of racherye
Stiburn and stronge and as a pye
Lorde howe couthe I daunse to an harpe smale
And synge y wys as eny nyȝhtyngale
When I hadde dronke a drawȝhte of swete wyne
Metelyng þe foule cherle þe swyne .
That with a staffe byrafte his wyffe her lyffe
For sche dranke wyne þogh I hadde bene his wyffe
Ne schuld he not / han daunted me fro drynke
And aft̉er wyne on venus moste I thenke
For also siker as colde engendreth hail
A likerous mouthe moste haf a likerous tayl
In wōmman vinolent is no defence
This knowen lecchours by exꝑperience
But lorde criste when þat it remembreth me
Opon my ȝouthe and my iolyte
It tikleth me a boute myn herte roote
Vn to þis daye it doith myne herte bote
That I haf had my worlde as in my tyme
But age allas þat al wol envenyme
Hath me birafte my beaute and my pithe
Lat go far wele þe deuyl go þ̉er with
The flour is gone þ̉er is no mor to telle
Þe brēn as I beste kan nowe mot I sel
But ȝit be riȝht myrie wol y fonde
Nowe forthe to tel of my iiij husbonde
I seye I hadde in herte grete despite
That he of eny oþ̉er hadde delite
But he was quytte by god and by seynte Iose
I made hym of þe same woode a croose
Not of my body in no foule maner
But certenly I made folke suche chier
That in his own grece I made him frye
For angers and for verrey Ielousye
By god in erthe I was his purgatorie
For whiche I hope his soule be in glorie
For god it wote he satte ful ofte and songe
When þat his scho ful bitterly hym wronge
For þ̉er was non saue god and he þat wiste
In mony wyse whor I hym twyste /
He dyed when I cam from Iherusalem
And lieth in a graue vndir þe rode beem
Al nys his tombe not so curious
As was þe sepulcr of hym darius
Whiche þat Appelles wroȝhten subtily
It nys but waste to bury hym pciously
Lat hym far wele god ȝiff his soule god reste
He is nowe in his graue and in his cheste
Nowe of my .v. husbonde wol I tel
God lat neủer his soule com in hel
And ȝit was he to me þe moste schrewe
That fele I on my ribbes al by rewe
And eủer schal on to myn endyng daye
But in our bedde he was so fressh and gay
And þer with al so wele couthe he me glose
When þat he wolde han my bele chose
That þogh he hadde me beten on eny bone
He couthe wynne a gayn my luff onone
I trowe I loued hym þe bette for he
Was of his loue daungerous to me /
We woman han ȝif þat I schal not lye
In þis maner a queynte fantasie /
Wayte what thynge we may not liȝhtly haue
Ther aft̉er wol we crie al daye and crave /
Forbede us thynge and þat desiren we
Preese on hus faste and þan wil we flye
With daunger vttren we al our chaffar
Grete preese at marketh der ware
And to grete chepe is y holde at litil prise
This knowen eủery man þat bene wyse
¶ My v. husbonde god his soule blesse
Whiche I toke for loue and for no richesse
He som tyme was a clerke of oxenforde
And had lefte scole and went at home to borde
With my gossep dwellyng in our town
God haue her soule her name was Alisoun
She knewe myn herte and al my priuete
Bett̉er þan our parissh preste so mot I thee
To hir bewreied I my counsel alle
For hadde myn husbonde pissed on a walle
Or done a thynge þat schulde haf coste his lyffe
To hir and to a noþ̉er wyrthy wyffe
And to my nece whiche I loue wele
I wolde hauen tolde his counsel eủerydele /
And so I did ful often god it wote
That made his face often rede and hote /
For verreye schame and blamed hym self / for he /
Hadde tolde to me so grete a priuete
And so it be fel þat / ones in a lente
So ofte tyme I to my gossipe wente
For eủer ȝit I loued to be gaye
And for to walke in marche aueril and Maye
Fro hous to house to herken soıı̄unday tales
That Ianken clerke and my gossepe dame Alys
And I my selfe in to þe feldes wente
Myn husbonde was at lond al þis lente
I hadde þe better laiser for to pley
And for to see ande eke for to be seye
Off lusty folke what wiste I wher my grace /
Was schapen for to be or in what place /
Ther for made I my visitacoıı̄uns
To vigiles and to processiouns
To prechynge eke and to þis pilgⁱmages
To pleyes of miracles and of mariages
And wered opon my gaye scarlet gytes
Thise wormes ne þise mothes ne þise mytes
Vpon my ꝑperil Frete hem neủer a dele
And wotest þou for þei wer vsed wele
Nowe wil I tellen forthe what happed me
I seye þat / in þe feldes walked he
Til trewly we hadde swiche dalyaunce
This clerke and I þat of my purveaunce
I spake to hym and said / howe þat he .
Ȝiff I wer wydowe schuld wedden me
For certenly I seye for no bobaunce /
Þat was I neủer ȝit with oute pʳueaunce
Of mariage ne of oþ̉er thynges eke
I holde a mouses witte not worth a leeke
That hath bot one hole for to / stirten to /
And ȝiff þat fail þan / is it al y doo
But nowe sir lat me se what schal I seyne
A ha by god I haf my / tale a gayne
When þat my ferthe husbonde was on ber
I wepe algate and made sory cher
As wiffes moten for it is vsage /
And with my keủerchief couered my visage
But for þat I was purveied of a maake
I wepe but smal and þat I vndirtake /
To chirche was myn husbonde y borne on þe morwe
With neiȝhbores þat for hym made sorowe /
And Ienkyn our clerke was one of þoo
As helpe me godde / when þat I see hym goo
Aft̉er þe ber me thoght he hadde a pair
Of legges and feete so clene and fair
That al myn herte I ȝaf vn to his holde
He was I trowe xx . wynt̉er olde
And I was fourtye ȝiff I schal / seye / þe sothe
But ȝit I hadde al weye a coltes tooth
Gat tothede I was and þat becom me wele
I hadde þe printe of seint venus seele
As helpe me / god I was a lusty one
And fair and riche and ȝonge and wele begone
And trewly as myn husbonde tolde me
I hadde þe beste . qm. þat myȝht be /
Myne ascendent was taur and mars þ̉erin
Allas allas þat eủer loue was synne
I folowed aye myn enclinacoıı̄un
Be vertue of my constellacioun
That made me I couthe / not with drawe
My / chambr of venus from a goode felowe
What schulde I seye but at þe monethes ende
This Ioly clerke Ienkyn þat was so hende
Hath wedded me with grete solempnite
And to hym ȝaff I al þe londe and fee /
That eủer was me ȝiffen þ̉er beforne
But aft̉erwarde repented me ful sor
He nolde suffr no thynge of my lyste
Be god he smote me ones on þe leste
For þat I rente oute of his booke a leefe
That of þat stroke myn eren wer / deefe /
Stiborne I was as is a leonesse
And of my tonge a verrey Iangeleresse
And walke I wolde as I had done be forne
From hous to hous al þof he had it / sworne
For whiche ful often tyme he wolde preche
And me olde romaunce gestes teche
Howe he simplicius gallus lefte his wyffe
And hir forsoke for terme of his lyffe
Nat but for opynhede he hir saye
Lokynge oute at his dor on a daye
A nother romayn tolde he me be name
That for his wiffe was at / a somm̉er gam /
With oute his wytynge he for soke hir eke /
And þan wolde he opon his / bible seke
That ilke ꝓprouerbe of eccliāesiastice
Wher he 9maundeth and forbedith faste
Man / schal not suffr his wyff go / royl aboute
Than wolde he sey riȝht so / with outen douȝte
Who so þat bildeth / his howse alle of salwys
And / priketh his blynde hors oủer þe falewes
And suffreth / his wiffe for to seken halowys
Is wyrthy to bene hongede on þe galwes
But al for nouȝt I sette not an hawe /
Of his ꝓprouerbes ne of his olde lawe /
Ne I wold not of hym corrected be
I hate hym þat my vice tellith m
And so do mo god wote of vs þan I
This made hym with me wode al vttirly
I nolde not forber hym in no caas
Nowe wil I seye ȝowe sothe be seynt thomas
Why þat I rente oute of his booke a leef
For which he smote me þat I was deefe
He hadde a booke þat gladly nyȝht and daye
For his disporte he wolde rede al weye
He teched valerie and theofraste /
At whiche boke he logh al weye ful faste
And eke þ̉er was somtyme a clerke in rome
A Cardinal þat hiȝht seynt Ierome
That made a booke a ȝeyn Ieuuniane /
In whiche booke eke / þ̉er was terculane
Crisippus trocula and helowys
That was Abbesse not ferr from parisshe
And eke þe ꝑparaboles of salamon
Ouydes arte and bookes mony one /
And al þise wer fouden in oo volome
And eủery nyȝht and daye was his custome
When he hadde leyser and vacacioun /
From oþ̉er worldly occupacoıı̄un
Te reden in þis booke of wykked wyffes
He knewe of hem mo legendes and / lyffes
Than be of goode wyffes in þe bible
For trusteth wele it is an inpossible
That eny clerke wol speken goode of wyffes
But ȝiff it be of holy seyntes lyffes
Ne of none oþ̉er wōmmān neủer þe moo
Who peynted þe lyoun tel me who
By godde ȝiff wymēn hadden writte stories
As clerkes han with in hir oratories
Thei wolde han writen of men mor wykkednes
Than al þe marke of Adam may redresse
The children of mercury and venus
Ben in hir worchynge contrarious
Mercury loueth wysdom and science
And venus loueth riote and despense
And for her diuerse disposicioun
Eithe fallith in others exaltacoun
As þus / god wote / mercurye is desolate
In pisces wher venus is exaltate
And venus falleth þer mcurye is reised
Ther for no wōmman of no man is preisede
The clerke when he is olde and may not do /
Of venus werkes worth his olde schoo
Than sitte he doun and writte in his dotage
That wōmmen kon not kepe her mariage
But nowe to purpos why I tolde þe
Þat I was beten for a booke ꝑparde
Opon a nyȝht Iankyn þat was our syr
Redde on his booke as he satte by þe fuyr
Of eua firste þat for hir wykkednesse
Was al man kynde brouȝht to wrecchednes
Tho redde he me howe sampsoıı̄un loste his hers
Slepyng his lēmman kit it with her scherys
Thourgh whiche tresoun loste he both his eyen
Tho redde he me ȝiff þat I schal not lyen
Of hercules and of his dyamyr
That caused hym to sette hym selfe on fir
No thynge forgat he þe penᵃnce and woo /
That socrates hadde with his wyffes twoo
Howe þat ancipa caste pisse on his hede
This sely man satte stil as he wer dede
He wyped his hede no mor durste he seyn
But er thunder stynt cōmeth a reyn
Of phasipha þat was þe quene of grete
For schrewdnes hym thouȝt þetale swete
Fye speke no mor it is a grissly thynge
Of hir horrible luste and hir likynge
Of clit̉ermistra for her leccherye
That falsly made hir husbonde for to dye
He redde it with wel goode deuocoıı̄un
He tolde me for what occasioun
Amphiorax at thebes loste his lyffe /
Myn husbonde hadde a legende of his lyffe
Eriphilem þat for a nouche of golde
Hath priuely vn to þe grekis tolde
Wher þat hir husbonde hidde hym in / a place
For whiche he hadde at thebes sory grace
Of lyma tolde he me and of lucye
Thei both made her husbondes for to dye
The tone for loue þe toþ̉er was for hate /
Lyma hir husbonde on euen late
Enpoisende had for / þat sche was his foo
Lucia likorous loued hir husbonde soo
That for he schuld opon hir alweye thynke
She ȝaf hym suche a loue man̉er drynke
That he was dede or / it wer by þe morowe
And þus / algates husbondes hauen sorowe
Than tolde he / me howe one latumius
Compleyned to his felowe Ari9
That in his gardyn growed suche / a tr
On whiche he seide þat his wiffes thr
Henged hem selfe for hertes despitous
O leue broþ̉er qd þis Arius
Ȝiff me a plante of þat blisful tr
And / in my gardyn planted shal it be
Of latter date of wyffes hath he redde
That han slayne hir husboıı̄unde in þe / bedde
And let hir lecchour diȝht hir al þis nyȝht
When þat þe cors lay in þe flour upriȝht
And som han driffen nailles in hir brayne
Whils þat þei slepe and þ9 þei han hem slayn
Som hauen ȝiffen poisen in her drynke
He spake mor harme þen herte may be thynke
And þ̉er with al he knewe of mo ꝓprouerbes
Than in þis worlde þ̉er growen gresse or erbes
Bet is qd he þine habitacioıı̄un
Betwix a lyoun or a foule dragoun
Than with a wōmman vsynge for to chide
Bet is qd he hieȝh in þe roofe abide
Than with an angry wyffe doun in an house
Thei bene so wykked and contrarius
Thei haten þat her husbondes loueth ay
He seide a wōmman Caste hir schame a weye
When scho caste of hir smokke and forþ̉ermo
A fair wōmman but sche be chaste also /
Is like a gold ryng on a sowes nose
Who wolde wene or wolde suppose
The wo þat in myn hert was and pyne
And when I sawe he wolde neủer fyne
To reden on þis cursed booke al nyȝht
Al sodenly thr leues haue I plyȝth
Out of his boke riȝht as he rede and eke
I with my fiste toke hym on þe chek
Þat in our fyr he fel bakwarde a doun
And he up stirte as doith a wode lyoun
And with his fiste he smote me on myn hede
That in þe flor I laye as I wer dede
Ande whan he sawe howe stil þat I laye
He was a gaste and wolde haf fledde a weye
Til at þe laste oute of my swowe I braide
O hast þou slayn me fals thefe I seyde
And for my lande þus hast þou murdered / me
Or I be dede ȝit I wil kisse þe
And ner he com and kneled fair a doun
And saide der suster Alisoun
As helpe me godde I schal þe neủer smyte
That I haf done it is þi self to wyte
Forȝiff it me and þat I þe beseke
And ȝit eft sones I hitte hym on þe cheke
And seide thefe þus mychel I am wreke
Nowe wil I dye I may no leng speke
But at þe laste with mychel car and woo
We fel acorded be us selffen twoo
He ȝaff me al / þe bridel in myn honde
To haue þe goủernaunce of house and londe
And of his tonge and his honde also
And made hym brenne his booke onon / riȝht þo
And when þat I had goten vn to me
Be maistr al þe souereynte
Than he seide myn own trewe luff my wyff
Do as þou liste þe terme of al þi lyffe
Kepe þin honour and kepe eke myn astate
Aft̉er þat day we hadde neủer mor debate
God helpe me so I was to hym als kynde
As eny wyffe from denmarke in to ynde
And also trewe and so was he to me
I pᵃye to godde þat sitteth in mageste
So blisse his soule for his mercy der
Now wil I sey my tale if ȝe wil her

div.l: THe frer logh when he had hard al þis
Now Dame qd he so haue I Ioye or blisse
This is a longe pamble of a tale
And when þe somnour herde þe frer gal
Loo qd þe somnoᵘur / by goddes armes twoo
A frer wil entremete hym eủermoo
Loo goode men a flie and eke a frer
Wollen falle in eủery dyssh and eke matier
What spekest þou of preambulacoıı̄un
What amble or trotte or go sitte a doun
Þou letteste our desporte in our manere
Ȝa wilt you so / somnoᵘur / qd þe frer

God saue ȝowe alle saue þis cursed frer͗e
My prologe woll I ende in þis maner͗e
¶ Here begynneth þe somnours tale
Lordynges þ̉er is in ȝorke schir͗e as I gesse
A mersshy countr͗e called holdernesse
In whiche þ̉er wente a limitour a boute
To preche and eke to begge it is no doute
And so bifeƚƚ þat on a daye þis frer͗e
Hadde preched at chirche in þis maner͗e
And specially abouen̄ eủery thynge
Excited he þe peple in his p̉rechynge
To trentales and for goddis sake
Ther with men̄ myȝht holy howses make
Ther as diuine seruice is honoured
Nouȝt þ̉er as it is wasted and deuourede
Ne þ̉er it nedeth not for to ben̄ ȝiffe
As to possessioners þat may ells lyffe
Thonked be god in wele ande habundaunce
Trentales seyd he deliuereth fro penᵃaunce
Her frendes soules as wele olde as ȝonge
Noȝt for to holde a preste Ioly and gaye
He syngeth not but o messe in a daye
Delyuerith oute qduod he onon̄ þe soules
Fuƚƚ harde it is with flessh hoke oþ̉er wᵗith oulys
Nowe spede ȝowe hastyly for cristis sake
To kepe ȝowe from þe peynes of fendes blake
And when þe frer͗e had seide al þˢis entente
With qui cum prẻre forth he wente
When̄ folke in cherche had ȝoff hym what hem leste
He wente his weye no leng̉er wolde he reste
With scrippe and tipped staf tucked full hye
In eủery house he gan̄ to pour͗e and prye
And beggeth mele or chese or eƚƚs corne
His felowe had a staffe tipped with horne
A pair͗e of tables of yuery
Ande a poyntell polisshed fetosly
And wrote þe names alweye as he stode
Of eny folke þat ȝiff hym eny goode
Ascaıı̄unce þat he wolde for hem preye
Ȝiff us a bussheƚƚ whete malte or rye
A goddis kechil or els a trippe of chese
Or ells what ȝowe liste we may not chese
A goddꝭes halpeny or a messe peny
Or ȝiff us of ȝour͗e bran ȝiff ȝe haf eny
A dagon̄ of ȝour͗e blanket leue dame
Our͗e sust̉er der͗e lo her͗e I write ȝour name
Bakon̄ or beefe or suche thynge as ȝe fynde
A sturdy harlot wente hym ay behynde
That was hir ostes man̄ and bar a sakke
And what men̄ ȝaf hym layde it on his bakke
And when̄ he was oute at þe dor͗e onon̄
He playned a weye þe names eủerychon̄
That he be for hadde writen̄ in his tables
He ʆserued hem with nyfles and with fables
Nay þ̉er þou lixte þou somnoᵘur qduod þe frer͗e
Pees qduod our͗e oste for cristꝭes moder der͗e
Tell fortħ þi tale spar͗e it noȝt at aƚƚlle
So thryfe I qduod þis somnoᵘur so I schaƚƚlle
So longe he wente house be house qduod he
Till he come to an hous þ̉er he was wonte to be
Refresshede mor͗e þan in an hundretħ plases
Syke lay þe bonde man̄ whose þe plase is
And opon̄ a couche lowe he lay
Deus hic qduod he O thomas frende good daye
Seyde þis frer͗e curtasly and softe
Thomas saide he god ȝelde ȝowe full ofte
Haf I opon þis benche faren full wele
Her͗e haf I eten̄ mony a mery mele
And fro þe benche he droffe a weye þe catte
And leyde doun̄ his potent and his hatte
And eke his scrippe and sette hym softe a doun̄
His felowe was gone walked in þe town̄
Fortħ witħ his knaue in to þat ostellerye
Wher as he schope hym þat ilke nyȝht for to lye
O der͗e maist̉er qduod þis seke man̄
Howe han̄ ȝe far͗e sethen̄ þat marche be ganne
I sawe not þis fourte nyȝħt and mor͗e
Godde wote qduod he laboured haf I fuƚƚ sor͗e
And specially for þi saluacon̄
Haue I seide mony a preciouse orison̄
And for our͗e other frendes god hem blesse
I haf to day done at ȝour͗e chirche a messe
And saide a sermoun aft̉er my symple wytte
Noȝt aƚƚ aft̉er þe texte of holy writte
For it his harde to ȝowe as I suppose
Therfor͗e I teche to ȝowe aƚƚ þe glose
Glosynge is a gloriouse thynge certeyn̄
For lett̉er sleeth as clerkes seyn̄ certeyn̄
Ther haf I tauȝht hem to be charitable
And spende hyr goode þ̉er it is resonable
Ther I sawe our͗e dame a wher͗e is sche
Ȝonde in þe ȝerde I trowe sche bee
Seide þis man and sche woƚƚ come onon̄
Eye maist̉er welcom̄ be ȝe be seynt Iohn̄
Seyde þis wyffe howe far͗e ȝe hertely
The frer͗e ariseth up fuƚƚ curtasly
And hir͗e enbrased in his armes narewe
And kisseth hir swete and chirketh as a sparowe
With his lippes dame qduod he riȝht wele
As he þat is ȝour͗e seruᵃaunt eủery dele
Y thanked be good þat ȝowe saf soule and lyffe
Ȝit sawe I not to daye so fair a wyffe
In aƚƚ þe chirche god so haue me
Ȝa god amende defautes sir͗e qduod sche
Algates welcom̄ be ȝe be my feye
Graunt m̉ercy dame þis haf I founde alweye
But of ȝour grete goodnes by ȝour͗e leue
I wolde pray ȝowe þat ȝe not ȝowe a greue
I will with thomas speken̄ a litiƚƚ throwe
This curates ben̄ fuƚƚ necligent and slowe
To gropen̄ tendirly a ꝯconscience
In schrifte and in p̉rechynge is my diligence
And studye in Petirs wordes and in Poules
I walke and fyssh mennys soules
To ȝelden̄ iħuihesu criste his ꝓpropre rente
To sprede his wordes his sette all myn̄ entente
¶ Nowe be ȝour͗e leue o der͗e sir qduod sche
Chidetħ hym wele for god in trinite
He is als angry as a pisse myr͗e
Þof þat he haf also þat he can̄ desir͗e
Thof I hym wrye a nyȝħt ande make hym warme
And on̄ hym leye myn̄ legge or myn̄ arme
He gronytħ like our͗e bor grouynge in þe stye
Oþer disporte of hym riȝħt none haf I ·
I may not plesen̄ hym in no man̉er caas
Ieo cons dye trescher ⁊and ben amy O thomas
Þis maketħ þe fende þis mot bene amended
Ir͗e is a thynge þat hiely god defended
And þ̉er of woƚƚ I speke a worde or twoo
Nowe maist̉er qduod þe wyffe or þat I goo
What woll ȝe dyne I woƚƚ go þ̉er a boute
Nowe dame qduod he ies vous dye saunz doute
Haue I not of a capon̄ but þe lyuer
And of ȝour͗e softe brede but a schyuer
And aft̉er þat a rosted pykges hede
But þat I wolde for me no beest wer͗e dede
Then hadde I witħ ȝowe holy suffisaunce
I am a man̄ of litiƚƚ sustenᵃaunce
My spirit is fostred in þe bible
The body is ay so redy and penyble
To wake þat my stomake is destroiede
I pray ȝowe dame þat ȝe be noȝt anoyede
Thof I so frendly my counseiƚƚ schewe
By god I wold not teƚƚ it but a fewe
Nowe sir qduod sche but oo worde or I goo
My childe is dede with in þise wokes twoo
Sen̄ þat ȝe wente oute of þis toun̄
His deth sawe I be reuelacoıı̄un
Seitħ þis frer͗e at home in our͗e dortour
I dar wele seyn̄ þat er þat half an hour
Aft̉er his deeth I sawe hym borne to blisse
In myn̄ a visioun so god me wyssh
So did our͗e sexteyn and our͗e fermorer
Þat han̄ bene trewe freres full · l · ȝer͗e
Þei may nowe god bithanke of his lone
Maken her iubilee and walken allone
And up I roose and aƚƚ our͗e couente eke
With mony a ter͗e trillynge on my cheke
With outen noyse or clat̉erynge of bellys
Te deum was our͗e songe and no thynge elles
Saue þat to criste I seide an orisoun
Thankynge hym of his reuelacoıı̄un
For sir and dame trustetħ me riȝħt wele
Our͗e orisons bene mor͗e espiritueƚƚlle
And more we seen̄ of Cristes secre thynges
Than burell folke in richesse and wynnynges
Of mete and drynke and in hir foule delite
We haue þis worldes luste aƚƚ in despite
Lazar and diues lifeden̄ diuersly
And diuerse guerdon̄ had þei þ̉er by
Who so woƚƚ preye he mot faste and be clene
And fatte his soule and make his body lene
We far͗e as seitħ þe aposteƚƚ clothe and fode
Suffisetħ us þof þei be not goode
The clennes and þe fastynge of us freris
Makth þat Criste accepteth our͗e praiers
Loo moyses · xl · dayes : and xl nyȝht
Fasted or þat þe hie god of miȝht
Spake with hym in þe mount of synay
Witħ empty wombe fastynge mony a daye
Resseyued he þe lawe þat was writen̄
With goddis fynger and helias wel ȝe wyten̄
In þe mounte or ells or he hadde eny speche
With hye god þat is our͗e liffes leche
He fasted longe and was in contemplaunce
And aaron̄ þat had þe temple of godde in goủernaunce
And eke þat oþ̉er p̉restes eủerychone
In to þe temple when̄ þei schuld gone
To praye for þe peple and to do seruice
Thei nolden̄ drynke in no man̉er wyse
No drynke whiche þat myȝht hem dronke make
But eủer in abstinence preye and wake
Leste þat þei died take hede what I seye
But þei bene sobr͗e þat for þe peple praye
War þat I seye no mor͗e for it suffiseth
Our͗e lorde iħcihesu as holy god deviseth
Ȝiffith us ensample of fastynge and of pᵃraiers
Ther for͗e we mendivauntes we por freres
Bene wedded to poủerte and to ꝯcontinence
To charite humblesse and also pacience
To persecucion̄ for riȝhtwysnes
To wepyng misericorde and clennesse
And þer for may ȝe see þat our͗e praiers
I speke of us we mendenᵃaunt freres
Bene to þe hye godde mor͗e acceptable
Than ȝowr͗es with ȝour͗e feste at þe table
For ꝑparadise firste ȝif I schaƚƚ not lye
Was man oute chased for his glotonye
And chaste was man in ꝑparadise certeyn̄
But herke þer what I schaƚƚ seyn̄
I haf no texte of þat as I suppose
But I schaƚƚ fynde it in a man̉er glose
That specially our͗e swete lorde iħcihesus
Spake þus by vers when̄ he seide þus
Blessed ben̄ þei þat por͗e in spirit bene
And so forth all þe gospelƚ may ȝe seen̄
Wher it be like our͗e ꝓprofessioun̄
Or her͗e þat swymmen̄ in possessioun̄
Fye on hir pompe and on hir glotonye
And for hir lewdnesse I hem deffye
Me thynketh thei ben̄ like Iouynyan
Fatte as a whall and walkyng as a swan
As violent as botell in þe spence
Hir praier is fulƚ of grete reuerence
When̄ þei for soules soules soules seyn̄ þe spalme of dauid .
Loo buff þei þei seyn̄ cor meuıı̄um eructauit
Who foloweth Cristes gospelƚ and his lor͗e
But we þat humble be and chaste and por͗e
Werkers of goddꝭes worde and eke auditours
Therfor͗e ryȝht as an hauke ripe at a soᵘurs
Vp spryngeth vn to þe eyr riȝht pᵃraiers
Of charitable and chaste besy freres
Maken̄ her soᵘurs to goddes eren̄ and who
Thomas þer for so mot I ride or goo
And by þat god þat cleped is seynt yue
Ner͗e þou wer our͗e brother schuldest þou neủer thryue
In our͗e Chapter praye we daye and nyȝħt
To criste þat he sende þe hele and myȝħte
Thy body for to welden̄ hastily
God wote qduod he no thynge þ̉er of wote I
As helpe me criste as in fewe ȝeres
Haue I spended opon̄ diuerse man̉er freres
Fuƚƚ mony a pounde ȝit far͗e it neủer þe bette
Certeyn̄ my goode haf I almoste be sette
Far wele my golde for it is alƚ a goo
The frer͗e answerde O thomas why dost þᵘou soo
What nedeth ȝowe diuerse freres to seche
What nedith hym þat hath a ꝑparfite leche
To sechen̄ oþ̉er leches in þe toun
For ȝour͗e inꝯconstance is ȝour͗e ꝯconfusioun̄
Holde ȝe þen me or elles our͗e couent
To preye for ȝowe bene insufficiente
Thomas þat iape is not worth a myte
Ȝour͗e maladye is for ȝe hauen̄ ȝiffen us so lite
A ȝiff þat couente halfe a quart̉er otes
A ȝiff hem one or twoo grotes
A ȝiff þe frer͗e a peny and lete hym goo
Nay nay thomas it may no thynge bee soo
What is a ferthyng worth ꝑparted in twelfe
Loo whiche thynge þat is oned by hym selfe
Is mor͗e strange þan when̄ it is slaterede
Thomas of me þou schalt not bene flatered
Thou woldest our͗e labour haf for nouȝte
The hie godde þat al þis worlde hath wrouȝht
Seith þat þe workeman is worthy his hir͗e
Thomas noȝte of ȝour͗e tresour I desir͗e
As for my selfe but þat al our͗e counente
To praye for ȝowe is ay so diligente
And for to bylden̄ cristes own̄ chirche
Thomas ȝiff ȝe wiƚƚ lerne for to wirche
Of byldynge up of chirches may ȝe fynde
If it be goode in thomas lyffe of ynde
Ȝe ligge her͗e fuƚƚ of angr͗e and of ir͗e
With þe whiche þe deueƚƚ sette ȝoᵘur ers of fyr͗e
And chyden̄ her þis holy innocente
Ȝour͗e wiff þat is so meke and paciente
And þer for thomas trowe me ȝiff ȝowe liste
Ne stryffe not wyffe alƚ for þe beste
And ber͗e þis worde a weye be þi faith
Touchyng suche thynge lo what þe wise man̄ seith
With in þine house ne be þou no lyoun̄
To þi subiectis do non̄ oppressioun
Ne make þine aqueyntaıı̄unce not for to flye
And thomas ȝit eftesones say I þee
Be war for hir͗e þat in þi bosom̄ slepitħ
Be war of þe serpent þat so slyle crepitħ
Under þe grasse þat skynkgeth sotelly
Be war my sone and herken paciently
That xx thousand men̄ han̄ loste her lyffes
For þat þei haue bene spitous to her wyffes
Nowe sethens ȝe han̄ so holy and so meke a wyffe
What nedeth ȝowe thomas to maken̄ stryffe
Ther is I wis no serpente so crwell
When̄ men trede on his taiƚƚ ne halfe so feƚƚ
As woman is when̄ sche hath cauȝht an ir͗e
Vengeaunce is þan aƚƚ þat þei desir͗e
Ir͗e is a synne one of þe grete of seuen̄
Abhominable vnto god of heuen̄
And to hym selfe it is destruccioun̄
This eủery lewed vicary or ꝑpersoune
Can say howe ir͗e engendreth homicide
Ir͗e in sooth is executor of pride
I couthe of ir͗e saye so muche sorowe
My tale schuld laste til to morowe
And þer For I pray god both day and nyȝht
An irous man send hym litiƚƚ myȝhte
It is grete harme and certes grete pite
To sette an Irous man in hiegh degree
¶ Whilom þer was an Irous potest ate
As seitħ senek duryng his estate
Opon̄ a day oute riden̄ knyȝhtes twoo
And as fortune wolde it wer͗e soo
The tone of hem com̄ home þe toþ̉er noȝte
A none þe knyȝht be for þe hie iugge is brouȝte
And said þus þou hast þi felowe slayn̄
For whiche I deme þe to deeth certeyn̄
And to a noþ̉er knyȝht ꝯconmaunded he
Go lede hym to þe dethe I charche þe
And happed as þei wente by þe waye
Towarde þe place þer as he schuld dye
The knyȝht come whiche þei wende had ben̄ dede
Then̄ thoȝhten̄ þei it wer͗e þe beste rede
To lede hem bothe to þe Iugge a ȝeyn̄
Thei seiden̄ lorde þe knyȝht ne hath not slayn̄
His felowe her͗e he stante on lyffe
Ȝe shulue be dede qduod he so mote I thryue
That is to saye both one and twoo and thr͗e
And to þe firste knyȝht riȝt þus spake he
div.note: ¶ Þe somnour ·
div.l: I dampned þe þou moste algate be dede
And þou also moste nedes lese þin hede
For þou art cause why þi felowe deietħ
And to þe thridde knyȝht riȝt þus he seitħ
Thou haste not done þat I ꝯcommaunded þe
And þus do slee hem aƚƚ thr͗e
Irous kambises was eke dronkelewe
And ay delited hym to bene a schrewe
And so befeƚƚ a lorde of his menȝee
That loued vertuos moralite
Saide on a day vn to hym selfe riȝht þus
A lorde is loste if he be vicious
And dronkenesse is eke a fouler recorde
Of eny man̄ and namely in a lorde
Ther is fuƚƚ mony an eye and mony an er͗e
Awaytynge on a lorde and he note wher͗e
For goddes luff drynketh mor͗e attemꝑperatlye
Wyne maketh man̄ to lesen wrichedly
His mynde and his lymes also eủerychon̄
The reủers schalt þou se qduod he onon̄
And proue it be þine own̄ exꝑperience
That wyne doith to folke non̄ suche offence
Ther is no wyne bereuȳth me my myȝht
Of hande ne fote ne of myn̄ eyen̄ siȝht
And for despite he dranke fuƚƚ myche mor͗e
An hundreth parte þen he hadde done be for͗e
And riȝħt onon̄ þis cursed wrecche
Lete þis knyȝhtes sone be forne hym fecche
Comandyng hem þei schuld be for hym stonde
And sothenly he toke his bowe on honde
And vp þe strenge he pulled vn to his er͗e
And with an arwe he slowe þe childe riȝht þer͗e
Nowe whedir haf I a siker hande or none
ꝘQuod he is aƚƚ my wytte and my myȝht agone
Hath wyne bereved me myn̄ eyen siȝht
What schuld I teƚƚ þe answer͗e of þe knyȝht
His son̄ was slayn̄ þ̉er is no more to saye
Be war þer fore with lordes howe þat ȝe pleȳe
Syngeth placebo and I schall ȝiff I can̄
But ȝiff it be vn to a por͗e man̄
To a por͗e man men̄ schulde his vices telle
But not to a lorde þof he schuld gon̄ to heƚƚlle
div.note: ¶ Þe somnoure ·
div.l: Lo Irous syrous þilke ꝑpercien̄
Howe he destroied þe ryủer of gysen̄
For þat an hors of his was dreynte þ̉er in
When þat he wente sabilon̄ to wynne
He made þat þe riuer was so smaƚƚlle
That wōmmen̄ myȝhten wade oủer aƚƚlle
Loo what seide he þat so wele teche can̄
Be þou no felowe to non̄ irous man̄
Ne with no woode man̄ walke by þe weye
Leste þe repente I woƚƚ no mor saye
Nowe thomas leue broþ̉er leue þine Ir͗e
Thou schalt me fynde as iuste as is a squir͗e
Holde not þe deuylls knyffe ay at þine herte
Thyn anger doith þe al to sor͗e smerte
But schewe to me aƚƚ þi confessioun̄
Nay qduod þe sike man̄ be seynt Symoun̄
I haue ben̄ schryffen̄ þis day at my curate
I haf hym tolde al holy myn̄ astate
It nedith no mor͗e speke of it said he
But if me luste of myn̄ humilite
Ȝiff me þen̄ of þi golde to make our͗e cloistr͗e
Qduod he for mony a muscle and mony an oistr͗e
Hath bene our͗e fode our͗e cloistr͗e for to reise
When̄ oþ̉er men̄ hauen̄ fuƚƚ wele at eyse
And ȝit good wote vnnethes þe foundement
ꝐParfourmed is ne of our͗e pauymente
Nys not at tile ȝit with in our͗e loues
By godde we owen̄ xl · li for stones
Nowe helpe thomas for hym þat harowed heƚƚlle
Or ells mot we our͗e bokes selle
And if we lakke our͗e predicacoıı̄un
Then goith þe worlde all to destruccioun
For who so wolde fro þis worlde us bireven̄
So god me saue thomas be ȝour͗e leuen̄
He wolde byreue out of þe worlde þe sonne
For who can̄ werche and teche as we conne
And þat is not of litiƚƚ tyme qduod he
But sethens Elye was or elisee
Hauen freris bene þat fynde I of recorde
In charite y thonked be our͗e lorde
Nowe thomas helpe for seynt charitee
⁊And doun on̄on he sette hym on his knee
This seke man̄ wex wel nyeȝh wodde for ir͗e
He wolde þat þe frer had bene in þe fir͗e
With his fals dissimulacoıı̄un
Suche thynge as is her in my possessioun
Qduod he þat I may ȝeue and non other
Ȝe seyn̄ me þus þat I am ȝour brother
Ȝe certes qduod þe frer trusteth wele
I toke our dame our letters with our sele
¶Nowe wele qduod he and somwhat schaƚƚ I ȝiffe
Vn to ȝour holy couent while y lyffe
And in þine honde þou schalt it haf onon̄
Vp on þis ꝯcondicion̄ myn̄ own̄ der brother
That eủery frer haf als myche as other
This schalt þou swer on þi professioun
With outen fraude or cauyllacioıı̄un
I swer it qduod þis frer opon̄ my faith
And þ̉er with al his honde in his he leieth
Loo her my faith in me schaƚƚ be no lakke
Then putte þine honde doun̄ be my bakke
Saide þis man̄ and grope wel be hynde
Bonethen̄ my buttoke þer schalt þou fynde
A thynge þat I haf hidde in priuete
A thouȝht þis frer þat schaƚƚ go with me
And doun his hande he launcetħ vn to þe clifte
He hoped þ̉er to fynden̄ a ȝifte
And þan̄ fuƚƚ besy was þis frer
A bouten̄ his toweƚƚ gropyng her and þer
A myd his hand he lete þe frer a ferte
Ther is no capeƚƚ drawynge in þe carte
That myȝht haf lete a farte of suche a soun̄
The frer up sterte as it wer a frers lyoun̄
A fals cherle qduod he for cokkes loues
This hast þou for despite done for þe nones
Thou schalt abye þis farte if þat I may
His menȝe which þat harden̄ þis affraye
Come lepynge in and chased oute þe frer͗e
And forth he goith with a fuƚƚ angry cher͗e
And fette his felowe þ̉er as laye his stoor
He loked as it wer a wilde bore
He grynted his teeth so was he wrothe
A sturdy paas doun̄ to þe courte he goith
Wher as þ̉er woned a man of grete honour
To whome þat he was alweye confessour
This worthy man̄ was lorde of þat village
Þis frer come as þof it wer in a rage
Where as þis lorde satte etynge at his borde
Vnnethes myȝht þe frer speke oo worde
Tiƚƚ at þe laste he seide god ȝowe see
This lorde gan loke and saide benedicite
Qduod he frer Ioħn what man̉er ***worlde*** is þis
I see wele þat som thynge is a mysse
Ȝe loken̄ as þe wode wer fuƚƚ of thefes
Sytte doun̄ onon̄ and teƚƚ me what ȝowe grefes
And it schaƚƚ be amended if þat I may
I haf qduod he had despite to daye
God ȝelde ȝowe a doun in ȝour vilage
That in þis worlde þ̉er is none so por a page
That he nolde haue abhominacoıı̄un
Of þat I haf resseyued in ȝour town̄
And ȝit me greuyth no thynge so sore
As þat þis olde cherle with lokkys hor
Blasfemed hath our holy conuent eke
Nowe maist̉er qduod þis lorde I ȝowe beseke
No maist̉er qduod he but seruitour
Thof I hadde in scole þat honour
God liketh not þat men̄ no Rabi calle
Neiþ̉er in Market ne in ȝour halle
No force qduod he but teƚƚ me of ȝour grefe
Sir qduod þe frer an hidous myschiefe
This day betidde is to myn̄ ordr͗e and me
And so ꝑpar consequens to ech degree

(base) To parte that wol nat departed be
