Here begynneth þe prologe of þe Clerke of Oxenforde
Sir clerke of oxenford oure ooste saide
Ye ride as stille and coy as doothdootha maide
Woer newe spowsed sittynge at þe borde
This day ne harde I of your mouthe a worde
I trowe þat þe studie aboute som Sophyme
But Salon seith al thyngs hath tyme
For goddes sake beeth of betr cher
It is no tyme nowe to studie her
Tel us som mery tale be your faye
For what mān is entred in to a playe
He nedes mote in to þat playe assente
But ꝑpercheth not as freres done in lente
To make us for our olde synnes to wepe
No þat þi tale no make vs not to slepe
Tel vs som mery thinge of aduentures
Your termes your figours and your coloures
Kepe hem in stoor til so be ye hem endite .
Heigh stile as when men to kynges write
Spekith so pleyne at þis tyms I yowe pye ¶
Þat we may vndrestonde what ȝe saye
This worthy clerke benignely answerede
Ooste qd he I am vnder your yerde
Ye haue as nowe of vs ye gouernaunce
And þer for wil I do yowe obeisaunce
As fer as resoıı̄un asketh hardely
I wil yowe a tale whiche þat . I
Lerned at Padowe of a worthy clerke
As proued by his wordews and his werke
He is nowe dede and nailled in his cheste
I py to god so sende his soule goode reste
Francistus Petrak þe laureol poete
Hiȝh þis clerke whos retorike swete
Enlumyneth al Italye thrygh poetrye
As Lynyan did of philosophie
Or lawe or oyer arte ꝑparticulere
But deth þat vyl suffre no thyngs here
But as it wer twynklynge of an eye
Both hath he slayn and al shal we dye
But for to tellen of þis worthy maıı̄un
That taught me þis tale as I firste began
I seye þat he firste with heigh stile enditeth
Er he þe body of his tale writeth
A ꝓprohem in ye wiche discrueth he
The monude and of Saluce ye contree
And spekth of Appenyıı̄un þe hilles hye
That bene þe boundes of Weste lumbardye
And of mount Vesulus in special
Wher as þe poo oute of wel smalle
Takth his firste springinge and his sours
Where as he holre eneıı̄un strouȝht days hur cours
To emelwarde and to Ferar and to Venyse
The which a long thyng were to deuyse
And trewly as to my iuggemente
Me thynketh it a thynge imꝑpartmente
Saue he woll comveieıı̄un his matier
But þis is þe tale þat ye shal her
Here endith þe prologe / and here begynneth þe tale .
Ther is at þe weste side of ytalie
Down at þ rote of Vsesilus þe colde
A lusty playn aboundante of vitaille
Wher mony a town þou maiste beholde
That foundede wer in tyme of eldres olde ¶þ
And mony a nother delectable syghte
And Saluce þis noble cuntr hiȝht
¶ A markeys whilom was in þat londe
As wer̉e his orthy eldres hym befor
And obeisaunt and redy to his honde
Wer al his lieges both lesse and mor
Thus in delite he lyssed and hath done yor
Byloued and dradde thurgh fauour and fortune
Both of his lordes and of his comune .
¶ Ther with he was as to speke of lynage
The gentilest y borne of alle lumbardye
A fair ꝑpersone and stronge and yonge of age
And ful of honour and curtesie
Discrete ynough his contr for to gye
Saue in some thynge he was to blame
And Walter was þis younge lordes name
¶ I blame hym þus þat he considered noȝt
In tyme comynge what miȝht betyde
But on his luste presente was all his thoȝthe
And for to hauke and hunte on eủery side
Wel nyegh al oỷer curse lete he slide
And eke he no wolde þat was worste of al
Wedde no wyffe for ouȝht þat myȝht befalle
¶ Only þat poynte his peple bar so sore
That floke meele on a daye þei wente
And one of hem þat wiseste was of lor
Or elles þat þe lorde wolde beste assente
That he shuld tel hym what his peple mente
Or els couthe he wol shewe suche mater
He to þe markeys saide as ye nowe her
¶ O noble markeys your humanite
Assureth vs and yiff vs hardinesse
As ofte tyme as it is necessite
That we to yowe mowe tel our heuynesse
Acceptith it lorde of your gentilnes
That we to yowe with pytous herte compleyıı̄un
And lete your eres noȝt my vois disdeyne
¶ Al haf I not to done in þis matere
More þan a nother hath in þis plase
Yet for als myche as ye my lorde so dere ¶
Haue alweys shewed fauour and gʳce
I dar þe bett̉er aske of yowe a space
Of audience to shewen our requeste
And ye my lorde to done riȝht do yowe leste
For certes lorde so wele vs liketh ȝowe
And alle ȝour werkes and eủer haıı̄un don þᵗat we
Ne couthe not not oure own selfe deuysen howe
We myȝht more liffe in felicite
Saue one thnge lorde if it ȝour wil be
That for tohisbe a wedded maıı̄un ȝiff ȝow luste .
That wer your peple in souereyn hertes reste
¶ Boweth ȝour nekke vnder þat besful ȝokke
Of souereynte noȝte of seruise
Whiche meıı̄un clepeıı̄un spousail or wedloke
And thenketh lorde amonge ȝour thouȝhtes wyse
For of wedloke cometh grete emprise
For þoȝ we slepe or wake ronne or ride
Ay flieth þe tyme it wil no maıı̄un abide
¶ And þoȝ ȝour grene ȝouthe growe as ȝitte
In crepith age alway as stil as stone
Abd deeth manaseth eủery age and smyte
In eche astate for dethe ne spareth none
And also certeyn do we knowen euerichon
that we shull dye and vncerteyn yat we al
Ben of þat day þat deth shal on vs fall
¶ Accepteth þan of vs þe trewe entente
Þat neuer ȝit refuse ȝour heste
And we wolen all lorde ȝiff ȝe woll assente
Chese ȝowe a wyffe in shorte tyme at þe leste
Borne of þe gentilest and of þe meste
Off all þis londe so þat it oute seme
Honour to god and ȝowe as we kon deme
¶ Delyuer vs of al þis besy drede
And take a wyffe for heigh goddes sake
And ȝiff it befell so as godde forbede
That/thurgh deeth ȝour lynage shulde slake
And a straunge linagie shulde take
Ȝoure heritage oo woo were vs an liffe
Wherefore we pray ȝowe hastily to wyffe
¶ Here meke prayer and hir pitous chere
Made þis Markeys haue such pitee ¶þ
Wol ȝe qd he myn own peple der
To þat I neủer erste thouȝte streyne me
I me reioise of my libertee
That selden tyme is founde in mariage
The I was free I mot bene in seruage
¶ But nathelesse I see ȝour trewe entente
And truste vpon ȝowe and haf done ay
Where for of my fre wil I assente
To wedde me as sone as eủer I may
But þer as ȝe haf profered me to daye
To chese me a wiffe I ȝow relese
Þat choise and pray ȝowe of þat ꝓprofer sese
For god I wote þat children ofte bene
Vnlike ir worthy eldar hem be fore
Bounte cometh al of god not of þe streyns
Fo whiche þey bene engendred and y bore
I triste in godds bounte and therfore
My mariage and myn estate and reste
I hym betake he may do as hym luste
¶ Let me allone in chesynge of my wiffe
That charge vpon my bak I wol endure
But I ȝow pray and charge vpon ȝour lyffe
Þat wyffe þat I take ȝe me ensure
To worship hir whil my liffe shal endur
In worde and werke both her and ells wher
As she an emꝑperoures douȝhter wer
And ferther more þis shull ȝe sweren þat ȝe
Aȝeine my choise shullen not grucchen ne strife
For seth I shal forgoo my libertee
At ȝour requeste as eủer mot I thryue
Ther as myn herte is sete þ̉er wol I wyffe
And but ȝe wulen assente in suche maner
I pray ȝow speketh no mor of þis mater
¶ Withe hertly wil þei sworen and assenten
To al þis thynge þ̉er saide no wiȝht nay
Besechyng hym of grace er þei wenten
That he hem wolde granten a c̉ertein daye
Of his spousail as sone as eủer he may
For ȝit alweye þe peple sum what dredde
Leste þus markeys wold no wyff wedde
He gʳnted hem a daye swiche as hym luste ¶þ
On whiche he wold be wedded sikirly
And said he did al þis at her requeste
And thei with humble entent ful buxomily
Kneling vpon her knees ful rev̉erently
Hym thankyn alle and thus þei han an ende
Of her entente and hoom aȝeyn þei wende
¶ And her vpon he toke his officers
Comaundynge for þe feste to pʳueie
And to his priue knyghtes and squirs
With suche charge ȝaf hem as luste on hem to leye
And þei his comandementes to obeie
And eche of hem doth his diligence .
To done vnto þe feste reủerence
xouȝt fer from þilke place honurable
Wher as þe markeys shepe his mariage
Ther stoode a thrope of site delitable
In whiche por folke of þat vilage
Hadden hir bestes and her herbigage
And of her labour toke hir sustenance
Aft̉er þat þe erthe hem ȝaf habundaunce
¶ Amonge þis por̉e folke þer dwelled a maıı̄un
Whiche þat was holden þe porest of hem alle
But hie god somtyme sende can .
His grace vnto a litel Oxe stalle
Ianicula men of þat threp hym calle .
A dought̉er had he fair and ȝonge of sighte .
And Griseld þis ȝonge mayden heighte
But for to speke of vertuos beautee
Than was she one þe fayrest vnder sonne
Wel pouerly y fostred was she
No likeroluss was on hir liste y ronne .
wele oft̉er of þ wel þan of þe tonne .
She dranke and for she wold vertue please
She knewe wel labour but none ydel ese
But þoȝ þis mayde wer tendir of age
Ȝit in þe breste of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sadde corage .
And in grete reueronce and grete charitee .
Hir olde pouer fader fostred she .
A fewe shepe spynnynge on þe folde she kepte
She wolde not bene idel til she slepte
¶ And when she homwarde come she wold brynge
Wortes and erbes tymes ful ofte
Whiche she shrad and seth for hir lyffynge .
And made hir bedde ful ofte and no thynge softe
And eủer she keped her fader liff on lofte .
With evʳy obeisaunce and diligence
That any childe miȝht do to þe faders reuerence
¶ Vpon Griselde þe pore creature
Wel ofte hathe þe markeys sate his eye .
As he on huntynge roode ꝑparauentur .
And whān it fel þat he myȝht hir aspie .
He not with wantōn lekynge of folye .
his eyen caste vp on hir but in sad wise .
Vpon hir chere he wolde hym ofte auise
¶ Commendyng in his herte hir womanhede
And eke her vertue passing any wight .
Of so ȝonge age as wele in cher as in dede .
For þof þe peple haue no grete insight .
In vertue he considered it full right .
Hir bounte and disposed þat he wolde .
Hir wedde if eủer he wedde sholde
¶ The day of weddynge came but no wight can
Tell what woman it shuld be .
For which meruaille wondred many man .
And seden whān þei where in priuete .
Wol not our lorde leue his vanite .
Wil je not wedde allas allas þe while .
Why wil je hym selfe and vs þus bigile
¶ But nathelesse þis markeys hath do make
Of gemmes sate in golde and of asur .
Broches and rynges for Griseld sake .
And of hir chothynge toke he þe mesur .
Of a mayden like to hir stature .
And eke of oþ̉er ornamentes alle .
That to suche a weddynge shuld falle
¶ The tyme of vndrene in þe same daye
Approcheth þat þis weddynge shuld be
And all þe palays putte was in araye ¶þ
Both halle and chambres eche in his degree
Howse of office stuffed with grete plente .
Ther maist þou se of deyntewus vitalle .
That may be fonde as fare as lasteth ytaille
¶ This roial markys ally arraiede
Lordes and ladies in his compainye . an
Þe whiche to þe feste wher prayed .
and of his retenue þe bachilrye .
With many a somn of sundry melodye .
Vn to þe village which I tolde .
In þis aray ye right way þei holde
¶ Griselde god wote of þis ful innocente
That for her was shape al þis araye .
To fechen water at þe welle is wente .
And comyth home as sone as eủer she may .
For wele she herde sey þat ilke daye .
That markeis shulde wedde and if she myȝht
She wold fayn seen som of þat siȝht
¶ She thouȝht I wol with oþ̉er maydens stonde
That bene my felaws in our dore and see .
The Markeys and þer for wol I fonde .
To done at hom als sone as it may be.
The labour whiche þat longeth to me .
And þan may I at laiser it beholde .
If she þis waye to þe castel holde
And as she wolde oủer þe th̉resswolde gone
The markys come and gan hir for to cal .
And she sete doun hir water potts anon.
Beside þe thressholde of þe oxe stalle .
And doun vpon hir knees she gan to falle .
And with sadde countence kneled stil .
Til she had herde what was þe lordes wil
¶ This thoughtful markeys spake vn to þis mayde
We soberly and saide in þis maner .
Wher is ȝour fader Griselde he saide .
And she with reuerence and with ful mylde cher
Answered lorde he is al redy her .
And in she goith with outen leng lette .
And to þe markeys she hire fader fette ¶þ
He by þe hande tan toke þis olde man
An saide þus when he hym hadde in side .
Ianicula I neither may ne can .
Lenger þe plesaunce of myn herte hide .
If þat ȝe wouchesaue what so betyde .
Thi doȝhter wol I take er þat I wende .
As for my wyffe in wedloke to my liffes ende
¶Thou louest me I wote wele certeyn
And art my faithfuls liege man ybor .
And al þat liketh me I dar wele seyn .
It liketh þe and specially þerfore .
Tell me þat poynt þat I haf saide be for .
If þat þou wolt vn to þat purpose drawe
To take me as for þi son in lawe
¶ The sodeyn caas þs man asonyed so
That reede he wepe al bashed and al quakynge
He stode vnnethe he seide wordes moo.
But only þid lotfr qd he my willynge .
Is as ȝe wol noth aȝeins ȝour likynge .
I wol no thynge ȝe be my lorde so der
Riȝht as ȝowe liste gouʳneth þis mater
¶ Than wol I do þis qd þs markeys softely
That in to þi chambr I and you and she .
Haue a collacioıı̄un and wotost you why .
For I will aske ȝif hir wil be .
To be my wyffe and reule hir aft̉er me .
And alle þis she shal done in þi psence
I wil not speke it oute of þine audience
¶ An in þe chambr whil þei wer aboute
Hir retys whiche ȝe shul aft̉er her .
The peple came in to ᵗe house with oute .
And wondred hem in howe honest maner
And tentifly she kepte hir fader der .
But vtterly Griseld wondred mych .
For neủer efte she sawe of siȝht non suche .
¶ Noo wonder is þot she is stonyede
To see so grete a geste com in to þat plase
She was neủer to swich grestys woned .
For whiche she loked with ful pale face
But shortly fro þis mat̉er for to pase ¶þ
This werthe wordes þat is markeys saide
To þis benigne verrey faithful maide
¶ Griseld he seide ȝe shol wele vnderstonde
It liketh vn to ȝour fader and me .
That I ȝowe wedde and eke it may so stonde .
As I suppose þat ȝe wil þat it so be .
But þis demᵃnde I aske firste qd he .
that sithen it shal be doıı̄un on hastyff wise
Wol ȝe assent or ells ȝowe auise
¶ I seye þis be ȝe redy with goode herte
To all my luste and þat I frely may .
As me beste thynketh do ȝowe lagh or smerte
And ȝe neủer grucche nyȝht ne daye .
And eke whan I seyye ȝa ȝe sey not naye .
Neither by wode ne fowarde contenᵃnce
Swer þis and her I swer our alyaunce .
¶ Wondrynge vpon þis worde quakynge for drede
She said vndine and vnworthy
Am I to þat þat ȝe me bede
But riȝht as ȝe wol ȝour selfe riȝht so wol I .
And I swer þat neủer wyllyngly
In wrode ne in thouȝht shal neủer ȝowe disobeye
For to be ded þof me wer loth to dye
¶ Thi is ynowgh Griseld myn gd he
And forth he goth with a sobr chere .
Out at þe dor aft̉er come she .
And to ᵗe peple he said on þis maner .
This is my wyffe qd he þat stondeth her .
Honureth her and loueth hir þ̉er is no mor to say
Who so loueth me . hertly I ȝowe praye
¶ And for nothynge of hir olde ger
She shulde brynge to his house he badde
That women shulden spoille hir riȝht þer
Of whiche þs ladies wer riȝht gladde
To handel hir clothes in whiche she was
But natheles þis maide briȝht of hewe
Fro foote to heede yclothed han al newe
¶ Hir heres han thei kombed þat lay vntressed
Ful rudely with hir fyngers smale .
And a crown on hir hede þei hane dressed ¶þ
And sette it ful of owches grete and smale
Of hir aray what shulde I make a tale .
Vnneth þe peple hir knowe for hir fairnesse
Whan she transformed was in suche richesse
¶ This markeys hath her spoused with a rynge
Broȝht for þhe same cause and þane hir sete .
Vpon an hors snowe white and wele amblynge
And to his palys er he lenger lete .
With ioyful peple þat he ladde and mette .
Conoyed hir and thus e day þei spende .
In reuel til þe sonne gan desende
¶ And shortly forth þis tale for to chase
I say þat to þis newe markeisesse .
God hath y sente swiche fauour of his gʳce.
Þat is semed not as by likenesse .
That she was borne and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an oxe stalle .
But norrysshed in an emꝑperoures halle .
¶ To eủery wyȝht she woxen is so der
And worshipfull þat folke þ̉er she was bor
And from hir burthe knewe hir from ȝer to ȝer
Vnnethe trowed þei but dorste haf swore
That to Ianicle of þed whiche I spak befor
She douȝhtr ne wer for as by coniectur
Hem thouȝht she was an other creatur
¶ For þat eủermor vertuose was . she .
She was encresed in swiche excellence
Of thewes sette in heigh bountee .
And so discrete and fair of elouence
So benigne and digne of reủerence .
And couthe þe peple hert so embrase .
That eche hir loued þat loked on hir face
¶ Nouȝt only of saluce in þe town
Publisshed was þe bounte of hir name
Budeke beside in mony a regioun
If one saide wel another said þe same
So sprad of hir bounte þe fame
That men and women both ȝong and olde
Gon to Saluce hir to beholde ¶þ
¶ This Walt lowly luffaih and ryaily
Weddeth with fortune honeste .
In goddes eese liffeth ful hesily .
At home and outewarde was ynogh hade he .
And for he saw vnder low degree .
Was ofte vertu hidde þe peple hym helde
A prudent man and þat is seine wel selde
¶ Nouȝht only þus Griseld thurgh hir wytte
Touche al þe feete of wyfely humblenes .
But eke when þe caas required it .
The cōmmune ꝓprofite couthe she redresse .
Ther no was discorde ranceur ne heuynesse .
In al þe londe þat she ne coude it ese .
And brynge hem al wysely in reste and ese .
¶ Thof þat hir husbonde presente wer or none
Yiff gentil men or other of hir countr
Wer wrothe she couthe brynge hem at one .
So wise and discrete wordes hadde she .
And Iuggement of so grete equitee .
That she from heuen was as mēn wende .
ꝐPresente peple to saue and eủery wronge to amende
¶ Nouȝt longe tyme aft̉er þat þis Griseld was wedded
She a fair daughter hath ybor
Al had she leid han leure a knaue childe .
Glad was þe markeys and his folke þerfor .
For þof a maydey childe come albefore
She may to a knaue shilde atteyne .
Be liklyed sethone she is not baren
¶ Therfor as it falleth tymes moo
Than this childe hath sowked but a throwe .
This markeys in his herte longeth soo .
To tempte his wyffe hir sadnes to knowe .
That he ne myȝht fro his herte throwe .
This merueylous desir his wyffe to assaye .
Natheles god wote he thouȝth hir to affraye
¶ He had assaied hir ynogh before
And fonde hir eủer goode what nedeth it .
Hir for to torment and alwey mor and mor .
Thof some mēy preise it for a subtel wytte .
But as for me I sey þat euyl it site ¶þ
To assaie a wyffe whēn it is no nede
And puten hir in anguissh and in drede
¶ For whiche tis markeys wroȝht on þis maner
He came a nyght allone þ̉er as she laye .
With serne face and trouble cher .
And said þus / Griselde qd he þat daye .
that I ȝouwe toke oute of your por aray .
And putte ȝowe in astate of he noblesse .
Ȝe hauen not ȝit forȝetēn as I gesse
¶ I say Griselde þis presente dignite
In whiche I haf pute ȝowe as I trowe
Maketh not ȝowe foryetful to be
That I ȝowe toke in poủer etate ful lowe
For any thynge ȝe motte ȝour selfon knowe
Tak hede of eủery worde þat I ȝowe saye
Ther is no wiȝht þat hereth þis but we tweye
Ye wote ȝour selfe wele howe þat ȝe come her
In to þis house it is not longe a goo .
And þof to me ȝe be lefe and dere .
Vn to my gentilesse ȝe be no thynge soo .
Thei seye to hem it is grete shame and woo
For to be subget and in seruage .
To þe þat art borne of so lowe lynage
¶ And namely seth þi dought̉er was bore
thise wordes hauēn þei spoke doutelesse .
But I desir as I haue done befor .
To liff my liffe with hem in reste and peese
I may not in þis caas bene recheles .
I must doıı̄un with þd dought̉er for þe beste .
Nought as I would but as my gentilesse liste
¶ And ȝit god wote þis is wel loth to me
But nathelesse with oute ȝour wytynge .
I wol not do but þis I wol qd he
that ȝe to me assent as in þis thynge .
Showeth moew ȝour pacience in ȝỏre thynge
that ȝe me beiȝht and swor in ȝore village
¶ That day þat maked was our mariage
When she had herd al þis she was not ameued
Nether in worde nor cher nor coutenᵃnce ¶þ
For as it demed she was not agreuede
She sad lorde al lieth your plesaunce .
My childe and I with hertly obesaunce .
Ben ȝoures al and ȝe may saue or spille
Your own thynge whether þat ȝe weyl
¶Ther may no thynge so god my soule saue
Likynge to ȝowe þat may displese me .
Ne I desir no thynge to haue .
Ne drede to lese saue only go .
This will is myn hert and ay shl be
No length of tyme or deth it may deface .
Nor chaunge my corage in to non other place
¶ Glad was þs markys for hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he wer nat so .
Al drery was his cher and his lokyng .
When he shuld out of þe chambre go.
Soon aft̉er þs a furlange weye or two .
He priuely tolde alle his entente
Vnto a man and to him his wyf sente
A man seriaint was þis priuee mān
The whiche þat feythfull founde he hadde .
In thynges grete and eke suche folke wel can .
Don execution of thynges badde .
The lorde knewe wele þat he hym loued and dradde
And when þis seriaunt wiste his lordes wil .
In to þe chamb̉re he salked hym full still
¶ Madame he said ȝe mote foryeue me
ꝒProoȝ I do þinge to whiche I am constreynede
Ȝe bene so wise þat wele knowen ȝe .
Þat lordes heses may not be fyned .
Þei mowe well be wailled or pleynede.
But man mote nede bn to her luste obeie .
And wo wol I þ̉er is no more to seye .
¶ This child I am cōmmanded for to take
And spak no mor but oute þe childe he hente .
Despitiously and gan a a cher to make .
As he wolde han slayn it er he wente .
Griseld mote alle suffre and alle sente.
And as a lambe she siteth meeke and stil .
And lete þis cruel seriaunt haf al his wyl
¶ Suspecious was þe fame of þis man
Suspect his face suspect his worde also. ¶þ
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doghter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right tho
But nathelees she neither weep ne syked
Conformynge hire to that the Markys liked
But at the laste speken she bigan
And mekely she to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she moste kisse hir child er that it deyde
And on hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kesse
And thus she seyde in hir benygne voys
Fare wel my child I shal thee neuere see
But sith I thee haue marked with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tree
Thy soule litel child I hym bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trowe that to a Norice in this cas
It hadde been hard this routhe for to se
Wel myghte a moder haue cryd allas
But nathelees so sad stedefast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn youre litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wol I pray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbad yow at the leeste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That bestes ne no bryddes it to race
But he no word wol to that purpos seye
But took the child and wente vp on his weye
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and playn
And hym persenteth with his doghter deere
Som what this lord hadde routhe in his manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes doon whan they wol han hir wille
And bad this Sergeant that he pryuely
Sholde this child softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tendrely
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp on peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entente
Ne whennes he cam ne whider that he wente
But at Boloigne he to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He sholde it take and shewe hir this matere
Bisekynge hir to doon hir bisynesse
This child to fostre in alle gentilesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hyde
From euery wight for aught that may bityde
The Sergeant goth and hath fulfild this thyng
But to this Markys now retourne we
For now goth he ful faste ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte se
Or by hir word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuere hir koude fynde
But euere in oon ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as busy in seruyse
And eek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euery maner wise
Ne of hir doghter noght a word spak she
Noon accident for noon aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuere hir doghter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game

l.hi: Explicit tercia pars

div.l: Incipit pars quarta
IN this estat ther passed ben 4 yeer
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly XXgeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
This Markys wondreth euer lenger the moore
Vp on hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soothly knowen ther bifoore
That perfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som subtiltee
And of malice or of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next hym self certayn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde I asken fayn
If thise assayes myghte nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond moore deuyse
To proue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuynge euere in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of swich condicioun
That whan they haue a certeyn purpos take
And so wilful suche assayes to make
They kan nat stynte of hir entencioun
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They wol nat of that firste purpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath purposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He wayteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neuere koude he fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was of age
The moore trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue and moore penyble
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wyl for as Walter leste
The same lust was hir plesance also
And god be thanked al fyl for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir housbond wolde
The sclaundre of Walter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a poure womman wedded hadde
Hath mordred bothe his children pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wonder is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For which wher as his peple ther bifore
Hadde loued hym wel the sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem that they hym hated therfore
To ben a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was set al his entente
Whan that this doghter xij yer was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil sente his message
Comaundynge hem swiche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
In this maner and in this same gyse
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde another if hym leste
I seye he bad they sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leue his firste wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and dissencioun
Bitwix his peple and hym thus seyde the bulle
The which they han publissed at the fulle
The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan thise tidynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euere mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thaduersitee of Fortune al tendure
Abidynge euere his lust and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey

l.hi: Explicit quarta pars

div.l: Incipit pars quinta
Among al this after his wikke vsage
Incipit pars qᵃnta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

l.hi: Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford

div.l: ¶ lenuoye de chaucer
Griselde is dede and eke hir pacience
And both atones buryed in ytalie
For whiche I crie in open audience /
No wedded man be hardy to. assail
His wiffes pacience in truste to fynde
Griseldes for in certeyn he schal faille
¶ O noble wiffes ful of hiegh prudence
Let non humilite ȝour tonge naylle
Ne lat no clerke haue cause or diligence
To write of ȝowe a storie of suche maruayl
As of Griseldꝭes paciente and kynde
Leste chicheuage ȝowe swelowe in hir entrail
¶ Folowith ekko þat holdeth no silence
But eủer answereth at þe countr tail
Beth not be daffed for ȝour Innocence
But scharply take on ȝowe þe gouernaille
Enprynteth wel þis lessoıı̄un in ȝour mynde
For commıı̄unꝓprofite sith it may a vail
¶ Ne drede hem noȝt doth hem no reủerence
For þof þine husbonde araied be in mayl
The arwes of þi crabbed Eloquence
Shal perse his breste and eke his aduentail
In Ialousie I rede eke þou hym bynde
And þat þou make hym couche as doith a quail
¶ If þou be fair þer folke bene in psencs
Shewe þou þi visage and þine apparaille
Ȝiff þou be foule be fr of þi despense
To gete þe frendes ay do þi trauail
Be ay of cher als liȝht as lefe on lynde
And lete hym car and wepe and wrynge and waille
¶ Ȝe Archewyffes stondith at ȝour defense
Seth ȝe be stronge as is a grete camail
Ne suffreth not þat man do ȝowe offence
And sclender wyffes feble as in bataille
Beth egr as a tigr ȝonde in ynde
Ay clappith as a Mil I ȝowe conseil
¶ Explicit fabula Griseldia
Here beginneth þe prologe of þe Frankeleyn:
Eye god mercy seid our oste þoo
Nowe suche a wyffe I pray god kepe me froo /
Lo suche sleighte / and subtilitees
As women bene for and as besy as bees .
Beth þei vs foly men for to disseyue .
And from a sothe euer willeth weyue
By þis marchaundes tale it ꝓproueth wele
But douteles als trewe as eủer was eny stele
I haf a wyff þof sche poủer be
But of her tonge a labbyng schrewe is sche.
And sche hath an hepe of vices moo.
Ther of no force lat all swiche thyngꝭes goo
But wite ȝe what in 9seill be it saide
Me rewith sor þat I am to her tyede
Whiche þat sche hath I wys I wer not wyse
And cause why for it schuld reported be
And tolde to hir of som of þise menȝee
Of whome it nedith not to declar
Seth wōmmen con outen suche chaffar
And eke my witte suffiseth not þ̉ertoo
To tell all þer for my tale is doo
Sir frankeleyn com ner ȝif it ȝour will be
And saye us a tale for certes ȝe ¶þ
Ȝe can þ̉er on as myche as eny man
With hertly will for I will not rebell
A ȝeniste ȝour will a tale woll I tell
Haue me excused ȝif y saye amys
My will is goode and lo my tale is þis

div.l: HA qd þe knyght goode sir no mor of þis
That ȝe han said is riȝht ynogh y wys ¶þ
And michel more / for litell heuynesse
Is riȝht ynogh to mychell folke as I gesse
I seye for me it is a grete disese
Wher as men han bene in grete welth and ese
To heren of hir sodeyn falle allas
And þe contrarie ioye and grete solas
And whan a man hath bene in por astate
And clymbeth up and wexeth fortunate
And þer abideth in prosperite
Suche thyng is gladsom / as it thynketh me
And þof suche thynge wer goodly for to tell
Ȝa qd our ooste be seynt Poules bell
Ȝe seye riȝht soth þis monke he clappeth lowde
He spak howe fortune couered with a clowde
I not neủer what and also of atreide
Riȝt nowe ȝe herde and ꝐParde no remedie
It is for to bewaill and 9pleyn
That is to don and als it is a peyn
As ȝe han seide to her of heuynesse
Sir monke no mor of þis so god ȝowe blisse
Ȝour tales annoieth all þis companye
Suche talkynge is not worth a butterflye
For þ̉erin is no desporte ne game
Wher fore sir monke daun piers be ȝour name
I pray ȝowe hertly tell us somwhat ells
For siker ner þe clynkynge of ȝour belles
That on ȝour bridell hongeth on eủery side
By heuen kynge þat for us all dyede
I schall for þis falle doun for slepe
Al þof þe slogh had neủer ben so depe
Than had ȝour tale be tolde in vayn
For certenly as þise clerkis seyne
Wher as a man may haf none audience
It helpeth noȝt to tellen his sentence
And wele þe substaunce is in me
If ony thynge schall wele reported be
Sir say somwhat of huntynge I ȝowe praye
Nay qd þe monke I haf no luste pleye
Nowe lete a noþ̉er tell as I haf tolde
Than spake our ooste with rude speche and bolde
And seide vn to þe nonnes preste onon
Come ner sir preste com hider ʆsir Iohn
Tell us suche thynges as may our hertes gladde
Be mery þof þou ride opon a iade .
That þof þine horse be foule or lene
Iff he will ʆserue þᵉ rekke þᵉ noȝht a bene þ
Looke þat þine herte be mery eủer moo
Ȝis oste qd he so mot I ride or goo
But I be mery I wys I will be blamed
And riȝht onon he hath his tale attamed
And þus he seide to us eủerychon
This swete preste þis good man ʆsir Ione

hi.hi: ¶ Here endith þe ꝓprologe ⁊and here begynneth þe tale .

div.l: A por wydowe som dele stope in age
Was whilom dwellynge in an narowe cotage
Besides a groue stondynge in a dale
This wydowe of whiche I told yowe my tale
Sethens þilke day þat sche was laste a wyffe
In paciens ladde a full simple lyffe
For litill was hir catell and hir rente
By husbondrye as of suche þat god hir sente
She fonde her selfe and eke hir doughtren twoo
Thr large sowes sche hadde and no moo
Thr kyen and eke a schepe þat hiȝht malle
Full soty was hir bowr and eke hir halle
In whiche sche ete mony a sklender mele
Of poynant sause her neded neủer a dele
No deynte morsell passed hir throte
Hir diete was acordant to hir cote
Replecioıı̄un ne made hir neủer seke
A tepre diete was al hire phisike
And esise and herte suffisaunce
The ȝoute letteth hir no thynge to daunce
Ne poplexie ne schent not hir hede
No wyne dranke sche nouther white ne rede
Her borde was serued moste with white and blakke
Milke and brounbrede in whiche sche fonde no lakke
Seynde bakoıı̄un and somtyme an eye or tweye
For sche was as it wer þe maner of a deye
A gardyn sche hadde enclosed all aboute
With stikkes and a drye diche with oute
In whiche sche hadde a coke þat hiȝht Chantcler
In all þe londe of crowynge was his per
His voys was merier þan þe merye orgon
On messe daies þat in chirche gone
Wel sikerer was þe crowynge in his logge
Then is a clokke or an Abbeye orlogge
By natur he knewe iche ascencoıı̄un
Of equinoxiall of þilke toun
For when degrees xv. wer descended þȝhþ
div.fw: Then knewe he þat it myȝht
div.l: Then knewe he þat it myȝht not bene amendede
His combe was redder þen þe fyne corall
And batelid as it wer a castell wall
I like azur wer his legges and his tone
His bille was blak and as þe gete it schone
His naylles whitter þan þe lily flour
And ylyke burnysshed golde was his colour
This gentill Coke hadde in his gouernaunce
Seuen hennes for to don his plesaunce
Whiche weren his sustres and his ꝑparamours
And wonder y like to hym as of coloures
Off whiche þe fayrest hewed vndir þe throte
Was cleped fair damysell ꝑpartilote
Curtas sche was discrete and debonair
And companable and bar hir selfe so fair
Sethyns þilke day þat sche was seuen nyȝht olde
That trewly sche hathe þe herte in holde
Off Chauntecler loken in eủery lith
He loued hir so þat wele was hym þ̉er wyth
But suche a Ioye as it was to her hem synge
And so befell þat in þe dawnynge .
As Chauntecler amonges his wyffes alle
Satte on his ꝑperche þat was in þe hall
And nexte hym satte þis fair ꝑpartelotte
This Chauntecler gān gronen in his throte
As a man þat is in dreme drecched sor
And when þat ꝑpartelot þus herde hym rore
She was a gast and seide hertis der
What eylith ȝowe to grone in þis manere
Ye ben a verrey sleper ffy for schame
And he answered and saide þus madame
I pray ȝowe þat ȝe take it not a greefe
By god me mette þat I was in suche myschiefe
Riȝht nowe þat ȝit myn herte is sor a fryȝht
Nowe god qd he my sweuen rede a riȝht
And kepe my body oute of foule prisoun
Me mette þat I romede up and doun
With in oure ȝerde wher as I sagh a beste
Was like an hounde and wolde haf made a reste
Vpon my body and wolde haf had me dede
His colour was be twix white and rede
And tipped was his taille and both his eres
With blake vnlike þe remenᵃıı̄unt of his heeres
His snowte small with glowynge eyen tweye
Yette of his looke for feer almooste I dye
This caused me my gronynge doutelesse
A voy qd sche. fy on ȝowe hertelesse ¶
Allas ꝙquod sche ffor by þat god aboue
Nowe haue ȝe loste myn herte and my loue
I con not loue a cowarde be my feyth.
For certes what so eny woman seith
We all desiren ȝiff it myȝht be
To hauen husbondes hardy wyse and free
And secree ne no negarde ne no foole
Ne hym þat is a gast of eủery toole
Ne none avontr be þat godde aboue
Howe dorste ȝe seyn for schame vn to ȝoᵘur loue
That eny thynge myȝht make ȝowe aferde
Haue ȝe no mannys herte and han a berde
Allas and kon ȝe ben agaste of sweıı̄unens
No thynge god wote but vanite in sweuen . is
Sweuens engendren of replexiouns
And ofte of fume and of complexiouns
When humors bene to habundant in a wyȝht
Certes þis dreme whiche ȝe haf harde to nyȝht
Comyth of þe grete suꝑperfluite
Of ȝour rede colour parde
Whiche causeth folke to dreme hir dremes
Of arwes and of fuyres with rede lemes
Of rede bestis þat wollen hem bite
Of conteke and of whelpes grete and lite
Riȝht as þe humore malencolye
Cawsith mony a man in slepe for to crye
For fer of beres and bulles blake
Or ells blake deuylls woll hem take
Of other humours couth I tell . also
That wyrken mony a man in slepe full woo
But I woll passe as liȝhtly as I kan
Loo Catoıı̄un whiche þat was so wise a man
Seide he not þus ne do no force of dremes
Nou sir ꝙquod sche when we fle fro þe bemes
For goddis luff as takith som laxatiue
Vpon ꝑperill of my soule and of my lyffe
I counseill ȝowe þe beste I woll not lye
That both of colour and malencolye
Ȝe purge ȝowe and for ȝe schull not tarie
Thogh þat in þis town nys none Apothecarie
I schall my selfe to herbes techen ȝowe
That schall be ȝour hele and ȝour prowe
And in þe gardyn two herbes schall I fynde
The whiche han of her ꝓpropirte be kynde
To purchen ȝowe be nethe and eke aboue
For ȝetith not þis for goddis own loue . ¶
Ye ben full coleryke of complexioıı̄un
Where þe sonne in his ascencioun
Ne fynde ȝowe replete of ȝour humours hote
And if it do I dar wele lay a grote
That ȝe schull haue a fevr terciane
Or an agu þat may be ȝour bane
A day or two ȝe schull haf digestyues
Or wormes or ȝe take ȝour laxatiues
Of laureal centaure and of fumytere
Or ells of ellebor þat growith þere
Of Catapuce or of gaytes buryes
Of herbe yne growynge in our ȝerde þ̉er merye is
Pyk hem up riȝht as þei growe ande ete hem in
Be mery husbonde for ȝour fadres kynne
Dredith no dreme I con saye to ȝowe no mor
Madame qd he gramercy of ȝour lore
But nathelesse as touchyng daun catoıı̄un
That hath of wysdom suche grete renoun
By god men may in olde bokes rede
One of þe grettest auctory oute of drede
Of mony a man mor of auctorite
Than eủer Catoıı̄un was so mot I thee
That all þe reủerse seyne of þis sentence
And hauen wele founden be exꝑperience
That dremes ben significacioıı̄uns
Als wele of Ioye as of tribulacoıı̄uns
That folke enduren in þis liffe psente
Ther nedith not to make of þis non argumente
The verrey preue schewith it in dede
One of þe grettest auctour oute of drede
Sēmīth þus þat whilom two felowes wente
On pilgⁱmage in full goode entente
And happed so þei comen in to a towne
Wher as þer was suche congregacioıı̄un
Of peple and eke of streyte herbergage
That þei fonde as myche as a cotage
In whiche þei both ne myȝht y logged be
Wherfore þei mosten of necessite
As for þat nyȝht deꝑparten of companye
And iche of hem goth in to his ostelerye
And toke his loggynge as it wolde fall
That one of hem was logged in a stall
Fer in a ȝerde with oxen of þe . plogh
That oþ̉er man was logged wele ynogh
As was his auentur or his fortune
That us goủerneth all as in comune . ¶þ
And so by fell longe ar it wer daye
Þis man mette in his bedde where as he laye
Howe þat his felowe gan on hym calle
And seide allas for in an oxe stalle
This nyȝht schall I be murdred ther I lye
Nowe helpe me dere brother or I dye
In alle haste come to me he saide
This man oute of his slepe for fer he brayde
But when þat he was wakened oute of his slepe
He turnyth hym and toke of þis no kepe .
Hym thoȝht his dreme was not but a vanite
Thus twies in his slepynge dremed he
And at þe thridde tyme ȝit his felowe
Come as he thouȝht I am nowe y slawe
Beholde my blody woundes depe and wyde
Arise up . erly in þe morowe tyde
And at þe westgate of þe towne qd he
A carte full of donge þ̉er schalt you see
In whiche his body is hidde full priuely
Do þilke carte aresten boldly
My golde causede my mordr sothe to seyn
And tolde hym eủery poynte howe he was slayn
With a full pytous face pale of hewe
And truste wele his dreme he fonde full trewe
For on þe morne als sone as it was daye
To his felowes in . he toke þe weye
And when he come to þis oxe stalle
Aft̉er his felowe he began to calle
The ostiler answered hym onon
And seide sir ȝour felowe is y gone
Als sone as day he wente oute of þe towne
This man gan fall in grete suspicioıı̄un
Remembrynge on his dremes þat he mette
And forth he goith no leng wolde he lette
Vn to þe weste gate of þe toune and fonde
A donge carte as he wente to dong þe londe
That was araied in þe same wyse
As ȝe han herde þe dede man devise
And with an hardy herte he gan to crye
Vencheance and iustice of þis felonye
My felowe murdrede is þⁱs same nyȝht
And in þis carte he lieth gapyng up riȝht
The dede man þat murdrede was al newe
O blysfull god þat arte so iuste and trewe
Lo howe þat þou bewreyest murdr al weye
Murdr woll oute þat see we day be daye þ
Mordr is so horrible and so abhominable
To god þat is so iuste and resonable
That he ne wolde it suffre not to heled be
Theigh it abide a ȝer or twoo or three
Murdr woll oute þis is my conclusioıı̄un
And riȝht onon ministres of þe toune
Hath hente þe Carter and sor hym pynede
And eke þe Osteler so fastly was engynede
That þei beknewe her wykkednes onone
And weren honged by þe nekke bone
Her may men se þat dremes bene to drede
And certes in þe same booke y rede
Riȝht in þe nexte chapitr I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haf I Ioye or blisse .
Two men þat wolden haf passed þe see
For certeyn causes in to a feir cuntr
If þat þe wynde ne hadde bene contrarye
That made hem in a Cite for to tarie
That stode full mery opon an hauen side
But on a day a ȝeinste þe euen tide
The wynde gan chonge and blowe riȝht as he luste
Iolyff and gladde þei wenten vn to reste
And kasten hem full erly for to saile
But herken howe o man fell in grete ꝑperill
The tone of hem in slepynge as he laye
Hym mette a wonder a wonder dreme aȝeinste þe daye
Hym thouȝht a man stode be his beddys side
And hym cōmmanded þat he schuld abyde
And seide hym þus if þou to morowen wende
Thow schalt be dreynte my tale is at an ende
He woke and tolde his felowe what he mette
And praied hym his viage for to lette
And for þat day he praied hym to abide
His felowe þat laye be his beddis syde
Gan for to lawgh and skorned full faste
No dreeme qd he may myn herte a gaste
That I woll lete for to do my thynges
I sate not a strawe by dremynges
For sweuens bene but vanites and iapes
Men dreme al weye of owles ande of Apes
And of mony a mase þer with alle
Men dremēn of thynge þat neủer was ne schall
But sithen I see þou wilte her abide
And þus forslewthen wilfully þi tyde
God wote it reweth me and haf good daye
And þus he toke his leue and wente his waye . ¶þ
And er þat he hadde halfe his course assailled
Note I not why ne what myschance it ayled
But casuelly þe schippes bottome rente
And schippe and man vnder þe wat̉er wente
In siȝht of oþ̉er schippes hym be side
That with hym sailled at þe same tyde
And þ̉erfor he seide ꝑpartelote so dere
By suche olde ensample mayst þou ler
That no man schulde be to rechelesse
Of dremes for I saye þe doutelesse
That mony a dreme full sore is for to drede
Loo in þe lyffe of seynte kenelme I rede
That was kenulphes son þe noble kynge
Off Mertenrike howe kenelme mete a thynge
A litill er he was mordrede on a daye
His murdr in his avision he seye
His norice hym expowned eủery dele
His sweuen and bad hym for to kepe hym wele
For treson but he was vij ȝer olde
And þ̉er for litill tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreme so holy was his herte
By god I had leủer þan my scherte
That ȝe had harde his legende as haff I .
Dame ꝑpartelotte I seye ȝowe trewly .
Maccobeus þat writte þe avisioun
In Affrike of þe worthy Cyprioun
Affermeth dremes and seith þᵗat þei bene
Warnynge of thynges þat men aft̉er seen
And forthermor I pᵃye ȝowe lokith wele
The olde testament of daniele
Ȝiff he helde dremes of eny vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and ȝe schullen see .
Whedir dremes bene somtyme I seye not alle
Warnynge of thynges þat schull aft̉er falle
Looke eke of egypte þe kynge daun pharao .
His baker and his botiler also
Wher þei ne felte non effecte in dremes
Who so woll seche þe acte of sundry remes
May reden of dremes mony a wonder thynge
Loo cresus whiche þat was of lide kynge
Mette he not þat he satte opon a tree
Whiche signified þat he schuld an honged be
Loo her of dromacha ectours wyffe
That day þat Ectour schuld lete his lyffe
She dremed on þe same nyȝht be forne
Howe þat þe lyffe of ectour schulde be lorne . þ
Yiff þilke daye he wente in to bataille
She warnyd hym but it myȝht not availl
He wente for to fyȝhten neủer þe lesse
But he was slayn of Achilles
But þilke tale is al to longe to tell
And eke it is nygh day I may not dwell
Shortly I seye as for conclusioun
That I schall haf of þis a visioun
Of aduersites and I seye forthermor
That I ne will telle of laxatiues no store
For þei bene venynous I wote riȝht wele
I hem defye I loue hem neủer a dele
Now lete us speke of myrthe and stynte all þis
Madame ꝑpartelote so haf I blysse
Off oo thynge god hath sente me large gᵃce
For when I see þe beaute of ȝour face
Ȝe bene so skarlete rede a boute ȝour eyen
It makith all my drede for to dyen
For also siker as in principio

l.hi: Mulier est hominus confusio

div.l: Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Woman is mannys Ioye and his blisse
For when I fele on nyȝht ȝour softe syde
Al be it þat I may not on ȝowe ride
For þat our ꝑperche is made so narowe allas
I am so full of Ioye and solace
That I desir both sweuen and dreme
And with þat worde I fliegh doune fro þe beme .
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a chukke he gan hem for to calle
For he hadde founde a corne laye in þe ȝerde
Reall he was no mor a ferde
He fethered ꝑpartelot . xx . tyme
And dradde als ofte er it wer pⁱrime
He lokith as it wer a grym lyoun
And on his toos he romed up and doun
Hym deygned not to sette his fete on grounde
Ay chukkede as when he hadde a corne y founde
And to hym þan ranne his wyfes all
Thus royall as a prince in his halle
Leue I þis Chauntecler in þis pastur
And aft̉er woll I tell of his auentur
When þe month þe whiche þe worde began
That hiȝht marche when god firste made man
Was plete and passede wele also
Sethen marche began xxx dayes and twoo. ¶þ
Byfell þat Chauntecler in his pride
His seuen wyffes welken hym beside
Caste up his eighen to þe bryȝht son .
That in þe signe of taurus was ronne
Twenty degrees and one and sumwhat mor
He knewe be kynde ande by none other lore .
That it was prime he crewe with blesfull steven
The sonne he seide is clomben vp on heuen
Fourty degrees and more and one of wys
Madame ꝑpartelote my wordliche blisse
Herken howe þise blesfull briddes synge
And se þe fressh floures howe þei spⁱringe .
Full is myn herte of reuell and solace
But sothenly hym fell a sorofull caase
Foreủer þe latter ende of ioye is sone a goo
And cmnly ofte tyme it fallith soo .
And if arthour couthe fair endite
He in cronikle myȝht sauely wrytte
As for a souereyn notabilite
Nowe eủery wyse man herken me
This storye is als trewe I vndirtake
As is þe booke of launcelot de lake
That wōmmen helde in full grete reuerence
Nowe woll I turne a ȝeyn to my sentence
A col fox full of sleight and iniquite
That in þe grove had wonned ȝeres thr̉re
Be hiȝhg ymaginacioıı̄un a forne caste
The same nyȝht þurgh oute þe hogges braste
In to þe ȝerde þer chaunteclere þe fair
Was wonte and eke his wyffes to repair
And in a bedde of wortes still he laye .
Til it was passed vndron of þe daye
Waytynge his tyme on chauntecler to fall
As gladly done þis homicides all
That in a wayte ligge to murther men
O fals mourdrour roukynge in þi denne
O newe skariot and newe genylon
Fals dissimilour o greke synion
That broȝht troye all vtterly to sorowe
O chauntecler a cursed be þat morowe
That þou in to þe ȝerde fliegh fro þe bemes
Thou wer full wele y werned by þe dremes
That ilk day was ꝑparlious to þe
Bot þat þat god a forwote mote nedys be
Han in myn house y been to ȝowe grete ese .
And certes sir riȝht fayne wolde I ȝowe pleess þ
But for men spekith of synginge I woll seye
So mot I broke myn eyen tweye
Safe ȝe I ne harde neủer man synge
As did ȝour fader in þe mornynge
Certis it was of herte all þat he songe
And for to make his voys þe more stronge
He wolde so peyn hym þat with both his eyen
He moste wynke so loude he did cryen
And stonden on his tiptoos þ̉er with all
And stretche forth his nekke longe and small
And eke he was of suche discrecioıı̄un
That þer nas no man in no regioun
That hym in songe or wysdom myȝht passe
I haf wele rede Daun Burnell þer as
Amonge his verse þer was a coke
For a prestis son ȝaf hym a knokke
O pon his legge whils he was ȝonge and nyce
He made hym for to lese his benefice
But c̉erten þ̉er is non comꝑperisoun
Betwix þe wysdom and discrecioıı̄un
Of ȝour fader and of his subtilite
Nowe syngith sir for seynte charitee
Lat see con ȝe ȝour fader countrfete
This Chauntecler his wen9 gan to bete
As man þat couthe not his treson aspie
So was he rauysshed with his flaterye
Allas ȝe lordes mony a fals flaterour
Is in ȝour courtes and mony a losenchour
That plesen ȝowe mor be my feyth
Than he þat sothefastnes vn to ȝowe seith
Redith ecclesiastr of flaterye
Beeth war ȝe lordes of her tretcherye
This Chauntecler þat stode hiegh opon his toose
Stregchynge his nekke and helde his eyen cloose
And gan to crowe lowde for þe nones
And daun Russell sterte up al at ones
And by þe gargache hente chauntecler
And on his bakke towardes þe wode hy ber
For ȝit was þ̉er no man hym swede
O destynee þat mayst not bene ethchewede
Allas þat Chauntecler fell fro þe bemes
Allas his wyffe ne rouȝht noȝte of dremes
And on a friday fell al þis myschaunce
O venus þat arte goddes of plesaunce
Sethens þat þi ʆseruant was þis Chauntecler
And in thy seruise did al his power þ
Mor for delite þan for þe worlde multiplie
Why woldest þou suffr on þi day to dye
O gaufrede der maist̉er souereyn
That when þi worthy kynge richarde was slayn
With shote compleynedest his deeth so sor
Why ne had I nowe þi sentence and þi lor
The friday for to chide as did ȝe
For on a friday shortly slayne was he
Than wolde I schewe howe þat I couthe pleyne
For chauntecler and for his peyne
Certes suche crye ne lamentacioıı̄un
Was of ladyes made when þat yleon
Was wonne and pyrus with his streiȝht swerde
When he hente kynge priame by þe berde
And slayn hym as seide enneidos
As maden alle þe hennes in þe cloose
When þei hadde seyn of Chauntecler þis siȝht
But souereyn dame ꝑpartelot schriȝht
Wel louder þen did hasdrubaldes wyffe
When þat hir husbonde had loste his lyffe
And þat þe romayns had hente Cartage
She was so full of torment and of rage
That wilfully in to þe fuyr sche stirte
And brente her selfe with a stedfaste herte
O wofull hennes riȝht so crieden ȝe
As when þat Nero brente þe Citee
Of rome crieden þe senatours wyffes
For þat her husbondes schulden lese her lyffes
With outen gilte Nero hath hem slayn
Nowe woll I turne to my tale a ȝeyne
This sely wydowe and hir doughters twoo .
Herden þe hennes crien and maken woo .
And oute at þe dor sterten þei onone
And sagh þe fox to warde þe groue gone
And bar opon his bak þe coke a weye
And crieden oute and harrowe and welawaye
A ha þe fox and aft̉er hym þei ranne
And eke with staffes mony an other man
Ranne . coll our dogge talbot and garlonde
And malkyn with hir distaff in hir honde
Ranne cowe and kalfe and eke þe verrey hogges
Sor a ferde for berkynge of dogges .
And schotynge of men and of wōmmen eke
Thei ranne so þat her herte þei thouȝht to breke
Thei ȝelleden as fendes done in helle
The dogges criden as men wolde hem quell ¶þ
Oute of þe hyves come þe sworme of bees
The gees for fer flowen ouer þe trees
So hidous was þe noys a benedicite
Certꝭes he Iak . strawe and his menȝee
Ne made neủer schowtes halfe so schrill
When þat þei wolde eny flemmyng kill
As þat ilk day was made opon þe fox
Of bras þei / broȝht bemes and a box
Of horne and bone in whiche þei powpede
And þ̉er with all / þei schryched and schoutede
It semed as þat heuen schuld fall
Now goode men I pᵃy ȝowe herkenyth all
Loo howe fortune turneth sodenly
The hope and eke pride of her envie
This cok þat lay opon þe fox bak
In all his drede vn to þe fox spake
And saied sir ȝiff I wer as ȝee
Ȝit schuld I seye as wys god helpe me
Turne a ȝeyn ȝe proude cherles all
A verrey pestilence opon ȝowe fall
Nowe . am I com vn to þis wood side
Mawgr ȝour hede þe cok schall her abide
I woll hym ete in feith and þat onon
The fox answered in feith it schall be don
And he spake þat worde all sodenly
The cok brak from his mouthe deliuerly
And hiegh opon a tr he fliegh onone
And when þe fox sawe þat he was gone
Allas qd he o chauntcler allas
I haf qd he done to ȝowe trespasse
In als muche as I made ȝowe a ferde
When I ȝowe hente and broȝht oute of þe ȝerde
But sir I did it not in no wykked entente
Comyth down and I schall tell ȝowe what I mente
I schall say þe sotth as helpe me god so
Nay þan qd he I schrewe us both twoo
And firste I schrewe my selfe both blode and bones
Ȝiff you begile me eny oft̉er þan ones
Thou schalt no mor with þi flaterye
Do me synge and wynke wyth myn eye
For he þat wynketh when he schuld see
As wysly god lat hym neủer thee
Nay qd þe fox god ȝiff hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaunce
That Iangleth when he schuld haue peese
Loo suche it is to be recchelesse ¶þ
And necligente and trusteth on flaterye
But ȝe þat holden̄ þis folye
As of a fox and of a cok and of an henne
Takith þe moralite good men̄
For seynt poule seith aƚƚ þat writen̄ is
To our͗ doctrine it is writen̄ y wys
Takith þe fruyte and letyth þe chaff be stiƚƚ
Nowe goode god if þat it be þi wiƚƚ
As seith my lorde so make us aƚƚ goode men̄
Ande brynge us aƚƚ to þe hye blysse amen
¶ Here endeth þe nōnne pⁱristes tale

And her͗ begȳnnyth þe .ij. nōnne
¶ Prologus .
div.note: ¶ De vita stēancte Cecilie
div.l: The ministr͗e of þe nurrys vn to vices
Whiche þat men̄ clepen̄ in ynglyssh yldnes
The porter of þe gate is of delices
To eschewe and by hir͗ ꝯcontᵃrarie hur͗ opp̉resse
That is to seyn̄ by lefuƚƚ besynesse
Wele ouȝht we to don̄ our͗ entente
Leest þat þe fende thurgh ydolnesse us schente
¶ For he þat with his thousande cordis slyiȝe
Continuelly us waiteth to be clappe
When̄ he may man̄ in ydelnesse aspie
He can so liȝhtly cacche hym in his trappe
Tiƚƚ þat a man̄ be brente riȝht by þe lappe
He nys not war͗ þe fende hath hym in honde
Wel ouȝhte us for to wirche and ildnesse to withstonde
¶ And þogh men̄ dradden̄ neủer for to dye
Ȝit seen̄ men wele be resoıı̄un doutelesse
Þat ildenesse is roten̄ slogardrye
Of whiche þ̉er cometh neủer none encresse
And sethens þat slouth hir͗ haldeth in a leese
Only to sleepe and for to ete and drynke
And to deuouren̄ aƚƚ þat oþer swynke
¶ And for to putten us from suche ildenesse
That cause is of grete confusioun̄
I haf her͗ done my faithfuƚƚ besynesse
Aft̉er þe legende in translacioun̄
Riȝht of þi gloriouse liffe and passioun̄
Þou with þi garlond wroȝht of roses and lilie
The . mene . I a maide and martir seynt cecilie
¶ And þou þat flour of virgynes arte aƚƚ
Off whome þat Bernard . luste so wele to write
To þe at my begynnynge firste I caƚƚ
Thou ꝯconforte of us wrecches do me endite
Thy maydens deth þat was thurgh hir͗ merite
The et̉ernall lyffe and of þe fende victorie
As men̄ may aft̉er reden̄ in her storye
¶ Thou mayden̄ and moder doght̉er of þi sonne
Thou weƚƚ of m̉ercy synfuƚƚ soules cure
In whome þat god for bounte chees to wonne
Thou humble and hiegh oủer eủery creatur͗
Thou nobledeste so feir͗ our͗ natur͗
That no disdeyn̄ þe maker hadde of kynde
His son̄ in bloode and flessh to clothe and wynde
¶ With in þe cloistr͗e blesfuƚƚ of þi sides
Toke mannys schappe þe et̉erne loue and peese
That of þe trine compas lorde and gyde is
Whome erthe and see and heuen̄ oute of relesse
Ay heryen̄ . and þou virgyne wēmmeles
Bar͗ of þⁱ body and dweldist mayden̄ pur͗
The creatour of eủery creatur͗
¶ Assembled is in þe magnificence
With mercy goodnes and with suche pite
That þou arte þe sonne of excellence
Noȝt only helpeste hem þat prayen þe
But ofte tyme of þi benignite
Fuƚƚ frely arte þat men̄ þine helpe beseche
Thou goiste beforne and arte her lyffes leche
¶ Nowe helpe þou meke and blesfuƚƚ fair͗ mayde
Me flemyd wrecche in þis deserte of galle
Thenke on þe wōmman̄ cananee þat saide
That whelpes eten̄ som̄ of þe crōmmes alle
That from her͗ lordes table bene yfalle
And þof þat I be þe vnworthy sonne of Eue
And am synfuƚƚ ȝit accepte my beleue
¶ And for þat feith is dede with outen werkis
So for to wirchen̄ ȝiff me wytte and space
That I be quyt from place þat most derke is
O þou þat arte so faire and fuƚƚ of grace
Be myn aduocate in so hie a place
Ther as with outen̄ ende is songe osanna
Thou Cristꝭes moder and doȝht̉er of Anna
¶ And of þi liȝht my soule in prisoıı̄un liȝhte
That troubled is by þe contagioun̄
Of my body and also by þe wiȝhte
Of erthly luste and fals affeccioıı̄un
O heuen̄ O refute o saluacioun̄
Of hem þat bene in sorow and in distresse
Nowe help for vn to my werke I wiƚƚ me dresse
¶ Ȝit preye I ȝowe þat redyn̄ þat I write
For ȝiffeth me þat I do no diligence
This ilke story subtily to endite
For both haf I þe wordes and þe sentence
Off hem þat at seyntes reuerence
The storye wrote ande folowen̄ her legende
And praye I ȝowe þat ȝe wolne my werke amende
Firste woll I ȝowe þe name of seynte Cecilie
Expowne as men̄ may in hir͗ storyes see
It is to seye on ynglisse heuen̄es lilye
For pure chastnesse of virginite
Other for sche wytnesse hadde of honeste
Of grene of conscience and of goode fame
The swete sauour lilie was hir͗ name
Ouþer Cecilye is to seye þe weye to blynde
For sche ensample was be goode techynge
Or els cecilles as I writen̄ fynde
Ys ioynyde · be a man̉er conioynynge
Of heuen̄ and lya and hier in fygᵘurynge
The heuen̄ is sette for thouȝht of holynesse
And lya for hir͗ lastynge besynesse
¶ Cecile may eke be saide in þis maner͗
Wantynge of blyndenes for hir͗ grete liȝht
Of sapiens and for her thewes cler͗
Oþ̉er els loo þis maydens name bryȝhte
Of heuen̄ and leos cometh for whiche be riȝht
Men̄ myȝht þe heuen̄ of peple hir͗ calle
Ensample of goode and wyse werkes alle
For leos peple in ynglissh is to seye
And riȝht as men̄ may in þis heuen̄ see
The sonne and mone and þe sterrys eủery waye
Riȝht so gostly in þis mayden̄ free
Seyen̄ þe feith of magnificence
And eke of helthe and of sapience
And sondry werkes bryȝht of excellence
¶ And riȝht as þis philisophers wryte
That heuen̄ is swyfte rounde and brennynge
Riȝht so was fair͗ Cecilie þe white
Full swyfte and besy eủer in goode wirkynge
And rounde and hole in goode ꝑperseuerynge
And brenne eủer in charite liȝhte
Nowe haf I declarede ȝowe what sche hiȝhte
¶ Hic incipit fabula
This mayden̄ briȝht Cecily as hir͗ lyffe seith
Was com̄yn of romayns and of noble kynde
And so forthe fostred up in þe feyth
Of Criste and bar͗ his gospeƚƚ in her mynde
She neủer cesed as I writen̄ fynde
Off hir͗ p̉reier and godde to luff and drede
Besechynge hym to kepen̄ hir͗ maydenhede
¶ And when̄ þis mayden̄ schulde vn to a man̄
Y wedded be that was fuƚƚ ȝonge of age
Whiche þat cleped was valerian̄
And þe daye was comen̄ of hir͗ mariage
She was full deuoute and humble in hir͗ corage
Vndir hir͗ robe of golde þat satte fuƚƚ fair͗
And nexte hir͗ flessh sche cladde was in an heir͗
¶ And whiles þe orgles mayden̄ melodye
To goode allone þus in herte sange sche
O lorde my soule and eke my body gye
Vnwēmmed leste þat I confounded be
And for his luff þat died opon a tree
Euery secounde or iij day sche faste
Ay biddynge in hir͗ orisouns full faste
¶ The nyȝht come and to bedde sche moste goone
With hir͗ husbonde as often̄ is þe maner͗
And priuely sche sayde onon̄
O swete and welebeloued spouse der͗
Ther͗ is a counseƚƚ and ȝe wolde it her͗
Which þat riȝht fayne I woll vn to ȝowe seyn̄
So þat ȝe me assur͗ it not to bewrayne
¶ Valerian̄ gan̄ faste vn to hir͗ swere
That for no caase ne thynge þat myȝht be
He schuld for no thynge neủer be wreyen̄ hir͗
And þan at arste þus to hym saide sche
I haue an Aungeƚƚ whiche þat louyth me
That with grete loue wheþ̉er so I wake or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
¶ And ȝiff þat he may felen̄ oute of drede
That ȝe wiƚƚ ȝowe goủerne no thyng amys
He wiƚƚ ȝowe saue and kepe tiƚƚ ȝe be dede
For ȝour͗ clene lyffynge and and ȝour goodnes
And brynge ȝowe streiȝht in to heuen̄ blisse
