He wolde ȝowe loue as me for ȝour͗ clennesse
And schewen̄ ȝowe of his Ioye and his briȝhtnesse
¶ Valerian correctid as god wolde
Answerde a ȝeyn̄ ȝiff I schaƚƚ truste to þe
Lat me þat Aungeƚƚ see and hym beholde
And ȝiff þat it a verrey Aungeƚƚ be
Than̄ woƚƚ I done as þou haste praied me
And ȝiff þou loue a noþ̉er man̄ for sothe
Riȝht with þis swerde I woll sle ȝowe bothe
¶ Cecile answerde onon̄ in þis wyse
Ȝiff þat ȝe luste þat Aungeƚƚ schull ȝee see
So þat ȝe trowe on criste and ȝowe baptise
Goth forth to Via Apia qduod sche
That from þis town̄ stante but miles thr͗e
And to þe pore folkes þat þ̉er dweƚƚ
Saye hem riȝht þus as þat I schaƚƚ ȝowe teƚƚ
¶ Teƚƚ hem þat I cecilye ȝowe to hem sente
To shewen̄ ȝowe þe gode Vrban̄ þe olde
For secree nedes and for goode entente
And whan þat ȝee seynt Vrban han be holde
Telle hym þe wordes whiche þat I to ȝowe tolde
And when̄ þat he hath purged ȝowe from synne
Than schuƚƚ ȝe see þat Aungeƚƚ ar ȝe twynne
¶ Valerian̄ is to þat place y gone
And riȝht as hym was tauȝht by hus lernynge
He fonde þis holy Vrbane onone
Amange þise deyntes buryells lotynge
And he onon̄ with outen taryynge
Did his message and when̄ þat he hadde tolde
Vrban for ioye gan̄ his hondes up holde
¶ The teres from his eyen̄ lete he falle
Al myȝhty god o iħuihesu criste qduod he
So were of chaste ꝯconseiƚƚ and herde of us aƚƚ
The fruyte of þilke seede of chastite
That þou haste sowe in Cecile take to þe
Loo y like a busy bee with outen gile
Þe ʆserueth ay þine oune thraƚƚ cecyle
¶ For þilke spowse þat sche tooke but nowe
Fuƚƚ like a fiers lyoıı̄un sche sendith here
As meke as eny lamb was to ȝowe
And with þat worde onon̄ þ̉er gan aper͗
An olde man̄ cladde with white clothes cler͗
And hadde a booke with lett̉ers of gold in honde
And gan̄ beforne Valerian̄ stonde
¶ Valerian̄ as dede fel doun for drede
When̄ he hym saugh and hym up hente þoo
And on his boke riȝht þus he gan̄ to rede
O lorde o feith . o . god with oute moo
Of Cristendome and fadur of al alsoo
A bouēn aƚƚ and oủer aƚƚ euery wher͗
This wordes al with golde writen̄ wer͗
¶ Whan̄ þis was rad þan saide þis olde man̄
Leuyst þou þis thinge or no sey ȝe or nay
I leue al þis thynge þan þis I dar wele saye
Vnder þe heuen̄ no wiȝht ne thenke may
Tho vanysshede þe olde man̄ he nyste wher͗
And pope Vrban̄ hym cristened riȝht þer͗
Valerian̄ goith home and seynt cecile
With in his chambr͗e an Aungeƚƚ did stande
This aungeƚƚ had of roses and of lylye
div.fw: Corones two þᵉ whiche he bar͗ in hande
div.l: Corones two þe whiche he bar͗ in hande
And firste to Cecile as I vndirstande
¶ He ȝaf þe tone and aft̉er gan he take
That oþer to Valerian her make
With body clene and with vnwemed thoȝht
Kepith ay wele þis corones ꝙquod he
From ꝑparadys to ȝowe haf I hem broȝht
Ne neuer more schuƚƚ þei roten̄ be
Ne lese her͗ swete sauour trusteth vn to me
¶ Ne neủer wyȝht schall sene hem with his eye
But if he be chaste and hate vilenye
And þou valerian for þou so sone
Assentidest to good ꝯconseƚƚ also
Say what þe luste and þou schalt haf þⁱ bone
I haf a broþ̉er qduod valerian þoo
Þat in þis worlde I luff no man̄ soo
¶ I pray ȝowe þat my broþ̉er may han̄ gᵃrace
To knowe þe trouthe as I do in þis place
The aungeƚƚ answerde god liketh ȝour͗ requeste
And both withe þe palme of martirdome
Ȝe schuƚƚ come vn to þe blisfuƚƚ feste
And with þat worde tiburce his broþ̉er come
And when̄ þat he þe sauour vndirnome
¶ With þat þe roses and þe lilies taste
With in his herte he gan̄ to wonder faste
And seide in þis tyme I wonder͗ of þe ȝeer͗
Whennes þis swete sauour cometh soo
Of roses and lilies þat I smelle here
For þoff I had hem in myn hondes twoo
The sauour myȝht in me no depper goo
¶ The swete smelle þat in myn̄ herte I fynde
Hath chaunged me al in a nother kynde
Valerian̄ seide two corones hauen̄ wee
Snowe white and roses rede þat schyneth cler͗
Whiche þat þine eien̄ han̄ no myȝht to see
And as þou smellest þam thurgh my pᵃraier
So schalt þou seen̄ hem leefe brother dere
¶ Ȝiff it so be þat þou wolt with outen slouthe
Beleese a riȝht and knowe verreye trowthe
Tiburce answerde saist þou þis to me
In sothenes or in dreme speken̄ ȝe þis
In dremes qduod Valerian̄ han̄ we be
Vn to þis tyme brother myn̄ y wys
And nowe at arste our͗ trowthe dwellynge is
¶ Howe woteste þou qduod tiburce and in what wise
Qduod valerian̄ þat schaƚƚ þe devise
¶ The Aungell of god hath me þe trouthe y tauȝht
Whiche þat þou schalt sene ȝiff þat þou wolt renye
The ydoles and be clene and ells noȝht
And of þe miracles of þise corones tweye
Seynt Ambrose in his p̉reface luste to seye
Solempnly þis noble doctour der͗
Comendeth it and seith in þis maner͗
¶ The palme of martirdome for to resseyue
Seynt cecyle fulfilled of goddes ȝifte
The worlde and eke her͗ chambr͗e gan̄ sche weyffe
Wytnesse tiburce and Cecilyes schryfte
To whiche god of his bounte wolde schyfte
Corones two of his boute wᵗith floures wele smellyng
And made þe Aungeƚƚ hem þe corones brynge
¶ Þis mayde hath brouȝht þise men̄ to blisse aboue
Þe worlde hath wiste what it is worth certeyn̄
Deuocioıı̄un of Chastite to loue
Tho schewed hym cecile open̄ and pleyne
That aƚƚ ydols nys but thynge in veyn̄
For þei bene dombe and þer to þei bene defe
And charched hym his ydols for to leue
¶ Who þat þis troweth not a beste he is
Qduod þo tiburce ȝiff þat I schaƚƚ not lye
She gan̄ þan to kysse his breste and þᵗat hard þis
And was fuƚƚ glad he couthe trowthe aspie
This day take I þe for myn̄ allye
Saide þis blesfuƚƚ maide fair͗ and der͗
For aft̉er þat sche saide as ȝe may her͗
¶ Loo riȝht so as þe loue of Criste qduod sche
Made me þⁱ brothers wyffe riȝht in þat wyse
Onon̄ for myn̄ allie her͗ take I þee
Sethen̄ þat þou wolte þine ydolis despise
Go with þi broþ̉er nowe and þe baptise
And make þe clene so þat þou maiste be holde
The Aungells face of whiche þⁱ brother tolde
¶ Tiburce answerde and seide brother der͗
First teƚƚ me whider I schaƚƚ and to what man̄
To whome qduod he come forth with riȝht goode cher͗
I woƚƚ þe lede vn to þe pope vrban̄
To Vrban broþ̉er myn̄ Valerian̄
Qduod þo tiburce wolt þou me þider lede
Me thynketh þat it wer͗ a wonder dede
¶ Nemenest þou noȝt vrban̄ qduod he þoo
That is so ofte dampned to be dede
And woneth in halkes to and froo
And dar not ones putte forth his hede
Men̄ schull hym brenne in a fir͗ so rede
Ȝif þᵗat he wer founde þᵗat men̄ myȝht hym aspie
And we also þat bere hym companye
¶ And whils we seken̄ þilke diuinite
That is y hidde in heuen̄ pryue
Algate y brente in þis worlde schull we be
To whome Cecilye answered boldlye
Men̄ miȝht drede wele and skilfully
This liffe to leese myn own̄ der͗ broþer
Ȝif þis wer͗ lyuynge only and non̄ other
¶ But þ̉er is bett̉er lyffe in other place
That neủer schaƚƚ be loste ne drede þe noȝhte
Whiche goddis son̄ us tolde thurgh his grace
Memorie Ingenye and intellecte also
So in oo beynge of diuinite
Thr͗e ꝑpersones riȝht wele þ̉er may be
¶ Tho gan̄ sche hym besily preche
Of Cristis comȳng and of his peynes teche
And mony poyntes of his passioun
Howe goddis son̄ in þis worlde was withholde
To do man̄ kynde pleyn̄ remissioıı̄un
That was y bounde in synnes and kares colde
Aƚƚ þis thynge sche vn to tiburce tolde
¶ And aft̉er þis tiburce in goode entente
To pope vrban̄ with valerian̄ he wente
Which thanked god and with glad herte and liȝht
He cristened hȳm and made hym in þat place
ꝐParfite in his liffynge goddis knyȝht
And aft̉er þat Tiburce gat suche gᵃrace
That eủery day he sawe in tyme and space
Þe Aungeƚƚ of god and eủery man̉er bone
Þat he asked of god it was spedde fuƚƚ sone
¶ It wer fuƚƚ harde be ordr͗e for to seyn̄
Howe mony wondres IħuIhesu for hym wrouȝht
But at þe laste to telle schorte and pleyn̄
Þe Sergeaunt of þe town̄ of rome hem soȝht
And hem beforne Almache þe Prouost broȝht
Which hem opposed and knewe al her͗ entente
And to þe ymage of Iubit̉er he hem sente
¶ And saide who so wiƚƚ not sacrifice
Smyte of his hede þis is my sentence her͗
Onon̄ þis martirs þat I ȝowe deuyse
One maximius þat was an officer͗
Of þe p̉refectꝭes and of Corniculer͗
Hem hente and when̄ he forth þe seyntes ladde
Hym selfe he wepe for pite þat he hadde
¶ When̄ maximius had herde þe sentence lore
He gat hem of þe tormentours leue
And hadde hem in his howse with outr͗ mor͗
And with þ̉er p̉rechynge er þat it wer eue
Þei gon̄ from þe tormentours to Reue
And from maximius and from his folke ilkon̄
The fals feith to trowe in god allone
¶ Cecile come whan̄ it was wexen̄ nyȝht
With p̉restes þat hem Cristened al in fer͗
And aft̉erwarde when̄ day was woxen̄ liȝht
Cecile to hem seide with a sobr͗ cher͗
Nowe cristꝭes own̄ knyȝhtes leefe and der͗
Casteth al a weye þe werkes of derkenesse
And armeth ȝowe in armour of liȝhtnesse
¶ Ȝe han̄ for soth y done a grete bataiƚƚ
Ȝour͗ our͗ is done ȝoᵘur feith han̄ ȝe conseruede
Gooth to þe corone of liff þat may not faiƚƚ
The riȝhtfuƚƚ iugge whiche þat ȝe han̄ deserued
To for hym ȝe ben̄ feithfully preseruede
And when̄ þis thynge was seide as I devise
Men̄ ladde hem forth to don̄ þe sacrifice
¶ But when̄ þei wer͗ vn to þe place y broȝht
To telle schortly þe conclusioıı̄un
Þei nolde encense nor sacrifice riȝht noȝt
But on her͗ knees þei setten̄ hem a doun̄
With humble herte and sadde deuocioıı̄un
And losten̄ both þ̉er hedes in þe place
Her͗ soules wenten̄ to þe kynge of gᵃrace
¶ This maximius þat sawe þis thyng betyde
With pitous talis tolde it onon̄ riȝht
That he her͗ soules sawgh to heuen̄ glide
With Aungells fuƚƚ of clernesse and of liȝht
And with his worde ꝯconuertid mony a wyȝht
For whiche Almachius did hym so to bete
With whippes of leede tiƚƚ he his lyffe gan̄ lete
¶ Cecile hym toke and beried hym onon̄
Be tyburce and valerian̄ softely
With in hir͗ beryynge place vnder þe stone
And aft̉er þis Almachius hastily
Badde his ministr͗es fecchen̄ openly
Cecile þat sche myȝht in his presence
Do sacrifice to Iubit̉er and hym encense
¶ But þei þat wer͗ conủerted thurgh her͗ wyse lore
Wepten̄ sore and ȝaf credence
Vnto hir͗ worde and creden mor͗ and mor͗
Criste goddis son̄ with outen̄ difference
Is verrey godde þis is al our͗ sentence
That hath so goode a ʆseruᵃaunt hym to serue
Thus with oo voys . we trowe þof we sterue
¶ Almachius þat herde al þis
Bad fecchen cecile þat he myȝht her see
And alderferst lo þis was his askynge
What man̉er wōmman̄ art þou þoo qduod he
I am a gentiƚƚ wōmman borne qduod sche
I aske qduod he þof it þe greue
Off þi religioıı̄un and of þi beleue
¶ Why þan̄ began̄ ȝe ȝour͗ questioıı̄un folily
Qduod she þat woldest two answers conclude
In oo demaunde ȝe asked lewdly
Almache answerde to þat similitude
Of whenes qduod sche when̄ þat she was refreynede
Of conscience and of goode feith vnfeynede
¶ Almachius saide takest þou non hede
Of þine answer͗ and sche hym answerde þus
Ȝour͗ myȝht qduod sche litiƚƚ is to drede
For euery morteƚƚ manes power nys
But y lyk a bladder fuƚƚ of wynde y wys
For with a nedlys poynt whan̄ þat is blowe
May al þe booste of it be leyde fuƚƚ lowe
¶ Fuƚƚ wrongefully be gan̄ þou qduod he
And ȝit in wronge is þine ꝑperseueraunce
Woste þou not howe our͗ myȝhty prince fr͗e
Ben þus ꝯcommanded and maken̄ ordenᵃaunce
That eủer Cristen̄ wiȝht schaƚƚ han̄ penance
But ȝiff þat his Cristendome with saye
And gone al quyte ȝiff he woƚƚ it resseyue
¶ Ȝour͗ princes erren̄ as ȝour͗ noblen̄ with
Qduod þoo cecile and a woode sentence
Ȝe make us gilty and it nys not sothe
For ȝe þat knowen̄ wele our͗ Innocence
For als myche as we don̄ a reủerence
To criste and for we ber͗ a cristen̄ name
Ȝe putte on us a cryme and eke a blame
¶ But we þat knowe þilke name so
For vertuos we may it not saye
Almachie answerde cheese one of þise two
Do sacrifice or Cristendome reneye
Þat þou mow now skapen̄ be þat weye
At whiche þe holy blisfuƚƚ mayde
Gan̄ for to lawh and to þe Iuge sche saide
¶ O Iugge confuse in þi nycete
Wolt þou þat I renye Innocence
To maken̄ me a wikked wiȝht qduod sche
Lo he dissimileth her͗ in audience
He starith and woodith in his adủertence
To whome Almachius O vnsely wrecche
Ne wooste þou not howe fer͗r͗ my myȝht may strecche
¶ Hath not our͗ myȝhty prince to me y ȝeffen̄
Ȝe both power and eke auctorite
To make folke to dyen̄ or to liffen̄
Why spekest þou so proudely þen̄ to me
I ne speke it not but stedfastly qduod sche
Not proudely for I sey as for my side
I hate dedely þilke vice of pride
¶ And ȝiff þou dredde not a soth to her͗
Than̄ woƚƚ I schewen̄ al openly be riȝht
That þou haste made a fuƚƚ grete lesynge her͗
Thou seiste þi prince hath ȝiffen̄ þe myȝht
Both to sleen̄ and for to quyk a wyȝht
Thou þat ne maiste but only liff liff her͗ be Reue
Thou ne haste þ̉er to neiþ̉er power ne leeue
¶ But þou maiste se þi princes han̄ þe maked
Ministr͗e of deeth For ȝiff þou speke of moo
Thou liest for þi power͗ is fuƚƚ nakede
Do wey þi boldenesse seide Almachius þoo
And sacrifice to our͗ goddis twoo
I ne recche not what wronge þat þou me ꝓprofer
For I can̄ suffr͗e it as a philisophr͗e
¶ But þilke wronges may I not endur͗
That þou spekest of our͗ goddis her͗ qduod he
Cecile answered O nyce creatur͗
Thou seidest no worde sethen þou spake to me
That I ne knewe þerwith þi nycete
And þat þou wer͗ in eủery man̉er wyse
A lewed officer͗ a veyn̄ iustise
¶ Ther lakketh no thynge to þine vtter eien̄
That þou ne arte blynde for thyng þat we seen̄ aƚƚlle
That is a stone þat men̄ wele may aspien̄
That ilke stone a godde þou wolt it calle
I rede þe lat þine honde opon̄ it falle
And taste it wele and stone þᵘou schalt it fynde
Seth þat þou seest it not with þine eyen̄ blynde
¶ It is a schame þat þe peple schaƚƚ
So scorne þe and lagh at þi folye
For cōmmnly wōmmen̄ wote it wele oủer aƚƚ
That myȝhty godde is mans heuenes hye
And þise ymages wel þan maiste þᵘou aspie
To þe ne to hem selfe may þei not profite
For in her͗ effecte þei be not worth a myte
¶ This and suche oþer wordes seide sche
And he wax wrothe and bad sche schuld be lede
Hom to her͗ howse and in hir͗ house qduod he
Brennen̄ hir͗ riȝht in a fuyr͗ with flames rede
And as he badde riȝht so was done in dede
And in a bathe þei gan hir͗ faste schetyn̄
And nyȝht and daye grete fuyr vnder þei maden̄
¶ Al þe longe nyȝht and eke þe daye also
For aƚƚ þe Fuyr͗ and eke þe bathes hete
She satte aƚƚ colde and felte of it no woo
But made hir͗ a drope not for to sweete
But in þat bathe hir͗ lyff sche moste lete
For he Almache with fuƚƚ wikked entente
To sleen̄ hir͗ in þe bath his sonde he sente
¶ Thre strokes in þe nekke he smoot hir͗ þoo
The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
He myȝht not smyten̄ aƚƚ hir͗ nekke atwoo
And for þ̉er was þat tyme an ordenᵃaunce
That no man̄ schuld do man̄ suche penᵃaunce
The ferthe stroke to smyten̄ softe or sor͗
This tormentour ne dorste no mor͗
¶ But half dede with hir͗ nekke y corven̄ þer͗
He lefte her͗ lye and in his weye he wente
The Cristen̄ folke whiche abouten̄ hir͗ wer͗
With schetes home fuƚƚ fair͗ her͗ hente
Thr͗e dayes liffed sche in þis tormente
And neủer cesed hem þe feith to teche
That sche had fostred hem sche gan̄ to preche
¶ And hem sche ȝaff her͗ moebles and hir͗ thynge
And to þe Pope Vrban̄ be toke hem þoo
And seide þus I askede þis of heuen kynge
To haue respite thr͗e dayes and no moo
To recomande to ȝowe er þat I goo
Thise soules loo and þat I myȝht to wirche
Her͗ of myn̄ hows ꝑperpetualiche a chirche
Seynt Vrban̄ with his dekenes priuely
The body fecched and buried it be nyȝht
Amonge his oþer seyntes honestly
Hir͗ house þe chirche of seynt cecille hiȝht
Seynt Vrban̄ halowed it as he wele myȝht
In þe whiche in to þis day in noble wyse
Men̄ done to criste and to his seynte seruyse
¶ Here endeth þe secounde nonnes tale

div.fw: ¶ Þe prologe of þe chanons yoman̄
div.l: When̄ endid was þe liffe of seynt Cecile
Er we fully hadde riden̄ fife Mile
At Boghton vndir þe blee vs gan atake
A man̄ þat clothed was in clothes blake
And vndir þat he had a white surplise
His hakney þat was aƚƚ pomeƚƚ gryse
So swette þat it wonder was to see
It semed he had prikked myles thr͗e
This horse eke þat his yoman̄ rode opon̄
So swette þat vnnethe myȝht he gone
Aboute þe paytreƚƚ stode þe fome fuƚƚ hieȝ
He was of fome aƚƚ flekked as a pye
A male twyfolde on his croper laye
It semed þat he caried litiƚƚ araye
Al liȝht for somer rode þis worthy man̄
And in myn̄ herte wondren̄ I began̄
What þat he was tiƚƚ þat I vndirstode
Howe þat his cloke was sowed to his hode
For whiche when̄ I longe hadde avised me
I demed hym som chanoıı̄un for to be
His hat honge at his bak doun̄ by a laas
For he had riden̄ mor͗ þan̄ trotte or pase
He hadde ay priked like as he wer wode
A clote leefe he had vndir his hoode
For swoote and for to kepe his hede from hete
But it was Ioye for to sene hym swete
His forhede dropped as a stillitorie
War͗ full of planteyn̄ and and of paritorie
And when̄ þᵗatee he come he gan̄ to crie
God saue qduod he þis Ioly compaignye
Fast haue I prikked qduod he for ȝour sake
By cause þat I wolde ȝowe oủertake
To riden̄ in þis mery companye
His yoman̄ eke was fuƚƚ of curtesye
And sirres nowe in þe morowe tyde
Out of ȝour͗ ostelerye I sawe ȝowe ride
And warned her͗ my lorde and my souẻreyn̄
Whiche for to ride with ȝowe he is fuƚƚ fayn̄
For his disporte he loueth daliaunce
Frende for þi warnynge god ȝif þe goode chaunce
S oste certis it wolde seme
Þ war wyse and so I may wele deme
He his fuƚƚ Ioconde also dar I laye
Kan̄ he ouȝht teƚƚ a mery tale or tweye
With whiche he gladen̄ may þis ꝯcompanye
Who sir͗ my lorde · ȝa ȝa · withouten lye
He can̄ of myrthe and eke of Iolitee
Not but ynogh all so sir trustenyth me
And ȝe hym knewe als wele as do I
Ȝe wolde wonder howe wele and thryftyly
He couthe werke and þat in sundry wyse
He hath take on hym mony diủerse apryse
Whiche wer fuƚƚ harde for eny þat is her͗e
To brynge aboute but þei of hym it lere
Als homely as he rute amonges ȝowe
Ȝiff ȝe hym knewe it wolde be ȝour͗ prowe
Ȝe nolde not forgone his aqueyntance
For mychell goode · I dar͗ leye in balance
Aƚƚ þat · I haue in my possessioıı̄un
He is a man̄ of hiegh discrecioun̄
I warne ȝowe wele he is a passyng man̄
Wele qduod our͗ oste I praye þe teƚƚ me þan̄
Is he a Clerke or none teƚƚ what he is
Nay he is grett̉er þan̄ a clerke I wys
Seyde þe yoman̄ and in wordes fewe
Ooste . and of his crafte sumwhat I woƚƚ ȝowe schewe
I seye my lorde can̄ suche a sotellte
But aƚƚ his crafte ȝe may not wyte at me
And somwhat helpe I ȝit to his worchynge
That aƚƚ þis grounde þat we ben on ridynge
Tiƚƚ þat we com̄ to canturbury town̄
He couthe aƚƚ clene turne up so doun
And pave it aƚƚ of silủer and of golde
And whan̄ þis ȝoman̄ had þus y tolde
Vn to our͗ oost he saide benedicite
This þinge is wonder meruelous to me
Sethens þat þi lorde is of so hiegh prudence
By cause of whiche men̄ schulde hym reủerence
That of his worschipe rekketh he so lite
His oủer slop ne is not worth a myte
As in effecte to hym so mot I goo
It is aƚƚ bawdy and to tor͗ alsoo
Why is þi lorde so slottys I þe preye
And is of power bett̉er clothes to bye
Ȝiff þat his dede acorde with þi speche
Teƚƚ me þat / and þat I þe beseche
Why qduod þis ȝoman̄ wherto aske ȝe me
God helpe me so for he schaƚƚ neủer thee
But I woƚƚ not avowe þat I seye
And þer for kepe it secree I ȝowe pᵃraye
He is to wyse in faith as I beleuee
That þat is oủer don̄ it nyƚƚ not preue
And riȝht as clerkes seyn̄ it is a vice
Wher͗for in þat I holde lewde and nyce
For when̄ a man̄ hath oủer grete a wytte
Fuƚƚ often̄ it happeth hym to mysvsen it
So doith my lorde and þat me greuyth sor͗
God it amende I can̄ seye nowe no more
Ther of no force goode ȝoman̄ qduod our͗ ooste
Syns of þe ꝯconniynge of þi lorde þou wooste
Tell howe he doith I praye þe hertily
Seth he is so crafty and so slye
Wher͗ dwellen̄ ȝe . ȝif it to teƚƚ be
In subarbes of a town̄ qduod he
Lurkynge in hirnes and in lane blynde
Wher͗ þise robbours and thefes be kynde
Holden̄ her pryue ferfuƚƚ residence
As þei þat dur not schewen̄ hur p̉resence
So far͗ we ȝiff I schaƚƚ seye þe sothe
Ȝit qduod our͗ ooste lat me talke tothe
Why art þou so discoloured on þi face
Petir qduod he god ȝiff it harde grace
I am so vsede in þe fir͗ to blowe
That it hath chaunged my colour͗ as I trowe
I am not wonte in no myrour to prye
But swynke sor͗ and lerne to multiplie
We blundren̄ eủer and pouren̄ in þe fir͗
And for aƚƚ þat we faillen̄ of our͗ desir͗
For eủer we lakken̄ our͗ ꝯconclusioıı̄un
To myche folke we bene but illusioıı̄un
And borowe golde be it a pounde or twoo
Or ten̄ or xij. or mony somes moo
And make hem wenen̄ at þe leste weye
That of a pounde we couthe make tweye
Ȝit is it fals and ay we han̄ goode hope
It for to don̄ and aft̉er it we grope
But þat science is so ferr͗ vs beforne
We mowe not al þof we had it sworne
It oủertake / it slideth a weye so faste
It woƚƚ us maken̄ beggers at þe laste
Whils þis ȝoman̄ was þus in þis talkynge
This Chanoıı̄un drewe hym ner͗ and harde al thyng
Which þat þis yoman̄ spake for suspecioıı̄un
Of mennes speche eủer hadde þis chanoıı̄un
For Catoıı̄un seith he þat gylty is
He dmyth al thyng to be spoke of hym I wys
By cause of þat he gan̄ so nyȝh to drawe
His ȝoman þat hard aƚƚ his sawe
And þus he seide vn to his ȝoman̄ þoo
Holde nowe þi pees and speke wordes no moo
For ȝif þou doist þou schalt it der͗ abye
Thou sklaundrest me her͗ in þis companye
And eke discouerest þat þou schuldest hide
Ȝee qduod our͗ ooste teƚƚ on̄ what so betyde
Of al þis thretynge recche þe not a myte
In faith ꝙquod he no mor͗ do I but a lite
And whan þis chanoıı̄un sawe it wolde not be
But algatꝭes his ȝoman̄ wolde teƚƚ his priuete
He fledde a weye for verrey sorowe and schame
A qduod þe ȝoman̄ her͗ schaƚƚ arise agame
Aƚƚ þat I can̄ onon̄ woƚƚ I teƚƚ
Sethen̄ he is gone þe foule fende hym queƚƚ
For neủer her͗ aft̉er woƚƚ I with hym mete
For peny ne for pounde I ȝowe behete
He þat me broȝht firste vn to þat game
Er þat he dye sorowe haf he and schame
For it is ernyst to me be my faith
That fele I wele what so eny man̄ seith
And ȝit for al my smerte and aƚƚ my greue
For aƚƚ my sorowe and labour͗ and myschiefe
I couth neủer leue it in no wyse
Nowe wolde god my wytte myȝht suffice
To tellen̄ aƚƚ þat longeth to þat arte
But natheles ȝit woƚƚ I teƚƚ ȝowe aparte
Syns þat my lorde is gone I wiƚƚ not spare
Swiche thynge as I knowe I woƚƚ declar͗e
¶ Explic̉it ꝓprologus
Incipit fabula
With þis Chanoıı̄un dwelled haf I seuēn ȝer͗
And of his science am I neủer þe ner͗
Aƚƚ þat I hadde I haf y loste þer by
And god wote so haueth mony moo þᵃn I
Ther I was wonte to be riȝht fressh and gaye
Of clothyng and eke of goode araye
Nowe may I wer͗ an hose opon̄ myn̄ hede
And wher͗ my colour was both fressh and reede
Nowe it is wan̄ and of a leden̄ hewe
Who so it vseth sore schaƚƚ he it rewe
And of my swynk ȝit / blerid is myn̄ eye
Loo whiche a vauntage it is to multiplie
That slidynge science hath me made so bar͗
That I haf no good wher͗ þat eủer I fare
And ȝit I am endetted so þ̉er by
Off gold þat I haf borowed trewly
That whils I lyffe I schaƚƚ it quite neủer
Lat eủery man̄ be war͗ be me for eủer
What man̉er man̄ þat castith hym þ̉er to
Ȝiff he ꝯcontinue I holde his thrifte y doo
For so help me god þ̉er by schaƚƚ he not wyn̄
But empte his purse and make his wittes thynne
And whan he thurgh his madnes and folye
Hath loste his own̄ goode thurgh Iepardye
Than he exciteth oþ̉er men̄ þ̉er to
To leese her͗ goode as hym selfe hath doo
For vnto schrewes ioye it is and ese
To haue her felowes in peyn̄ and disese
Thus was I ones lernede of a clerke
Of þat no charche I woƚƚ speke of our͗ werke
When̄ we ben̄ þ̉er as we schuƚƚ exc̉ercise
Our͗ eluessh crafte we seme wonder wyse
Our͗ termes bene so clergeaƚƚ and so queynte
I blewe þe fir͗ tiƚƚ þat myn̄ herte was feynte
What schuld I teƚƚ eche ꝓproporcioun̄
Of thynges whiche þat we worchen̄ opon̄
As on fife or sex vnces may wele be
Of siluer or of som̄ other quantite
And besie me to teƚƚ ȝowe þe names
Of orpiment brente bones yren̄ squames
That in to powder grounden̄ bene fuƚƚ smaƚƚ
And in an erthen̄ potte howe þat pit is aƚƚ
And salte y putte in and also papir͗
Befor þise powdres þat I speke of her͗
And wel y couered with a laumpe of glasse
And of myche other thynge what þᵗat þ̉er was
And of þe potte and glasse englutyng
Ther of þe eyr myȝht passe no thynge
And of þe esy fyr͗ and smerte alsoo
Whiche þat was made and of þe car͗ and woo
That we hadde in our͗ maters sublymynge
And amalgamynge and Calcenynge
Of quik silủer y cleped mercurye crude
For aƚƚ our͗ sleȝhtes we kan̄ not ꝯconclude
Our͗ orpiment and sublymed mercurye
Our͗ grounde litarge eke on þe porphirie
Of iche of þise of vnces a certayn̄
Nat helpith us our͗ labour is in vayn̄
Ne eke our͗ spirites ascensioıı̄un
Ne eke our͗ matiers þat lien̄ our͗ al fix a doun
Mown̄ in our͗ wirkynge no thynge us a vaile
For loste is aƚƚ our͗ labour͗ and our͗ trauaille .
And al þe coste on twenty deuyƚƚ waye
Is loste also whiche we opon̄ it leye
Ther is also mony a nother thynge
That is to our͗ crafte aꝑpertenynge
Þof I be order hem ne reherse can̄
Be cause þat I am a lewde man̄
Ȝet wolde I teƚƚ hem as þei com̄ to mynde
Þof I ne kan̄ sette hem in her͗ kynde
As boole Armoniyk / vertegrese boras
And sondry vessels maade of erthe and glasse
Our͗ vrinales and our͗ descensories
Violes Criselites and sublimatories
Concurbites and Alembykes eke
And oþ̉er swiche der͗ ynogh a leeke
Not nedeth it to rehersen̄ hem aƚƚ
Watres rubyssynge and boles gaƚƚ
Arsenyk sal Armoniak and brymstoıı̄un
And herbes couthe I teƚƚ eke mony one
As egrymoyne Valerian̄ and lunarye
And other suche ȝif þat me luste tarie
Our͗ laumpes brennynge both nyȝht ⁊and day
To bryngen̄ aboute our͗ crafte ȝif þat we may
Our͗ fourneys eke of calcinacoıı̄un
And of watres Albificacoıı̄un
Vnslekked lyme chalke and gleyr͗e of an eye
Poudr͗es diuerse Asshes donge pysse and cleye
Serid pokettys sal petir and vitriole
And diuerse fires made of wode and cole
Sal tartar͗ Alcaly and sal p̉reparate
And combuste matiers and coagulate
Cley made with horses or mannes heer͗ and oyƚƚ
Of tartar͗ Alymglasse berme wortne and argoyƚƚ
Risalgar and oþ̉er maters enbykynge
And eke of our͗ matiers encorporynge
And of siluer Citrinacoıı̄un
Our͗ sementynge and fermentacoıı̄un
Our͗ Ingotes testes and mony moo
I woƚƚ ȝowe teƚƚ as was me tauȝht also
Þe four͗ spirites and þe bodyus seuen̄
By ordre ofte as I harde my lorde neuen̄
The firste spirite quyk siluer called is
The seconde orpymente þe thrid y wys .
Sal armoniak and þe ferthe bremston̄
The bodies seuen̄ eke lo hem her͗ onon̄
Sol golde is and luna siluer we threpe
Mars yrene mercur͗ quyk siluer we clepe
Saturnus lede and Iubiter is tynne
And venus copur be my fader kynne
This cursed crafte who so wiƚƚ exc̉ercise
He schaƚƚ no goode hauen̄ þat may hym suffise
For aƚƚ þe goode he spendith þer aboute
He it schaƚƚ lese þer of haue I no doute
Who so þat liste to outen̄ his folye
Let hym come forth and lerne for to multiplie
And eủery man̄ þat hath ouȝht in his cofer
Lat hym apper͗ ande wex a philisopher͗
As escaunce þat crafte is so liȝht for to ler͗
Nay nay god wote aƚƚ be he monke or frer͗
Preste or chanoıı̄un or eny oþ̉er wyȝhte
Þof he sitte at his booke both day and nyȝht
In lernynge of þis eluyssh nyce lor͗
Aƚƚ is in vayn̄ and parde myche mor͗
It is to lerne a lewde man̄ þis sotelte
Fy speke not þ̉er of for it woƚƚ not be
Al couthe he letterur͗ or couthe he none
As in effecte he schaƚƚ fynde it al one
For both two be my saluacioıı̄un
Concluden̄ in multiplicacoıı̄un
Y liche wele whan̄ þei han̄ aƚƚ y doo
This is to seyn̄ þei faiƚƚ both twoo
Ȝet for þat I to miche rehersaille
Off watirs corrosyffe ande of lymaille
And of bodyes mollificacoıı̄un
And also of hir͗ induracoıı̄un
Oilles ablucoıı̄un and metalls Fusible
To tellen̄ aƚƚ wolde passen̄ eny bible
That owher͗ is wher͗for is for þe beste
Of al þis names nowe wol I me reste
For as I trowe I haue ȝowe tolde y nough
To raysen̄ a fende looke he neủer so rough
A nay lat be þi philisopher͗ stone
Elixer cleped / we sechen it faste ichon̄
For hadde we hym þan̄ wer͗ we siker ynogh
But vnto godde of heuen̄ I make a vowe
For aƚƚ our͗ crafte when̄ we haf aƚƚ y doo
And aƚƚ our͗ sleiȝhte he wiƚƚ not come us to
He hath us made to spenden̄ micheƚƚ goode
For sorowe of whiche al moste we wexen woode
But þat gode hope crepith in our͗ herte
Supposynge eủer þof we sor͗ smerte
To be releuyd by hym aft̉erwarde
Supposyng and hope is scharpe and harde
I warne ȝowe wele it is to seken̄ euer
That futur͗ temps hath made men̄ disseuer
In truste þ̉er of from aƚƚ þat eủer þei hadde
Ȝit of þat arte þei couthe not wexen sadde
For vn to hem it is a bitturswete
So semeth it for ne had þei but a schete
Whiche þei myȝht wrappe in a nyȝhte
And a bak to walken̄ in be day liȝhte
Thei wolde hem sellen̄ and spenden̄ on þis crafte
Thei can not stynt tiƚƚ no thynge be lafte
And eủermor͗ wher͗ þat eủer þei gone
Men̄ may hem knowe by smeƚƚ of bremston̄
For al þe world þei stynken̄ as a goote
Her͗ sauour is so rammyssh and so hote
That þof a man̄ from hem a Mile be
The sauoᵘur woƚƚ enfecte hem trusteth me
Loo þus by smellynge and by threedbar͗ array
Ȝiff þat men̄ liste þis folke þei knowe may
And ȝiff a man̄ woƚƚ asken̄ hym priuely
Why þei bene clothed so vnthriftily
Riȝht onon̄ þei wiƚƚ rownen̄ in his er͗
And seye ȝiff þei aspied wer͗
Men wolde hem slee be cause of her͗ science
Lo þus þis folke betraien̄ Innocence
Passe oủer þis I go my tale vnto
Er þan þe pot be on þe fir͗ . y doo
Of metalls with ac̉erteyn̄ quantite
My lorde hem tempreth and no man̄ but he
Nowe he is gone I dar seye boldly
For as men̄ seyen̄ he can do craftily
Algate I wote wele he hath suche a name
And ȝit fuƚƚ he renneth in þe blame
And witte ȝe wele fuƚƚ ofte it happeth soo
Þe potte to breketh and far͗ wele aƚƚ is goo
Thise metalls bene of so grete violence
Our͗ walles may not make hym resistence
But ȝif þei wer͗ wroȝht of lyme and stone
Thei ꝑpercen̄ so and thurgh þe waƚƚ þei gone
And som of hem synken̄ in to þe grounde
Thus haf we loste be tymes mony a pounde
And some arne skat̉ered al þe floore a boute
Some lepen̄ in to þe roofe with outen doute
Þof þat þe feende not in our͗ siȝht hym schewe
I trowe þat he with us be þat schrewe
In helle wher͗ þat he is lorde and sir͗
Ne is þ̉er no mor͗ woo ne anger nor ir͗
When̄ þat our͗ potte is broke as I haf saide
Eủery man̄ chitte and halte hym euyƚƚ apaide
Som saide it was longe on þe fir͗ makynge
Som saide Nay it was on þe blowynge
Than was I ferud for þat was myn̄ office
Strawe qduod þe thridde ȝe bene lewde and nyce
It was not tempred as it ouȝht to be
Nay qduod þe ferthe stynte and herken̄ me
By cause our͗ fir͗ was not made of beche
That is þe cause non oþ̉er so theeche
I can not teƚƚ wher͗ on it is a longe
But wel I wote grete stryffe is us amonge
What qduod my lorde þer no mor͗ to don̄
Of þise ꝑperills I wiƚƚ be war͗ efte sone
I am riȝht siker þat þe potte was crasede
Be as be may be ȝe no thynge amasede
As vsage is lat swope þe floor͗ as swythe
Pluk up ȝour herte and be ȝe gladde and blithe
The mollok on an hepe y sweped was
And on þe floor͗ kaste a Canevasse
And aƚƚ þis mullok in a syffe y throwe
And y syftyde and y plukked mony a throwe
Parde qduod one sumwhat of our͗ metaƚƚ
Ȝet is þ̉er her͗ þof we haf not aƚƚ
And þof þis thynge myshappud hath as nowe
A noþ̉er tyme it may be wele ynowe
Vs most putte our͗ goode in auentur͗
A marchaund ꝑparde may not ay endur͗
Trustyth me · wele in his prosꝑperite
Somtyme is goode is drowned in þe see
And somtyme cometh it saufe in to þe lande
Pees qduod my lorde þe next tyme I wiƚƚ fonde
To brynge our͗ crafte aƚƚ in a nother plite
And but I do sirres lat me haf þe wyte
Ther was defaute in somwhat wele I wote
And oþ̉er seide þe fir͗ was ouer hote
But he is hote or colde I dar saye þis
That we ꝯconcluden̄ eủermor͗ amys
We Faillen̄ of þat whiche þat we wold haue
And in our͗ madnesse eủermor͗ we raue
And when̄ ben̄ to gyder eủerychon̄
Eủery man̄ semyth als wyse as salamon̄
But al thyng whiche þat semith as þe golde
Is not gold as I haf harde be tolde
Ne eủery appeƚƚ þat is fair͗ at eye
Ne is not goode what so men̄ clappe or crie
Riȝht so loo farith it amonge us
He þat semyth þe wyseste be Ihsesus
div.fw: Is moste foole when̄ it cometh to þe preefe
div.l: Is þe moste fole when̄ it cometh to þe preefe
And he þat semyth trewest he is a theefe
That schuƚƚ ȝe knowe er þat I from ȝowe wende
Be þat I of my tale haf made an ende
Ther is a chanoıı̄un of religioun
Amonges us wolde infecte al a town̄
Thogh it als grete wer as was nynyue /
Rome Alisaunder Troye and other thr͗e
His sleightes and his infinite falsenes
Ther couthe no man̄ writen̄ as I gesse
Þof þat he myȝht lyuen̄ a thousand ȝeer͗
In aƚƚ þis worlde of falsenes nys his per͗
For in his termes he wolde hym so wynde
And speke his wordes in so sliegh a kynde
When̄ he com̄e schaƚƚ with ony wyȝht
What he woƚƚ make hym dote onon ryȝht
But it þe feend be as his selfen̄ is
Fuƚƚ mony a man̄ hath he begiled er þis
And will ȝiff þat he may liff a while
And ȝit men̄ riden̄ and goon̄ full mony a myle
Hym for to seke and haue a queyntance
Not knowynge of þis fals gouernaunce
And ȝiff ye luste to ȝiff me audience
I woƚƚ it tellen̄ her͗ in ȝour͗ presence
But worschipfuƚƚ chanoıı̄un religiouse
Ne demeth not þat I sclaunder ȝour͗ house
Al þof my tale of a chanoıı̄un be
Of eủery ordr͗e som schrewe þ̉er is ꝑparde
And god forbede þat aƚƚ a companye
Shuld rewe oo singuler mannes folye
To sclaunder ȝowe is not myn̄ entente
But to correcten̄ þat mys I mente
This tale was not only tolde for ȝowe
But eke for oþ̉er mo ȝe wote wele howe
That amonges cristes apostells xij.
Ther ne was no traitour but iudas hym selfe
Than why schuld þe remenaunt aƚƚ haf blame
That giltles wer͗ be ȝowe seye I þe same
Saf only þis ȝif ȝe wiƚƚ herken̄ me
Ȝiff eny iudas in ȝour͗ conuent be
Remeveth hym be tyme I ȝowe rede
Ȝiff schame or losse may causen̄ eny drede
And beith no thyng displesed I ȝowe praye
But in þis caas herkenyth what I seye
¶ In lond þ̉er was a preste an anneler͗
That þ̉er in had dwelled mony a ȝer͗
Whiche was so plesaunte and so seruisable
Vn to þe wyffe wher͗ he was at table
That he wold suffren hym no thyng for to paye
For borde neþ̉er clothynge wente he neủer so gaye
And spendyng siluer had he riȝht ynogh
Ther of no force I woƚƚ ꝓprocede as nowe
And teƚƚ forth my tale of þe Chanoun
That brouȝht þis preste to ꝯconfusioıı̄un
This fals chanoıı̄un cam̄ opon̄ a daye
Vnto þe p̉restes chambr͗e þ̉er he laye
Besechyng hym to lene hym ac̉erteyn̄
Of gold ⁊and he wold quite it hym a gayn̄
Leneth me a marke qduod he but daies thr͗e
And at my day I woƚƚ it quite þe
And if so be þou fynde me fals
Another daye honge me be þe hals
This p̉reste hym toke a marke and þat als swythe
And þis Chanoıı̄un hym thanked ofte sithe
And toke his leue and wente forth his waye
And at þe thrid day broȝht his moneye
And to þis preste he toke þis gold a gayn̄
Ther of þis preste was gladde and fayn̄
Certes qduod he nothynge anoieth me
To lene a man̄ a noble or two or thr͗e
Or what thynge wer͗ in my possessioıı̄un
When̄ he so trewe is of condicioıı̄un
That in no wyse he wiƚƚ not breke his daye
To suche a man̄ I can̄ not say Naye .
What qduod þis Chanoıı̄un schold I be vntrewe
Nay þat wer thynge fallen̄ al of þe newe
Trewthe is a thynge þat woƚƚ I eủer kepe
Vn to þe day in whiche þat I schaƚƚ crepe
In to my graue and els god forbede
Beleeueth þis as siker as is ȝour͗ crede
God I thanke and in goode tyme be it saide
That þ̉er was neủer man̄ ȝit euyƚƚ apaiede
For golde ne silủer þat he to me lente
Ne neủer falshede in myn̄ herte I mente
And sir qduod he nowe of my pruyte
Seth ȝe so goodliche haf bene to me
And kithed to me so grete gentilnesse
Somwhat to quyten with ȝour͗ kyndnes
I woƚƚ ȝowe schewe and ȝif ȝowe liste to her͗
I schaƚƚ it schewe to ȝowe onon̄ riȝht here
Howe I can̄ worchen̄ in philosophie
Taketh gode heede ȝe schul seen̄ wel at eye
That I woƚƚ done a maistrye or I goo
Ȝa qduod þe preste ȝa sir͗ and woƚƚ ȝe soo
Marie þ̉er of I pray ȝowe hertly
At ȝour͗ ꝯcommaundemente sir trewly
Qduod þe Chanoıı̄un and els god forbede
Loo howe þis theefe couth his seruise bede
Fuƚƚ soith it is þat suche ꝓprofered seruice
Stynken̄ as witnesen̄ þis olde men̄ wyse
And þat fuƚƚ sone I will it verefye
In þis chanoıı̄un is rote of aƚƚ trecherye
That eủermor͗ delite hath ⁊and gladnesse
Such feendly thouȝhtꝭes in his herte emp̉resse
Howe cristꝭes peple he may to myschief brynge
God kepe us from his fals dissimilynge
¶ What wyste þis preste with whome þat he delte
Ne of his harme ꝯcommynge no thynge he felte
O sely preste o cely Innocente
With couetise onon̄ þou schalt be blente
O graceles fuƚƚ blynde is þi conceyte
No thynge art þou war͗ of þi deceyte
Whiche þat þis fox schapen̄ hath to þe
His wyly wrenches þou maiste not flye
Wher͗ forto go to þe conclusioun̄
That refferreth to þi confusioun̄
Vnhappy man̄ onōn I woƚƚ me hye
To tellen̄ þine vnwytte and þi folye
And eke þe falsnes of þat oþ̉er wrecche
As ferforth as my connynge woƚƚ strecche
This chanoıı̄un was my lorde ȝe wolde wene
Sir ofte in feith and by þe heuen̄ quene
It was a nother Chanoıı̄un and not he
Than can̄ an hundreth folde mor͗ sotilte
He hath betraied folke mony tyme
Of his falsnes it dulleth me to ryme
Eủer when̄ I speke of his falshede
For schame of hym my chekes wexen̄ rede
Algatꝭes þei be gynne for to glowe
For redenes haf I nowe riȝht wele y knowe
In my visage for fumes diuerse
Of metalls whiche ȝe han̄ harde me reherse
Consumed and wasted han̄ my rednesse
Nowe take hede of þis chanons cursednes
¶ Sir qduod he to þe p̉reste lat ȝour man̄ goon̄
And bryng quik silủer þat we it had onon̄
And lat hym brynge vnces two or thre
And when̄ he comyth als faste schull ȝe see
A wonder thynge whiche ȝe sawe neủer ar þis
Sir qduod þe prest it schaƚƚ be don̄ y wysse
He bad his seruᵃaunt fecchen̄ hym his thynge
And he al redy was at his biddynge
And wente hym forth and cam̄ onon agayn̄
With þis quyk silủer schortly for to seyn̄
And toke þise vnces thr͗e to þe chanoıı̄un
And he it leyde fair͗ and wele a doun̄
And bad þe seruᵃaunte coles for to brynge
That he onon̄ myȝht go to his worschynge
The coles riȝht onon̄ weren̄ fette
And þis chanoıı̄un toke oute a crosselette
Of his bosom̄ and shewed it to þe preste
This Instrument qduod he whiche þou seest
Take in þine honde and putte þi selfe þ̉er in
Of þis quyk silủer an vnce and her͗ begȳnne
In þe name of Criste to wex a philisophr͗e
Ther bene fuƚƚ fewe whiche þat I wolde ꝓprofer
To schewe hem þus mycheƚƚ of my science
For ȝe schuƚƚ sene her͗ be exꝑperience
That þis quyk siluer I wiƚƚ mortefie
Riȝht in ȝour siȝht onon̄ onon̄ with outen lye ·
And make it as good silủer and als fyne
As þ̉er is eny in ȝour purs or in myne
Or ells wher͗ and make it malliable
And els hold me fals and vnable
Amonges folke euer to aper͗
I haf a pouder her͗ it coste me riȝht der͗
Shaƚƚ make al goode for it is cause of aƚƚ
My cōnnynge which þat I ȝowe schewe schaƚƚ
Voideth ȝour͗ man and lat hym be þ̉er oute
And schitte þe dore whils we ben̄ a boute
Our͗ pⁱriuete þat no man̄ us aspie
Whils we werken̄ in þis philosophie
Al as he bad fuƚƚ filled was in dede
This ilke ʆseruᵃaunt onon̄ riȝht oute ȝede
And his maist̉er schet þe dor͗ onon̄
And to her͗ labour͗ spedily þei gone
This preste at þis cursed chanoıı̄uns biddynge
Vpon þe fir͗ onon̄ sette þis thynge
And blewe þe fir͗ and besyed hym fuƚƚ faste
And þis chanoıı̄un in to þis crosselet caste
A powder not I wher of þat it was
Y maad oþ̉er of chalke outher of glasse
Or somwhat els was not worth a flye
To blynd with þis preste and bad hym hye
The coles for to couchen̄ aƚƚ a boue
The crosselet for in þe token̄ þat I þe loue
Qduod þis Chanoıı̄un þine hondes twoo
Shull worche al thynge whiche as schaƚƚ be do
Graunt m̉ercy qduod þe preste and was fuƚƚ gladde
And couched coles as þe Chanoıı̄un badde
And whils he besy was þis feendly wrecche
This fals Chanoıı̄un þe foule fende hym fecche
Out of his bosom̄ toke a bechene cole
In whiche fuƚƚ softly was made an hole
And þ̉er in put was of silủer lymaiƚƚ
An vnce and stopped was with oute faiƚƚ
This hole with wex to kepe þe lymaiƚƚ in
And vndirstondeth þat þis fals gyn̄
Was not made þer but it was made befor
And other thynges I schaƚƚ teƚƚ mor͗
Ar he com̄ þer to begile hym he thouȝhte
Of thynges whiche þat he with hym brouȝht
And so he did ar þei wente atwynne
Tiƚƚ he had torned hym couthe he not blynne
It dulleth me when̄ þat I of hym speke
On his falsede fayn̄ wolde I me awreke
Ȝiff I wyste howe but he is her͗ and þer͗
He is so variant he bit nowher͗
Bot takith hede nowe sirres for goddis loue
He toke his cole of whiche I spake aboue
And in his honde he bar͗ it priuely
And whils þe preste couched besily
The coles as I tolde ȝowe er þis
This chanoıı̄un saide frende ȝe don̄ amys
This is not y couched as it ouȝht to be
But sone I schaƚƚ amende it qduod he
Now lat me medle þ̉er with but a while
For of ȝowe haf I pyte be seynt gyle
Ȝe ben̄ riȝht hote I see wele howe ȝe swete
Haue her͗ a clothe and wype a weye þe wete
And whils þe p̉reste hym wyped haas
This Chanoıı̄un toke his cole I schrewe his faas
And leide it opon a bofen̄ þe mydwarde
Of þe crosselet and blewe wele aftirwarde
Til þat þe coles gon̄ faste brenne
Nowe ȝiff us drynke qduod þe chanoıı̄un þenne
As swithe al schaƚƚ be wele I vndirtake
Sit we doun and let us mery make
And when̄ þe Chanons bechene cole
Was brent al þe lymaiƚƚ oute of þe hole
In to þe Crosselet onon̄ fiƚƚ a doun
And so it moste nedes be resoun
Sethens it so euen̄ a bouen̄ couched was
But þ̉er of wiste no thynge þe preest allas
He demede aƚƚ þe coles liche goode
For of þe sleiȝhte no thynge he vnderstode
And when̄ þis alkamystr͗e sawe his tyme
Riseth up sir preste and stondeth be me
And for I wote wele Ingot haf ȝe noon̄
Goth walketh forth and bryngeth a chalk stone
For I wiƚƚ make it of þe same schappe
Þat is a Ingot ȝiff þat I haf happe
And brynge with ȝowe a boƚƚ or a panne
Fuƚƚ of water and ȝe schuƚƚ se þan̄
Howe þat our͗ besynesse schaƚƚ happe and preue
And ȝit for ȝe schaƚƚ haue no mysbeleue
Ne wronge ꝯconceyt of me in ȝour͗ absence
I woƚƚ not bene oute of your p̉resence
But go with ȝowe and com̄ with ȝowe agayn̄
The chambr͗e dor͗ schortly for to seyn̄
Thei opened and schette and wente forth her waye
And forth with hem þei caried þe keye
And comen̄ a gayn̄ withouten̄ eny delay
What schuld I tarie aƚƚ þe longe daye
He toke þe chalke and schepe it in þe wyse
Of a Ingot as I schaƚƚ ȝowe deuyse
I seye he toke oute of his own̄ sleue
A chheyne of silủer euyƚƚ mot he cheve
Whiche þat was but an vnce of weiȝht
And taketh hede nowe of his cursed sleiȝht
He schepe his ingot in lenghte and in brede
Of þe cheyne with outen̄ eny brede
So slylye þat þe preste it not aspiede
And in his sleue a gayn̄ he gan̄ it hide
And from þe fir͗ toke up his mater͗
And in to þe ingot it putte with mery cher͗
And in to þe water vesseƚƚ he it caste
Whan̄ þat hym liste and bad þe preste as faste
Loke what þer is pit in þine honde and grope
Thou schalt fynde þer siluer as I hope
What deuyƚƚ of heƚƚ schulde it els be
Schafyng of silủer / syluer is parde
He putte in his honde and toke up a cheyn̄
Of siluer fyne / and glad in eủery veyne
Was þis preste / whan̄ he sawgh þat it was so
Goddꝭes blessynge and his moders also
And aƚƚ halowes haf ȝe sir chanoıı̄un
Seyde þe preste and I her malisoun
But and ȝe vouchesaue to techen̄ me
This noble crafte and þis sotelte
I woƚƚ be ȝour͗ in aƚƚ þat euer I maye
Qduod þe chanoıı̄un ȝit woƚƚ I make assaye
The seconde tyme þat ȝe mowe taken hede
And bene exꝑperte of þis and in ȝour͗ nede
Another daye in myn̄ absence
This disciplyne and þis crafty science
¶ Lat take a noþ̉er vnce qduod he þoo
Of quyk silủer with outen wordes moo
And do þ̉er wyth as ȝe han̄ don̄ er þis
With þat other whiche þat nowe silủer is
This preeste hym besieth in aƚƚ þat he can̄
To don̄ as þis chanoıı̄un þis cursed man̄
Comandeth hym and faste blewe þe fir͗
For to come to þe effecte of his desir͗
And þis chanoıı̄un riȝht in þe mene while
Aƚƚ redy was þis preste efte to begile
And for a ꝯcontenaunce in his honde he bar͗
An holugh stykke take hede and be war͗
In þe ende of whiche an vnce and no mor͗
Of silủer lymaiƚƚ put was aƚƚ befor͗
Was in his coole and stopped with wex wele
For to kepe in his lymaiƚƚ eủery dele
And whils þise preste was in his besines
This chanoıı̄un with his stykke gan̄ hym dresse
To hym onōn and his powder͗ caste in
As he did þ̉er þe deueƚƚ oute of his skynne
Hym torne I praye to god for his falshede
For he was eủer fals in othe and dede
And with his stykke a boue þe crosselette
That was ordeyned with þat fals gette
He sterith þe coles til relente gan̄
The wex agayn̄ the fuyr as eủery man̄
But he a foole be woote wele and mot nede
And al þat in þe hole was oute ȝede
And in to þe crosselet hastily it feƚƚ
The preest supposed no thynge but weƚƚ
But busyed hym faste and was wonder fayn̄
Supposyng noȝht but trowth / sothe to seyn̄
He was so gladde I can̄ not expresse
In no maner his mirthe and his gladnesse
And þe chanoıı̄un he ꝓprofered efte son̄
Body and goode ȝa qduod þe chanoıı̄un son̄
Thogh I be por͗ crafty þou schalt me fynde
I warne þe ȝit is þ̉er mor͗ be hynde
Is þ̉er eny copper her in seide he
Ȝa sir qduod þe preste I trowe þerbe
Ells go by som̄ and þat as swythe
Nowe sir go forth þi way and hythe
And wente his way and with þis coper he cam̄
And þis chanoıı̄un in his honde it nam̄
And of þat Coper weyed oute but an vnce
Al to symple is my tonge to pronıı̄unce
His moustre and his wytte þe doublenesse
Of þis chanoıı̄un rote and cursednesse
He semed frendly to hem þat knewe hym noȝt
But he was feendly both in werke and thoȝht
It werieth me to telle of his falsenesse
And nathelesse ȝit woll I it expresse
To þat entent þat men̄ may be war͗ þ̉er by
And for non̄ other cause trewly
He putte þis vnce of coper in to þe crosselete
And on þe fuyr als swythe he hath it sette
And keste in poudr͗e and made þe p̉reste to blowe
And in his worchynge for to stoupe lowe
As he did erste and aƚƚ nas but a Iape
Riȝht as hym liste þe preste he made his ape
And aft̉er warde in to þe Ingot he it caste
And in þe panne pute it at þe laste
Of water and in he putte his own̄ hande
And in his sleeue as ȝe beforne hande
Herde me teƚƚ he hadde a siluer cheyne
He slyly toke it oute þis cursed heyne
Vnwytynge þis p̉reste of his fals crafte
And in þe pannes bottom̄ he hath it lafte
And in þe water rombleth to and froo
And wonder priuely toke it up alsoo
The coper cheyne not knowyng þis preste
And hidde it and hente hym by þe breste
And to hym spake and þus seide in his game
Stoupeth a doun̄ be god ȝe ben̄ to blame
Helpeth me nowe as I did ȝowe whil er
Putte in ȝour͗ hande and loketh what is þ̉er
This p̉reste toke up þis siluer cheyn̄ onon̄
And þan saide þe chanoıı̄un lat us gone
With þise .iii. cheynes which þat we haf wroȝht
To som̄ goldsmyth and wyt if it be ouȝht
For be my faith I nold for myn̄ hoode
But ȝif þei wer͗ siluer fyne and goode
And þat as swithe proued schaƚƚ it be
Vnto þe goldsmyth with þise cheynes thr͗e
Thei wente and putte þise cheynes in assay
To fir͗ and hamer myȝht no man̄ say nay
But þei wer͗ as hem oght to be
This sotted preste who was gladder þan he
Was neủer bridde gladder aȝeyns þe daye
Ne nyȝhtyngale in þe sesoıı̄un of may
Was neủer none þat liste bett̉er to synge
Ne lady lustyer in carolynge
And for to speke of loue and womanhede
Ne knyght in armes to don̄ an hardy dede
To stondyn in grace of his lady der͗
Than hadde þis preste þis crafte to ler͗
And to þe Chanoıı̄un þus he spak and seide
For þe loue of god þat for us aƚƚ died
And as I may deʆserue it vn to ȝowe
What schaƚƚ þis Receyt coste telleth nowe
By our͗ lady qduod þe chanoıı̄un it is der͗
I warne ȝowe for saue I and a frer͗
In ynglonde þ̉er can̄ no man̄ it make
No fors qduod he nowe sir for goddis sake
What schaƚƚ I pay teƚƚ me I ȝowe praye
I wys qduod he it is fuƚƚ der͗ I seye
Sir at o worde ȝif þat ȝe liste it haue
Ȝe schuƚƚ pay fourty pounde so god me saue
And ne wer þe frend schip þat ȝe me did er þis
To me ȝe schuld paye mor͗ ywys
This preste þe sōmme of xl li and mor͗ onon̄
Of nobles fecched and toke hym eủerichon̄
To þis chanoıı̄un for þis ilke resseyte
Aƚƚ his wirchynge was fraude and deceyte
Sir p̉reste he seide I kept not haf no losse
Of my crafte for I wolde it wer kepte cloos
And as ȝe loueth me kepith it secree
For and men̄ knewe al my sotelte
By god men̄ wolde haf so grete envie
To me be cause of my philosophie
I scholld be dede þ̉er wer non̄ other weye
God it forbede qduod þe preste what ȝe seye
Ȝit had I leủer spenden̄ aƚƚ þe goode
Whiche þat I haue and els wex I wode
Than þat ȝe schuld fallen̄ in such myschefe
For ȝour͗ goode wiƚƚ sir haf ȝe riȝht good p̉reefe
Qduod þe chanoıı̄un Sir far͗ wele and grauntmercy
He went his waye and neủer þe p̉reste hȳm aft̉er seye
Aft̉er þat day and when̄ þat þis preste schulde
Maken̄ assay at swiche tyme as he wolde
Of þis receyt far͗ wele it wold not be
Lo þus beiaped and begiled was he
Thus maketh he his introduccioıı̄un
To bryngen folke to her͗ destruccioıı̄un
Considereth sirres howe þat in iche astate
Betwix men̄ and golde þer is debate
So ferforth þat vnnethes þ̉er is oone
This multiplyynge blyndeth so mony oon̄
That in goode faith I trowe þat it be
The cause gretteste of þis grete skarsete
Thise philisophres speken̄ so mystyly
In þis crafte þat men̄ kon̄ not com þ̉er by
For ony wytte þat men̄ hauen̄ nowe . o . dayes
Thei may wele chitren̄ and Ianglen̄ as don̄ þe Iayes
And in her termes sette luste and peyn̄
But to her͗ purpose schaƚƚ þei neủer atteyne
A man̄ may liȝhtliche lerne ȝif he haf ouȝht
To multiplye and brynge his goode to noȝht
Loo suche a lucr͗e is in þis lusty game
A manes myrthe it woƚƚ turne aƚƚ to grame
And empte also grete and heuy purses
And maken folke to purchasen̄ curses
Of hem þat han þ̉er to her͗ goode y lente
O fy for schame þei þat haue ben̄ brente
Allas can̄ þei not flye þe fyres hete
Ȝe þat it vsen̄ I reede ȝe it leete
Leest ȝe lese al for bett̉er þan neủer is late
Neủer to thrife wer to longe a date
Thoȝh ȝe proƚƚ ay ȝe schuƚƚ it neủer fynde
Ȝe bene as bolde as is bayȝarde þe blynde
That blundreth forth and ꝑperiƚƚ he non̄
He is as bolde to renne a gayn̄ a stone
As for to go besides in þe weye
So far͗ ȝe þat multiplie I seye
Ȝiff þat our͗ eyen̄ can̄ not seen̄ a riȝht
Lokith þat ȝoᵘur mynde lak not his siȝhte
For þof þe looke neủer so broode and star͗
Ȝe schull not wynne a myte in þat chaffar͗
But wasten̄ aƚƚ þat ȝe may rappe and renne
Withdrawe þe fir͗ leste it so faste brenne
Medleth no mor͗ with þat arte I mene
For ȝif þe done ȝour thrifte is gone ful clene
And riȝht as swithe I woƚƚ ȝowe teƚƚ her͗
What þat þe philisophres seyn̄ in þis mater͗
Lo þus seith arnolde of þe newe town̄
As his rosarie maketh mencioıı̄un
He seith ryȝht þus with outen̄ eny lye
Ther may no man̄ mercurye mortefye
But ȝif it be with his brothers knowleggyng
Howe þat he whiche þat firste saide þis thynge
Of philisophers fader was hermes
He saith howe þat þe dragoun douteles
Ne dyeth not but ȝif he be slayn̄
With his brother and þat is for to seyn̄
By þe dragoun mercurie and non̄ other
He vndirstode þat bremston̄ wer͗ his brother
That once of sol and luna wer y drawe
And þer for saide he take hede to my sawe
Lat no man̄ besye hym þis arte for to seeche
But he þat þe entencioıı̄un and speche
Of philisophres vndirstonde kan̄
And ȝiff he do he is a lewde man̄
For þis science and þis konnynge qduod he
Is of þe secree of secrees ꝑparde
Also þer was a disciple of plato
That on a tyme saide his maist̉er too
And his booke somer . wiƚƚ ber͗ wytnesse
And þis was his demaunde in sothefastnes
Tel me þe name of þe priue stone
And plato answerde to hym onon̄ .
Take þe stone þat tytanos men̄ name
Which is þat qduod he magnasia þe same
His disciple saide ȝa sir and is it þus
This is ignotūm ꝑper ignocius .
What is magnasia goode sir I praye
It is a water þat is made I seye
Of elementes four͗ qduod plato
Teƚƚ me þe roche goode sir qduod he þoo
Of þat water ȝif it be ȝour wiƚƚ
Nay nay qduod plato c̉erteyn̄ þat I nyƚƚ
The philisophers wer sworne echon̄
That þei schuld discoủer it to no mon̄
Ne in no boke it write in no maner͗
For vn to criste it is so leefe and der͗
That he wiƚƚ not þat it discouered be
But wher͗ it liketh to his deyte
Man̄ to enspir͗ and eke for to defende
Whome þat hym liketh lo þis is þe ende
Than ꝯconclude I þus sethen̄ þat god of heuen̄
Ne woƚƚ not þat þe philisophers neuen̄
Howe þat a man̄ schaƚƚ come vn to þis stone
I rede as for þe beste lat it gone
For who so makith god his aduersarie
As for to wirche eny thynge in contrarie
div.fw: ¶ Þe prologe of þe dottoᵘur of phisik
div.l: Vn to his wiƚƚ certes neủer schaƚƚ he thryue
Þof þat he multiplie þe terme of aƚƚ his lyffe
And þer a poynte for ended is my tale
God send eủery trewe man̄ bote of his bale
¶ Explicit
¶ Here begynneth þe prologe of þe doctour of phisik
When̄ þat þis ȝoman his tale ended hadde
Of þis fals chanon whiche þat was so badde
Our͗ ooste gan̄ seye trewly and certeyn̄
This preste was begiled sothely for to seyn̄
He wenynge for to be a philisophr͗e
Tiƚƚ he riȝht no golde lefte in his coffr͗e
And softely þis preste had a lither iape
This cursed chanoıı̄un put in his hode an ape
But al þis I oủer passe as nowe
Sir doctour of phisike I praye ȝowe
Teƚƚ us a tale of som̄ honeste mater͗
It schaƚƚ be done ȝif þat ȝe woƚƚ it her͗
Said þis doctour and his tale began̄ onon̄
Nowe goode men̄ qduod he herkeneth eủerychon̄
Ther was as tellith us Titus lyueus
A knyȝht þat cleped was virgineus
Fulfilled of honures and worthynesse
And stronge of frendes and of richesse
A doght̉er he hadde be his wyffe
And neủer hadde he mo in al his lyffe
Fair͗ was þis maide in excellente beaute
A bouen̄ eủery wyȝht þat men̄ may see
For natur͗ hath with souereyn̄ diligence
Formed hir͗ in so grete excellence
As þogh sche wolde saye lo I natur͗
Thus can̄ I forme and peynte a creatur͗
When̄ þat me liste who can̄ me countrefete
Pigmalyon̄ noȝt þof he alwey forge and bete
Or graue or peynte for I dar wele seyne
Apollus zephirus schold werche in veyne
To graue or peynte or forge or bete
Ȝiff þei p̉resumede me for to countrefete
For he þat is þe fourmour principaƚƚ
Hath made me his vicair͗ generaƚƚ
To forme and peynte eche ertly creatur͗
Riȝht as me liste for al thynge is in my cur͗
Vnder þe Mone þat may wane and wexe
And for my werke no thynge woƚƚ I axe
My lorde and I bene fully at acorde
I made hir͗ to þe worchipe of my lorde
So do I aƚƚ myn̄ other creatures
Of what coloure þei be or what figᵘures
Thus semyth me þat natur͗ wolde seye
This mayde was of age xij ȝer͗ and tweye
In whiche þat natur͗ hath suche delite
For riȝht as sche can̄ peynte as lilye white
And roddy as rose riȝht with suche peyntur͗
She paynted hathe þis noble creatur͗
Er sche was borne opon̄ hir͗ lymmes free
Wer also bryȝht as suche coloures schuld be
And phebus hadde dyed hir͗ trusses grete
Like to þe stremes of his bornyd heete
And ȝiff þat excellent was hir͗ beaute
A thousand folde more vertuos was sche
In hir͗ ne lakkith no condicioıı̄un
That is to preise as by discrecioıı̄un
As wele in body as goiste chaste was sche
For whiche sche floured in virginite
With al humilite and abstinence
With al attemꝑperance and pacience
With mesur͗ eke and berynge of araye
Discrete sche was in answerynge al way
Thogh sche wer wyse as pallays dar͗ I seyn̄
Hir͗ fawcond eke fuƚƚ wom̄manly and pleyn̄
None coıı̄untr͗efeted termes had sche
To seme wyse but aft̉er hir͗ degree
She spake and aƚƚ hir͗ wordes mor͗ and lesse
Sownynge wer͗ in vertue and in gentilnesse
Schamefaste sche was and maydens schamefastnes
Constant in herte and eủer in besynesse
To dryve hir͗ oute of hir͗ slogardrye
Bachus had of hir͗ mouthe no maistrye
For wiƚƚ and thoȝht done venus encrese
As men̄ in fir͗ woƚƚ casten̄ oyƚƚ or grece
And of hir͗ own̄ vertue vnconstreynede
She hath fuƚƚ oftyme hir͗ seyk y feynede
For þat sche wolde flye þe companye
Wher͗ likly was to treten̄ of folye
As is at festes Reuels and at daunces
That bene occasioıı̄uns of daliaunces
Suche thynges maken̄ children for to be
To sone rype and bolde as men̄ may see
Whiche is fuƚƚ ꝑperlious and hath bene ȝor͗e
For al to sone may sche lerne lore
Of boldenesse when̄ sche is a wyffe
And ȝe maistres in ȝour͗ olde lyffe
That lordes doughtres han̄ in goủernaunce
Ne taketh of my worde no displesaunce
Thynges þat bene sette in gouernynges
Of lordꝭes douȝhtres only for two thynges
Outher for ȝe han̄ kepte ȝour͗ honeste
Oþ̉er els ȝe han fallen̄ in freelte
And knowen̄ welynogh þe olde daunce
And kon̄ forsake fully meschaunce
For eủer mo þ̉erfor for cristes sake
Kepith wele þo þat ȝe vndirtake
A theef of venysoıı̄un þat hath forlafte
His lykorosnes and aƚƚ his thefꝭes crafte
Kan̄ kepe a foreste beste of eny man̄
Nowe kepith hem wele for and ȝe woƚƚ ȝe kan̄
Loketh wele to no vice þat ȝe assente
Leste ȝe be dampned for ȝour͗ euyƚƚ entente
For who so doith a traitour is c̉erteyn̄
And taketh of þat þat I schaƚƚ seyne
Off aƚƚ tresoun̄ suffreyn̄ pestilence .
Is when̄ a wyȝht betraieth Innocence
Ȝe fadres and ȝe modres eke also
Þof ȝe haf children̄ be it one or moo
Ȝour is þe charche of aƚƚ her͗ suffraunce
Whils þei bene vnder goủernance
Beth war͗ þat be ensample of ȝoᵘur liffynge
Outher be necligence in chastisynge
That þei ne ꝑperysshe for I dar wel seye
Ȝiff þat þei done ȝe schuƚƚ fuƚƚ sor͗ abye
Vnder a schepard softe and necligente
The wolff hath mony a schepe and lambe to rente
Suffiseth one ensample nowe as her͗
For I mot turne aȝeyn̄ to my mater͗
¶ This mayde of whiche I teƚƚ my tale exp̉resse
She kepte hir͗ selfe hir͗ neded no maistresse
For in hir͗ lyffynge maydens myȝht rede
As in a booke eủery goode worde and dede
That longeth to a maide vertuos
She was so prudent and so bountyvous
For whiche oute spronge on ẻerry syde
Both of hir͗ beaute and of hir͗ bounte wyde
That thurgh þe londe þei preised her echon̄
That loued vertues saue envye allone
That sory is of oþ̉er mēnnys wele
And glad is of iche sorowe and vnhele
The doctour maketh þis descripcioıı̄un
This maide on a day in to þe toun̄
¶ Towarde þe temple with hir͗ moder der͗
As is of ȝonge maydens þe maner͗
Nowe was þer a Iustise in þe town̄
That goủernour was of þat regioun̄
And so befeƚƚ þis Iugge his eyen̄ caste
Vpon þis maide avisynge hir͗ fuƚƚ faste
As sche come forth by þer þe Iugge stoode
Onon his herte chaunched and his mode
So was he kauȝht with beaute of þis maide
And to hym selfe fuƚƚ priuely he seide
This maide schaƚƚ be myn̄ for eny man̄
Onone þe feende in to his herte ranne
And tauȝht hym sodenly be what sleiȝhte
The maide to his purpose wynne he myȝhte
For certes be no force ne by no mede
Hym thouȝht he was not able for to spede
For he was stronge of frendes and eke sche
Confermed was in suche souereyn̄ beaute
That wele he wiste he myȝht hir͗ neủer wynne
As for to make hir͗ with hir͗ body synne
For whiche with grete deliberacioıı̄un
He sente aft̉er a clerke in to þe toun̄
The whiche he knewe for subtile and for bolde
This Iugge vn to þis clerke his tale hath tolde
In secre wise and made hym to assure
He schuld teƚƚ it to no creatur͗e
And ȝif he did he schuld lese his heede
Whan̄ assentid was þis cursed rede
Glad was þe Iuge and made glad cher͗
And ȝaf hym ȝiftes p̉recious and der͗
When schapen was al þis conspiracye
From poynt to poynt howe þat his leccherye
ꝐParfourmed schuld be fuƚƚ sotelly
As ȝe schaƚƚ her͗ aft̉erwarde openly
Home goith þis clerke þat hiȝht Claudius
This fals Iugge þat hiȝht Apius
So was his name for it is no fable
But knowen̄ for an historiaƚƚ thynge notable
The sentence of it sothe is oute of doute
This fals Iugge goith nowe faste aboute
To hasten̄ his delite al þat he may
And so be feƚƚ sone aft̉er on a daye
¶ This fals Iugge as tellith us þe storie
As he was wonte / sat in his consistorie
And ȝaff his domes opon sundry caases
This fals clerke com forthe a wel good pase
And seid lorde ȝif it be ȝour wiƚƚ
As doith me riȝht opon̄ þis pitous byƚƚ
In whiche I pleyne opon̄ virginyus
And ȝif it be wele seyn̄ it is not þus
I woƚƚ proue it and fynde goode wytnes
That soth it is þat my biƚƚ woƚƚ expresse
The Iugge answered of þis in his absence
I may not ȝiff diffinitiue sentence
Lat done hym / calle and I woƚƚ gladly her͗
Thou schalt haue riȝht and no wronge her͗
Virginyus come to wite þe Iugges wiƚƚ
And riȝht onon was radde þis cursede biƚƚ
¶ The sentence of it was as ȝe schuƚƚ her͗
To ȝowe my lorde sir Apius so der͗
Sheweth ȝour pour seruᵃaunt claudius
Howe þat a knyȝht Called Virginyus
Aȝeins þe lawe a ȝeins aƚƚ equitee
Holdeth expresse a ȝeins þe wiƚƚ of me
My seruᵃaunte whiche þat is thraƚƚ be riȝht
Whiche from myn house was stollen̄ on a nyȝht
Whils ȝhe was fuƚƚ ȝonge I woƚƚ it preue
Be witnesse lorde so þat ȝe ȝowe not greue
She is not his doughter what so he seye
Wher for my lorde þe Iugge to ȝowe I praye
Ȝelde me my thraƚƚ ȝif it be ȝour wiƚƚ
Loo þis was aƚƚ þe sentence of his bylle
Virginyus gan̄ opon̄ þe clerke beholde
But hastely er he his tale tolde
He wolde haf defended it as schuld a knyȝht
And by wytnesse of mony a trewe wyȝht
That aƚƚ was fals þat saide his Aduersarie
This cursede Iugge wolde no leng̉er tarie
Ne her͗ a worde mor͗ of Virgineus
But ȝaff his Iuggement and seide þus
I deme onon̄ þis clerke his seruᵃaunte hafe
Thou schalt no leng̉er in þine house hir͗ saue
Go brynge her forth and put hir͗ in our͗ warde
This clerke schaƚƚ haf his thraƚƚ þus I awarde
And when̄ þis worthy knygth virgineus
Thurgh þe assente of þe Iugge Apius
Moste beforce his dere doughter ȝiffen̄
Vnto þe Iugge in leccherye to lyffen̄
He goith hym home and sette hym in his haƚƚlle
And lete onon his der͗ douȝht̉er calle
And with a face dede as asshen̄ colde
Vpon hir͗ humble face he gan̄ beholde
div.fw: With faders pite stykkyng thurgh his herte
div.l: Wyth Faders pyte stykkynge thurgh his herte
Al wolde he not from his purpose conuerte
Douȝht̉er qduod he Virginea be þi name
Ther bene twoo weyes outher deth or schame
That þou moste suffr͗e allas þat I was bore
For neủer þou deseruedeste wharfore
To dyen̄ with a swerde or with a knyffe
O dere douȝht̉er ender of my lyffe
Whiche I haf fostred up with suche plesance
That þou ne wer͗ oute of my remembraunce
O douȝht̉er whiche þat arte my laste woo
And in liffe my laste ioye also
O gēmme of chastite in pacience
Take þou þi deeth for þis is my sentence
For loue and nat for hate þou moste be dede
My pitous honde mot smyten̄ of þine hede
Allas þat eủer Apius þe saye
Thus hathe he iugged þe to daye
And tolde hir͗ aƚƚ þe caas as ȝe be fore
Han herde it nedeth not to teƚƚ it more
Mercy der͗ fader qduod þis mayde
And with þat worde sche bothe hir͗ armes layde
A boute his nekke as sche was wonte to doo
The terys brasten̄ oute of her eyen twoo
And seide goode fader schaƚƚ I dye
Is þ̉er no grace is þer no remedye
No certꝭes der͗ dought̉er myn̄ qduod he
Thanne ȝiff me leue fader myn̄ qduod sche
My deth to compleyn̄ a litiƚƚ space
For ꝑparde Ieffa ȝaf his douȝht̉er grace
For to compleyn̄ ar he hir͗ slowgh allas
And god it wote no thynge was hir͗ trespas
But þat sche ranne hir͗ fader firste to see
To wel com̄ hym with grete solempnitee
And with þat worde sche fiƚƚ on swown̄ onon̄
And aft̉er whan̄ her swownynge was gone
She riseth up and to hir͗ fader saide
Blessed be god þat I schaƚƚ dye amaide
Ȝiff me my deth er þat I haf a schame
Doith with ȝour childe ȝour͗ wiƚƚ on goddis name
And with þat worde sche praied ful ofte
That with his swerde he schuld smyteher softe
And with þat word on swown̄ doun sche feƚƚ
Hir͗ fader with fuƚƚ sorowfuƚƚ herte and feƚƚ
Hir͗ hede of smote and by þe top it hente
And to þe Iugge he ȝaf it to presente
As he satte in his dome in consistorie
When̄ þe Iugge it sawe as seith þe storie
He bad take hym and honge hym also faste
But riȝht onon al þe peple in thraste
To saue þe knyȝht for reuthe and for pitee
For knowen̄ was þis foles iniquite
The peple onon̄ had suspecioıı̄un in þis thynge
By maner of þis Clerkꝭes chalangynge
That it was by þe assente of Apius
Thei wiste wele þat he was leccherous
For whiche vn to þis Apius þei gone
And kesten̄ hym in prisoıı̄un riȝht onone
Wher͗ as he slowgh hym selfe and claudius
That seruᵃaunt was vn to þis Apius
Was demed for to honge opon a tree
But Virgineus of his grete pite
Praied for hym þat he was exiled
And els Certꝭes he had bene begiled
The remenᵃaunt wer honged mor͗ and lesse
That consented wer͗ to his cursednes
Her͗ may men̄ see howe synne hath his merite
Be ware for no man̄ wote howe god woƚƚ smyte
In no degr͗e ne in whiche man̉er wise
The worme of conscience woƚƚ arise
Of wikked liffe þof it so prevy be
That no man̄ wot of it but god and he
Whedir he be lewed man̄ or lerned
He not howe sone þat he may bene a fered
Therfore I rede ȝowe þis counseƚƚ for to take
Forsakith synne er synne ȝowe forsake
¶ Here begynneth þe prologe of þe pardoner
Oure ooste gan̄ swer͗ as he wer͗ woode
Harrowe qduod he by naylles and by blode
This was a fals cherle and a fals iustise
Als schamefuƚƚ deth as tonge kan̄ devise

Home vn to myn house or ells to ȝoures
For wele I wote þat all þis golde is oures
Then wer we in hiegh felicite
But trewly be day it may not be
Men wolde seyn þat we weren thefis stronge

This tresour moste ben y caried be nyȝht

O lorde qd he ȝiff it so wer I myȝht
Haue al þis tresour to my selfe allone
Ther is no man þat liffeth vndir trone

And at þe laste þe fende our enmye
Put in his thouȝht þat he schuld bye poyson

For why þe fende fonde hym in suche lyffynge

For þis was outrely his entente

And forth he goith no lenger wolde he tarie

Som poisen þat he myȝht his rattes kyll
And eke þer was a polcat in his hawe

And seide he wolde wreke hym ȝif he myȝht
Of vermyn þat destroied hym be nyȝht
The potykarie answered þou schalte haue
A thynge þat as god my soule saue
In all þis worlde þernys no creatur

Noȝht but þe mounteyns of a corne of whete
That he ne schall his liffe onon for lete
Ȝa . sterue he schall and þat in lasse while

This poyson þat is so herde and violente
This cursed man hath in his honde it hente
This poisen in a box and sethens he ranne
In to þe nexte strete vn to a man
And borowed hym large botells thr
To his felowes onon repaireth he
What nedith it to sermon þer of mor
For riȝht as þei had caste his dethe befor
Riȝht so þei hauen hym slayn and þat onon
Nowe lat us sitte and drynke and make us merye
And aft̉erwarde we wolen his bodye berye
And aft̉er þat it happed hem ꝑpar cas
To taken a botell wher in þe poisen was
And dranke and ȝaf his felowe drynke also
Thurgh whiche onon þei sterueden both twoo
But certes I suppose þat avisen
Wrote neủer in no canon ne in no fen
Mo wonder sorowes of enpoysenynge
Then hadde þise wrecches two at her endynge
Thus ended bene þise homicides two
And eke þis fals enpoysoner also
O cursed synne full of all cursednes
O traitours homicides o wykkednes
O glotonye luxurie and hasardrye
Thou blasfemour of Criste with vilanye

Allas man kynde howe may it be tide
That to þi creatour whiche þat þe wroȝht

Nowe goode men godde forȝiff ȝowe ȝo trespasse

Myn holy ꝑpardoun may ȝowe alle waryssh

Bowith ȝowr hede vndir þis bull

Ȝour names I entr her in my Roll onon
In to þe blisse of heuen schull ȝe al gone
I ȝowe assoile be myn hie power
Ȝe þat wollen as clene and eke als cler
As ȝe weren borne and lo sirres þus I pche
And ihu Criste þat is our soules leche
So graunte ȝowe his ꝑpardoun to resseyue

Bot sirres o worde forgat I in my tale
I haf relikes and ꝑpardoıı̄un in my male

Whiche wer ȝiffe to me by þe popes honde
Ȝiff eny of ȝowe will of deuocion

That ȝe may haf ꝑparte of my ꝑpardoun

So þat ȝe offren alwey newe and newe

It is an honour to eủerichon þat bene her
That ȝe may haf a suffisaunt ꝑpardoner

For auentures whiche þat may betide
For ꝑparauentur þer may fall one or twoo

Loke whiche a surtee it is to ȝowe all

When þat þe soule schall fro þe body passe

Ȝa for a grote vnbokell onone þi porse
Nay nay qd he þan haf I cristes curse

div.l: In stede of Relikes or saynt warie
Lete cutte hem of and I woll hem helpe to carie

This ꝑpardoner answered not a worde

Nowe qd our ooste I woll no lenger playe
With þe ne with none other angry manne

Whan þat he sawgh þat al þe peple lough

¶ Here endeth þe ꝑpardoners tale .
¶ Here begynneth the prologe of sir thopace ;
Whan saide was þis tale eủery man

And þan at erste he loked opon me

¶ Approche þan and loke meryly
Nowe war ȝowe sirres and lat ȝour men haf place

¶ Say nowe somwhat sethens oþ̉er folke han seide

Ȝa þat is goode ꝙquod he schull we here

Here begynneth þe tale of Chaucer be sir thopas

And I woll tell varraimente

Of a knyȝht was fair and gente
In bataille and in tornamente
His name was sir thopas
Y borne he was in ferr cuntr
In flaundres alle be ȝonde þe see
At poperynge in þe prelace
His fader was a man full free
And lorde he was of þat cuntr
As it was goddes grace
Sir thopas was a doughty swayn
White was his face as payndemayn
His lippes rede as roose
His rodde y like skarlet in grayn
And I ȝowe tell in goode certeyn
He had a semely nose
His her his berde was like saffron
That to his girdell kauȝt a doun
His schone of Cordwayne

His robe was of Ciclatoun

He couthe hunte at þe wilde der

Ther eny man schulde stonde
Full mony a maide bryȝht in lour
Thei morne for him ꝑparamour
Whan þei wer better to slepe
But he was chaste and no lecchour
And swete as is þe bremble flour
That bereth þe rede heppe
And so byfell opon a daye
For sothe as I ȝowe tell may
Sir thopas wold oute ride
He worthe up on his stede greye
And in his honde a launcegay
A longe swerde be his side
He priketh thurgh a fair foreste

And when he harde þe throstell synge

His fair stede in his prikkynge
So swette þat men miȝht hym wrynge
His sides wer al blode
Sir thopas eke so wery was
For prikkynge on þe softe gras
So fers was his corage

For he was so sauage
O seynt Marie benedicite
What ayleth þis loue at me

in toun

And to an elf quene I me take

In to his sadell he come onone

Þe cuntr of farye
¶ So wilde .
For in þat cuntr nas þ̉er none
Neþ̉er wyffe ne childe
Till hym þ̉er come a Ioly geaunt
His name was cleped ʆsir olifaunt
A ꝑparlious man of dede

¶ With mace
Here is þe quene of fairye

Dwellynge in þis place
The childe saide so mot I the

When I haf myn Armour
And ȝit I hope ꝑparma faye

¶ Thurgh þi mawe
Shall I perce ȝif I may
Or it be fully prime of þe daye
For her þou schalt be slawe
Sir thopas drewgh o bak ful faste
This geaunt at hym stones caste
Out of a fell staff slynge
But fair escapeth childe thopas
And al it was thurgh goddis grace
And thurgh his faire berynge
Ȝit listneth lordes to my tale
Murier þan þe nyȝhtyngale
For nowe I woll ȝowe rowne
Howe ʆsir thopas with sides smale
Prikkyng ouer doune and dale
Is come a ȝeyn to town
His mery men 9mandede he

For nedes moste he fyȝht
With one geaut with hedes thr /
For ꝑparamour and Iolite

Anon in myn armynge

And eke of loue likynge

And þ̉er in was a bores hede

Howe þat þe geaunte schall be dede
Betide what betyde
His Iaumbeure wer of quirbole

His helme of laton bryȝht
His sadell was of rowell bone

¶ In londe
Lo lordes myn her is a fytte
If ȝe will eny mor of it

Nowe hold ȝour mouthe for charite

Onon I will ȝowe tell

But ʆsir thopas he berith þe flour

His goode stede he bistrode

And for he was a knyȝht aunterous

¶ The prologe of Mellibe
No mor of þis for goddis dignite

Nowe suche a ryme þe deuyll I beteche

Þi drasty rymynge nys not worth a torde

Ther for lordynges al I ȝowe beseche
Ȝiff þat ȝe thenke I arye as in my speche
As þus þof þat I tell somwhat mor

And þof I not þe same wordes saye
As ȝe han herde ȝit to ȝowe all I praye
Blameth me not for in my sentence
Shull ȝe no wher fynden difference
Fro þe sentence of þis tretys lyte
Aft̉er þe whiche þis mery tale I wryte
And þer for herkeneth what I schall seye
And lat me tell all my tale I praye
