¶ And
þer for our der and benigne lady We preyen ȝowe ande be-
sechen ȝowe als mekely as we conne or mowe

þat if it
like vn to ȝour grete goodnes to fulfille in dede ȝoᵘur goodly
wordes

For we consideren and knowen þat we han offen-
ded and greved my lorde Meleby oute of mesur /

so fer-
forth þat we ben not of power to maken his amendes

And þ̉er for we oblige and bynde us and our frendes for to
don all his will and his 9maundemente

But ꝑparauenture
he hath suche heuynesse and suche wrethe to us ward
be cause of our defense

þat he will enioyne us suche
peyne as we may not ber and sustene

¶ And þ̉erfore noble
lady we be seke to ȝour wōmmanly pite

taketh suche avisemet
in þis nede þat we ne our frendes be not disherited ne destro-
ied thurgh our folie

¶ Certis qd prudence It is an harde
thynge and riȝht ꝑparlyous

þat a man putte hym al vttrely īn
þe arbitracion and iuggement and in þe myȝht and power
of his enmyes

¶ For salomon seith Troweth and ȝiffeth cre-
dence to þat I schall seyne ¶ I say qd he ȝiff peple and go-
uernours of holy chirche

to þi son to þi wiffe and þi frende
Ne to þi brother

ȝiff þou neủer myȝht ne maistrye of thy
body whil þou lyffeste

¶ Nowe seth þat he forfendeth
þat a man schulde not ȝiff to his brother ne to his frende
þe myȝht of his bodye

Than be a strenger reson he forfen-
dith and forbedith a man to ȝiff hym selfe vn to his enmye

¶ And nathelesse I counseill ȝowe þat ȝe mystruste not my
lorde

For I wote wele and knowe verrely þat he is debonayre
and meke large and curtas

And nothyng desirous ne coue-
tous of goode ne riches

For þ̉er nys no thynge in þis worlde
þat he desireth saue only worschipe and honour

¶ Forþ̉ermor
I knowe wele and I am riȝht swr þat he will no thynge
doo in þis nede with oute þe counseill of me

and I schall
so worche in þis cause þat by þe grace of our lorde godde
ȝe schull be recounsiled vn to us

Than seide þei with oon
voice Worschipfull lady we putten us and our goodes all
fully in ȝoᵘur will and in ȝour disposicion

and bene redy for to
come what day þat it liketh vn to ȝour noblenesse to lymite
us

for to make our obligacion and to be bounde als stronge
as it like vn to ȝour goodnes

þat we may fulfille þe will
of ȝowe and of my lorde Meleby

¶ And when dame
prudence hadde þe answer of þise men sche badde hem
gone a ȝeyn pⁱriuely

and sche retourned to hir lorde Meleby
and tolde hym howe sche fonde his adủersaires ful repēn-
taunt

knowlecchynge full lowly her synnes and trespases
and howe þei weren redy to suffren all peyn

requirynge
and preynge hym of mercy and pite

¶ Than sawe melo-
by þat he is wel worthy to haue ꝑpardon and forȝifnesse
of his synne þat excuseth not his synne

but knowlecheth
and repenteth hym askynge indulgence

¶ For senek seith
Ther is þe remission and forȝifnes wher as þᵉ 9fession
is
For confession is neiȝhbor to innocence

¶ And he
seith in an other place / þat he þat hath schame of his
synne and knowleccheth it he is worthy remissioun
and þ̉er for I assente and conferme me to haf pees

But
it is goode þat we do it not with outen þe assent of
our frendes

¶ Than was Prudence riȝht gladde
and ioyfull and seide þus

Certꝭes sir ꝙquod sche ȝe han wele
and goodly answerede

For riȝht as by þe counsell of assent
and helpe of ȝour frendes ȝe haf bene stirred to venchen
ȝowe and make werr

Riȝht so with outen her counseille
schall ȝe not acorde ȝowe ne haue pees with ȝoᵘur adủersai-
es

¶ For þe lawe seith Ther nys no thynge so goode by
weye of kynde as thynge to bene vnbownde by hym þat
was y bounde

¶ And þan Dame prudence / with outen
delaye or taryynge sent onon messangers for her kynne and
for her olde frendes whiche þat wer trewe and wyse

and
tolde hem by ordr in þe psence of Meleby all þis mater
as it is aboue expssede and declared

and praied hem ~
þat þei wolde ȝiffen her avice and counseill what wer
beste to don in þis nede

¶ ANd when Mellibes frendꝭes
hadde taken þ̉er avise and deliberacion of þis forsaide ma-
ter

and hadden examined it by grete besynes and grete
diligence

þei ȝaff hym þan full counseill for to hauen
pees and reste

and þat Melobius schulde resseyue with
goode herte his adủersaries to forȝifnes and mercy

¶ And
whan Dame prudence had herde þe assent of her lorde
Melobius / and þe counseill of his frendes

accorded with
hir will and hir entencion

sche was wonderly glad in her
herte and seide

Ther is an olde proủerbe qd sche þat seith
þat þe goodnes þat þou maiste don þis daye do it

ande .
abide not till þe morowe

And þ̉er for I counseill ȝowe þat
ȝe sende ȝour messangers whiche þat bene discrete and
wise
vn to ȝour aduersares Tellynge hym in ȝoᵘur behalfe
þat if þei will gete of pees and acorde

þat þei schapen
hem with outen delay or taryynge to come vn to us

The
which thynge was ꝐParfourmede in dede

And when þise
trespassours and repentynge folke of her folyes þat is to
seye þe aduersaries of Melobye

hadden herde what þe
Messangers saiden to hem

þei wer riȝht gladde ande
Ioifull and answerden full mekely and benyngly

ȝel-
dynge graces and thonkes to her lorde Meleby and to al
his companye

and schopen hem with outen delay to go wᵗith
messangers and obeye to þe 9maundemente of her lorde
Melobius /

¶ And riȝht onon þei token her waye to þᵉ courte
of Meloby

And token with hem som of her trewe frendes
to maken feith for hem and for to bene her borowes

¶
And when þei weren com to þe psence of Melebius He
seide hem þise wordes

It stondeth þus qd Melobye . and
sothe it is þat ȝe

causeles and with outen skill and
resoun

haf don grete iniuries and wronges to me ande
to my wyffe Prudence and to my douȝhter also

For
ȝe han entred in to myn house by violence

and haf don
suche outrage þat al men knowe wele þat ȝe han deserued
deeth
And þ̉er for will I knowe and witte of ȝowe

wheder
ȝe putte þe punyssmente and þe chastisement and þe venche-
aunce of þis outrage in þe will of me and of my wyffe
Dame Prudence or ȝe will not

¶ Than þe wisest of he thr
answered for hem all and seide

Sir qd he we knowe wele
þat we bene vnworthy to come vnto so grete and worthy
as is bene

For we han so gretly mystaken us and haff
offended and gulted in suche a wise a gayn ȝour hieghe
lordeschipe
þat trewly we han deserued þe deth

But ȝit
for þe grete goodnes ande debonairte þat all men don wit-
nesse of ȝour ꝑpersone

we submitten us to ȝour excellence ⁊and
benignite of ȝour gracious lordschipe

For we ben redy to obey
to all ȝour 9maundementes

Besekynge ȝowe þat of ȝour
merciable pite ȝe will 9sider our grete repentaunce and
lowe submission

and graunt us forȝifnes of our outrage tres-
pas and offence

For wele we knowen þat ȝour liberall
grace and mercy streccheth forther in to goodnes þen doith
our outracheous trespas and offence in to wikkednesse

Al be it so þat cursedly and dampnably we han trespased
aȝeins ȝour grete lordeschipe

¶ Than Melobye toke hēm
up fro þe grounde full benignely

and resseyued her obla-
ciouns and her londes by her othes opon hir plegges and
borowes .

And assigned hem a c̉erteyn daye to retourne vn to
his courte

for to accepte and to resseyue þe sentence ⁊and
þe Iuggemente þat Meloby will 9maunde to be don
to hem be þise causes a forseide

whiche thyngꝭes so y ordeyned
eủery man retourned home to his house

¶ And when þat
dame prudence seigh her tyme sche feyned and askede
her lorde

what vencheānce he thouȝht to take on his adủer-
saries

To þe whiche Melobius answerde and seide Certꝭes
I thenke and purpose me fully

to disherite þem and al þᵗat
eủer þei haue and for to putte þam in exill for euer more

¶ Certis qd Dame prudence / þis were a crwell sentēnce
and michell a ȝeinste resoun

For ȝe bene riche ynogh
and haue non nede of other mēnys goode

Ande ȝe
myȝhten liȝhtly geten ȝowe a couetous name

whiche is a
vicious thynge and ouȝhte to bene eschewede of euery
man

¶ For aft̉er þe worde of þe apostell Couetise is
þe rote of all synnes and harmes

And þer for it wer
better to ȝowe to lese so muchell goode of ȝoure own
þan for to take of her goode in þis maner

For bett̉er it is
to lese goode with worschipe þen it is to lese goode wᵗith
vileny ande schame

And eủery man ouȝht to don his
diligence of his besynesse to getēn hym a goode name

And ȝit schall he not oonly besyen hym in kepynge of his
goode name

But he schall also enforsen hym al weye
to don som thynge by þe whiche he may renouell his goode
name

¶ For it is writen / ¶ The olde goode loose or þe
goode name of a man is sone done or gone or passed whēn
it is not y newed ne renouellede

¶ And as touchynge
þat ȝe seyn ȝe will exile ȝour aduersaries /

þat thynketh
me moche a ȝeyn resoun and oute of mesur

considered þe
power þat þei hauen ȝiffen ȝowe opon hem selfe

¶ And
it is writen / þat he is worthy to lesen his puilege þᵗat mys-
vseth þe myȝht ande þe power þat is ȝiffen hym

And I sette
caas ȝe myȝht enioyne hem þat peyne be riȝht and lawe
whiche I ȝe mowe not don

I say ȝe myȝht not putte it in
execution ꝑparauentur

And þan wer it likly to retourne to þe
werre as it was beforne

Ande þer for ȝif ȝe þan woll .
þat men done ȝowe obeisaunce ȝe moste demen mor cur-
taslye

This is to seyne ȝowe moste ȝiff mor esye sentence
and Iuggementꝭes

¶ For it is writen þat he þat moste cur-
tasly 9maundeth to hym men moste obeyeth

And þerfor
I preye ȝowe þat in þis necēssite and in þis nede ȝe kaste
ȝowe to oủercome ȝour herte

¶ For seneke saith he þat
ouercōmyth his herte he oủercōmyth twyes

And Tullius
seith Ther nys no thynge so 9mendable in a grete lorde .

As when he is debonair and meke and apaiseth hy selfe
liȝhtly

And I preye ȝowe þat ȝe will forber nowe to don
vencheaunce

in suche a maner þat ȝour goode name may
be kepte and 9seruede

and þat men mowe hauen a cause
and mater to preise ȝowe of pite and of mercy

and þat
ȝe haue no cause to repente ȝowe of thynge þat ȝe done

For senek seith He ouercōmeth in all euyll man þat repetith
hym of his victorie

Wherfor I preye ȝowe lat mercy be in ȝoᵘur
herte

to þe effecte and þe entente þat god almyȝhty haf mcy
on ȝowe in his laste iugemente

¶ For seynt Iames seith
in his pistell Iuggement with outen mcy schall be don
to hym þat hath no mercy on a noþ̉er wiȝht

¶ When Melobi9
had herde þe grete skilles and prudente resouns of Dame
Prudence and her wise enformacion and techynge /

his hert
gan to encline to þe will of his wyffe considerynge her
trewe entente

And 9fourmed hym onon and 9tened fully
to worchen Aft̉er her counseill

And thonked god of whome
ꝓprocedith al goodnes þat hym sente a wiffe of so grete dis-
crecion

Ande when þe day come þat his aduersaries schuld
aperen in his psence

he spake to hem full goodly and seide
in þis wise

Al be it so þat of ȝour pride and hiegh pre-
sumpcion and folye and of ȝour necligence

ȝe han euyll
¶ Þe prologe of þe maunciple
mysborne ȝowe and trespassed vn to me

ȝit for als miche
as I se and beholde ȝoure grete humilite

And þat ȝe bene
sorye and repentaunte of ȝour͗e giltes

It constreyneth me
for to don̄ ȝowe grace and mercy

And þerfor I resseyue ȝowe
to my grace and mercy

and forȝiff ȝowe vtterly all þe offen
ses Iniuries and wronges þat ȝe haf done aȝeinste me ⁊and
myne

to þis effecte and to þis ende þat god of his endles
mercy

will at þe tyme of our͗e deyenge forȝiff us our͗e giltes
þat we han̄ trespassed vn to hym in þis wrecched worlde

For douteles ȝiff we bene sorye and repentaunte of our͗e
synnes in þe whiche we han̄ trespassed in þe siȝht of our͗e lorde
godde
he is so free and so merciable

þat he will forȝiff
us our͗e giltes and brynge to þe endles blisse Amen

ab.hi: ¶ Here endeth Chaucers tale of Meloby ⁊and prudence ;

l.hi: ¶ Here begynneth þe prologe of the Maunciple

div.l: Wote ȝe not wher͗e stondeth a litill town̄
Which þᵗat cleped bob up and down̄
Vnder þe blee in Cauntirbery waye
Ther ganne our͗e oste to Iape and to pleye
And seid sires Dun is in þe myr͗e
Is þ̉er no man̄ for preier ne for hire
That will a wake our͗e felowe behynde
A theef myȝht hym both robbe and bynde
Se howe he nappith for goddes bones
A waite he will fall from his horse at ones
This is a coke of londoıı̄un with myschaunce
Do hym com̄ forthe he knoweth his penᵃaunce
For he schall tell a tale be my fay
Al þof it be not worth a botell of haye
A wake þou coke god ȝif ye sorowe
What aileth þe slepe so by þe morowe
Hast þou hadde fleen̄ to nyȝht or þou arte dronke
Or hast þou alnyȝht with som quene y swonke
So þat þou maiste not hold up þine hede
This Cooke þat was pale and no thynge rede
Saide to our͗e oste so god me blesse
As þer is holden̄ on me suche an heuynesse
That I not whedir me wer͗e leuer slepe
Than þe beste galoıı̄un wyne in þe chepe
Wel qduod þe maunciple it will done ese
To þe sir Coke and to no wyȝht mysplese
Whiche þat riden̄ in þis companye
Þat so our͗e oste will of his curtesye
I will as nowe excuse þe of þi tale
For in good faith þi visage is riȝht pale
Þine eien dasen̄ as me thenkyth
And wele I wote þi brethe sor͗e stynketh
That schoweth þou ne arte not wele disposede
Of me Certeyn̄ þou schalt not be glosede
See howe he goleth þis dronken̄ wiȝhte
As þof he wolde swown̄ onon̄ riȝht
Holde cloos þi mouthe man̄ be þi fader kyn̄
The deuyll of hell sette his fote þer in
Thy cursede breeth will a reke us all
Fy stynkynge hog foule mot þe befall
Nowe taketh hede sirres of þis lusty man̄
Nowe swete sir will ȝe iuste at þe fanne
¶ Therto me thenkith ȝe bene wele y schape
I trowe ȝe haue dronken̄ wyne of goode grape
And þat is when̄ men̄ hem pleye with a strawe
And with þis speche þe Coke wex al wrawe
Ther was grete schowynge to and froo
To lifte hym up and mykell car͗e and woo
So vnweldy was þis apalled goiste
And to þe Maunciple þan̄ spak our͗e ooste
Be cause drynke hath dominacioıı̄un
Vp on þis man̄ / Be my saluacioıı̄un
I trowe he wolde lowly tell his tale
For wer͗e it wyne or eld moiste ale
That he hath dronken̄ he spekith in his nose
And galpeth faste and eke he hathe þe poose
He hath also to don̄ mor͗e þan y nogh
To kepe hym and his capell oute of þe slough
And if he fall from his capell efte sone
Than̄ schall we all haf ynogh to done
In liftynge vp of his heuy corps
Tell on þi tale of hym make I no force
But nowe maunciple in feith þou art to nyce
Thus openly to repreue hym of his vice
A nother daye he will ꝑparauentur͗e
Recleyme þe and brynge þe to þe lur͗e
I meene he speke wolde of smale thyngꝭes
And for to pynchen̄ at þi rekkenynges
That wer not honeste ȝiff it come to preefe
Nowe qduod þe maunciple þat wer͗e a grete myschiefe
So myȝht he brynge me in þe snar͗e
Ȝit had I leủer paien̄ for þe mar͗e
Whiche he rit opon̄ þan he schuld with me stryfe
I will not wreþe hym als mot I thryffe
That þat I spak I saide it in my bourde
And wote what I haf her͗e in a gourde
A drauȝht of wyne ȝa of a ripe grape
And riȝht onon̄ ȝe schull se a goode Iape
This Coke schall drynke þ̉er of ȝif þᵗat I may
Vpon̄ peyn̄ of dethe he woll not say me nay
And certenly to tellen̄ as it was
Of þis vessell þe Coke Dranke faste alas
What neded it he dranke ynogh to forne
And when̄ he had poped in his horne
To þe maunciple he toke þe gourde a gayn̄
And of þat drynke þe Coke was wonder fayn̄
And thonked hym suche wyse as he couthe
Than̄ gan̄ our oste to laughen̄ wonder louthe
And seide I see wele it is necessarie
Where þat we gone good drynk with us to carie
For þat turne rancour and disese
To peese and loue and mony a wronge to sese
O bachus blessed be þine name
That so can̄ turne erneste in to game
Worschip and thonke be vn to þe
For of þis mater ȝe get no mor͗e of me
Tell on þou maunciple I þe praye
Wel sir qduod he nowe herkenyth what I seye

l.hi: Thus endeth þe ꝓprologe
And here begynneth þe tale .

div.note: ¶ Þe tale
div.l: When̄ phebus dwelled her͗e in þis erthe a doun̄
As olde bokes maken̄ mencioıı̄un
He was þe moste lusty bachiler͗e
Of all þis worlde and eke þe best archer͗e
He slough phitoıı̄un þe serpente as he lay
Slepynge a ȝeinste þe son̄ opon̄ a daye
And mony another worthy noble dede
He with his bowe wrouȝht as men̄ may rede
Pleyen̄ he couthe on euery mynstralcye
And syngen̄ þat it was a Melodye
To herken̄ of his cler͗e vois þe soun̄
Certꝭes þe kynge of Thebes Amphyoun̄
That with his syngynge walled þat citee
Couthe neủer synge halfe so wele as he
Therto he was þe semeliest man̄
That is or was sith þe worlde began̄
What nedith it his fetures to descrive
For in þis worlde was non̄ so fair͗e on liffe
He was þ̉erwith fulfilled of gentilnesse
Of honour and of ꝑparfite worthines
This phebus þat was þe flour͗e of bachilerye
As wele in fredom as in chiualrye
For disporte and in signe eke of victorie
Of phetoıı̄un so as tellith us þe storye
Was wonte to beren in his honde a bowe
Nowe hath þis phebus in his house a crowe
Whiche in a kage he fostred mony a daye
And tauȝht it to speke as men̄ done a Iaye
White was þis crowe as is a white swan̄
And countrefetede þe speche of eủery man̄
He couthe when̄ he schulde tell a tale
Ther with in al þis londe þ̉er is no nyȝhtyngale
That couthe be an hundreth thousande dele
Synge so meryly and eke so wele
Nowe had þis phebus in his house a wyffe
Whiche þat he loued / mor͗e þan his own̄ liffe
And nyȝht and daye did eủer diligence
Her for to plese and done reuerence
Saue only ȝif þat I þe sothe schall seyn̄e
Ialous he was and wolde haf kepte hir͗e fayne
For hym wer lothe y Iaped for to be
And so eủery man̄ wolde in suche degree
But al for noȝht for it availleth not
A goode wyffe þat is clene of werke and thoȝht
Shuld not be kepte in non̄ awayte certeyn̄
And trewly þe labour is in veyne
To kepe a schrewe for it will not be
This holde I for a verrey nycete
To spille laboure for to kepe wyffes
Thus writen̄ olde clerkꝭes in her lyffes
But nowe to purpose as I firste began̄
This worthy phebus / doth al þat he can̄
To plesen̄ hir͗e wenynge by suche plesaunce
And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
That no man schuld haf putte hym from her gᵃrace
But god it wote þ̉er may no man̄ enbrace
As to destroie a thynge which þat natur͗e
Hath naturelly sette in a creatur͗e
Take eny bridde and putte it in a cage
And do all þine entente and þi corage
To fostr͗e it tendirly with mete and Drynke
Off all deyntes þat þou canste bethynke
And kepe also clenly as he may
All þof his cage of golde be neủer so gaye
Ȝit hath þis bridde be xx thousand folde
Leuer in a foreste þat is wilde and colde
Gone eten̄ wermes and suche wrecchednes
For eủer þis bridde woll done his besynesse
To escape oute of his cage if he may
His liberte þis bridde desireth ay

All þise ensamples speke I be þise men̄
That ben̄ vntrewe and no thynge by women̄
For men̄ haue eủer a lykorous appetite
On lower þinge to ꝑparfourme her delite

Ne neủer so trewe ne so debonair͗e

The worde mot nedes accorde with þe dede
Ȝiff men̄ schall tellen̄ ꝓpropurly a thynge

Ȝiff it so be þei wirke both amys
But þat þe gentill is in þe state aboue

I will go to my tale as I beganne

This Crowe songe Cokko Cokko Cokko

For all þi beaute and þi gentilnesse
For all þi songe and all þi mynstrallsye

I woll þe quyte onon̄ þi fals tale
Thou songe whilom̄ like a nyȝhtyngale
Nowe schalt þou fals thefe þi songe for gone
Eke þi white federes eủerychon̄e
Ne neủer in all þi lyffe schalt þou speke
Thus schall men̄ on a traitour bene a wreke
Thowe and þine osprynge eủer schall be blake
Ne neủer swete noys schull ȝe make
But euer crye aȝeinste tempeste and reyne

And to þe crowe he sterte and þat onon̄
And pulled his white federes eủerychon̄

Vn to þe deuell to whome I hym betake
And for þis caas bene al crowes blake
Lordynges be þis ensample I ȝowe preye
¶ Beeth war͗e and taketh kepe what þat ȝe seye
Ne telleth neủer no man̄ ȝour liffe
Howe þat a noþ̉er man̄ hath diȝht ȝour͗e wyffe

Daun salamon̄ as wise clerkes seyn̄

My son̄ thenke on þe crowe in goddes name
My son̄ kepe wele þi tonge and kepe þi frende
A wikked tonge is worse þan a fende
My son̄ from a fende men̄ may hem blisse
My son̄ god of his endles goodnes

For man̄ schuld hym avise what þat he speke
My son̄ full ofte for to mychell speche

My son̄ þi tonge schuldest þou restreyne
At al tyme but when̄ þou doiste þi peyne
To speke of god in honur͗e and praier͗e
The firste vertue son̄ if þou wilte ler͗e
Is to restreyne and kepe wele þi tonge
Thus lerne childern̄ when̄ þei bene ȝonge
My son̄ of myche spekynge euyll avised
Þer lasse spekynge had ynogh suffisede

Wotest þou wheroff a rakell tonge ʆserueth

Nowe lakketh us no tale mor͗e but one

Tell us a fable onon̄ for Cokkꝭes bonys
This ꝑperson̄ answered all at onys

Repreueth hem þat wayveth sothfastnes

Why schuld I schewen̄ draff oute off my feste
When̄ I may schewe whete if þat me leste
For whiche I seye if þat ye luste to her͗e
Moralite and vertuous mater͗e
And þan þat ȝe will ȝiff me audience
I woll full fayne at Cristes reuerence
Saue ȝowe plesaunce lefull as . I kan
But trusteth wele I am a sotheren man
I can not geste rum ram ruff by letter
Ne god wote ryme holde I but litell better
Ande þerfor if þou luste I nyll not glose
I will ȝowe tell a mery tale in prose
To knytte up al þis feste and make an ende
And witte for his grace Ihu me sende
To schewe ȝowe þe waye in þis viage
Of þilke ꝑparfite glorious pilgrimage
That hieght Ihrlm celestiall
And if ȝe wouchesaue onon ȝe schall
Begynne to her me tale / for whiche I preye
Tell ȝour avise avise I can no bett̉er seye
But natheles þis meditacioıı̄un
I putte aye vndir correccioıı̄un
Of clerkes for I am not textuell
I take but þe sentence trusteth wele
Therfor I make protestacioun
That I will stonde to correccioun
Opon þis worde we han assented soıı̄un
For as it semed it / was for to done
To enden in som vertuos sentence
And for to ȝiff hym space and audience
And bad our ooste he schuld to hym seye
That all we to tell his tale hym preye
Our ooste hadde þe wordes for us all
Sir preste qd he nowe far ȝowe befall
Seye what ȝowe luste and we schullen gladly her
And with þat worde he saide in þis maner
Telleth qd he ȝour meditacioun
But hasteth ȝowe þe son will a doun

And to doo wele god sende us his grace
